('8', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. LATE MR. ARATHOON
('8', 0, 2, 3, 64) The mail last week brought the sad news of Mr. Arathoon’s death.
('8', 0, 2, 4, 129) Mr. Arathoon in his capacity as the honorary secretary of the East India Association served it for a number of years faithfully and well.
('8', 0, 2, 5, 267) As Editor of The Asiatic Quarterly Review, his work is known to all who have any connection with India.
('8', 0, 2, 6, 371) But he is best known to Indians in South Africa for his very great sympathy for them and the constant attention he gave to the question in connection with the Association, with which he was so closely identified.
('8', 0, 2, 7, 584) He never missed an opportunity of bringing it to the notice of the Association, and thereby to that of the authorities.
('8', 0, 2, 8, 704) He rendered very valuable assistance to the deputation last year by his whole hearted co operation.
('8', 0, 2, 9, 804) We tender our condolences to Mr. Arathoon’s family.
('8', 0, 2, 10, 856) Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('8', 0, 3, 11, 883) 2. VOLKSRUST CASES
('8', 0, 4, 12, 902) The cases instituted in Volksrust against Mr. Mahomed Essak and other Indians deserve attention.
('8', 0, 4, 13, 999) Originally, it was the intention of the Government to frame the charge under the new law, but it lost nerve at the last moment and the case was brought up under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('8', 0, 4, 14, 1194) Mr. Mahomed Essak having taken the lead, others too could follow.
('8', 0, 4, 15, 1260) He has saved the honour of the Konkanis.
('8', 0, 4, 16, 1301) No one would now be justified in blaming the Konkanis.
('8', 0, 4, 17, 1356) The magistrate discharged Mr. Mahomed Essak, holding that he was entitled under his permit to reside in the Colony.
('8', 0, 4, 18, 1472) These cases have brought out the courage of the people.
('8', 0, 4, 19, 1528) It was good that no bail was offered.
('8', 0, 4, 20, 1566) It was also good that those arrested included people from all communities.
('8', 0, 4, 21, 1641) This case reveals the extreme weakness of the Government.
('8', 0, 4, 22, 1699) The Government is demoralized.
('8', 0, 4, 23, 1730) It does not know what to do.
('8', 0, 4, 24, 1759) Its condition is like that of an angry man who has started raving.
('8', 0, 4, 25, 1826) It would be to our advantage if there were still more cases like this.
('8', 0, 4, 26, 1897) If the Government were really strong, it would arrest the people in the Transvaal who are opposing the law.
('8', 0, 4, 27, 2005) That it is not able to do.
('8', 0, 4, 28, 2032) Hence it is trying desperately to stop the people from coming from outside.
('8', 0, 4, 29, 2108) The Government cannot but be defeated in such an attempt.
('8', 0, 4, 30, 2166) For, there is a big loophole in the new law.
('8', 0, 4, 31, 2211) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('8', 1, 0, 1, 2254) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 1, 1, 2, 2294) 3. NATAL LICENSING ACT
('8', 1, 2, 3, 2317) Under this Act, the Government has made new regulations which include three remarkable sections.
('8', 1, 2, 4, 2414) First, from now on the application for a licence will have to be published in a newspaper.
('8', 1, 2, 5, 2505) The officer will have the right to take a thumb impression on the application.
('8', 1, 2, 6, 2584) Finally, one will have to pay £12.10.0 when making an appeal.
('8', 1, 2, 7, 2646) All this is bad, but one must consider on what point relief is possible.
('8', 1, 2, 8, 2719) It does not appear likely that the requirement to have the application published in a newspaper will be cancelled.
('8', 1, 2, 9, 2834) There is such a law in the Cape.
('8', 1, 2, 10, 2867) Taking of a thumb impression is left to the discretion of the officer.
('8', 1, 2, 11, 2938) This can be interpreted to mean that those who can sign will not be required to give thumb impressions.
('8', 1, 2, 12, 3042) We cannot advise making any petition to the Government on either of these two points, for it will be useless to do so.
('8', 1, 2, 13, 3161) The obligation to pay £12.10.0 is not a new thing.
('8', 1, 2, 14, 3212) There is only one remedy against it: when anyone has an occasion to file an appeal, he must refuse to pay the sum and fight out the point.
('8', 1, 2, 15, 3351) We believe that the fee is illegal; that is what the ruling of the court will probably be.
('8', 1, 2, 16, 3442) The best course is to ignore the law and violate it.
('8', 1, 2, 17, 3495) Wherever licences are refused in large numbers, people must trade without licences, rather than think of disposing of their stocks.
('8', 1, 2, 18, 3627) For all such ailments, passive resistance is the best cure.
('8', 1, 2, 19, 3687) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('8', 1, 3, 20, 3730) 4. LATE NAWAB MOHSIN UL MULK
('8', 1, 4, 21, 3759) We have already reported 1 the news of the passing away of this gentleman.
('8', 1, 4, 22, 3834) In this issue, we give a brief sketch of his life.
('8', 1, 4, 23, 3885) Every Indian, especially every Muslim, should take a lesson from his services in the field of education.
('8', 1, 4, 24, 3990) He placed education above politics.
('8', 1, 4, 25, 4026) That was on the whole a realistic attitude, especially in his time.
('8', 1, 4, 26, 4094) The community can derive the highest benefits from education provided that, along with it, the people acquire truthful conduct and moral life.
('8', 1, 4, 27, 4237) But education is a dangerous thing in the absence of lofty conduct and morality.
('8', 1, 4, 28, 4318) It can be compared to a creeper unable to climb without the
('8', 1, 5, 29, 4378) 1 Not reproduced here
('8', 2, 0, 1, 4400) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 3
('8', 2, 1, 2, 4443) support of a hedge.
('8', 2, 1, 3, 4463) It is such education accompanied by moral training that everyone should receive; that is what we can learn from the life of the late Nawab.
('8', 2, 1, 4, 4603) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('8', 2, 2, 5, 4646) 5. GERMAN EAST AFRICA LINE
('8', 2, 3, 6, 4673) A new spirit of self respect and dignity is in the air these days among Indians.
('8', 2, 3, 7, 4754) At such a time, the incident that has occurred involving Mr. Peeran Mahomed calls for notice.
('8', 2, 3, 8, 4848) He asked for a first class ticket on a Europe bound steamer belonging to the [German East Africa] Line and it was refused to him.
('8', 2, 3, 9, 4978) We think this was a highly insulting thing to do.
('8', 2, 3, 10, 5028) It does not befit the German Company.
('8', 2, 3, 11, 5066) The Company derives a big income from Indian passengers.
('8', 2, 3, 12, 5123) Ignoring all this, it refuses to issue a first class ticket when demanded by an Indian passenger.
('8', 2, 3, 13, 5221) This ought to make us feel sorry for ourselves.
('8', 2, 3, 14, 5269) They know our ways.
('8', 2, 3, 15, 5289) They insult us becausewe are not likely to do anything about it.
('8', 2, 3, 16, 5354) They dare not do such a thing to a white passenger.
('8', 2, 3, 17, 5406) There are three remedies for this to be adopted simultaneously: (1) A strong protest should be made to the Company.
('8', 2, 3, 18, 5522) (2) Their agent, Mr. Osman Ahmad, should bring to the notice of the Company the loss that it might suffer.
('8', 2, 3, 19, 5629) (3) Passengers should be dissuaded from using the steamers of this Line.
('8', 2, 3, 20, 5702) The third step is the best.
('8', 2, 3, 21, 5730) The other two will have some effect only if the third is taken.
('8', 2, 3, 22, 5794) We have acquired new strength, which should be used on every occasion.
('8', 2, 3, 23, 5865) It is not enough that we oppose the Transvaal law.
('8', 2, 3, 24, 5916) That is to be treated only as a beginning.
('8', 2, 3, 25, 5959) Look at the example of Japan.
('8', 2, 3, 26, 5989) After coming into light, that nation has been paying attention to its education, its trade and its honour.
('8', 2, 3, 27, 6096) We, too, should work for progress in every field.
('8', 2, 3, 28, 6146) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('8', 3, 0, 1, 6189) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 3, 1, 2, 6229) 6. ATTACK ON INDIANS 1
('8', 3, 2, 3, 6252) The air is thick with the excitement of the new law.
('8', 3, 2, 4, 6305) There is no doubt that people are now eagerly waiting to be arrested.
('8', 3, 2, 5, 6375) Nine Indians arrived from Durban on the morning of Friday last.
('8', 3, 2, 6, 6439) Eleven others came on the evening of the same day, and 17 on Saturday and Sunday.
('8', 3, 2, 7, 6521) All of them had their permits or registers with them.
('8', 3, 2, 8, 6575) Thirty five of them had arrived by the Sultan.
('8', 3, 2, 9, 6622) Of the remaining two, one was a Madrasi who was going to Johannesburg on business, and one was a Gujarati who had gone to Durban in October and was returning to Johannesburg.
('8', 3, 2, 10, 6797) At first, it was reported that all these persons were arrested for being without permits under the new law.
('8', 3, 2, 11, 6905) Mr. Gandhi presented himself at the court on Friday.
('8', 3, 2, 12, 6958) These men were not produced in the court on that day, since the police were awaiting orders from Pretoria.
('8', 3, 2, 13, 7065) They were produced on Saturday, and the case was adjourned till Monday.
('8', 3, 2, 14, 7137) Mr. Gandhi went to Johannesburg again on Monday.
('8', 3, 2, 15, 7186) The police wanted to bring up the case under the new law.
('8', 3, 2, 16, 7244) But there was an order from Pretoria that it should be proceeded with under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('8', 3, 2, 17, 7354) Hence they were prosecuted under Section 5 of the Peace Preservation Ordinance on a charge of being without permits.
('8', 3, 3, 18, 7471) DEPOSITION BY SERGEANT MANSFIELD 2
('8', 3, 4, 19, 7506) I arrested these Indians in accordance with instructions from Pretoria.
('8', 3, 4, 20, 7578) They all held valid permits, which, however, did not authorize them to return.
('8', 3, 4, 21, 7657) They were arrested because they did not have permits under the new law.
('8', 3, 5, 22, 7729) CROSS EXAMINATION Q.—Did you examine the permits of these men?
('8', 3, 5, 23, 7792) A.—Yes.
('8', 3, 5, 24, 7800) I found on examination that they contained their thumb impressions.
('8', 3, 5, 25, 7868) Q.—Do they also have with them registers taken out under the law of 1885?
('8', 3, 5, 26, 7942) A.—They all have such registers.
('8', 3, 5, 27, 7975) Q.—What are your orders from Pretoria?
('8', 3, 5, 28, 8014) A.—I have orders to arrest every Indian coming from outside if
('8', 3, 6, 29, 8077) 1 This was published with the sub titles, “Proceeding from Natal to the Transvaal, Thirty seven Persons Arrested, Released by Court”.
('8', 3, 6, 30, 8211) 2 The translation has been collated with the English report of the trial; vide “trial of Indians”, 9 12 1907.
('8', 4, 0, 1, 8321) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 5
('8', 4, 1, 2, 8364) he is without a permit under the new law or any other authority.
('8', 4, 1, 3, 8429) Q.—Do these instructions also apply to Indians whom you may know personally?
('8', 4, 1, 4, 8506) A.—Yes, it will be my duty to arrest everyone.
('8', 4, 1, 5, 8553) Q.—Is it true that, under the permits which you saw with the accused, Indians enjoyed complete freedom of movement till now?
('8', 4, 1, 6, 8678) A.—Yes, I had instructions so far that those permits were sufficient authority.
('8', 4, 1, 7, 8758) The Public Prosecutor closed the case here.
('8', 4, 1, 8, 8802) Mr. Gandhi demanded that the accused should be set free for want of evidence.
('8', 4, 1, 9, 8880) The Public Prosecutor admitted that his case was weak, but that he had drafted the summons under orders from the Government.
('8', 4, 1, 10, 9005) Under the permits produced before the court, people were entitled to enter and reside [in the Transvaal] but not to leave and return.
('8', 4, 1, 11, 9139) Mr. Gandhi stated that the Crown witness himself had proved his clients’ case.
('8', 4, 1, 12, 9218) The authority for the clients to enter [the Transvaal] was the permit which the Crown witness had produced before the court.
('8', 4, 1, 13, 9343) In the summons, they were charged with entering without permits.
('8', 4, 1, 14, 9408) That charge had not been proved.
('8', 4, 1, 15, 9441) It had been held by the court in the case of Bhabha that a permit to enter the Colony included permission to leave it and to return.
('8', 4, 1, 16, 9574) His clients should therefore be discharged.
('8', 4, 1, 17, 9618) Many of them had suffered for four days by that time.
('8', 4, 1, 18, 9672) The magistrate upheld this contention and discharged all of them.
('8', 4, 1, 19, 9738) The following are the names of those who were prosecuted: Omar Yusuf, Nathu Govind, Madha Galal, Lala Madhav, Govind Dadi [Daji?], Ratanji Maharaj, Kunvarji Manor, Kala Pema, Nagar Bhavan, Morar Bhikha, Samandarkhan, Kana Gopal, Nana Vallabh, Babu Sukha, Prabhu Narain, Jasmat Fakir, Fakir Lakha, Hari Daji, Pema Bhana, Parbhu Chhana, Lallu Khushal, Ramasami Chokkalinga Pillay, Mani Dahya, Bhima Vasan, Zina Kidia, Dahya Pancha, Vallabh Govind, Dhana Hira, Hari Bhikh, Dayal Vallabh, Makan Morar, Madhav Jivan, Govind Dahya, Budhiya Lala, Daji Bhana, Ranchhod Gopal and Bhikha Ratanji.
('8', 4, 1, 20, 10325) I am glad to observe that there are here persons from all communities, one Pathan, one Konkani, one Madrasi, and the rest Gujarati Hindus.
('8', 4, 2, 21, 10464) MAHOMED ESSAK’S CASE This case was heard on Friday in Volksrust.
('8', 4, 2, 22, 10529) The Public Prosecutor said that he did not know on what charge Mr. Essak was to
('8', 5, 0, 1, 10609) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 5, 1, 2, 10649) be prosecuted.
('8', 5, 1, 3, 10664) He could say that only after hearing from the Government.
('8', 5, 1, 4, 10722) After argument, the magistrate agreed to transfer the case to Johannesburg and ordered the case to be heard there on Wednesday.
('8', 5, 1, 5, 10850) Mr. Mahomed Essak and other Indians had refused to offer bail.
('8', 5, 1, 6, 10913) They were therefore released unconditionally.
('8', 5, 1, 7, 10959) In the court, the Government was being ridiculed for these cases.

('8', 5, 2, 9, 11068) 7. REGULATIONS FOR MAKING APPLICATIONS FOR LICENCES IN NATAL
('8', 5, 3, 10, 11129) We give below a summary of all the important sections of the Regulations published in the Natal Gazette for making applications for the issue, renewal or transfer of licences or appeals in respect of them: Section 2. The application, in the prescribed form, should be addressed to the magistrate duly authorized for the purpose or to the Town Office, and the applicant shall publish a copy of the application at least one day in each week for at least two weeks in a local newspaper.
('8', 5, 3, 11, 11613) 4. Upon receipt of an application, the Licensing Officer shall be at liberty to obtain from the Health Officer or the Sanitary Inspector a report in respect to the sanitary arrangements on the premises proposed to be licenced.
('8', 5, 3, 12, 11840) 5. If required, the applicant shall appear personally and produce to the Licensing Officer his books of accounts, or such other documents as may be necessary, to show to the satisfaction of that Officer that he is able to fulfil the conditions laid down by Section 7 in regard to keeping books of accounts in the English language.
('8', 5, 3, 13, 12171) 6. The Licensing Officer shall endorse upon each application his decision as regards the issue or refusal of a licence.
('8', 5, 3, 14, 12291) 8. A licence shall not be issued until the necessary stamps are affixed or the money paid.
('8', 5, 3, 15, 12382) 9. The Licensing Officer may require an applicant, when issuing a licence to him, to give his signature or impressions of his thumb or fingers.
('8', 5, 4, 16, 12526) REGULATIONS CONCERNING APPEALS
('8', 5, 5, 17, 12557) 10. An applicant intending to file an appeal may give notice
('8', 6, 0, 1, 12618) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 7
('8', 6, 1, 2, 12661) within two weeks of the decision to the Clerk of the Board or the Council of his intention to appeal against the decision of the Licensing Officer.
('8', 6, 1, 3, 12809) With the notice of appeal shall be deposited a sum of £ 12. 10.0 towards the expenses of the members of the Board.
('8', 6, 1, 4, 12924) If there are more applicants than one, the expenses of the Appeal Board shall be divided equally among them.
('8', 6, 1, 5, 13033) 11. A notice of the day fixed for the hearing of appeals, together with a list of appeals, shall be fixed to the door of the Court House or Town Office for at least five days before the appointed date.
('8', 6, 1, 6, 13235) 13. The proceedings of the Board shall be open to the public.
('8', 6, 1, 7, 13297) 16. The appellant, and any interested person, shall be entitled to be heard upon the appeal by himself or by any person acting under his written authority, and also to bring forward evidence in support of the appeal.
('8', 6, 1, 8, 13514) The person opposing the appeal shall be entitled to the same rights.
('8', 6, 1, 9, 13583) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('8', 6, 2, 10, 13626) 8. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('8', 6, 3, 11, 13649) PUNJABIS’ PETITION
('8', 6, 4, 12, 13668) The reply to this petition is still under the consideration of the Government.
('8', 6, 4, 13, 13747) But the world has already given the reply, which has turned the sympathies of many Englishmen in favour of the Punjabis.
('8', 6, 4, 14, 13868) Everyone says that they should get justice.
('8', 6, 4, 15, 13912) The discussion on the petition is still going on.
('8', 6, 4, 16, 13962) We have already referred to the very strong criticism that has appeared in The Daily Graphic of England.
('8', 6, 5, 17, 14067) I WITHDRAW
('8', 6, 6, 18, 14078) I wrote about Mr. Parekh’s spirit.
('8', 6, 6, 19, 14113) 1 I find that it was written in haste, and hence I withdraw my remarks.
('8', 6, 6, 20, 14185) At the time of writing this, Mr. Parekh is still in Newcastle.
('8', 6, 6, 21, 14248) Whether he will be there or not when this is published, I cannot say.
('8', 6, 6, 22, 14318) But to have called him especially brave and to have advised others to follow his example—that itself was an error.
('8', 6, 6, 23, 14433) A brave man will take the lead in battle.
('8', 6, 6, 24, 14475) Mr. Parekh is still outside the Transvaal, hence the implied suggestion in my statement that he was braver than all of us does not stand.
('8', 6, 7, 25, 14613) 1Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 26 11 1907
('8', 7, 0, 1, 14653) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 7, 1, 2, 14693) FALSEHOOD Mr. Hasan Mahomed Kala made a public statement that he regretted having made the application for registration and that he wished to withdraw it.
('8', 7, 1, 3, 14848) I now find that, on the very day that he wrote this letter declaring his intention to withdraw his application, he wrote another private letter to a friend of his saying that he would be glad if the title deed of slavery were issued to him immediately, and expressing concern at the delay.
('8', 7, 1, 4, 15138) I expose this duplicity merely as a matter of duty with a view to preventing a recurrence of such instances among us.
('8', 7, 1, 5, 15256) I am very sorry that Mr. Kala was one of the pickets at Pietersburg, which gave occasion to Mr. Chamney to assert that even pickets had applied for registers.
('8', 7, 2, 6, 15415) WHAT DOES VOLUNTARY REGISTRATION MEAN?
('8', 7, 2, 7, 15454) This question has often been discussed in this paper, but I find that there are still many Indians who do not understand the meaning of voluntary registration.
('8', 7, 2, 8, 15614) The whites did not understand what the new law meant till the time [for its enforcement] came; we are in the same position.
('8', 7, 2, 9, 15738) The main point of difference between voluntary registration and registration under the law is that the law confers upon us the status of slaves, whereas voluntary registration gives us human dignity.
('8', 7, 2, 10, 15938) To submit to registration under pressure by the Government is like riding an ass.
('8', 7, 2, 11, 16020) To register ourselves voluntarily is like riding an elephant.
('8', 7, 2, 12, 16082) Even though in voluntary registration we may have to supply the same particulars as under compulsory registration, the former is to be preferred; on the contrary, compulsory registration will not cease to be slavery even if the specific indications of slavery are removed therefrom.
('8', 7, 2, 13, 16365) It is a very harsh law, and that is the reason why the local Government clings to it like leeches, and we have been striving for these fifteen months to prevent their sticking on to us.
('8', 7, 2, 14, 16551) In other words, we wish to be on a footing of equality with the whites, and the whites want to degrade us.
('8', 7, 2, 15, 16658) The law will involve violation of our oath and bring us lasting disgrace.
('8', 7, 2, 16, 16732) If anyone asks why even voluntarily we should have our documents exchanged, the question can be easily and simply answered: (1) Just as we have taken an oath against the law, so also have we offered to have our documents exchanged voluntarily.
('8', 7, 2, 17, 16976) If now we refuse to do so, we shall have gone back on our word and proved ourselves liars.
('8', 7, 2, 18, 17067) (2) Indians are charged by many people with entering [the Transvaal] under false permits or without permits.
('8', 7, 2, 19, 17176) By voluntary registration we can disprove the charge; it is our
('8', 8, 0, 1, 17240) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 9
('8', 8, 1, 2, 17283) duty to do so, and it is because we have shown ourselves ready for it that we have been able to win the sympathies of people everywhere.
('8', 8, 1, 3, 17420) (3) To resist voluntary registration is to admit that we have been in the wrong.
('8', 8, 1, 4, 17501) (4) By voluntary registration we shall win still greater prestige than we have gained so far.
('8', 8, 1, 5, 17595) It should be remembered that as a general rule, it is only when people refuse to do a particular thing of their own free will, i.e., prove their weakness, that the law intervenes and exercises compulsion.
('8', 8, 1, 6, 17800) There are many Kaffirs who do not of their own accord stop drinking, hence wherever it is found necessary to use compulsion against them, legislative measures are resorted to to stop them from drinking.
('8', 8, 1, 7, 18003) The man who stops drinking under compulsion by law, and not as a matter of duty, cannot be called a virtuous man.
('8', 8, 1, 8, 18117) It is the man who of his own free will avoids drinking that is really virtuous.
('8', 8, 1, 9, 18197) There is the same difference between compulsory and voluntary registration.
('8', 8, 1, 10, 18273) (5) Voluntary registration will always keep us free.
('8', 8, 1, 11, 18326) For, under it no one can bind us more than we bind ourselves of our own accord.
('8', 8, 1, 12, 18406) A volunteer enlists himself for war only when he chooses to do so.
('8', 8, 1, 13, 18473) A mercenary who is driven by necessity to enlist himself is bound to fight whenever called upon to do so.
('8', 8, 1, 14, 18579) We can enumerate many such advantages of voluntary registr ation.
('8', 8, 1, 15, 18645) For the present, these arc enough.
('8', 8, 1, 16, 18680) No reference is made here to finger prints, etc.
('8', 8, 1, 17, 18729) For, that will be a matter of our own free will.
('8', 8, 1, 18, 18778) But we shall consider next week the difference, from a scientific point of view, between ten finger prints, and two thumb impressions.
('8', 8, 1, 19, 18913) For the present, what is necessary is to understand the exact meaning of voluntary registration.
('8', 8, 1, 20, 19010) OBJECTION In view of the possibility of a compromise at any time now, the Association has started giving thought to the question of voluntary registration.
('8', 8, 1, 21, 19166) An objection has been raised to this by some Gentlemen, who want to know why all people are not being consulted.
('8', 8, 1, 22, 19279) The objection has no force.
('8', 8, 1, 23, 19307) If the question of voluntary registration were a new proposal, it would have been undoubtedly necessary to invite delegates from all places, but the resolution concerning voluntary registration was passed at the mass meeting in the Empire Theatre by delegates representing all the places, and they had fully acquainted
('8', 9, 0, 1, 19626) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 9, 1, 2, 19667) themselves with all facts relating tovoluntary registration.
('8', 9, 1, 3, 19728) Hence, there is no further need to consult delegates from all places.
('8', 9, 1, 4, 19798) Moreover, there is no time for it.
('8', 9, 1, 5, 19833) All the same, every Indian can express his opinion at any time.
('8', 9, 1, 6, 19897) We want that this struggle should lead us to a better understanding of political matters.
('8', 9, 1, 7, 19987) We also want to learn how meetings are conducted, how other associations are run and how public work is organized.
('8', 9, 1, 8, 20102) We have been fighting a strenuous battle to get the new law repealed, claiming that we are really a civilized people; if so, a proper understanding of the points referred to above is a mark of being truly civilized.
('8', 9, 2, 9, 20318) WHY TEST CASE SHOULD NOT BE MADE Some gentlemen have been arguing why we should not make a test case against the new law.
('8', 9, 2, 10, 20440) I have expressed myself against this for two reasons.
('8', 9, 2, 11, 20494) First, we are not fighting to make a test case, but to prove our strength by going to gaol.
('8', 9, 2, 12, 20586) There is nothing as effective as one’s own strength.
('8', 9, 2, 13, 20639) If we proceed to make a test case, our struggle will get into a mess and we shall invite ridicule.
('8', 9, 2, 14, 20738) The whites will immediately say: “What happened to those who were to go to gaol?” Hence, making a test case will amount to an admission of weakness.
('8', 9, 2, 15, 20887) Second, the Privy Council will hardly be able to invalidate the new law or any other laws of the Colony.
('8', 9, 2, 16, 20992) An opinion has already been expressed against us by Mr. Leonard, Mr. Esselen, Mr. Gregorowski, Mr. Duxbury, Mr. Ward and Mr. De Villiers.
('8', 9, 2, 17, 21130) The Supreme Court has pronounced many judgments which go against us.
('8', 9, 2, 18, 21199) If the Privy Council were to invalidate the new law, that would mean that the laws passed against Kaffirs would also be ultra vires.
('8', 9, 2, 19, 21332) This can never happen.
('8', 9, 2, 20, 21355) If, by any chance, this did happen, immediately new laws would be passed to set matters right.
('8', 9, 2, 21, 21450) In the end we would only be where we were to start with.
('8', 9, 2, 22, 21507) We have called for [legal] opinion from England, which Mr. Ritch has not been able to send so far.
('8', 9, 2, 23, 21606) For, no one except Sir Raymond West is prepared to give it.
('8', 9, 2, 24, 21666) It should also be remembered that Sir Raymond West had advised us to make a test case instead of opposing the law.
('8', 9, 2, 25, 21781) Now, that gentleman has come over to the side of passive resisters.
('8', 9, 2, 26, 21849) How can a test case be made, then?
('8', 9, 2, 27, 21884) Moreover, no one should forget that a test case will mean an expense of £ 1,000. Who will be able to raise such a sum?
('8', 9, 2, 28, 22003) At the same time, let us be careful not to assume that the Government will not harass people while the test case is pending.
('8', 9, 2, 29, 22128) The law cannot remain suspended in the meantime.

('8', 10, 1, 2, 22221) HAMIDIA SOCIETY MEETING A large meeting was held again on Sunday.
('8', 10, 1, 3, 22287) So many people had collected that it was impossible to accommodate them in the hall.
('8', 10, 1, 4, 22372) Hence the meeting was held in the open ground outside.
('8', 10, 1, 5, 22427) Messrs Cachalia, Suj, Manibhai Desai, Pillay, Gopal, Beg and Vyas had comedown specially from Pretoria.
('8', 10, 1, 6, 22531) Mr. Emam Abdool Cadir was in the chair.
('8', 10, 1, 7, 22571) The meeting was addressed by him, and by Messrs Beg, Suj, Cachalia, Naidoo, Hajura Singh, Ahmed Khan, Alibhai Akuji and other gentlemen.
('8', 10, 1, 8, 22708) Mr. Gandhi explained the situation.
('8', 10, 1, 9, 22744) Mr. Moulvi Ahmed Mukhtiar, who had returned from Delagoa Bay where he had gone to attend to some work, explained [the situation] to the people and, in the end, it was agreed that voluntary registration must be accepted; there were, however, two Punjabi gentlemen who were against giving thumb impressions.
('8', 10, 1, 10, 23050) Others argued that there was no objection to giving them voluntarily.
('8', 10, 1, 11, 23120) This spirit of the people deserves admiration.
('8', 10, 1, 12, 23167) It shows that people are not afraid of expressing their views, and that they speak out with courage.
('8', 10, 1, 13, 23268) Those who did not understand anything about the law six months ago now understand something of it.
('8', 10, 1, 14, 23367) All this is the result of our trying to depend on our own strength.
('8', 10, 1, 15, 23435) I think everyone will come round in the end for, there is no humiliation in giving two thumb impressions.
('8', 10, 1, 16, 23541) It is humiliating to do so under compulsion.
('8', 10, 1, 17, 23586) Once the law is defeated, we can claim to be free.
('8', 10, 2, 18, 23637) PATHETIC CONDITION OF DELAGOA BAY Moulvi Saheb reports about Delagoa Bay that, at a time when throughout South Africa the Indian community is awake and fighting for its honour, the leaders there are sunk in lethargy.
('8', 10, 2, 19, 23854) They silently endure whatever harsh treatment the Government chooses to mete out to them.
('8', 10, 2, 20, 23944) People do not care for their honour.
('8', 10, 2, 21, 23981) They look upon money as their God.
('8', 10, 2, 22, 24016) And with the Government they behave like submissive courtiers.
('8', 10, 2, 23, 24079) Will not the Indians of Delagoa Bay rouse themselves from this pitiable condition?
('8', 10, 3, 24, 24162) STRENGTH OF INDIANS The Government is betraying more signs of weakness every day on the question of the new law.
('8', 10, 3, 25, 24275) Even the whites see this.

('8', 11, 2, 6, 25170) SUCCESS OF ASSOCIATION The Municipality has passed a regulation prohibiting Indians from riding in a first class carriage.

('8', 11, 2, 10, 25509) This shows that it will do nothing but good to the Indian community if it asserts itself.
('8', 11, 3, 11, 25599) NO PASSPORTS A representation was made to Lord Selborne against the refusal of passports to Mr. Moosa Ismail and Mr. Davaji, in reply to which Lord Selborne has said that, if the Government did so, that would be tantamount to admitting the right of Indians to return even without having been registered.
('8', 11, 3, 12, 25903) This matter is not likely to rest here.

('8', 11, 4, 18, 26305) It was made much of by Lord Selborne, Lord Elgin and everyone else.
('8', 11, 4, 19, 26373) Now even that is gone.
('8', 11, 4, 20, 26396) General Smuts raised an objection to transferring land to the heirs under that section, saying that it could not apply to this case since the land was already transferred to the name of a white.
('8', 11, 4, 21, 26591) The objection was upheld by the court, though it expressed sympathy [for the heirs].
('8', 11, 4, 22, 26676) But what is the use of such sympathy?
('8', 11, 4, 23, 26714) This means that in the present case, even that one section of the law is proved to be of no avail.

('8', 11, 4, 25, 26859) The heirs are thinking of proceeding to obtain relief.
('8', 11, 4, 26, 26914) Meanwhile, the adverse decision in this case has given one more argument against the law.
('8', 11, 4, 27, 27004) And correspo ndence on the subject has commenced.

('8', 12, 1, 3, 27257) The monster is fond of Indian blood.

('8', 12, 1, 6, 27411) Now Mr. Mohanlal Joshi is in trouble.
('8', 12, 1, 7, 27449) He had a well paid job as an interpreter in the court at Pretoria.

('8', 12, 1, 10, 27634) Though a man with a family, Mr. Joshi sacrificed his job for the sake of the country and upheld the honour of the community, on which I offer him my congratulations.
('8', 12, 1, 11, 27800) It is the duty of Indians to find jobs for those who are thus thrown out of employment.
('8', 12, 1, 12, 27888) If any Indian needs a clerk, I would strongly urge him to employ Mr. Joshi or others like him who become unemployed.

('8', 13, 3, 5, 29630) [JOHANNESBURG, December 14, 1907]
('8', 13, 4, 6, 29664) [THE HON’BLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('8', 13, 5, 7, 29709) SIR,] I have the honour to state that I was discharged yesterday from the Johannesburg gaol.
('8', 13, 5, 8, 29802) I was sentenced to be imprisoned for one month under the Peace Preservation Ordinance and the Asiatic Law Amendment Act for remaining in the Colony without a permit, my permit having expired on the 30th day of September last.
('8', 13, 5, 9, 30028) The reasons for my having disobeyed the order of the Registrar of Asiatics that I should leave the Colony are set forth in the letter addressed to him by me.
('8', 13, 5, 10, 30186) The Hindu temple at Germiston, in its present form, owes its existence to me.
('8', 13, 5, 11, 30264) I was, and still am, the only priest in charge.
('8', 13, 5, 12, 30312) On proceeding to the temple yesterday, I found it in a desolate condition.
('8', 13, 5, 13, 30387) The temple had remained closed for the whole of the month.
('8', 13, 5, 14, 30446) I cannot here describe adequately the state of my feelings on seeing the condition of the temple yesterday.
('8', 13, 5, 15, 30554) I am aware that now, in accordance with the laws of the Colony, I should leave it within 7 days if I wish to escape imprisonment.
('8', 13, 5, 16, 30684) But a law higher than the laws of the Colony dictates to me another course that, as a British subject, and as a preacher of religion in charge of the Hindu temple at Germiston, I should adhere to my duty, irrespective of all consequences.
('8', 13, 5, 17, 30923) With due submission and in all humility, and consistently also with my duty to the Imperial Government and to the local Government, I beg now to inform you that it is not my intention to leave the Colony.
('8', 13, 5, 18, 31128) The Hindu congregation at Germiston and I myself would appreciate the strength of the Government in allowing me to continue my duty to my temple and congregation by issuing to me a permit, for which I hereby apply.
('8', 13, 5, 19, 31343) In this connection; I cannot help stating that the charges, of which I still know nothing, hinted at by the Registrar of Asiatics and which were given as the reason for refusing to extend my permit, were, so far as I have guessed them, unfounded.
('8', 13, 5, 20, 31590) If there are any charges
('8', 14, 0, 1, 31615) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 15
('8', 14, 1, 2, 31659) against me, I request that they may be formulated and I may be put on my trial; and, if I have, in anything I have done, departed from my religion, as I know it, or from my avocation of priest, I should immediately and voluntarily leave the Colony.
('8', 14, 1, 3, 31908) If the charges are such that they cannot be brought against me legally, even then I should be preparedto answer them before any impartial person with a legal training who might be specially appointed by the Government for the purpose.
('8', 14, 1, 4, 32143) This is the least that I venture to claim from a civilised and Christian Government.

('8', 15, 10, 14, 34746) 12. IMPATIENCE
('8', 15, 11, 15, 34761) We observe that some Indians in the Transvaal are getting impatient to see the end of the struggle.
('8', 15, 11, 16, 34861) But the end is not in sight just yet.
('8', 15, 11, 17, 34899) Great things are not achieved in a day.
('8', 15, 11, 18, 34939) Everywhere in South Africa people know that this is a struggle for the honour of Indians.
('8', 15, 12, 19, 35029) 1 This was, however, declined by the authorities.
('8', 16, 0, 1, 35079) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 17
('8', 16, 1, 2, 35123) is intended to prove that we are a nation, that we ought to have our rights, that we are free.
('8', 16, 1, 3, 35218) What is the point of being hasty when fighting for such big stakes?
('8', 16, 1, 4, 35286) The end will come only after a large number of persons become seasoned in gaol, the others remaining unbending, meanwhile.
('8', 16, 1, 5, 35409) It will be seen from our Johannesburg Letter this week that General Smuts is in no mood to yield.
('8', 16, 1, 6, 35507) It will appear from this that he has been privately informed that the Indians will give in at last.
('8', 16, 1, 7, 35607) He has yet the weapon of Licences which he can use.
('8', 16, 1, 8, 35659) Why should he abandon oppressive measures against the Indians before he has tried out every means?
('8', 16, 1, 9, 35758) W. Warriors on the battle field yield only is a last resort.
('8', 16, 1, 10, 35819) No one should imagine that our struggle is not a battle because it involves no bloodshed or use of real ammunition.
('8', 16, 1, 11, 35935) Ours also is a battle, with this difference, that in it, the right being on our side, there can be only one result.
('8', 16, 1, 12, 36051) If we become impatient, that will mean that to that extent we are less in the right.
('8', 16, 1, 13, 36136) Truth is to win, it can be only in the fulness of time.
('8', 16, 1, 14, 36192) In fact it wins soon enough, but when we look at the matter superficially, we get an impression of long delay.
('8', 16, 1, 15, 36303) Those who are prepared to defend their oath and honour at any cost as they would defend their life have nothing to lose if the result is slow in conning.

('8', 17, 5, 23, 38824) 16. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('8', 17, 6, 24, 38848) ADDITIONS TO BLACKLEGS For once, the Asiatic Office has proved to be right.
('8', 17, 6, 25, 38924) It says that, in all, 511 Indians have applied for registration as slaves.
('8', 17, 6, 26, 38999) According to Indian estimates, only 399 persons had applied.
('8', 17, 6, 27, 39060) But I realize from reliable information received by me that the correct figure is 511.
('8', 17, 7, 28, 39147) 1 This was published as “A Special Report”.
('8', 18, 0, 1, 39191) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 19
('8', 18, 1, 2, 39235) Besides, there is the more painful information that gentlemen like Mr. Hasan Mia Camroodeen Zatam, of the firm of Sheth M. C. Camroodeen, Mr. Gulam Mahomed Hurzug, the Treasurer of the Anti Indian Law Fund, Mr. Hajee Cassim, Mr. Haji Jusab of Pretoria and Mr. Ally Habib have had their faces blackened.
('8', 18, 1, 3, 39538) I shall not say anything about Mr. Hasan Mia.
('8', 18, 1, 4, 39584) I think he has lost his balance of mind in connection with this law.
('8', 18, 1, 5, 39653) Mr. Gulam Mahomed’s case is very much to be regretted.
('8', 18, 1, 6, 39708) It appears that they performed the black deed in great secrecy.
('8', 18, 1, 7, 39772) The have been rumours about them for quite some time, but I did not [so far] attach any weight to them.
('8', 18, 1, 8, 39876) I feel ashamed to find that therumours have proved true.
('8', 18, 1, 9, 39933) Mr. Hajee Cassim and Mr. Ally also appear to have registered themselves quite secretly.
('8', 18, 1, 10, 40021) Their words come back to me even as I write this.
('8', 18, 1, 11, 40071) There is no point in reproducing them.
('8', 18, 1, 12, 40110) But I think it is at any rate my duty to say that, if persons like Mr. Hajee Cassim and Mr. Ally wanted to get themselves registered, they should have come out boldly in the open to do so.
('8', 18, 1, 13, 40299) I see their names at the end of the list.
('8', 18, 1, 14, 40341) That shows that they got their hands soiled at the very last minute.
('8', 18, 1, 15, 40410) They will feel hurt by what I write.
('8', 18, 1, 16, 40447) I assure them that they could not feel more hurt than I did when I heard of their cowardice.
('8', 18, 1, 17, 40540) I am obliged to publish these names, hoping that the community will thus be rid of false personal considerations, groundless fears and corruption.
('8', 18, 1, 18, 40687) In addition, I also see the names of Khoja Velsi Keshavji.
('8', 18, 1, 19, 40746) and Khoja Manji Keshavji.
('8', 18, 1, 20, 40772) There are other names with me, but I shall publish them later.
('8', 18, 1, 21, 40835) This time I have given only the more prominent ones.
('8', 18, 2, 22, 40888) APPEAL TO BLACK LEGS AND SUGGESTION People’s memories being short, I assume that in the course of time we shall forget the black deeds of the black faced ones.
('8', 18, 2, 23, 41048) We shall remember that, notwithstanding their acts of treachery against the community, they are Indians.
('8', 18, 2, 24, 41153) If they feel really ashamed and desire the good of the community, they can take part in the struggle that will commence in January.
('8', 18, 2, 25, 41285) They will have to produce the title deeds of slavery when applying for licences.

('8', 22, 4, 5, 49139) SIR, This morning I received from the local Indian Committee at Standerton a letter of which the free translation is as follows: The balance of the month’s rations that were given to the railway employees in the beginning of the month was all taken away from them, and the rooms that were occupied by them wereunroofed yesterday (19th inst.).
('8', 22, 4, 6, 49482) Therefore, all have come here.
('8', 22, 4, 7, 49513) The Committee has arranged for their accomm odation.
('8', 22, 4, 8, 49566) They worked until noon yesterday, but they were not paid anything for that day.
('8', 22, 4, 9, 49646) They implored that they might be allowed to go to town to find accommodation, and then take away their wives and children, but even the children have been put out.
('8', 22, 4, 10, 49810) You were pleased to give me your assurance, and I notice the same assurance repeated in your communication to the press, namely, that there is no desire on the part of your Department “to act harshly or to take advantage in any way of its rights”.
('8', 22, 4, 11, 50058) If, therefore, there is any truth in the above communication, the officials who were carrying out the instructions have evidently been guilty of a grave dereliction of duty.
('8', 22, 4, 12, 50232) May I ask you kindly to make the necessary inquiries, and let me know?

('8', 24, 1, 2, 51514) 19. SPEECH AT HAMIDIA ISLAMIC SOCIETY 1
('8', 24, 2, 3, 51554) [VREDEDORP, December 27, 1907]
('8', 24, 3, 4, 51585) Mr. Gandhi said, when he read the announcement with reference to the Immigration Restriction Act that morning, the first thing that voluntarily came to his lips was that Lord Elgin had put an undue strain on Indian loyalty.
('8', 24, 3, 5, 51809) Lord Elgin, an ex Viceroy of India, had forgotten altogether Indian tradition.
('8', 24, 3, 6, 51888) When he advised His Majesty to sanction this legislation, he forgot altogether that he was trustee for the millions of India.
('8', 24, 3, 7, 52014) He forgot altogether that India was today on the brink of a departure which had been unknown in Indian annals.
('8', 24, 3, 8, 52125) India has never been revoluntionary, but today they found that the revolutionary spirit had crept into the minds of some Indians.
('8', 24, 3, 9, 52255) It would be a bad day for India when that forcible revolutionary spirit gained a substantial footing, but he could not help saying that Lord Elgin had sown the seed.
('8', 24, 3, 10, 52421) If this had been confined to the student world, it would probably never grow in Indian soil, but he found today that the merchant, who did not know a word of English, was steeped in the new spirit with reference to the Act and its evil.
('8', 24, 3, 11, 52658) He felt proud of the fact that he had taken so much part in the matter.
('8', 24, 3, 12, 52730) But he coupled with that the statement that his thoughts had been their thoughts, and in expressing them he had, if anything, moderated them.
('8', 24, 3, 13, 52872) It was for this reason that he expressed the feeling that Lord Elgin had put an undue strain on Indian loyalty by sanctioning this Immigration Restriction Act.
('8', 24, 3, 14, 53032) That Act, to his mind, was a barbarous Act.
('8', 24, 3, 15, 53076) It was the savage Act of a civilized Government, of a Government that dared to call itself Christian.
('8', 24, 3, 16, 53178) If Jesus Christ came to Johannesburg and Pretoria and examined the hearts of General Botha, General Smuts and the others, he thought he would notice something strange, something quite strange to the Christian spirit.
('8', 24, 3, 17, 53395) He (Mr. Gandhi) recognized that in proceeding under the Act, General Smuts had selected those men who had been in the public eye, and had not laid his hands on the poor people.
('8', 24, 3, 18, 53572) And he had not the slightest doubt that if those men who had to appear before the magistrate were imprisoned or deported, those who remained behind would be firm in opposition
('8', 24, 4, 19, 53748) 1 Gandhiji addressed a crowded meeting in the Hamidia Islamic Society hall in the evening.
('8', 24, 4, 20, 53839) Earlier that morning, Gandhiji had received a telephone message from Mr. H.F.D. Papenfus, Acting Commissioner of Police for the Transvaal, asking him to call on him.
('8', 24, 4, 21, 54005) Upon arriving there, he was informed that arrests had been ordered of himself, Thambi Naidoo (chief picket, Johannesburg), P.K. Naidoo (picket, Johannesburg), C.M. Pillay, Jamadar Nawab Khan (pickets, Johannesburg), Karwa (ex soldier, Johannesburg), Leung Quinn (Chairman, Chinese Association, Johannesburg), John Fortoen (Chinese picket), Martin Easton (Johannesburg), Ram Sundar Pundit (Germiston), G.P. Vyas (Pretoria), A.F.C. Beg (Pretoria), M.I. Desai (chief picket, Pretoria), A.M. Cachalia (Pretoria), Ismail Suliman Suj (Pretoria), Goolam Mahomed Abdool Rashid (Pretoria), B. Gangaram (Pretoria), V.U. Sheth (Pretoria), Ismail Jooma (Pretoria), Rahmat Khan (Pretoria), M.M. Khanderia (Pietersburg), Amershi Gokul (Pietersburg) and Ambalal (Pietersburg).
('8', 24, 4, 22, 54767) Gandhiji gave his word that all would appear before the respective magistrates at 10 a.m.
('8', 24, 4, 23, 54857) the next day, Saturday, December 28. Mr. Papenfus accepted this guarantee.

('8', 25, 0, 1, 54963) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 25, 1, 2, 55004) tothis Registration Act.
('8', 25, 1, 3, 55029) gave powers which would press hard 1 on the poor husbands.
('8', 25, 1, 4, 55088) They might be taken away from their families, and he instanced the case of Mr. Naidoo, who had shone brilliantly throughout the campaign.
('8', 25, 1, 5, 55226) He had a wife and five children who had been in the Colony for five years.
('8', 25, 1, 6, 55301) What was to happen if he were deported, and who was going to take care of his wife and children?
('8', 25, 1, 7, 55398) He could not find a single section in the Act which was to protect the families of those deported.
('8', 25, 1, 8, 55497) What was it the Government wanted to do?
('8', 25, 1, 9, 55538) Why had it not the honesty to tell the Indians they were not wanted in the country?
('8', 25, 1, 10, 55622) And why this indirect method of enforcing its powers?
('8', 25, 1, 11, 55676) He had called some sections of the Act savage, and he said they were only worthy of an uncivilized Government.
('8', 25, 1, 12, 55787) If those powers were so used and if all of them were deported or imprisoned, that were an honour for them rather than that they should forsake their solemn obligations and bid good bye to their manhood and self respect only because they were earning a few miserable pence or pounds.
('8', 25, 1, 13, 56070) He would never be sorry for the advice he had given them, and he also said, with reference to their 15 months’ fight, 2 that it was well done.
('8', 25, 1, 14, 56213) This was legislation which no self respecting nation and no self respecting man could accept—not because of its regulations, but because it was class legislation of the worst type, based on entire distrust of the community and based on charges flung against them without any proof.
('8', 25, 1, 15, 56495) They had asked Lord Selborne and General Smuts that these charges should be proved before an impartial tribunal.
('8', 25, 1, 16, 56608) They were brought by a man steeped in prejudice and incapable of judging facts.
('8', 25, 1, 17, 56688) Why should the Government not acknowledge that the least due to them was a fair trial?
('8', 25, 1, 18, 56775) He did not dwell on the fact that the Indians had no representation, but he did dwell on the fact that the Government should be so callous in reference to the feelings of the people who had no representative.
('8', 25, 1, 19, 56984) It seemed to him that they had come to the parting of the ways.
('8', 25, 1, 20, 57048) The Imperial Government must hesitate if it meant to retain its hold on the people of India through their affections and not at the point of the bayonet.
('8', 25, 1, 21, 57202) England might have to choose between India and the Colonies.
('8', 25, 1, 22, 57263) It might not be today or tomorrow, but he felt the seeds had been sown by Lord Elgin’s action.
('8', 25, 1, 23, 57358) It had not been possible for him to choose soft words or to strain his comment when he found the Asiatic Act with the Immigration Act super added.
('8', 25, 1, 24, 57505) There was a story of how Mahomed and two 3 fellows were sheltering in a cave, being pursued by a large hostile force.
('8', 25, 1, 25, 57623) His companions began to quail, and asked what they three could do against such heavy odds.
('8', 25, 1, 26, 57714) “You say ‘We three’,” said Mahomed, “I say ‘We four’, for God is with us, and with Him on our side we shall prevail.” God was with them, and so long as their cause was good, he did not mind a bit what powers the Government were given or how savagely those powers were used.
('8', 25, 1, 27, 57988) Even then he would give the same advice that he had ventured to give them for the last 15 months.

('8', 26, 1, 2, 58535) 20. INDIANS IN DELAGOA BAY 1
('8', 26, 2, 3, 58564) We publish in another column the full text of the remarkable regulations framed by the local Government at Delagoa Bay to restrict Asiatic immigration.
('8', 26, 2, 4, 58716) The regulations deal with three kinds of immigrants; or, rather, Asiatic visitors: (l) those who may leave Delagoa Bay; (2) those who may enter Delagoa Bay from outside districts; (3) Asiatics from Portuguese possessions in Asia.
('8', 26, 2, 5, 58946) They have decidedly a Transvaal flavour about them.
('8', 26, 2, 6, 58998) The Asiatics at Delagoa Bay, who have approached the Governor General, have been told that the regulations are necessary because “the province is threatened with a large influx of Asiatic immigrants from the neighbouring colonies, and that they are of a merely temporary nature”.
('8', 26, 2, 7, 59278) We trust that the British Indians at Delagoa Bay will not rest satisfied with the explanation given by the Governor General.
('8', 26, 2, 8, 59403) As a matter of fact, there is absolutely no influx into Portuguese territory from the Transvaal, and, even if there were, there would be little justification for harassing the domiciled British Indians in that Province.
('8', 26, 2, 9, 59623) Why, for instance, should they possess a special going out permit?
('8', 26, 2, 10, 59690) We understand that permanent documents have already been issued to them.
('8', 26, 2, 11, 59763) Why cannot British Indians leave Delagoa Bay without a licence and without proving that they are neither criminals nor bankrupts?
('8', 26, 2, 12, 59893) Under given circumstances, probably such a precaution may be in the interests of public justice, but Asiatics have by no means a monopoly of crime and bankruptcy.
('8', 26, 2, 13, 60056) Europeans leave Delagoa Bay as often as they please without having to prove that they have not criminally broken the laws of the country, or become insolvent.
('8', 26, 2, 14, 60215) The only redeeming feature of these harsh regulations is that the Portuguese Government, unlike Colonial British Governments, have recognised the necessity of drawing a broad distinction between Asiatics who are their own subjects and those who are not.
('8', 26, 2, 15, 60469) We trust that, as Delagoa Bay is a foreign country, Lord Elgin will find it possible to secure some measure of relief from these vexatious restrictions.
('8', 26, 2, 16, 60622) Indian Opinion, 28 12 1907
('8', 26, 3, 17, 60649) 1 Not reproduced here, vide also “Indians of Delagoa Bay”, 28 12 1907
('8', 27, 0, 1, 60719) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 27, 1, 2, 60760) 21. WHAT TO DO FOR THOSE THROWN OUT OF EMPLOYMENT?
('8', 27, 2, 3, 60811) The reader will gather from this issue that the Indian railway workers at Standerton and Heidelberg have lost their jobs for refusing to submit to the obnoxious law.
('8', 27, 2, 4, 60977) What should be done if a large number of people become unemployed in this manner?
('8', 27, 2, 5, 61059) This question ought to engage the attention of every Indian.
('8', 27, 2, 6, 61120) We have repeatedly stated that, if anyone suffers monetary loss before he is imprisoned, he will have to bear the loss himself.
('8', 27, 2, 7, 61248) The community can offer no help in such a case.
('8', 27, 2, 8, 61296) But it will be cruel to remain indifferent when hundreds of people face starvation.
('8', 27, 2, 9, 61380) We are told, besides, that starvation may drive a man to the meanest of jobs.
('8', 27, 2, 10, 61458) 1 In India, people in famine stricken areas are driven by hunger to sell their children.
('8', 27, 2, 11, 61547) It should not then be surprising if such ignoble hunger drives men to take out registers.
('8', 27, 2, 12, 61637) If therefore a large number of men are thrown out of employment, it will be necessary to provide aid to them.
('8', 27, 2, 13, 61747) Every Indian must think of this problem and send whatever he can to the Association at Johannesburg.
('8', 27, 2, 14, 61848) The next question to consider is what should be done after money has been collected.
('8', 27, 2, 15, 61933) If doles or allowances are paid to people for days on end without taking any work from them, that will only encourage vice and harm the recipients.
('8', 27, 2, 16, 62081) We are therefore of the view that the services of such people should be utilized for some public work project.
('8', 27, 2, 17, 62192) Mr. Gandhi has suggested the construction of a big hall.
('8', 27, 2, 18, 62249) It is a difficult undertaking, but worth taking up, and will be very easy to carry out if there is a large number of Indians to help.
('8', 27, 2, 19, 62383) It will serve three purposes.
('8', 27, 2, 20, 62413) The community will have a big building in the Transvaal for political purposes; jobless Indians will be provided with means of livelihood and the Indian struggle will get wide publicity through the construction of such a big building.
('8', 27, 2, 21, 62648) Indians outside the Transvaal ought not to be tight fisted, taking the view that, in case the Transvaal Indians build a hall, they alone will get the benefit of it.
('8', 27, 2, 22, 62813) Whether the hall is built or not, aid has to be provided to the jobless.
('8', 27, 2, 23, 62886) It is a problem that should engage the attention of every Indian.
('8', 27, 2, 24, 62952) If a hall is built, most of the expenditure will have to be borne by the Transvaal Indians themselves.
('8', 27, 2, 25, 63055) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 28 12 1907

('8', 28, 1, 2, 63268) 22. BRAVE WOMEN 1
('8', 28, 2, 3, 63286) Women in England have surpassed all expectations.
('8', 28, 2, 4, 63336) When the Indian community started the struggle against the obnoxious law in the Transvaal, the suffragette movement in England was many months old.
('8', 28, 2, 5, 63484) They are still continuing the struggle undaunted.
('8', 28, 2, 6, 63534) The struggle of the Transvaal Indians is nothing when compared with the courage and the tenacity of these women.
('8', 28, 2, 7, 63647) Moreover, they have to face opposition from many women.
('8', 28, 2, 8, 63703) There is a much larger number of women against than in favour of franchise for themselves.
('8', 28, 2, 9, 63794) Though a mere handful, these women do not admit defeat.
('8', 28, 2, 10, 63850) The more they are repressed, the more the resistance they offer.
('8', 28, 2, 11, 63915) Many of them have been to gaol.
('8', 28, 2, 12, 63947) They have borne being kicked and stoned by base and cowardly men.
('8', 28, 2, 13, 64013) There was a cable last week that they had resolved to intensify their struggle still further.
('8', 28, 2, 14, 64107) There are taxes to be paid to the Government by these women or their husbands.
('8', 28, 2, 15, 64186) If they do not pay the taxes, whatever things they possess can be auctioned.
('8', 28, 2, 16, 64263) They may even be imprisoned.
('8', 28, 2, 17, 64292) The women have now resolved that they will not pay any taxes or levies till they get their rights, but will rather allow their possessions to be auctioned, and they themselves will suffer imprisonment.
('8', 28, 2, 18, 64494) This courage and tenacity deserves to be emulated by the Transvaal Indians, in fact, by the whole Indian community.
('8', 28, 2, 19, 64610) The Natal Indians think it much of a hardship if their goods are to be auctioned for trading without a licence.
('8', 28, 2, 20, 64722) These people do not realize that the Government cannot auction the goods of a large number of people.
('8', 28, 2, 21, 64824) But what would it matter if it did ?
('8', 28, 2, 22, 64861) If women can sacrifice their possessions for a matter like franchise, cannot we put up with a similar hardship while fighting for our livelihood?
('8', 28, 2, 23, 65007) The movement of the suffragettes will go on for a long time, and they will keep up the agitation, resolute and tireless.
('8', 28, 2, 24, 65128) They fight on with faith in truth, persuaded that, though they will not be there to enjoy the rights, if only the succeeding generations enjoy them, it will be as good as if they had themselves done so.
('8', 28, 2, 25, 65331) Indians have to fight with the same spirit.

('8', 29, 1, 2, 65501) 23. INDIANS OF DELAGOA BAY
('8', 29, 2, 3, 65528) We publish elsewhere in this issue the full text of the Regulations for Registration of Indians in Delagoa Bay.
('8', 29, 2, 4, 65640) These Regulations are quite harsh.
('8', 29, 2, 5, 65675) It appears that Indians have already seen the Governor in this connection, but so far they have received no satisfactory reply.
('8', 29, 2, 6, 65803) If these Regulations come to stay, even the most princely Indian will need a permit accompanied with his photograph while going to Delagoa Bay.
('8', 29, 2, 7, 65947) A person on his way from the Transvaal can have a permit only if he establishes his right to return to the Transvaal.
('8', 29, 2, 8, 66065) All this mischief has originated in Pretoria.
('8', 29, 2, 9, 66111) Even if an Indian wishes to leave Delagoa Bay for good, he cannot do so without a permit.
('8', 29, 2, 10, 66201) He can leave only when he proves that he has never committed a crime, and that he is not an insolvent.
('8', 29, 2, 11, 66304) This is a new kind of oppression that is being introduced.
('8', 29, 2, 12, 66363) The Portuguese subjects of India are exempted from this law.
('8', 29, 2, 13, 66424) Are the Indians of Delagoa Bay going to submit to such a law?
('8', 29, 2, 14, 66486) When Moulvi Saheb Ahmed Mukhtiar returned from Delagoa Bay, he gave a fine account of the lethargy and indifference of the Indians there.
('8', 29, 2, 15, 66624) If the Indian community at Delagoa Bay does not shake off its lethargy even now and do what is required, it will deserve the scorn of every Indian.

('8', 30, 2, 5, 68086) 25. SOME ENGLISH TERMS
('8', 30, 3, 6, 68109) To respect our own language, speak it well and use in it as few foreign words as possible—this is also a part of patriotism.
('8', 30, 3, 7, 68234) We have been using some English terms just as they are, since we cannot find exact Gujarati equivalents for them.
('8', 30, 3, 8, 68348) Some of these terms are given below, which we place before our readers.
('8', 30, 3, 9, 68420) We shall publish in this journal the name of the person who supplies Gujarati equivalents for them which may be found acceptable.
('8', 30, 3, 10, 68550) We shall also present him with 10 copies of the booklet we have published on the new law, which may be circulated by him among friends.
('8', 30, 3, 11, 68686) The book is not offered by way of inducement, but to honour the recipient and spread information about the obnoxious law.
('8', 30, 3, 12, 68808) We hope that our readers will take the trouble of suggesting suitable equivalents not for the sake of the prize but out of patriotism.
('8', 30, 3, 13, 68943) The following are the terms in question: Passive Resistance; Passive Resister; Cartoon; Civil Disobedience.
('8', 30, 3, 14, 69051) There are other words too, but we shall think of them some other time.
('8', 30, 3, 15, 69122) It should be noted that we do not want translations of these English terms, but terms with equivalent connotations.
('8', 30, 3, 16, 69238) There will be no objection if the words are derived from Sanskrit or Urdu.
('8', 30, 3, 17, 69313) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 28 12 1907
('8', 30, 4, 18, 69356) 26. INDIA’S PLIGHT
('8', 30, 5, 19, 69375) The news of the death of the eldest son of Mr. Dadabhai of Johannesburg has set us thinking about many things.
('8', 30, 5, 20, 69486) Such deaths occur in India by hundreds of thousands every year.
('8', 30, 5, 21, 69550) Whole villages have been wiped out by the plague.
('8', 30, 5, 22, 69600) Families have been destroyed.
('8', 30, 5, 23, 69630) Very often we read newspaper reports of all the members of a family, parents and children, having perished.
('8', 30, 5, 24, 69738) Why is it that, though the plague occurs elsewhere, too, it does not destroy as many people as it does in India?
('8', 30, 5, 25, 69851) I am sure no lover of India can help asking this question.
('8', 30, 5, 26, 69910) The answer to it, we believe,
('8', 31, 0, 1, 69940) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 31, 1, 2, 69981) includes everything connected with the welfare of India.
('8', 31, 1, 3, 70038) It is easy to ask the question, but difficult to find the answer.
('8', 31, 1, 4, 70104) It is still more difficult, when the answer is found, to convince others that it is the right answer.
('8', 31, 1, 5, 70206) However, we think it worth while to make an attempt to give a partial answer to this question.
('8', 31, 1, 6, 70301) After careful thought, we have come to the conclusion that, if the plague, starvation, etc., have become more widespread in India, it is because of the sinfulness of the people.
('8', 31, 1, 7, 70479) If anyone wants to attribute it to the wickedness of the Government, we shall agree with him.
('8', 31, 1, 8, 70573) It is a common experience that people suffer when the rulers are wicked.
('8', 31, 1, 9, 70646) But it needs to be borne in mind that it is only a sinful people who have wicked rulers.
('8', 31, 1, 10, 70735) Besides, it is as a rule more profitable to examine our own faults than to blame others.
('8', 31, 1, 11, 70824) Disunity and enmity between Hindus and Muslims are sins.
('8', 31, 1, 12, 70881) But they are not fundamental sins.
('8', 31, 1, 13, 70916) If disunity disappears and the two communities live in peace and amity, foreign rule may go or the ways of the rulers may change.
('8', 31, 1, 14, 71046) But there is no reason to believe that when that happens, the plague and famines will disappear as a matter of course.
('8', 31, 1, 15, 71165) The chief sin is the untruthfulness of the people of India.
('8', 31, 1, 16, 71225) During the plague, we deceive the Government and deceive ourselves.
('8', 31, 1, 17, 71293) We make an outward show of cleanliness, but do not really observe it.
('8', 31, 1, 18, 71363) If anything is to be fumigated, we only make a show of doing it.
('8', 31, 1, 19, 71428) If we can do so with impunity, we avoid carrying out our obligations by bribing the police, if possible.
('8', 31, 1, 20, 71533) We are used to this state of affairs from our childhood.
('8', 31, 1, 21, 71590) They teach something at school.
('8', 31, 1, 22, 71622) The pupils readily accept it.
('8', 31, 1, 23, 71652) Returning home, they do exactly the contrary.
('8', 31, 1, 24, 71698) Parents acquiesce in such conduct.
('8', 31, 1, 25, 71733) Rules are given as to how cleanliness should be maintained.
('8', 31, 1, 26, 71793) Whether they are such as should be observed or not is a different question.
('8', 31, 1, 27, 71869) There can be a difference of opinion on that point.
('8', 31, 1, 28, 71921) What we want to prove is that we base our conduct on falsehood.
('8', 31, 1, 29, 71985) In most matters we only make an outward show.
('8', 31, 1, 30, 72031) That has a debilitating effect on our nerves.
('8', 31, 1, 31, 72077) Our blood becomes poisoned with the impurities of sinfulness and succumbs to germs of any kind.
('8', 31, 1, 32, 72173) It is observed that certain castes or communities are not affected by the plague.
('8', 31, 1, 33, 72255) The reason is that they do not make any false pretences with regard to cleanliness or any other matter.
('8', 31, 1, 34, 72359) They do not show themselves better than they are.
('8', 31, 1, 35, 72409) To that extent, we think they are superior to those who make a false show.
('8', 31, 1, 36, 72484) We do not imply by this that all people behave in this manner.
('8', 31, 1, 37, 72547) But by and large that is what happens.There is another dreadful habit, born of this very sin, which has spread among all classes of people.
('8', 31, 1, 38, 72687) And that is the sensuality— adultery —prevalent among us.
('8', 31, 1, 39, 72745) This matter can be touched upon only
('8', 32, 0, 1, 72782) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 33
('8', 32, 1, 2, 72826) in brief.
('8', 32, 1, 3, 72836) Ordinarily, people fight shy of discussing this question.
('8', 32, 1, 4, 72894) We, too, feel some hesitation.
('8', 32, 1, 5, 72925) However, we think it our duty to place our views beforethe readers.
('8', 32, 1, 6, 72993) Adultery does not consist merely in sexual intercourse with another man’s wife.
('8', 32, 1, 7, 73073) We are taught by every religion that there can be adultery even in intercourse with one’s own wife.
('8', 32, 1, 8, 73173) Sexual intercourse is justified only when it is the result of a desire for offspring.
('8', 32, 1, 9, 73259) Ordinarily, it is observed that sexual intercourse is the result of passion, the birth of a child following merely as a consequence.
('8', 32, 1, 10, 73392) India, in our judgment, is in such a miserable state that it is necessary at present for births to be reduced to a minimum.
('8', 32, 1, 11, 73516) Therefore, whatever sexual intercourse takes place will for the most part be in the nature of adultery.
('8', 32, 1, 12, 73620) If this view is correct, it is the duty of every thoughtful Indian not to marry.
('8', 32, 1, 13, 73701) In case he is helpless in regard to marriage, he should abstain from sexual intercourse with his wife.
('8', 32, 1, 14, 73804) All this is quite difficult to practise.
('8', 32, 1, 15, 73845) But there is no escape from it.
('8', 32, 1, 16, 73877) Otherwise we shall find it necessary to imitate the people of the West.
('8', 32, 1, 17, 73949) They adopt monstrous methods to control child birth.
('8', 32, 1, 18, 74002) They start wars and allow large numbers of people to be destroyed and, having abandoned their faith in God, they only seek means of surrounding themselves with material comforts and luxuries.
('8', 32, 1, 19, 74194) By following them, the Indians, too, can in course of time win freedom from the plague, etc.
('8', 32, 1, 20, 74287) But we do not think the evil tendencies of the West can have a foothold in India.
('8', 32, 1, 21, 74369) That means that India will either keep herself free from sinful ways of living, with her eyes fixed on God, and so win happiness, or will ever remain in a state of death in life, enduring never ending slavery, cowardly and fearful of death, rotting with the plague or such other inflictions.
('8', 32, 1, 22, 74661) Some people will find these ideas strange, or ridiculous, or as born of ignorance.
('8', 32, 1, 23, 74744) But we make bold to assert that every thoughtful Indian ought to give them his fullest consideration.
('8', 32, 1, 24, 74846) Such as they are, these thoughts are the result of this writer’s deep experience of life.
('8', 32, 1, 25, 74936) In any case, there will be no harm in putting them into practice.
('8', 32, 1, 26, 75002) No one will lose anything by observing truth and celibacy.
('8', 32, 1, 27, 75061) And it need not be asked what the people will gain if just a few persons follow this way of life.
('8', 32, 1, 28, 75159) If anyone asks such a question, he will be taken for an ignorant person.
('8', 32, 1, 29, 75232) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 28 12 1907
('8', 33, 0, 1, 75275) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 33, 1, 2, 75316) 27. ARAB WISDOM
('8', 33, 2, 3, 75332) We discussed in previous issues some books in the series The Wisdom of the East 1. The same writers have brought out a book on the subject noted above and have sent us a copy for review.
('8', 33, 2, 4, 75519) It is hardly necessary to say that the book is in English.
('8', 33, 2, 5, 75578) It is priced at one shilling only.
('8', 33, 2, 6, 75613) It contains extracts from the holy Koran, and reproduces the sayings of Arab thinkers on different matters.
('8', 33, 2, 7, 75721) For instance, with reference to nobility, it is said that “He who disregards his own honour gets no good from an honourable lineage .
('8', 33, 2, 8, 75855) Learning and high principles cover the shame of low origin.” 2 The book is full of rich thoughts having a bearing on our struggle for honour.
('8', 33, 2, 9, 75997) The poet says: “Men see no fault in one who respects himself.” Then again: “Be ashamed in your own sight more than in the sight of men.” Once more: “He who respects not himself can have no respect for others.” And elsewhere it is said: “Life has no worth and this world has no happiness for a man who has lost his self respect and abandoned himself to shamelessness.” Under Character, we have: “A man is truly religious when he is truly good.” Under Knowledge, we have: “A man without education is like a brave man without arms.” “Kings govern men and learned men govern kings.” “A wise man is not he who considers how he may get out of an evil, but he who sees to it that he does not fall into it.” On Truthfulness, it is said: “No man’s religion can be right unless his heart becomes right, nor can his heart become right unless his tongue is right.
('8', 33, 2, 10, 76849) That man is a hypocrite who prays and fasts, but is untruthful in what he says, false to his word, and unfaithful in discharging a trust.” Such are the golden sayings contained in this little book.
('8', 33, 2, 11, 77047) We advise everyone who can read English to buy this book.
('8', 33, 2, 12, 77105) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 28 12 1907
('8', 33, 3, 13, 77148) 1Vide “The Wisdom of the East”, 15 6 1907 and “The Wisdom of the East Series”, 13 7 1907 2 The extracts quoted here have been collated with an English review published in Indian Opinion.

('8', 34, 2, 3, 77403) MASS MEETING
('8', 34, 3, 4, 77416) A mass meeting of Indians will be held in front of the Surati mosque on Wednesday, January l, at 4 p.m.
('8', 34, 3, 5, 77520) to consider the struggle regarding licences from January onwards.
('8', 34, 3, 6, 77586) It is hoped that the meeting will be attended by Indians from all parts.
('8', 34, 4, 7, 77659) SOME THOUGHTS ON QUESTION OF LICENCES
('8', 34, 5, 8, 77697) We considered some aspects of the question last week, but it is necessary that we should give it further thought.
('8', 34, 5, 9, 77811) There is reason to believe that the real struggle will centre on this question.
('8', 34, 5, 10, 77891) It will certainly be necessary to trade without licences.
('8', 34, 5, 11, 77949) I find that there will be no need to produce registers when making applications for licences in respect of every kind of business.
('8', 34, 5, 12, 78080) The words used in the law are “trading licences”, which denote licences for business.
('8', 34, 5, 13, 78166) Such licences do not include licences for washermen or for bicycles.
('8', 34, 5, 14, 78235) That means that washermen will get their licences without having to produce registers.
('8', 34, 5, 15, 78322) It is the merchants and hawkers who will feel the need most.
('8', 34, 5, 16, 78383) If both these classes of Indians behave like men, the community will be free soon enough.
('8', 34, 5, 17, 78473) Also, on looking into the law, I find it doubtful whether Indians can be prosecuted in the month of January.
('8', 34, 5, 18, 78582) No person can be prosecuted for failure to take out a licence until after a month is over.
('8', 34, 5, 19, 78673) It appears therefore that prosecutions will take place in the month of February.
('8', 34, 5, 20, 78754) If any merchant is nervous, he can take out a licence in the name of his wife, in case he is married.
('8', 34, 5, 21, 78856) He can save himself from imprisonment by doing so.
('8', 34, 5, 22, 78907) But we are fighting to be, and to prove ourselves, men of courage.
('8', 34, 5, 23, 78974) I cannot therefore advise playing for safety.
('8', 34, 5, 24, 79020) I ask every Indian to apply for a licence for the sake of formality.
('8', 34, 5, 25, 79089) There is no need to spend anything on a lawyer for the purpose of making an application.
('8', 34, 5, 26, 79178) All that has to be done is to make an application and, after tendering the fee, mark time.
('8', 34, 6, 27, 79269) MOULVI SAHEB

('8', 34, 7, 33, 79658) If not, he will be allowed to go free.

('8', 35, 4, 12, 80264) The balance of the month’s rations that was given to them was taken away from them.
('8', 35, 4, 13, 80348) Turning a deaf ear to the entreaties of the workers on behalf of their womenfolk and children, they removed the roofs of their rooms that very day with a view to driving them out.

('8', 35, 4, 15, 80583) He has ordered payment of wages up to the end of the month.

('8', 35, 4, 17, 80707) This is a case which will infuriate every Indian.
('8', 35, 4, 18, 80757) The Government is afraid of Indians who are independent and strong, and therefore seeks: to intimidate the weak.
('8', 35, 4, 19, 80870) This is the limit of tyranny.

('8', 35, 4, 21, 80989) If those merchants and leaders now yield at the last moment and embrace slavery out of fear of imprisonment or monetary loss, they will earn the curses of the poor Indians and their families.

('8', 35, 6, 27, 81581) Punditji and Mr. Naidoo then went to Forchew and, spending the night at Mr. Mogalia’s, started work in the morning.

('8', 36, 6, 25, 84094) DIFFERENCE BETWEEN IMPRESSIONS OF FINGERS AND THUMBS
('8', 36, 7, 26, 84147) I had promised to discuss this matter some time, 1 and I do so now.
('8', 36, 7, 27, 84215) Thumb impressions are widely used in civil matters in India.
('8', 36, 7, 28, 84276) In England they have become a rage.
('8', 36, 7, 29, 84312) Friends send their thumb 
('8', 36, 8, 30, 84338) 1Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 14 12 1907
('8', 37, 0, 1, 84378) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 37, 1, 2, 84419) impressions to one another.
('8', 37, 1, 3, 84447) Pensioners and others are required to give impressions of thumbson receipts.
('8', 37, 1, 4, 84524) In Natal it is the practice to have thumb impressions on promissory notes.
('8', 37, 1, 5, 84599) Thumb impressions are thus taken because they make it easy to identify a person.
('8', 37, 1, 6, 84680) Impressions of two thumbs are taken, rather than of one, in order that, in case the impression of one of the thumbs is not clear, or is defaced, or has any other defect, the other impression can serve the purpose.
('8', 37, 1, 7, 84894) Apart from these, no impressions of fingers are required for the purpose of identification.
('8', 37, 1, 8, 84986) Digit impressions are taken from criminals because the person who is a criminal wants to evade being identified.
('8', 37, 1, 9, 85099) He always wants to remain unrecognized.
('8', 37, 1, 10, 85139) A person who has been required to give impressions of all fingers and thumbs can be identified by means of these impressions even if he has not given his correct name.
('8', 37, 1, 11, 85307) Research workers have prepared an index by means of which persons can be classified into different categories according to the impressions of their fingers and thumbs.
('8', 37, 1, 12, 85475) Hence, it is possible to prepare an index with the help of impressions.
('8', 37, 1, 13, 85547) Any person who has given his name as Ramji, which is not available on the records of the Government, can however be traced with the help of the index of impressions, if the impressions of his fingers and thumbs are available.
('8', 37, 1, 14, 85773) In this way many crimes have been detected in India and elsewhere.
('8', 37, 1, 15, 85840) This means that impressions of all fingers and thumbs are taken from criminals.
('8', 37, 1, 16, 85920) The Indian, on the other hand, wants himself to be identified.
('8', 37, 1, 17, 85983) If he does not describe himself correctly, he cannot live in this country; hence his interest will be in supplying correct particulars of his name, etc.
('8', 37, 1, 18, 86136) If his name is not on the records of the Government, he cannot live here.
('8', 37, 1, 19, 86210) It is therefore useless to demand digit impressions from him.
('8', 37, 1, 20, 86272) It can be proved to the Government with this convincing argument that taking ten impressions serves no purpose and involves unnecessary expenditure.
('8', 37, 1, 21, 86421) The argument has a scientific basis.
('8', 37, 1, 22, 86458) Hence, even after the new law is defeated, the Indian community can argue with the Government against ten impressions without fear of being called childish.
('8', 37, 1, 23, 86615) There is no such argument against the impressions of two thumbs.
('8', 37, 1, 24, 86680) Every struggle must have some substantial ground, otherwise public opinion will be against us.
