('8', 38, 5, 9, 87502) [JOHANNESBURG, December 28, 1907]
('8', 38, 6, 10, 87536) .Sharp at 10 a.m.
('8', 38, 6, 11, 87554) on Saturday last, all the Johannesburg men attended at the B. Criminal Court, where Mr. H. H. Jordan sits.
('8', 38, 6, 12, 87661) They were asked by Superintendent Vernon whether they held duly issued registration certificates under Law 2 of 1907, and upon receiving replies in the negative, they were all promptly arrested, and charged under Section 8 sub section 2 of Act 2 of 1907, in that they were in the Transvaal without a registration certificate issued under the Act.
('8', 38, 6, 13, 88008) The Court was crowded to excess and it seemed as if, at one time, the barrier would be overthrown.
('8', 38, 7, 14, 88107) Among those present were Mr. George Godfrey, Dr. M. A. Pereira, the Editor of Indian Opinion, and many other friends of and sympathisers with the accused.
('8', 38, 8, 15, 88262) Mr. P. J. Schuurman prosecuted on behalf of the Crown.
('8', 38, 9, 16, 88317) Mr. M. K. Gandhi, Attorney, Barrister at Law of the Inner Temple, Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal, was the first of the accused to be dealt with.
('8', 38, 10, 17, 88501) Superintendent Vernon, of the T.T.P., gave evidence as to the arrest.
('8', 38, 10, 18, 88571) He said the accused was an Asiatic over 16 years of age, resident in the Transvaal.
('8', 38, 10, 19, 88655) At 10 a.m.
('8', 38, 10, 20, 88666) that morning he called on Mr. Gandhi to produce his registration certificate, but he failed to do so, and said he had not got one.
('8', 38, 11, 21, 88797) Mr. Gandhi asked no questions, but went into the box, prepared to make a statement.
('8', 38, 11, 22, 88881) He said [that] what he was about to state was not evidence, but he hoped the Court would grant him indulgence to make a short explanation, seeing that he was an officer of that Court.
('8', 38, 11, 23, 89065) He wished to say why he had not submitted to this.

('8', 43, 1, 2, 99750) Mr. Jordan, in the course of his reply, pointed out that a deputation of Indians had gone home to the Imperial Government on the very matter before them.
('8', 43, 1, 3, 99904) That deputation had, however, been in vain.
('8', 43, 1, 4, 99948) The Act to which such exception was taken had been passed by the present Legislative Assembly of the Transvaal, and the King’s assent had been obtained.
('8', 43, 1, 5, 100101) And, all sentimentality apart, he had nothing to do but to administer the law, which he had sworn to do to the best of his ability.
('8', 43, 1, 6, 100233) These people (the accused) had deliberately defied the Government and had taken up a very serious position—one which he was sorry to see any resident in this country adopt.
('8', 43, 1, 7, 100406) It had been a mistake, he had no doubt, which had been copied from the passive resisters at Home in connection with the Education Bill, and that was an attitude which had never appealed to him in any shape at all.
('8', 43, 1, 8, 100620) The laws of a country must be complied with by the people resident there, and if they could not do that, there was but one alternative— such people must go somewhere else.
('8', 43, 1, 9, 100792) He could not, however, for the life of him understand, if a man put his thumb print on a registration certificate—as had been done in years past—where the offence against his religion came in when he had to put the print of the four fingers of each hand on this certificate.
('8', 43, 2, 10, 101067) Proceeding, he referred to the practice under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and urged that had they objected then to the thumb print, their position would have been stronger at the present time.
('8', 43, 2, 11, 101266) The registration certificates which required the thumb print had been the only mode they had for identification.
('8', 43, 2, 12, 101379) That was in the days of [the] old yellow pass which had been issued by the former Government; but all at once, when it came about that they had to register in the new form, the Asiatics simply defied the law.
('8', 43, 2, 13, 101588) Mr. Gandhi must be aware that he (Mr. Jordan) had more experience under the Peace Preservation Ordinance in the Transvaal than any other magistrate, and Mr. Gandhi must know also the big traffic that was done by the sale of the yellow certificates which rendered it difficult to trace the owner and caused an enormous amount of trouble and expense.
('8', 43, 2, 14, 101937) Coming back to the case of the youth then before the Court, he would make an order that he (the accused) must leave the Colony in seven days.
('8', 43, 3, 15, 102079) In a brief reply, Mr. Gandhi said that a distinction had always been drawn between the thumb print on the old permit and finger print under the new law.
('8', 43, 3, 16, 102232) The one was compulsory and the other was a voluntary act.
('8', 43, 3, 17, 102290) The Court, he said, was well aware that in cases where a clear thumb impression was taken, the man could be spotted and trafficking in permits had been [made] impossible.
('8', 43, 4, 18, 102461) He thanked the Court, the public prosecutor and the police for the courtesy which had been shown throughout the trials.

('8', 44, 2, 3, 102684) [JOHANNESBURG, December 28, 1907]
('8', 44, 3, 4, 102718) .They were going on with the struggle, no matter what happened to him or to anyone else.
('8', 44, 3, 5, 102807) He would certainly not change his views, and he urged the Asiatic communities to strive against the Registration Act even if it meant deportation from the Colony.

('8', 44, 3, 12, 103420) This was a religious struggle, and he gave them the advice he had always given them—to fight to the bitter end.

('8', 44, 4, 14, 103557) 32. LETTER TO “THE STAR” 2
('8', 44, 5, 15, 103584) JOHANNESBURG, December 30, 1907
('8', 44, 6, 16, 103616) TO THE EDITOR
('8', 44, 7, 17, 103630) THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('8', 44, 8, 18, 103654) SIR, The Government are to be congratulated on boldly and honestly taking proceedings mainly against those only who have led the passive resistance movement against the Asiatic Act.
('8', 44, 8, 19, 103836) That, indeed, is the only method of testing the reality and universality of Asiatic feeling.
('8', 44, 8, 20, 103929) But among those arrested are some who have never taken an active part in the agitation, and there are also remarkable omissions.
('8', 44, 8, 21, 104058) Both these facts tell their own tale.

('8', 45, 1, 2, 104594) on your courtesy, to deal with this phase of the question.
('8', 45, 1, 3, 104653) The arrests have synchronised with the announcement of the Royal Assent to the Immigration Act.
('8', 45, 1, 4, 104749) This shows that the Government intend to use their newly acquired power.
('8', 45, 1, 5, 104822) They have now three strings to their bow, viz., imprisonment, the stopping of trade licences, and deportation.
('8', 45, 1, 6, 104933) All these powers have been taken or given in order to enable the Government, not to stop an influx of Asiatics, because no one wants it, and the Registration Act cannot stop it; not to avoid trade competition, because every Indian submitting to the Act can have as many licences as and where he wants; but to enable them to bend Indians to their will, to force them to do violence to their conscience, in short, by delivering a crushing blow, to unman them, so that they may become as wax in their hands.
('8', 45, 1, 7, 105438) Do the colonists know that deportation under the Immigration Act is worse than ordinary deportation?
('8', 45, 1, 8, 105539) If I committed murder and were sentenced to transportation for life, I should be sent to a place where I should be housed and fed even as the few native rebels sent from Natal to St. Helena are.
('8', 45, 1, 9, 105734) But if I do not submit to the Asiatic Act I am deported, that is, put across the border or sent to India without a penny on me, if I do not possess private property, to shift for myself as best I can, the cost of deportation to be paid by me.
('8', 45, 1, 10, 105977) And if I have a family in the Transvaal, so far as the Government are concerned, they will be allowed to die of starvation.
('8', 45, 1, 11, 106101) And this, mind, is to happen to men to whom the Transvaal is their adopted home and India a foreign country for purposes of earning a livelihood.
('8', 45, 1, 12, 106247) Some of the Indians arrested are traders of nearly fifteen years’ standing, with wives born in South Africa and living in the Transvaal.
('8', 45, 1, 13, 106384) One Chinaman came to South Africa a mere lad, knows China only in name.
('8', 45, 1, 14, 106456) He was born and bred in Western institutions.
('8', 45, 1, 15, 106502) All the Asiatics arrested are lawful residents in possession of documents entitling them to remain in the country.
('8', 45, 1, 16, 106617) These men, because they do not violate their conscience, but violate the Asiatic Act, may not only be imprisoned, but deported, in the above fashion under a warrant signed by the Colonial Secretary!
('8', 45, 1, 17, 106816) I do not say that those who do not comply with the law, even when non compliance is due to the dictates of the conscience, should not be punished at all, but I do say that when the punishment is disproportionate to the offence, it savours strongly of barbarism.
('8', 45, 1, 18, 107078) And if the powers under the Immigration Act are exercised in respect of the Asiatic Law, an act of barbarism will have been committed in the name of the electors of the Transvaal.

('8', 46, 1, 4, 107494) I consider myself a lover of theBritish Empire, a citizen (though voteless) of the Transvaal, prepared to take my full share in promoting the general well being of the country.
('8', 46, 1, 5, 107671) And I claim it to be perfectly honourable, and consistent with the above profession, to advise my countrymen not to submit to the Asiatic Act as being derogatory to their manhood and offensive to their religion.
('8', 46, 1, 6, 107883) And I claim, too, that the method of passive resistance adopted to combat the mischief is the cleanest and the safest, because, if the cause is not true, it is the resisters, and they alone, who suffer.

('8', 48, 2, 4, 112506) 34. INTERVIEW TO REUTER 1
('8', 48, 3, 5, 112532) [JOHANNESBURG, December 30, 1907]
('8', 48, 4, 6, 112566) The Indians had all along offered to aid the Government in the matter of identification, but the Government had ignored their offers of assistance.
('8', 48, 4, 7, 112714) The Indians had always agreed that the Transvaal had the right to regulate and control future immigration.
('8', 48, 4, 8, 112821) What most concerned them was the position of the Indians now lawfully resident in the Transvaal.
('8', 48, 5, 9, 112918) Mr. Gandhi denied the imputation that the Indians had insulted the Government by putting the most offensive construction upon the Government’s Acts.
('8', 48, 5, 10, 113067) They would warmly welcome a reference of their case to the Imperial Conference, feeling assured that the result would be a humane and satisfactory arrangement which both sides would abide by.
('8', 48, 5, 11, 113259) Mr. Gandhi complained of the excessive power given to the Government by the Immigration Restriction Act in dealing with passive resisters—a power which he considered altogether disproportionate to the offence.
('8', 48, 5, 12, 113469) He anticipated that Indians who declined to register would have their trading licences refused on January 1, with the result that they would continue to trade without licences.
('8', 48, 6, 13, 113646) Mr. Gandhi mentioned that the Indians here have received telegrams from the Indian National Congress at Surat and from other quarters expressing sympathy and promising support.—Reuter.
('8', 48, 6, 14, 113831) India, 3 1 1908
('8', 48, 7, 15, 113847) 1 Gandhiji gave this interview commenting on Sir Raymond West’s remarks made in London that both sides had gone “too far”—the Transvaal Government had “cynically” ignored the susceptibilities of the Indians and the Indians had put “the most, instead of the least, insulting construction” on the Acts of that Government.
('8', 48, 7, 16, 114167) He suggested a compromise.
('8', 48, 7, 17, 114194) The Indians should offer to aid the work of identification by “inoffensive means”, and tender co operation in regulating immigration on terms of “inoffensive registration” of residents in the country.

('8', 59, 1, 2, 136934) 38. RAM SUNDER “PUNDIT”
('8', 59, 2, 3, 136958) Ram Sundar is no longer a “pundit”, and so we have had that part of his name set up in smaller type.
('8', 59, 2, 4, 137059) “Pundit” was a title he him self had assumed.
('8', 59, 2, 5, 137105) But now that he has lost the qualities of one, he should no longer be known by that name.
('8', 59, 2, 6, 137195) We apologize to our readers for earlier having showered praises on Ram Sundar in this journal, for having used grand epithets to des cribe him and held up his attitude to the law as an example.
('8', 59, 2, 7, 137389) 1 We are guiltless for we were misled; we were unaware of the facts.
('8', 59, 2, 8, 137458) We have a saying that no one can divine what lies in the heart of a man or in the hollow of a drum.
('8', 59, 2, 9, 137558) We could not peer into Ram Sundar’s heart.
('8', 59, 2, 10, 137601) We believed his professions and thought him brave.
('8', 59, 2, 11, 137652) We will continue to do so with others in future.
('8', 59, 2, 12, 137701) That is the only way for man to live in society.
('8', 59, 2, 13, 137750) It will be to claim omniscience to suspect one who is appar ently sincere, or to shun his company.

('8', 59, 2, 18, 138114) That is our way of atoning for an unwitting error.

('8', 62, 1, 2, 143433) 40. LETTER TO RECEIVER OF REVENUES 1
('8', 62, 2, 3, 143470) [JOHANNESBURG, January 4, 1908] 2
('8', 62, 3, 4, 143504) [F. C. BIGGAR, ESQ.
('8', 62, 3, 5, 143524) THE RECEIVER OF REVENUES JOHANNESBURG]
('8', 62, 4, 6, 143563) SIR, My Association has seen the notice in the Gazette to the effect that trading licences will not be issued to British Indians unless they can produce registration certificates under the Asiatic Law Amend ment Act No.
('8', 62, 4, 7, 143783) 2 of 1907, and undergo certain other formalities.
('8', 62, 4, 8, 143833) My Association understands, too, that several British Indians have applied for licences and formally tendered the licence fee, but that their licences have not been granted, because of the above notice.
('8', 62, 4, 9, 144036) On behalf of my Association, therefore, I beg formally to in form you that, as the large majority of British Indians have for consci entious reasons declined to submit to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, and as it is not possible for Indian traders or hawkers to earn their liv ing otherwise than as traders or hawkers, they are reluctantly comp elled to continue their trade without proper licences.
('8', 62, 4, 10, 144435) I may further add that, should the notice regarding licences be withdrawn, andshould you be pleased to grant licences, on a notification from you, the licence fee will be immediately paid and licences taken out
('8', 62, 5, 11, 144646) 1 This was very likely drafted by Gandhiji.
('8', 62, 5, 12, 144690) 2 The date of this letter is mentioned in the reply sent by the Receiver of Revenues, who said: “In reply I beg to point out to you that Indian traders who are disposed to contravene the law in the manner indicated render themselves liable to the provisions of the Revenue Licence Ordinance, 1905, which imposes heavy penalties on any persons carrying on any trade or business without being in possession of a licence, irrespective of whether the persons are offenders against the requirements of any other statute or not.
('8', 62, 5, 13, 145213) “The Press notice on the subject of renewal of licences, 1908, is not of a sta tutory character, but merely an advisory notice inserted in the papers for the infor.
('8', 62, 5, 14, 145378) and guidance of the business community.
('8', 62, 5, 15, 145418) Its publication or withdrawal has no force or effect on the question at issue”.

('8', 63, 5, 6, 145938) 41. REPLY TO “THE STAR”
('8', 63, 6, 7, 145962) [JOHANNESBURG] [THE EDITOR THE STAR JOHANNESBURG]
('8', 63, 7, 8, 146012) SIR, In your survey of the Asiatic question you say:
('8', 63, 8, 9, 146065) It is the possible effect on the native races, who live under differential legislation themselves which makes it impossible in our opinion for the Government to yield to agitation without loss of prestige now that things have gone as far as they have.
('8', 63, 8, 10, 146317) May one infer from this that “if things had not gone as far as they have” the Asiatic case would, in your opinion, be strong enough to require reconsideration?
('8', 63, 8, 11, 146477) However, whether the inference is justified or not, with your permission, I would merely deal with the religious aspect of the question.
('8', 63, 8, 12, 146614) I beg to remind you that the matter wore a religious aspect at the first mass meeting 1, at the old Empire Theatre, in the September of 1906, when the now famous solemn covenant not to submit to the Asiatic Act was, after due deliberation, made by British Indians.
('8', 63, 8, 13, 146879) The disqualification against Turkish Mahomedans on the ground of reli gion was then present in the Bill and has always been pointed out as a ground of complaint.
('8', 63, 8, 14, 147041) 2 In my humble opinion, the solemn obligation by itself constitutes sufficient religious objection against the Act.
('8', 63, 8, 15, 147157) And a State that overbears such an objection on the part of its inhabitants fails to fulfil its primary duty to respect conscientious scruples.
('8', 63, 8, 16, 147301) I shall now endeavour to place before the public the general rel igious objection.
('8', 63, 8, 17, 147384) A and B are resident in the same state.
('8', 63, 8, 18, 147424) B is charged
('8', 63, 9, 19, 147437) 1Vide “The Mass Meeting”, 11 11 1906 2Vide “Deputation Notes II”, 17 11 1906 & “Deputation to Morley”, 22 11 1906.
('8', 64, 0, 1, 147552) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 65
('8', 64, 1, 2, 147596) with having committed a fraud.
('8', 64, 1, 3, 147627) Although both A and B have deman ded a public inquiry into the charges, the fraud has never been pro ved; yet A and his children over the age of eight years, in common with B. are called upon to submit to a punitive measure on account of B’s alleged fraud.
('8', 64, 1, 4, 147884) If A accept that measure, and, for that matter evenB, either does violence to his religion,because he surrenders his manhood and his conscience through fear of personal inconvenience or loss.
('8', 64, 1, 5, 148076) The position of A and B is that of every Asiatic in the Colony.
('8', 64, 1, 6, 148140) This would be the essential religious objection, even if there were no binding oath and no discrimination against a particular religion.
('8', 64, 1, 7, 148277) If it be true that Asiatic feeling has been intensely roused, a concession to that feeling instead of producing an injurious effect on the Native mind, would produce a reassuring effect, in that, if the sen timents of one unrepresented class are respected, those of another such class also, it will be argued, are likely to be respected.
('8', 64, 1, 8, 148615) Prestige is a high horse which, under conceivable circumstances, may bring down the rider, if he do not take care.

('8', 64, 6, 13, 148836) Mr. Gandhi, interviewed by a Star representative this morning on the situation in general and on the statement made by the Colonial Secretary at Pretoria in parti cular, said : 2
('8', 64, 7, 14, 149015) Probably General Smuts has no notion of how difficult it made the position of Indians like myself who want to serve both the local Government and the Indian community, when he talks of all Asiatics as coolies.
('8', 64, 7, 15, 149225) Instead of trying to bridge the gulf, by such language he is only widening it.
('8', 64, 8, 16, 149304) LAW 3 OF 1885 AND PEACE PRESERVATION ORDINANCE
('8', 64, 9, 17, 149351) General Smuts has evidently mixed up Law No.
('8', 64, 9, 18, 149396) 3 of 1885 with the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('8', 64, 9, 19, 149445) Law 3 of 1885 never stopped the immigration of Asiatics; it merely penalized Indian traders to the extent of £3. If I may go into history a bit, originally this tax upon
('8', 64, 10, 20, 149615) 1 This and the following item are both reports of the same interview.

('8', 65, 1, 2, 149775) Indian traders was to be prohibitive, that is to say, £25. Lord Derby protested against it, and it was reduced to £3 in the amending law.
('8', 65, 1, 3, 149913) This showed that the late Mr. Kruger’s Government never aimed at prohi bition of Asiatic immigration.
('8', 65, 1, 4, 150015) As a matter of fact, I well remember the late President having told an Indian traders’ deputation that he did not mind Indians coming into the country so long as they helped his; farmers to sell their produce and he did not want Indians to remain in the country on a basis of equality.
('8', 65, 2, 5, 150301) FIRST ATTEMPT AT RESTRICTION
('8', 65, 3, 6, 150330) The restriction of immigration was only thought of after the British Government was established and the Peace Preservation Ordin ance, which was designed only to cope with disloyal people and crimi nals, was adroitly and effectively used to restrict Indian immigration.
('8', 65, 3, 7, 150600) It is necessary to bear this distinction in mind because the Asiatic Reg istration Act is improperly called an amendment of Law 3 of 1885. It inaugurates a new policy altogether so far as British Colonies are con cerned and particularly the Transvaal.
('8', 65, 3, 8, 150852) Before the introduction of the Registration Act there was no question of identification at all except in the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('8', 65, 3, 9, 150991) If the identifcation under the Peace Preservation Ordinance was incomplete a more complete system could have been devised without any new legislation at all as was done by Captain Hamilton Fowle 1. but when there was talk of having a more systematic identification a suggestion was made that the Peace Preservation Ordinance should be amended, and a draft Bill was actually sent by Mr. Duncan 2 to Lord Elgin.
('8', 65, 3, 10, 151401) That Bill appears in the last Asiatic Blue book.
('8', 65, 3, 11, 151450) To that no one took any exception at all.
('8', 65, 4, 12, 151492) INCEPTION OF REGISTRATION ACT Subsequently it appears Mr. Lionel Curtis 3 came on the scene,
('8', 65, 5, 13, 151585) 1 Permit Officer 2 Patrick Duncan, former Colonial Secretary in the Transvaal Government; member of the Legislative Council 3 Town Clerk of Johannesburg, 1909 3; Assistant Colonial Secretary for Urban Affairs in the Transvaal, 1903 6 and later nominated member of new Transvaal Legislative Council; a pioneer of the Closer Union Movement; had a passion for “scientific method” and “is now known to fame as the missionary for diarchy in India”; vide Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. ('8', 66, 0, 1, 152356) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 67
('8', 66, 1, 2, 152400) and he rejected the amendment of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and drafted the present Registration Bill, which deals with the Asiatics as such, and treats them as a class apart.
('8', 66, 1, 3, 152583) It is this which has so irritated the Indian community.
('8', 66, 1, 4, 152639) It is perfectly true that there has been some class legislation before, but never of such a drastic type.
('8', 66, 2, 5, 152745) ALLEGED INFLUX OF ASIATICS
('8', 66, 3, 6, 152772) As regards the influx of British Indians we have always denied it so far as any organized illegal influx is concerned.
('8', 66, 3, 7, 152891) A little knowledge of the working of the Asiatic Offices ought to show that the forging of permits, after the permits adopted by Captain Fowle came into opera tion, was well nigh impossible.
('8', 66, 3, 8, 153082) What actually happened was that some times wrong men received permits, because they successfully bribed the Asiatic officers in Johannesburg.
('8', 66, 3, 9, 153224) It was after the British Indian Asso ciation had repeatedly brought this corruption to the notice of Sir Arthur Lawley 1 that these officers were removed.
('8', 66, 3, 10, 153379) When I speak of wrong men I do not mean men who were not entitled to permits, but men who had not the prior right.
('8', 66, 3, 11, 153494) I know several old refugees who were obliged to make these payments before they could get their permits.
('8', 66, 3, 12, 153599) All the same such documents were bona fide documents and held by the persons described in them.
('8', 66, 3, 13, 153695) It was the touts of these officers who handled the enormous sums of money.
('8', 66, 4, 14, 153770) A DENIAL
('8', 66, 5, 15, 153779) I do deny that “thousands of Indians” who had no right to enter the country have so entered.
('8', 66, 6, 16, 153872) The interviewer drew Mr. Gandhi’s attention to Mr. Smuts’ statement that 5,000 Indians had gone out of the country rather than register, and the latter replied that the majority of these had every right to remain—their right could not be questioned—but they were not strong enough to face the trouble.
('8', 66, 6, 17, 154174) The prosecutions, numbering 1,500 during a period of five years, go to show that the Indian contention is correct, namely, that whenever an attempt has been made the Peace Preservation Ordinance has been sufficient to cope with it.
('8', 66, 6, 18, 154406) It should also be remembered that most of these prosecutions were at the border in connection with men who were trying to enter but failed.
('8', 66, 6, 19, 154546) It may be as well to mention that 563 convictions took place between November 15, 1902, and Febru ary 28, 1903. It should be within the recollection of the public that immediately after peace was declared, although there was a Peace Pre servation Ordinance, people came in freely.
('8', 66, 6, 20, 154827) So did Indians and they were not molested at all.

('8', 69, 2, 11, 161118) 43. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('8', 69, 3, 12, 161158) [JOHANNESBURG, January 6, 1908]
('8', 69, 4, 13, 161190) A representative of The Leader waited upon Mr. Gandhi yesterday and sought from him an expression of opinion upon General Smuts’ speech at Mayville on Saturday last 1.
('8', 69, 5, 14, 161358) Mr. Gandhi in expressing his willingness to discuss the matter, said: I wish to make it clear that Indians have no desire to oppose General Smuts or any Colonist, or to place any obstacles in the way of an honourable compromise.
('8', 69, 5, 15, 161587) The Indians recognize that the only con dition on which they can remain in the country is to work smoothly and amicably, and to understand their limitations also.
('8', 69, 5, 16, 161750) They have always, I venture to think, worked on that basis, and, no matter what may be now said to the contrary, they still remain law abiding resi dents of the Transvaal.
('8', 69, 6, 17, 161922) 1 January 4, 1908. General Smuts had made the following points among others: (I) Mr. Gandhi had argued that the Asiatic Act was class legislation “but the whole subject had been dealt with as class legislation since 1885, and the Indians had submitted to it”; (2) “the law had not been passed for chasing the Asiatics out of the country who had been there for 10, 15 or 20 years” but “to recognize all Asiatics who were in the country before the war” and to “stop further immigration”; (3) “no parliament in the country was capable of repealing the Act”; (4) they had the British Government with them and he saw no reason why it should not continue to assist the Transvaal; (5) if the Indians did not submit to the law they must take the consequences.
('8', 69, 6, 18, 162674) They could be refused licences, placed in prison (about 9,500 of them) which would not be very effectual, or put over the border.
('8', 69, 6, 19, 162804) The Indians had been misled by their leaders and the Government had arrested these.
('8', 69, 6, 20, 162888) If they came forward not as individuals but as a whole to be registered then the opportunity would be given them.
('8', 69, 6, 21, 163002) However, he was not expressing the opinion of the Government but his own.
('8', 70, 0, 1, 163076) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 71
('8', 70, 1, 2, 163120) [INTERVIEWER:] How does that agree with their present attitude of ‘passive resistance’?
('8', 70, 1, 3, 163208) [GANDHIJI:] Passive resistance is merely a respectable protest against what they, rightly or wrongly, consider to be a degradation and an offence to religious feeling.
('8', 70, 1, 4, 163376) The whole speech of General Smuts unfortunately shows that there is absolutely no desire on his part to consult or to reconcile Indian sentiment.
('8', 70, 1, 5, 163522) I say without hesitation that he has not mastered his facts.
('8', 70, 1, 6, 163583) For instance, he talks of the oft denied influx of Asiatics into the country on an organized scale.
('8', 70, 1, 7, 163683) Speaking for British Indians, I deny it in toto.
('8', 70, 1, 8, 163732) This does not mean that some Indians have not surreptitiously entered this country, but all these can be effectively dealt with, even today, under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('8', 70, 1, 9, 163913) Those who remain in the country without permits, or with false permits, can only be hiding themselves in nooks and corners, and those will never be reached by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('8', 70, 1, 10, 164103) It is not likely that those who have no permits or those who hold docu ments which are not permits at all, will go to the Registrar in order to receive notice to quit.
('8', 70, 2, 11, 164271) THE SURREPTITIOUS INFLUX
('8', 70, 3, 12, 164296) The allegation as to the surreptitious entering is based on the report 1 that was published last year.
('8', 70, 3, 13, 164399) That report condemns itself, and, if any thing, proves the contrary; 1,500 prosecutions during live years show the effective working of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and that was the deduction drawn from it by Captain Hamilton Fowle in his report to Lord Milner.
('8', 70, 3, 14, 164666) Any Indian found without a permit in the Colony can be almost summarily removed, and, if he does not leave the Colony, soon finds himself in gaol.
('8', 70, 3, 15, 164813) Most of the prosecutions, how ever, were in connection with Indians who were trying to enter the country, who were successfully prevented from so doing by strict ins pection at the border towns.
('8', 70, 3, 16, 165008) Nor were those Indians necessarily ende avouring to enter fraudulently.
('8', 70, 3, 17, 165080) They were, in the initial stages, trying to do so under the false belief, shared by many Europeans, that under the British flag there could be no difficulty in them [sic] entering, or rather re entering, the Transvaal, for most of those were Indian refugees waiting at the coast towns for an opportunity of re entering.
('8', 70, 3, 18, 165400) General Smuts talks of forged permits, and in the same breath says it is difficult to say when a permit is forged and when it is gen uine.
('8', 70, 3, 19, 165539) This is preposterous.
('8', 70, 3, 20, 165561) The permit officials always had counter foils containing the same numbers as given on the permits issued to applicants, so that a forgery could always be detected.
('8', 70, 3, 21, 165725) I know that a
('8', 70, 4, 22, 165739) 1Vide “Chamney’s Report”, 13 4 1907 & “Johannesburg Letter”, 13 4 1907
('8', 71, 0, 1, 165810) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 71, 1, 2, 165851) few months ago an official from the present Registrar’s Office circu lated some documents which he called permits.
('8', 71, 1, 3, 165966) The dupes were never able to use those documents at all.
('8', 71, 1, 4, 166023) They not only lost their money, but their honour.
('8', 71, 1, 5, 166073) That official is now no longer in the country, but, I believe, left it after he had sufficiently fleeced the people, and after he saw that the fraud was likely to be found out.
('8', 71, 1, 6, 166250) There never was an office either in Bombay or Delagoa Bay, or in any other place, where the traffic alleged by General Smuts could possibly take place.
('8', 71, 1, 7, 166402) Touts there undoubtedly were, not in India, but in South Africa, who gave real permits from the Asiatic Office in Johannesburg to refugees, and, in some instances, others who wanted to enter the country.
('8', 71, 1, 8, 166606) THE PERMIT FRAUD The fraud was committed in this way.
('8', 71, 1, 9, 166660) The Asiatic officials in Johannesburg submitted the names to the Colonial Secretary as proper applicants for permits.
('8', 71, 1, 10, 166778) The Colonial Secretary sanctioned the granting of such permits.
('8', 71, 1, 11, 166842) These names, however, were often faked, though the permits were properly issued and bore proper thumb impressions, or signatures.
('8', 71, 1, 12, 166972) In such manner men who were entitled to enter the country had to pay large sums before they could come in, or before their claims were considered.
('8', 71, 1, 13, 167119) This was three times brought to the notice of Sir Arthur Lawley, who, at last, ordered a prosecution, which proved abortive, but the officials concerned were dismissed, because the charge was proved against them, so far as the department was concer ned.
('8', 71, 1, 14, 167373) But these things show how effective the Peace Preservation Ordinance was.
('8', 71, 1, 15, 167447) It confuses the issue to talk about Law 3 of 1885 in connection with the influx, and to describe it as inadequate.
('8', 71, 1, 16, 167562) That law was never intended to control Asiatic immigration.
('8', 71, 1, 17, 167622) It simply says, ‘Those who settle in the Republic for the purpose of carrying on any trade or otherwise shall be bound to have their names entered in a register.” Thus it was merely to exact a poll tax from those who wished to trade in the Transvaal, for Indians were not even bound to register or pay anything.
('8', 71, 1, 18, 167934) Asiatic immigration was as free as European immigration.
('8', 71, 1, 19, 167991) The question of restricting such immigration was raised after peace was declared, and the Peace Preservation Ordinance was then utilized, quite improperly) to check Asiatic entry.
('8', 71, 1, 20, 168171) For some reason or other it was suggested that the Peace Preservation Ordinance should be amended.
('8', 71, 1, 21, 168270) The Draft Amendment appears at page 9 of the Blue book, Legislation affecting Asiatics in the Transvaal, published last 1 year.
('8', 71, 1, 22, 168398) That would have been quite proper, and British Indians could not have complained.
('8', 71, 1, 23, 168480) A Draft Amendment of Law 3 of 1885 was also suggested at the same time.
('8', 71, 2, 24, 168552) 1 Actually, it was published in January 1908; vide “Blue Book”,29 2 1908
('8', 72, 0, 1, 168625) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 73
('8', 72, 1, 2, 168669) POLICY SUDDENLY CHANGED It was quite of a mild type, but suddenly the whole thing was changed, and I believe it was Mr. Lionel Curtis who, after all, changed the whole scope and tenor of such legislation, and who sprung upon the community the draft of the Asiatic Amendment Ordinance, now sanctioned as an Act.
('8', 72, 1, 3, 168980) It is a misnomer to call it an Amendment of Law 3 of 1885; it really makes a change in the whole Asiatic policy.
('8', 72, 1, 4, 169093) Class legislation affecting Asiatics has been passed before now, and not much has been heard against it, but the Asiatic Registration Act is absolutely a novel thing, and, based as it is on the false charge above referred to, can never be accepted by the Indian community, more so as the community is bound by a solemn declaration.
('8', 72, 1, 5, 169425) It is surprising to me that General Smuts has persistently igno red these things, and asked British Indians to violate their consciences.
('8', 72, 1, 6, 169563) One would have thought that he, as representing a very strong Gov ernment and an overwhelmingly large number of Europeans, would have sufficient grace and condescension to respect Indian sentiment, so long as he got the essential thing—viz., identification of every Indian or m Asiatic residing in the Colony.

('8', 74, 3, 5, 174477) Mr. Gandhi then drew attention to General Smuts’ concluding remarks, and said he had there laid down a proposition which, if it were to hold good generally, would mean the end of all agitation, healthy or otherwise.

('8', 74, 5, 17, 176159) THE WAY OUT
('8', 74, 6, 18, 176171) Is there no honourable way out of the present difficulty?
('8', 74, 6, 19, 176229) Yes, Indians have always offered to fulfil the essential object of the Act, viz., to give every facility to the Government for complete identification of British Indians entitled to remain in the Colony.
('8', 74, 7, 20, 176433) 1Vide “Natal Municipal Bill”, 23 2 1907 2 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 13 4 1907
('8', 75, 0, 1, 176513) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 75, 1, 2, 176554) could have been done voluntarily under the Peace Preservation Ordi nance.
('8', 75, 1, 3, 176628) Now that that Ordinance is virtually repealed, and must be totally repealed if the Asiatic Act is also repealed, the only practical way out of the difficulty is to amend, during the next session of Parliament, the Immigration Restriction Act, so as to embody the necessary clauses for identification, regard being had to the statements always made by the Indian community with reference to minors under 16, and with reference to those who can pass the education test under the Act, which is severe enough.
('8', 75, 2, 4, 177134) Asked to elaborate his proposal, Mr. Gandhi said the Immigration Restriction Act, which contains the drastic power of deportation under the hand of the Minister, is ample for every purpose.
('8', 75, 2, 5, 177324) Let the Asiatic Law Amendment Act of 1907 be entirely withdrawn, and the Immigration Restriction Act be slightly amended so that every Asiatic would become a “prohibited immigrant”.
('8', 75, 2, 6, 177506) That was to say, he would then have to prove that he was entitled to remain in the Colony.
('8', 75, 2, 7, 177597) If he could produce his certi ficate issued to him under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, or under Law 3 of 1885, he would be given a certificate of domicile, which would take the place of his former certificate, and other documents at present held, and this new certificate of domicile should contain ample proofs of the identity of the holder.
('8', 75, 2, 8, 177944) Children under the age of 16 should not be required to take out certificates of domicile, but a complete enumera tion of such children would be detailed, together with their names, on the certificates of domicile issued to their parents and guardians.
('8', 75, 2, 9, 178196) The Immigration Act already con tains sufficiently drastic provisions against trafficking in these certificates of domi cile.
('8', 75, 2, 10, 178322) This scheme, Mr. Gandhi contended, would give the Govern ment all that they reasonably required—viz., it would prevent any further immi gration of Asiatics, and would ensure complete identification and registration of all Indians and Asiatics enti tled to remain here.
('8', 75, 2, 11, 178591) Thus the wishes of the Government and the people of the Trans vaal would be fully met without putting any unnecessary affront upon the Indians.
('8', 75, 2, 12, 178735) It has been often said that the Transvaal, being an inland Colony, cannot have an Immigration Act like the Cape or Natal.
('8', 75, 2, 13, 178857) That, in my opinion, is a mistake.
('8', 75, 2, 14, 178892) What is meant is that the Immigration Act of the Transvaal should provide for stricter identification than the Natal Act.
('8', 75, 2, 15, 179014) According to the Natal Act, any Indian can at any time prove his domicile and demand entry.
('8', 75, 2, 16, 179106) Under the amendment suggested by me, every Indian would have to prove his domicile, or his right of resi dence in the Transvaal, within a stipulated time, after which he would be for ever stopped.
('8', 75, 2, 17, 179303) Surely nothing more than this can be required?

('8', 76, 2, 3, 179451) [JOHANNESBURG] January 8, 1908]

('8', 76, 3, 5, 179725) The Act would then be unnecessary, and could be withdrawn.

('8', 76, 4, 9, 180183) The Indian community considered that his suggestion that a High Court Judge should hold an enquiry into the surreptitious entry of Indians into the Transvaal and the question of identification would give the Government an opportunity of reviewing the situation.

('8', 81, 3, 5, 191994) Miss Schlesin 1 is an unmarried girl of twenty.
('8', 81, 3, 6, 192042) Very few Indians know how hard she has worked for the community.
('8', 81, 3, 7, 192107) She works indeed not for a salary, but because of her deep sympathy [for the Indian cause].
('8', 81, 3, 8, 192199) She attends cheerfully to everything that is entrusted to her.
('8', 81, 3, 9, 192262) She asked to speak at the recent mass meeting.
('8', 81, 3, 10, 192309) What follows is a translation of her thoughts.
('8', 81, 3, 11, 192356) She had obtained her parents’ permission for making a speech.
('8', 81, 3, 12, 192418) This girl has passed her matriculation examination, and she can be said to have had an excellent education.
('8', 81, 3, 13, 192526) Her speech was read out by Mr. Gandhi: 2
('8', 81, 4, 14, 192567) Now that the struggle has reached its culminating point, I, who have followed it with the closest attention almost from its inception, would fain say a few words of sympathy, of heartfelt sympathy, in the sufferings which you have already undergone, in the sufferings still before you, of which the former are but aforetaste.
('8', 81, 4, 15, 192893) But I implore you not to flinch from the hardships which now confront you, not to falter at the shoals ahead, but to continue steadfastin your heroic resolve to give up all, aye very life itself, for the noble cause of country and religion.
('8', 81, 4, 16, 193134) Let me remind you of a similar crusade now being waged by my sisters in England.
('8', 81, 4, 17, 193215) I refer to the suffragettes.
('8', 81, 4, 18, 193244) For the sake of a principle, they are prepared to lose their all, to brave innumerable trials.
('8', 81, 4, 19, 193339) Many have already suffered imprisonment, more are ready, nay eager, to do so.
('8', 81, 4, 20, 193417) If delicately nurtured women can do this, will hardy men, inured to toil, do less?
('8', 81, 4, 21, 193500) Do not swerve from the course upon which you have entered, be true to the ideal before you; and ‘heart within and God o’erhead’, proceed to conquer or to die.
('8', 81, 4, 22, 193659) And, if you do that, if you adhere to your solemn covenant with God, if you prove yourselves resolute in deed, as you have already shown yourselves gentle in method, then it will not be to die!
('8', 81, 4, 23, 193853) Success then is assured, victory is yours, is ours.
('8', 81, 4, 24, 193905) It is a young girl who addresses this sincere exhortation to us.
('8', 81, 4, 25, 193970) If, after all this, we accept loss of face out of a cowardly fear of gaol, we are sure to repent it much.
('8', 81, 5, 26, 194076) 1 Sonja Schlesin; a Jewish girl with “a character as clear as crystal and courage that would shame a warrior”; joined Gandhiji as a steno typist at the age of 16; made herself very useful to Indian Opinion; was ardently interested in the Indian cause.
('8', 81, 5, 27, 194328) “Thousands of stalwart Indians looked up to her for guidance.
('8', 81, 5, 28, 194390) When during the satyagraha days almost everyone was in jail, she led the movement single handed.

('8', 87, 9, 19, 208733) 48. INTERVIEW TO “THE STAR”
('8', 87, 10, 20, 208761) [JOHANNESBURG, January 10, 1908]
('8', 87, 11, 21, 208794) Mr. Gandhi insisted upon the elimination of the element of compulsion of the Act and the consequent withdrawal of the notices regarding the issue of licences and registration.
('8', 87, 11, 22, 208970) In return he undertook that every Indian in the country would be registered in a month’s time according to a form to be mutually agreed upon which would be issued to those Indians entitled to remain in the Colony or who were otherwise approved.
('8', 87, 12, 23, 209215) 1 The names are not reproduced here and the figures in square brackets indicate the number of persons from each town.
('8', 88, 0, 1, 209333) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 89
('8', 88, 1, 2, 209377) If voluntary registration were faithfully carried out, the Registration Act would become useless, and the Indian community would look for its withdrawal during the next session of Parliament.
('8', 88, 1, 3, 209569) If on the other hand the undertaking of the leaders were not fulfilled, Mr. Gandhi said he would welcome the enforcement of the Act against those who had not complied.
('8', 88, 2, 4, 209737) He was prepared to go further, evidently with the view of meeting the prejudice against the Indian trader, and was anxious that the Government and the various municipalities should frame by laws governing the issue of trading licences, so that only Indians with suitable premises and with the means of keeping a proper system of accounts should be licensed to trade.

('8', 88, 3, 6, 210130) 49. LAST MESSAGE TO SOUTH AFRICAN INDIANS
('8', 88, 4, 7, 210172) [JOHANNESBURG, January 10, 1908]
('8', 88, 5, 8, 210205) TO TRANSVAAL INDIANS
('8', 88, 6, 9, 210226) It must be borne in mind that success in the struggle will depend on what the Transvaal Indians do while those arrested remain in gaol.
('8', 88, 6, 10, 210362) It is well therefore that the Government has arrested some persons.
('8', 88, 6, 11, 210430) It will be a testing time for the others.
('8', 88, 6, 12, 210472) Cowards will spread panic.
('8', 88, 6, 13, 210499) Blacklegs will say all manner of things.
('8', 88, 6, 14, 210540) It is my appeal to all my brave fellow countrymen to remain undaunted by these, and be ever mindful of their pledge and keep up their courage.
('8', 88, 6, 15, 210683) At the very beginning of the campaign we had resolved not to compromise our honour by submitting to the obnoxious law, whateverthe cost.
('8', 88, 6, 16, 210820) We find hundreds of examples, among the British, of persons sacrificing their all for honour and country.
('8', 88, 6, 17, 210926) It is only when we do likewise that we shall become esteemed men and retain that esteem.
('8', 88, 6, 18, 211015) I therefore take it that Indians will remain unshaken, whether or not they get licences, whether or not they are allowed credit, and that they will only become confirmed in their resolve to endure imprisonment or deportation.
('8', 88, 6, 19, 211241) If only they will prepare themselves in their own minds, they will find that gaol is not something to be frightened of.
('8', 88, 6, 20, 211361) Let no one look to the others; let each depend on his own strength, so that even if in fear a few Indians submit to the outrageous law, the others will not be tempted to do likewise.
('8', 88, 6, 21, 211544) You will, in this manner, serve your interests as well as those of the country.
('8', 88, 6, 22, 211624) If you make the mistake of registering, you will throw
('8', 89, 0, 1, 211679) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 89, 1, 2, 211720) away success just as it has come within reach.
('8', 89, 1, 3, 211767) Not only does this righteous campaign call for courage; but it is also based on truth.
('8', 89, 1, 4, 211854) Large numbers [of Indians] must be faced with the prospect of starvation.
('8', 89, 1, 5, 211928) It will be necessary to provide for their relief.
('8', 89, 1, 6, 211978) This will call for honesty of the highest degree.
('8', 89, 1, 7, 212028) Contributions will be received from various towns, and these will have to be utilized to good purpose.
('8', 89, 1, 8, 212131) Let no one ask for aid unless in need.
('8', 89, 1, 9, 212170) Those in charge of distributing aid should act with the utmost scrupulousness in utilizing whatever funds or food grains are placed at their disposal.
('8', 89, 1, 10, 212321) This struggle will test the strength of all the elements of character and lay bare all our weaknesses.
('8', 89, 1, 11, 212424) Let us be careful, then, after sending so many people to gaol not to throw away this opportunity by panicking and submitting to the law.
('8', 89, 1, 12, 212561) We should bear no grudge against those who have taken out registers or may do so hereafter.
('8', 89, 1, 13, 212653) If you are convinced that their action is not right, you will not feel the slightest temptation to follow their example.
('8', 89, 1, 14, 212774) Those who have the courage to fight till the last will be able to earn a livelihood anywhere in the world.
('8', 89, 2, 15, 212881) TO OTHER INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('8', 89, 3, 16, 212914) The Transvaal Indians put up with hardships of every description—physical, mental, financial.
('8', 89, 3, 17, 213008) You are asked to make sacrifices only of money.
('8', 89, 3, 18, 213056) Do not therefore fall behind.
('8', 89, 3, 19, 213086) Money will be needed in plenty.

('8', 89, 3, 22, 213248) This is a campaign that concerns not only the Transvaal Indians, but the entire Indian community.
('8', 89, 3, 23, 213346) Your interests, too, are atstake.
('8', 89, 3, 24, 213380) It is in your power to give financial aid; equally, you can help by holding meetings and passing resolutions.
('8', 89, 4, 25, 213490) TO ALL INDIANS
('8', 89, 5, 26, 213505) Success will never be ours if we do not at all costs keep Hindu Muslim differences out of matters of common interest.
('8', 89, 5, 27, 213623) Let everyone accept this as a guiding principle.
('8', 89, 5, 28, 213672) We shall succeed only when we feel a strong urge that all of us, Hindus and Muslims alike, belong to the Same land and are children of the same mother.

('8', 90, 1, 2, 213937) 50. SPEECH AT NEWTOWN MOSQUE 1
('8', 90, 2, 3, 213968) [JOHANNESBURG January 10,1908]
('8', 90, 3, 4, 213999) There was considerable commotion among the Indian community this morning, says The Star (Johannesburg) of Saturday last, when it became known that Mr. Gandhi and the other Indians and Chinese who were ordered to leave the Colony within 48 hours a fortnight ago were called upon to attend Court for sentence.
('8', 90, 3, 5, 214307) There was a large gathering outside B Court at ten o’clock, and before the doors were opened word was circulated that the proceedings against the defaulters would not be taken until the afternoon.
('8', 90, 3, 6, 214504) Mr. Gandhi availed himself of the opportunity the few hours’ postponement allowed to address his countrymen.
('8', 90, 3, 7, 214613) It was to be a valedictory exhor tation to the rank and file of the Indians to stand firm during the incarceration of the leaders of the passive resisters’ movement.
('8', 90, 3, 8, 214779) The meeting was held in the Mosque grounds, Newtown, at 11 o’clock, and despite the short notice of the meeting there was a large gathering.
('8', 90, 3, 9, 214920) For the purpose of such [a] meeting a platform had been erected in the grounds, and seating accommodation was provided by means of the serviceable paraffin tins which were strewn about in thousands.
('8', 90, 3, 10, 215119) On the platform were Essop Ismail Mia, Chairman of the British Indian Association, an Indian priest in an artistic Oriental garb, and Mr. Gandhi.
('8', 90, 3, 11, 215265) A few introductory remarks were made by Mr. Mia, and then Mr. Gandhi spoke.
('8', 90, 3, 12, 215341) He was listened to with the greatest intentness.
('8', 90, 3, 13, 215390) Every eye was fixed upon the slim central figure of Mr. Gandhi, and the meeting gave an indication of the hold he has upon his countrymen.
('8', 90, 4, 14, 215529) After his speech 2 in Hindustani Mr. Gandhi spoke in English.
('8', 90, 4, 15, 215591) He said he could not detain them for any length of time.
('8', 90, 4, 16, 215648) The telephone message he had received that morning was that those who were under notice and whose period of notice had expired had to appear before the Court at 10 o’clock.
('8', 90, 4, 17, 215821) Just as they were about to leave for the Court, Superintendent Vernon came to inform them that they were to appear at two o’clock.
('8', 90, 4, 18, 215952) He believed that those who had to go to gaol today were not at all afraid.
('8', 90, 4, 19, 216027) On the contrary, they considered that it was a fit opportunity given them by the Government to serve their country and to show that they weremen, not dogs.
('8', 90, 4, 20, 216183) All the same, he was superstitious enough to believe that when these things were postponed from time to time, even though they might ultimately happen, they showed which way the wind was blowing, and they showed also that God was with them.
('8', 90, 5, 21, 216424) FREE HOSPITALITY
('8', 90, 6, 22, 216441) He thought he would not have had that opportunity of addressing his countrymen before accepting the free hospitality of His Majesty.
('8', 90, 6, 23, 216574) But God had willed
('8', 90, 7, 24, 216593) 1 This is the Star report as reproduced in Indian Opinion under the title “Mr. Gandhi’s Valediction: Leaders Imprisoned”.
('8', 90, 7, 25, 216715) 2 This is not available.
('8', 91, 0, 1, 216740) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 91, 1, 2, 216781) otherwise, and he was there to give them the last word probably for a month, it might be for two months, it might be for six months, and the word he had to place before them was “Do not deceive yourselves; do not deceive the Government; do not deceive your humble servant.” He believed sincerely that that struggle had been undertaken at their desire; that when he placed before them the true position of the law, all of them said that it was not possible for them to submit to the law—that rather than submit to a law of that nature they would suffer imprisonment, be banished from the country, lose everything that they possessed, rather than submit to the law.
('8', 91, 2, 3, 217445) THE STING OF THE ACT
('8', 91, 3, 4, 217466) That law, he repeated for the thousandth time, was not a question of giving a wife’s name or a mother’s name, or giving one thumb impression or ten digit impressions, although all those things were undoubtedly to be considered when they were compelled to give these things, but the sting lay in the spirit itself.
('8', 91, 3, 5, 217780) Jesus Christ had said that no man had seen God because He was a spirit.
('8', 91, 3, 6, 217852) Similarly it was not possible to describe in words the underlying spirit of the Act.
('8', 91, 3, 7, 217937) Every Indian felt that spirit, and having felt it shunned it as he would shun Satan.
('8', 91, 3, 8, 218022) The law was based upon the condemnation of the whole of the Indian community, and it did not matter a bit whether General Smuts said that he wished to treat them justly and fairly.
('8', 91, 3, 9, 218203) Judgment should be pronounced upon his acts and not upon his words.
('8', 91, 3, 10, 218271) What they saw was that by reason of false dignity the Government would not have what they wanted to give freely, but wanted to compel them to give as if they were slaves.
('8', 91, 3, 11, 218442) Compulsion was possible in a matter of personal freedom only when it was slaves who were to be dealt with.
('8', 91, 4, 12, 218549) THE DOG’ S COLLAR
('8', 91, 5, 13, 218567) He well recalled an incident that happened when with Mr. Ally he went to England as their servant.
('8', 91, 5, 14, 218666) A gentleman on board said, “I see you are going to London in order to get rid of the dog’s collar.” Precisely; it was because they did not want to wear a dog’s collar that they had put up that fight.
('8', 91, 5, 15, 218866) They were willing to sacrifice everything for sentiment, but it was a noble sentiment.
('8', 91, 5, 16, 218953) It was a sentiment that had to be cherished as a religious sentiment.
('8', 91, 5, 17, 219023) It was a sentiment that bound people together; it was a sentiment that bound creatures to the Creator.
('8', 91, 5, 18, 219126) That was the sentiment for which he had asked them, advised them, if necessary, to die.
('8', 91, 5, 19, 219214) Their action would be reflected throughout the British dominions, through the length and breadth of India, and they were now upon their trial.
('8', 91, 6, 20, 219357) GENERAL SMUTS’ ACTION
('8', 91, 7, 21, 219379) He did consider General Smuts had performed an honourable action in arresting them and wishing to lodge them in gaol.
('8', 91, 7, 22, 219497) He (General Smuts) was quite justified in believing, because of the reports he had read, that the whole of this agitation depended upon a few Indians.
('8', 91, 7, 23, 219648) If it depended upon a few Indians only, and if the whole of his countrymen had not been acting together throughout the past sixteen months, then he thought they had proved that they deserved the Act.
('8', 91, 7, 24, 219848) But if, after he and his
('8', 92, 0, 1, 219873) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 93
('8', 92, 1, 2, 219917) colleagues were safely out of harm’s way, they remained firm, stuck together, and were prepared to suffer every inconvenience and to lose all, then he had not the slightest doubt that they would gain all, gain the estimation of all the reasonable Colonists whose estimation was worth prizing.
('8', 92, 1, 3, 220210) If they submitted to the Act it was true that they would be able to live a dog’s life, and had [sic] earned the Colonists’ kicks.
('8', 92, 1, 4, 220340) The gates of the Registration Office [—] it was highly probable [—] would be flung open once more immediately he and his colleagues had retired from the scene, but he did hope that whatever they had said in public, whatever they had prayed for in secrecy before their God, they would carry out to the bitter end.
('8', 92, 1, 5, 220653) He hoped that no terrorism, no intimidation, no amount of meetings held by their fellow subjects, if he might call them so, held by European British subjects would deter them from the action that they had embarked upon.
('8', 92, 1, 6, 220873) There was no terror and no fear for a man who believed in God.
('8', 92, 2, 7, 220936) “A STRUGGLE FOR RELIGIOUS LIBERTY”
('8', 92, 3, 8, 220971) No matter what might be said he would always repeat that that was a struggle for religious liberty.
('8', 92, 3, 9, 221071) By religion he did not mean formal religion, or customary religion, but that religion which underlay all religions, which brought them face to face with their Maker.
('8', 92, 3, 10, 221237) If they ceased to be men, if on taking a deliberate vow they broke that vow in order that they might remain in the Transvaal without physical inconvenience, they undoubtedly forsook their God.
('8', 92, 3, 11, 221430) To repeat again the words of the Jew of Nazareth, those who would follow God had to leave the world, and he had called upon his countrymen in that particular instance to leave the world and cling to God as a child would cling to the mother’s breast.
('8', 92, 3, 12, 221680) If they did that he had not the slightest doubt that this struggle could have but one issue.
('8', 92, 4, 13, 221773) A MONTH HENCE
('8', 92, 5, 14, 221787) It did not matter what General Smuts thought today, but it would matter what he thought a month hence, when they had shown, every one of them, that they were men.
('8', 92, 5, 15, 221950) He had not the slightest doubt that General Smuts had sufficient humanity in him to recognize the sincerity of purpose, the real feeling that underlay the community, and if they showed to him that the majority of Indians were not going to accept the Act, but would rather suffer imprisonment and degradation, forfeiture of all their goods, then General Smuts, without anybody going to him, would say, ‘Yes, these are the people I shall prize as my citizens; these are the people whom I shall prize as fellow citizens with me and who will be of service to the State.’ But if they did not take up that position, then General Smuts would certainly also say, ‘Yes, 10,000 Indians may remain in the Colony.
('8', 92, 5, 16, 222652) We can keep them as dogs and allow them todie their natural death.’ Their natural deaths they would die far outside the Transvaal, wherever there was a piece of earth given them, but if they would die a noble death, a man’s death, there was only one course open to them.
('8', 92, 5, 17, 222923) If, perchance, even after they had taken that course it came to pass that every one of them had to leave the Transvaal, then was it not better that they should leave as men than remain as cowards
('8', 93, 0, 1, 223119) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 93, 1, 2, 223160) who had gone back upon their sacred resolution taken at the old Empire Theatre?
('8', 93, 1, 3, 223240) He thought the whole of the Colony would rise and tell General Smuts, if the Colony was convinced that they were sincere, willing to suffer for their cause and country, religion and honour, then the Colonists would tell General Smuts he had not received a mandate to expel these people from the country.
('8', 93, 1, 4, 223544) They did not want future immigration, they did not want to remain there and set up undue competition with white people.
('8', 93, 1, 5, 223664) People who were capable of putting up a fight like that would not offer undue competition, but would fall in with any legislation that might be devised for the common good of all, but certainly not for the good of only a handful of store keepers.
('8', 93, 1, 6, 223911) If it were necessary that stores should be regulated for the common good of the country, why, they had offered it times without number.
('8', 93, 1, 7, 224047) They did not want to flood the Colony with Indians, but the handful of Indians who had a right to remain in the Transvaal should be allowed to remain as worthy citizens of a mighty Empire, but should not remain as beasts so long as he could help it.
('8', 93, 1, 8, 224297) (Applause.) Indian Opinion, 18 1 1908
('8', 93, 2, 9, 224335) 51. TRIAL AT JOHANNESBURG 1
('8', 93, 3, 10, 224363) [JOHANNESBURG, January 10, 1908]
('8', 93, 4, 11, 224396) The eastern side of Government Square presented an extraordinary scene of excitement this afternoon.
('8', 93, 4, 12, 224497) All through the lunch hour there was a big gathering of Indians, and at two o’clock precisely a continuous stream of Indians indicated the approach of the leaders.
('8', 93, 4, 13, 224661) Mr. Gandhi was the first to appear.
('8', 93, 4, 14, 224697) It was drizzling, and his ardent admirers sheltered him with umbrellas as he walked along slowly reading the first edition of The Star.
('8', 93, 4, 15, 224833) The Indians kept pouring on to the Square, and the public entrance to the Court was blocked.
('8', 93, 4, 16, 224926) The Magistrate, Mr. Jordan, was seen walking through the crowd, and of course he attracted considerable attention.
('8', 93, 4, 17, 225041) At ten minutes past two the lock was heard in the door, and the press outside became greater.
('8', 93, 4, 18, 225135) The doors were flung open and the crowd was met by Captain Potter, Superintendent Vernon, and two police.
('8', 93, 4, 19, 225241) The officer ordered the entrance to be cleared and considerable confusion followed.
('8', 93, 4, 20, 225325) The dense mass swayed backward, and when it was possible for egress to be obtained by a few people at a time, people were allowed to pass in.
('8', 93, 4, 21, 225467) The Indians continued to force their way, and attempted to rush the police at the door.
('8', 93, 4, 22, 225555) The Commissioner of Police, who was in the Court, saw that the force at the door was strengthened, and the entrance was again cleared.

('8', 95, 3, 6, 229113) 52. MESSAGE TO “RAND DAILY MAIL”
('8', 95, 4, 7, 229146) [JOHANNESBURG, January 10, 1908]
('8', 95, 5, 8, 229179) Asked for a final message previous to his incarceration, Mr. Gandhi gave the following to a Rand Daily Mail representative: I have undertaken this struggle prayerfully and in all humility believing in the entire righteousness of the cause, and I hope that one day the Colonists will do justice to my countrymen.
('8', 95, 5, 9, 229491) So far as my countrymen are concerned, I can only hope that they will remain firm in their sacred and solemn resolution.
('8', 95, 5, 10, 229612) By doing so they have nothing to lose.
('8', 95, 5, 11, 229651) Even though they may have to lose their all they can only gain in the esteem of their fellow men by being resolute.
('8', 95, 5, 12, 229767) I sincerely state that in effecting my arrest General Smuts has done a very honourable act.
('8', 95, 5, 13, 229859) He believes that my countrymen have been misled by me.
('8', 95, 5, 14, 229914) I am not conscious of having done so, but I may have been misled myself.
('8', 95, 5, 15, 229987) In any case removing me from the arena will show whether the position is real or unreal.
('8', 95, 5, 16, 230076) The position therefore is absolutely in our own hands.

('8', 96, 1, 2, 230776) 53. PETITION TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 1
('8', 96, 2, 3, 230814) [JOHANNESBURG GAOL, January 21, 1908] 2
('8', 96, 3, 4, 230854) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED BEING AT PRESENT PRISONERS IN HIS MAJESTY ‘S GAOL AT JOHANNESBURG
('8', 96, 4, 5, 230952) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT
('8', 96, 5, 6, 230972) The Petitioners are all Asiatics, in all twenty one.
('8', 96, 5, 7, 231025) Eighteen of the Petitioners are British Indians and three are Chinese.
('8', 96, 5, 8, 231096) The eighteen British Indians get mealie meal for breakfast.
('8', 96, 5, 9, 231156) Of the other fourteen meals seven consist of rice and ghee, three of beans and four of mealie meal.
('8', 96, 5, 10, 231256) On Saturdays potatoes and on Sundays vegetables are: added to the mealie meal.
('8', 96, 5, 11, 231335) For religious reasons all the above are vegetarians—some only because they cannot get religiously killed meat or proper meat.
('8', 96, 5, 12, 231461) The Chinese get whole mealies and fat in place of rice and ghee.
('8', 96, 5, 13, 231526) All the Petitioners have been either in the habit of taking European food or mostly so—their staple consisting either of bread or some preparation of flour.
('8', 96, 5, 14, 231683) None of your Petitioners has been used to taking mealie meal.
('8', 96, 5, 15, 231745) They are most of them suffering from constipation, probably due to the eating of mealie meal.
('8', 96, 5, 16, 231839) Seven of the Petitioners have gone without breakfast ever since their incarceration except that some Chinese witnesses, knowing their plight, once parted with one loaf which was divided among them.
('8', 96, 5, 17, 232037) This was only brought to the notice of the Governor, who said the witnesses ought not to have done so.
('8', 96, 5, 18, 232140) In the Petitioners’ humble opinion, the diet above referred to is totally unsuitable for them.
('8', 96, 5, 19, 232235) The Petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the diet according to European scale with the exception of mealie meal may be prescribed for them, or such other diet as may be considered suitable to keep body and soul together and may be consistent with their national habits, or habits formed by prolonged residence in South Africa.
('8', 96, 5, 20, 232566) As the matter is one of extreme emergency, the Petitioners crave

('8', 97, 4, 8, 233274) 54. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY 1
('8', 97, 5, 9, 233309) JOHANNESBURG GAOL, January 28, 1908 2
('8', 97, 6, 10, 233347) TO THE HON’BLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY OF THE TRANSVAAL
('8', 97, 7, 11, 233402) SIR, As representatives of the Indian and the Chinese communities 3
('8', 97, 8, 12, 233470) who have taken a prominent part in the opposition to the Asiatic Registration Amendment Act, we have the honour to lay the following considerations before you: Our opposition has never been directed so much against the fingerprint requirements of the Regulations under the Act—in so far as such finger prints were deemed necessary for the identification of Asiatics who could not very well be otherwise identified—as against the element of compulsion contained in the Act itself.
('8', 97, 8, 13, 233950) On that ground we have repeatedly offered to undergo voluntary registration if the Act were repealed.
('8', 97, 8, 14, 234052) And even now at this late hour we would urge on the Government the adoption as far as possible of the course more than once proposed by us.
('8', 97, 8, 15, 234192) We recognize that it is not possible during the Parliamentary recess to repeal the Act, and we have noted your repeated public declarations that there is no likelihood of the Act being repealed.
('8', 97, 9, 16, 234387) 1 This letter as well as the draft Cartwright brought to Gandhiji in jail were published in Indian Opinion, 11 7 1908. The draft was either prepared or approved by General Smuts; vide Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XXI and “Johannesburg Letter”, p.
('8', 97, 9, 17, 234637) 66. There exist four sources for this letter: the Pretoria Archives; the records of the Colonial Office to whom a copy of this letter was sent by the Transvaal Government; an office copy of the Cartwright draft together with handwritten changes made at Gandhiji’s instance (S. ('8', 97, 9, 18, 234944) 2 The Indian Opinion version, however, is dated January 29, 1908. 3 The Cartwright draft has only “the Indian community”.
('8', 98, 0, 1, 235066) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 99
('8', 98, 1, 2, 235110) would however point out that the periods fixed for registration under the Act by the various Government Notices have expired and that therefore anyregistration at present would necessarily have to be of that voluntary nature which we originally prayed the Government to concede 1. Under these circumstances we would once more respectfully suggest to the Government that all Asiatics over the age of sixteen years 2 should be allowed within a certain limited period, say three months, to register themselves, and that to all who so register, the Act 3 be not applied, and that the Government take whatever steps they deem advisable to legalize such registration.
('8', 98, 1, 3, 235772) Such mode of registra tion should apply to those also who being out of the Colony may return and otherwise possess the rights of re entry.
('8', 98, 2, 4, 235911) In taking the registration of Asiatics we do not object that the requirements of the Act and the regulations be as nearly as possible 5 complied with, provided the registration officials do not press for any information which offends the religious sense of the applicants, and receive discretion to dispense with the finger print requirement in the case of those applicants who by reason of their education or property or public character are well known or can be easily identified other wise.
('8', 98, 2, 5, 236405) In those cases we urge that the officials should have discretion to accept the signature of the applicant as a sufficient identification.
('8', 98, 2, 6, 236543) Should the Government agree to these suggestions and accept 6 registration on these terms, we assume that all further prosecutions or punishments under the Act will be suspended during the period set aside for registration.
('8', 98, 2, 7, 236767) We on our part again would undertake to use all our influence to induce our compatriots to register and withdraw all

('8', 99, 3, 6, 238583) 55. INTERVIEW TO “RAND DAILY MAIL”
('8', 99, 4, 7, 238618) [JOHANNESBURG, January 30, 1908]
('8', 99, 5, 8, 238651) Mr. Gandhi on his return [from Pretoria] was seen by a Mail representative...
('8', 99, 6, 9, 238729) Many questions regarding the compromise were immediately levelled at his head....
('8', 99, 7, 10, 238811) [REPORTER:] Honourable to both sides, Mr. Gandhi?
('8', 99, 7, 11, 238861) [GANDHIJI:] Perfectly.
('8', 99, 7, 12, 238884) The honour of the Colony has not been affected in the least, while the feelings and scruples of the Asiatics have received the fullest consideration.
('8', 99, 8, 13, 239034) Then it is no climb down?
('8', 99, 8, 14, 239060) Absolutely not.
('8', 99, 8, 15, 239076) We have merely made an arrangement by which the whole question has been satisfactorily settled—satisfactory to all parties concerned.
('8', 99, 9, 16, 239210) 1 “violating our consciences” added by Gandhiji.
('8', 99, 9, 17, 239259) The Pretoria Archives version has, however, “conscience” in the singular.
('8', 99, 9, 18, 239333) 2 The draft had “cast” which Gandhiji changed to “casting”.
('8', 99, 9, 19, 239393) 3 “Leader of the Chinese residents of Johannesburg”; chairman of the Chinese Association and the Cantonese Club.
('8', 99, 9, 20, 239506) 4 Thambi Naidoo; a Tamil businessman from Mauritius whom Gandhiji described as “lion like”; who but for his rashness of temper would have “assumed leadership of the Transvaal Indian community”; had a flair for languages and cooking; passive resister and later chairman of the Tamil Benefit Society.
('8', 99, 9, 21, 239805) Vide also Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XX.
('8', 100, 0, 1, 239851) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 101
('8', 100, 1, 2, 239896) Anything more?
('8', 100, 2, 3, 239911) Mr. Gandhi drew the line here and intimated that the time was not opportune to say anything further regarding the negotiations.
('8', 100, 3, 4, 240039) Our representative then noticed that Mr. Gandhi’s head was closely cropped and that his moustache was cut.
('8', 100, 3, 5, 240146) He was asked whether he had been subjected to the regulations usually applied to criminals.
('8', 100, 3, 6, 240238) No, this is all my own doing.
('8', 100, 3, 7, 240268) As you know prisoners are not allowed the use of combs and brushes, so from hygienic motives I applied to the Governor of the Fort to be allowed to have myself cropped.
('8', 100, 3, 8, 240437) He demurred at first but finally consented and—now look at me
('8', 100, 4, 9, 240499) How were you treated while in the Fort?
('8', 100, 4, 10, 240539) With as much consideration as the Governor could possibly allow me under the regulations.
('8', 100, 4, 11, 240629) I must express my appreciation of the manner in which we were treated by the officials there, but their powers in this direction are limited.
('8', 100, 5, 12, 240771) And the food?
('8', 100, 5, 13, 240785) The usual diet.
('8', 100, 6, 14, 240801) In what part of the prison were you placed?
('8', 100, 6, 15, 240845) In the Native section.
('8', 100, 7, 16, 240868) This was all the conversation that could be had during the short journey to the Mosque at Fordsburg.
('8', 100, 7, 17, 240969) At the latter gathering place Mr. Gandhi met a number of his compatriots—although the hour was past midnight.
('8', 100, 7, 18, 241079) To these faithful henchmen he briefly explained what had led to his release.
('8', 100, 8, 19, 241156) The impression gained during the conversation given above was that Mr. Gandhi was in no way inclined to consider his release from gaol as a victory to the participants m the passive resistance movement.
('8', 100, 8, 20, 241359) On the other hand he seemed keenly pleased that a settlement had been come to by which neither side had suffered in honour, integrity or prestige
('8', 100, 9, 21, 241505) The remaining Asiatics will be liberated from the Fort this morning.
