('8', 100, 10, 23, 241601) 56. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER” 1
('8', 100, 11, 24, 241643) [JOHANNESBURG, January 30, 1908]
('8', 100, 12, 25, 241676) Yesterday morning some Indian hawkers saw, as they believed, Mr. Gandhi proceed to the Railway Station in company with another gentleman, who proved to be Superintendent Vernon, who is in charge of the Fordsburg Police Station.
('8', 100, 13, 26, 241904) 1 This was republished with minor variations in Indian Opinion, 8 2 1908.
('8', 101, 0, 1, 241978) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 101, 1, 2, 242020) was, however, no certainty that it was Mr. Gandhi, and the fact of his having been seen was the basis of an interesting rumour only.
('8', 101, 1, 3, 242153) As a fact, the Indians referred to were quite correct in their conjecture, for about a quarter past eleven Mr. Gandhi left the Port for Park Station, whither he proceeded with Superintendent Vernon to Pretoria.
('8', 101, 1, 4, 242364) But Mr. Gandhi’s release—it technically takes place only today—came as a great surprise to his compatriots last night.
('8', 101, 1, 5, 242483) Mr. Gandhi returned from Pretoria at 10 o’clock, and there was no one to meet him except the Chairman of the British Indian Association— Mr. Essop Mia—so well had the secret of the whole position been kept.
('8', 101, 1, 6, 242690) A Leader representative sought an interview with Mr. Gandhi after his arrival.
('8', 101, 1, 7, 242769) In general health he seemed none the worse for his recent experiences, and was quite cheerful.
('8', 101, 2, 8, 242864) PRISON TREATMENT
('8', 101, 3, 9, 242881) Asked as to the treatment meted out to him in prison, Mr. Gandhi replied that he and his fellow prisoners could not be sufficiently grateful to the Governor and all the other officials for the kindness and consideration shown to them within the four corners of the prison regulations.
('8', 101, 3, 10, 243166) But he added there was much to be said with respect to those regulations, and the accommodation and diet provided for Asiatics, who, to all intents and purposes, with one or two exceptions, were classed with Natives.
('8', 101, 3, 11, 243383) Mr. Gandhi, however, preferred to explain the position more fully at a later stage.
('8', 101, 4, 12, 243467) THE COMPROMISE
('8', 101, 5, 13, 243482) Replying to questions on the larger issue, Mr. Gandhi remarked: The compromise arrived at is largely the same that was offered by the Asiatic communities before proceedings under the Registration Act were commenced.
('8', 101, 5, 14, 243698) This compromise will give complete identification of every Asiatic over the age of 16 years in the Colony, and those who may be entitled to remain in or re enter it.
('8', 101, 5, 15, 243864) The main distinction between the Act and the identification under the offer will consist in the sting of compulsion being removed.
('8', 101, 5, 16, 243995) The compromise puts Asiatics on their honour and responsibility, and if it is not carried out faithfully by my countrymen I have no doubt that our position will deservedly be worse than it would have been under the Act.
('8', 101, 5, 17, 244215) But I do not anticipate any difficulty.
('8', 101, 5, 18, 244255) With reference to the wholesale arrests that have taken place during the last three weeks, I do not think that Asiatics can have any cause to grumble; that procedure was necessary in order to test the intensity—as also the reality—of our feeling about the Act.
('8', 101, 5, 19, 244516) I may state that we who were at the Fort were allowed to petition the Government offering once more voluntary registration, and the course adopted by the Government was in response to that petition 1. In my humble opinion the Government have shown real
('8', 101, 6, 20, 244769) 1Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 28 1 1908.
('8', 102, 0, 1, 244818) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 103
('8', 102, 1, 2, 244863) strength in acceding to the request.
('8', 102, 1, 3, 244900) I would further and at this stage say that the leaders of the Asiatic communities, so far as I am aware, will loyally abide by the decision of the Colonists to avoid further immigration of Asiatics not entitled to enter by reason of previous domicile.
('8', 102, 2, 4, 245152) PRISONS TO BE EMPTIED TODAY
('8', 102, 3, 5, 245180) Last night a representative of the Leader gathered that today the incarcerated Indians, numbering some 220, will be set at liberty.
('8', 102, 3, 6, 245312) As far as Johannesburg is concerned, there is no intention of holding anything in the nature of a demonstra tion, and the next few days will be devoted by the leaders of the Asiatics to the quiet instruction oftheir compatriots as to the new position of affairs.
('8', 102, 3, 7, 245575) The leaders have every confidence that the compromise will be faithfully carried out.
('8', 102, 3, 8, 245661) The Transvaal Leader, 31 1 1908
('8', 102, 4, 9, 245693) 57. LETTER TO “INDIAN OPINION” 1
('8', 102, 5, 10, 245726) [JOHANNESBURG, After January 30, 1908]
('8', 102, 6, 11, 245765) THE EDITOR, INDIAN OPINION
('8', 102, 7, 12, 245792) SIR, My fellow prisoners and I have been inundated with telegrams of congratulation on what the senders have considered a victory for the Indian cause.
('8', 102, 7, 13, 245944) We can only consider it a victory for Truth.
('8', 102, 7, 14, 245989) In any case may I on behalf of my associates and myself, through the columns of this journal, thank the numerous senders of wires and writers of letters for their kindly thought.
('8', 102, 7, 15, 246168) It has not been possible to write to individuals, for which omission, being unavoidable, I trust they will excuse us.
('8', 102, 7, 16, 246286) I hope and pray to the Almighty that, should the occasion arise again, we will all be prepared to undergo imprisonment or any other hardship —if such it may be called—for the sake of Truth, Honour and Self respect.
('8', 102, 8, 17, 246501) I am etc., M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 15 2 1908

('8', 103, 1, 2, 246749) 58. SPEECH AT MEETING OF BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION 1
('8', 103, 2, 3, 246803) [JOHANNESBURG, January 31, 1908] It is God in whom I placed my trust while launching on this struggle and advising the people to do likewise; it is He who has given us this unexpected victory, and it is to Him therefore that we must give our thanks.
('8', 103, 2, 4, 247053) It is because I have always believed that God helps the cause of truth that I started this movement in His name.
('8', 103, 2, 5, 247166) The success we have achieved is there for all of us to see.
('8', 103, 2, 6, 247226) What has made the Government remit the sentences and open the prison gates and let the people out?
('8', 103, 2, 7, 247325) Surely our truthfulness and strength.
('8', 103, 2, 8, 247363) I used to say that, if we scrupulously followed the path of truth, the white Colonists themselves would veer to our side, and that is exactly what has happened.
('8', 103, 2, 9, 247524) We are also thankful to the whites for the pains they took to further our just cause.
('8', 103, 2, 10, 247610) They did so because they were inspired by God within to have sympathy for His oppressed devotees, and to fight on their behalf.
('8', 103, 2, 11, 247738) I need not refer to the remark General Smuts made in the course of a speech 2 that it was impossible to send everyone to gaol.
('8', 103, 2, 12, 247865) All these things indicate that, if the [Indian] community remains united, it will always win through.
('8', 103, 2, 13, 247967) We will now register voluntarily for purposes of identification and the scrutiny [of our rights of domicile] and the Government has accepted this [offer].
('8', 103, 2, 14, 248122) That means that the obnoxious law will die altogether.
('8', 103, 2, 15, 248177) The stigma that attached to us under the law will now disappear.
('8', 103, 2, 16, 248242) Under the proposed arrangement, the Government will accept signatures by educated persons and by owners of property, but unlettered people have to give ten finger prints on the application forms.
('8', 103, 2, 17, 248438) Though I am against this myself and will strive with the Government to the best of my ability to have the requirement waived, I see nothing wrong in having to give finger impressions if the Government does not come round.
('8', 103, 2, 18, 248660) For after all we shall be giving them of our own free choice.
('8', 103, 2, 19, 248722) They must not be given if they are made compulsory.
('8', 103, 2, 20, 248774) And the Government has allowed us a period of three

('8', 104, 1, 7, 249751) It will be no use having anything in writing from the Government, since the final authority is that of Parliament.
('8', 104, 1, 8, 249866) We have thus to depend only on what Parliament does.

('8', 104, 1, 11, 250247) The object of the Government will thus be secured, and we shall get the freedom that we have been demanding.
('8', 104, 1, 12, 250356) The reason why we have won is that people went to gaol,—150 from Johannesburg, 25 from Pretoria and many persons from other towns as well.
('8', 104, 1, 13, 250495) Women did their true duty.
('8', 104, 1, 14, 250522) The pickets in particular displayed unsurpassed skill which even the Government could not help admiring; the selfsame Government [which had resisted our demands earlier] came round clearly because it perceived the strength of the community.
('8', 104, 1, 15, 250763) A campaign that is carried on in the name of God cannot but end in success.
('8', 104, 1, 16, 250839) I am hopeful that I shall succeed in the matter of fingerprints also.
('8', 104, 1, 17, 250909) We have, however, no reason to feel triumphant over the measure of success that we have achieved, neither have the whites any cause to complain against the Government.
('8', 104, 1, 18, 251077) Even God is won over by humility.
('8', 104, 1, 19, 251111) It is, therefore, humility which will ensure our success in a just struggle.
('8', 104, 1, 20, 251188) We must not play foul with the Government; rather, by adopting the highest standard of conduct for ourselves, we must convince the Government and the white Colonists that we do respect laws which uphold our dignity.
('8', 104, 1, 21, 251404) If, through an oversight on the part of the Government, the door is left open and there is scope for some kind of fraud, our duty will be to shut that door.
('8', 104, 1, 22, 251561) The Government will see for itself that we do not practise deception.
('8', 104, 1, 23, 251631) When we have thuscreated a [favourable] impression on the minds of the Colonists by acquitting ourselves as befits us, the redress of our grievances is

('8', 105, 1, 4, 251996) That was the weapon with which we brought the Government to its senses.

('8', 107, 6, 10, 256921) DEAR MR. SMUTS, After the conversation that Mr. Chamney had with me on Thursday, I sought an interview with you again, and Mr. Lane 3 told me thatI would be able to see you before I went.
('8', 107, 6, 11, 257109) I was not, however, fortunate enough to do so.
('8', 107, 6, 12, 257156) The conversation with Mr. Chamney made me a little uncom fortable, because he still harped away on the Asiatic Act.
('8', 107, 6, 13, 257272) Indeed, from him I gathered that the registration that will now proceed will be legalized under that Act.

('8', 107, 6, 15, 257530) I am most anxious to see this business finished without the slightest difficulty and with perfect satis faction to yourself.
('8', 107, 6, 16, 257655) I am, therefore, naturally most anxious to avoid any misunderstanding.
('8', 107, 6, 17, 257726) Pray believe me also when I say that I shall leave no stone unturned to remove the difficulties in your path owing to the clamour of anti Asiatic agitators.
('8', 107, 6, 18, 257883) May I, therefore, ask you to

('8', 108, 1, 2, 258458) be good enough to re assure me on the point?
('8', 108, 1, 3, 258503) To legalize voluntary registration under the Asiatic Act would be to re open the question at the sorest point.
('8', 108, 1, 4, 258614) You were good enough to tell me that the method of legalization 1 will be discussed later on as between us.
('8', 108, 1, 5, 258722) I have already suggested that the best way to do so would be under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act by amending it in so far as may be necessary.
('8', 108, 1, 6, 258867) I take it, too, that the form of application and registration will be settled in consultation with the leaders of the community, and that this will be done as quickly as possible, so that registration may proceed.
('8', 108, 1, 7, 259081) I left a message, too, with Mr. Lane with reference to the ten finger prints.
('8', 108, 1, 8, 259159) I discussed this with Mr. Chamney, and he could show absolutely no justification for the ten finger prints.
('8', 108, 1, 9, 259267) Indeed he admi tted that, for identification, one thumb impression was quite sufficient.
('8', 108, 1, 10, 259356) While to me, personally, it is immaterial whether thumb prints or digit impressions be given, there are many amongst the Asiatics to whom the latter present an impassable difficulty, and, as I know you want only effective identification, I do hope you will accept thumb impressions.
('8', 108, 1, 11, 259639) In answer to my inquiry, I have now received telegrams from the Protector of Indentured Immigrants and the Principal Immigration Restriction Officer in Natal.
('8', 108, 1, 12, 259798) The Protector says:
('8', 108, 2, 13, 259818) The system of taking ten finger impressions from indentured Indians on arrival commenced in April 1903, on being found desirable.
('8', 108, 2, 14, 259948) The Immigration Restriction Officer who controls the immigration of free Asiatics has replied as follows:
('8', 108, 3, 15, 260054) Referring yours of date both thumb impressions only required for certificates issued in this Department.
('8', 108, 3, 16, 260159) You will now see that the information given to you by Captain (?) Clarke is incorrect.
('8', 108, 3, 17, 260246) The distinction observed by the Immigration Department and the Protector’s Department, too, is most valuable testimony in favour of my contention.
('8', 108, 3, 18, 260393) The Protector has to deal with a class of Asiatics who have every temptation to hide their identity.
('8', 108, 3, 19, 260494) Classification in their case is, therefore, necessary.
('8', 108, 3, 20, 260549) The Immigration Department has to deal with a class of Asiatics and others who have always to prove their identity in order to make good their claim to enter or remain in Natal.
('8', 108, 3, 21, 260727) Hence that Department requires only thumb impressions.
('8', 108, 3, 22, 260782) Does not this show conclusively that you do not need digit impressions at all?
('8', 108, 3, 23, 260861) And, as my expert adviser tells me, the system

('8', 110, 7, 14, 263660) This campaign has undoubtedly shown one thing, if it has shown anything—that Indians in the Transvaal are deserving of self respect and of being classed as men.
('8', 110, 7, 15, 263821) The charge has often been brought against them that they are incapable of acting in concert for the com mon good.

('8', 111, 1, 5, 265298) It is not possible to give an adequate idea of the sacrifice made by hundreds of Indians, and in this category I includethose Indians who left the Colony because they did not consider themselves strong enough to brave the struggle.

('8', 111, 1, 11, 266027) We have to show to the Government and to the Colonists that Indians as a body have nothing to do with surreptitious entry—that although there is no legal obligation we recognize a moral obligation to give the Government complete identification of every Asiatic who is entitled to remain in the Colony or to re enter it, and if we succeed in doing that I think that the bitterest opponent of British Indians will have to admit that those who prove their right to domicile and give the Government full particulars as to identification should not only be left in the Colony unmolested, but that they should have every encourage ment, so that instead of remaining in the Colony as a festering sore they may so far as possible be assimilated and form part of the future South African nation.
('8', 111, 1, 12, 266814) I do think that the highest statesmanship in South Africa consists not in treating any class of its inhabitants as almost animals or pariahs, but it consists in treating them as men, and raising them to a higher level.
('8', 111, 1, 13, 267033) The question of unfair competition and such other questions crop up only because sometimes one notices cases of unfair competition, but all these matters can certainly be rem edied if the different races living in South Africa were to be educated up to a proper sense of citizenship.
('8', 111, 1, 14, 267317) By proper citizenship I don’t for one moment claim that all the races should be clothed with the franchise, but I do claim that the dominant race should look forward to a time when those lower races will be raised higher in the scale.

('8', 116, 4, 6, 277965) 68. HUMILITY There is an Indian proverb that “the more the mango tree flourishes, the more it droops”.
('8', 116, 4, 7, 278068) There can be no gainsaying the fact that Indians in the Transvaal have come out of their struggle with honour, and, what is more, without their sacred resolution having been broken.
('8', 116, 4, 8, 278250) The suffering that they have gone through must be taken as a necessary process of purification.
('8', 116, 4, 9, 278346) The compromise contemplates the ultimate repeal of the Act, which was the soul of the objection.
('8', 116, 4, 10, 278443) The voluntary registration which has been offered often has now been accepted, and the condition stated in the dignified, yet humble, letter written by Messrs Gandhi, Quinn and Naidoo is that the Act is not to apply to those who volun tarily register themselves.
('8', 116, 4, 11, 278706) The Government receive all they wanted in the way of identification, so that each party gets the substance it was striving for.
('8', 116, 4, 12, 278834) Looked at in that light, the compromise reflects credit alike on the Government and on the Indian community.
('8', 116, 4, 13, 278943) The Govern ment have shown their strength in having even at the eleventh hour recognized the necessity of consulting Indian sentiment.
('8', 116, 4, 14, 279078) The much discussed finger prints remain, though in an elastic manner, and their acceptance by the Indian community shows not only its prudence, but it shows that the Indian objection has never centred round finger prints.
('8', 116, 4, 15, 279300) We must decline to call this compromise a victory for Indians.
('8', 116, 4, 16, 279363) That were an abuse of terms, but, if it be at all applicable in this connection, the victory is for Truth.
('8', 116, 4, 17, 279470) Indians have always stated, and rightly so, that this was a religious fight.
('8', 116, 4, 18, 279547) People who only give a superficial meaning to the word religion, have failed to see any in the Indian struggle, but Indians themselves have thought otherwise.
('8', 116, 4, 19, 279706) They undertook it in the name of God, and they have to humble themselvesbefore Him for having received sufficient strength to come through the ordeal.
('8', 117, 0, 1, 279857) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 117, 1, 2, 279899) Moreover, Indians have little reason to glory over the com promise, but every incentive to walk humbly, because the work of a different and higher type has only just commenced.
('8', 117, 1, 3, 280076) The community has, of its own asking, been put upon its trial.
('8', 117, 1, 4, 280139) Instead of the law requi ring it on pain of suffering the penalties, they have incurred a moral and, therefore, a higher obligation by offering the Government every facility for identifying all Indians entitled to reside in the Transvaal.
('8', 117, 1, 5, 280378) It is, therefore, now constructive work, and, whilst the community has proved itself capable of carrying on in an orderly, peaceful and per fectly courteous manner, the necessary work of destruction, it has now to show that it is capable of solid and substantial constructive work.
('8', 117, 1, 6, 280660) When it has proved itself worthy of the confidence reposed in it, the Indian community may have reason to congratulate itself, and will certainly have risen very high indeed in the estimation of all thought ful men.
('8', 117, 1, 7, 280876) Indian Opinion, 8 2 1908
('8', 117, 2, 8, 280901) 69. VOLUNTARY REGISTRATION We have been informed that the work of voluntary registration for all the Indians in the Transvaal and which has been accepted by the Government commences in right earnest on Monday next, the 10th instants Johannesburg, in the Old Dutch Church, Von Brandis Square, from 9 o’clock in the morning, except on the first day, when it will be from 10 o’clock.
('8', 117, 2, 9, 281282) Due information will be given with reference to registration in other places, and it is stated that, except in Pretoria and Johannesburg, the receiving of applications will be left in the hands of the magistrates in the different parts.
('8', 117, 2, 10, 281519) The form of registration certificate and the form of application have been considerably changed, in order to suit the new situation.
('8', 117, 2, 11, 281652) Every adult male Indian should present himself for registration, and all those who are entitled to receive the certificate will be registered.
('8', 117, 2, 12, 281795) Roughly, those who are in possession of permits bona fide issued to them, and those who are in possession of old Dutch registration certificates, being their property, and all children who entered the country openly when they were under the age of 16 years will be registered.
('8', 117, 2, 13, 282072) The following may be, to all intents and purposes, laid down as the rule regarding the methods of identification: (a) At the discretion of the Registrar, signatures, that is to say signatures well formed, bearing the impress of the signatory and not a mere tracing of letters, will be accepted in place of finger prints from those who may possess property qualifications, or may be otherwise known as residents of the Transvaal.
('8', 118, 0, 1, 282501) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 119
('8', 118, 1, 2, 282546) (b) Signatures in place of finger prints will be accepted from those who possess educational qualification sufficient to satisfy the test under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('8', 118, 1, 3, 282723) (c) Those who have any real or conscientious objections to giving ten finger prints, and who do not fall under either of the above clauses, may be allowed to give thumb prints instead of digit imp ressions.
('8', 118, 1, 4, 282930) Whilst all these are very liberal concessions, in our opinion, it will be more becoming of the Indian community not to take advan tage of them.
('8', 118, 1, 5, 283074) The main point having been secured, we are of opinion that everyone should give digit impressions without the slightest hesitation.
('8', 118, 1, 6, 283206) In any case, the leaders who have a right not to give finger prints should be the first to waive it and offer to give those impres sions, so as to facilitate the workof identification, and make the pro cess easier for the Government.
('8', 118, 1, 7, 283440) We believe that the Indian commu nity will show its real dignity by making as limited a use of the con cession as possible.
('8', 118, 1, 8, 283564) We understand that Messrs Essop Mia, Gandhi, and others who have been closely identified with the struggle, have decided not to claim the concession.

('8', 124, 3, 5, 298199) WHAT LETTERS MEAN
('8', 124, 4, 6, 298217) Both of them are political documents.

('8', 124, 4, 10, 298528) He obtained special permission from the Governmentto meet Mr. Gandhi in gaol and visited him twice.
('8', 124, 4, 11, 298628) The first meeting took place on Tuesday, the 21st.

('8', 124, 4, 13, 298899) The agreement was also put down in writing.
('8', 124, 4, 14, 298943) Mr. Cart wright then met the leaders of the Progressive Party.

('8', 124, 4, 19, 299581) Mr. Gan dhi therefore proposed changes on both these points.

('8', 126, 1, 10, 303756) A meeting of the Cabinet was then called, and the draft reply reproduced above in translation was given to Mr. Gandhi after it had been approved by the Cabinet, and Mr. Gandhi was then set free.
('8', 126, 2, 11, 303951) IMPLICATION
('8', 126, 3, 12, 303963) This compromise implies that the offer of voluntary registration made by the Indian community has been accepted in full.
('8', 126, 3, 13, 304084) This registration will not be under the law; it will be outside that law, which will therefore not apply to such registration.
('8', 126, 3, 14, 304211) There is no need to withdraw the Gazette notice regarding the registration for, since the time limit is over, the notice is already invalid.
('8', 126, 4, 15, 304352) WHAT ABOUT LICENCES?
('8', 126, 5, 16, 304373) The notice about licences stands, and it has therefore been agreed that, except the blacklegs, all Indians may carry on trade without licences for the time being.
('8', 126, 5, 17, 304536) They will get licences after the new registration is legalized, and meanwhile no one will be prosecuted for trading without a licence.
('8', 126, 6, 18, 304671) WHAT ABOUT FINGER IMPRESSIONS?
('8', 126, 7, 19, 304702) “Ten impressions if you give, humbled will your manhood be.” Will Mr. Gandhi, forgetting the songs that were then sung, now advise the giving of finger impressions?
('8', 126, 7, 20, 304867) Mr. Gandhi has answered this, and repeats the reply, “Yes, I do give such advice.
('8', 126, 7, 21, 304949) Our campaign is not against finger prints but against the law.
('8', 126, 7, 22, 305012) It is enough that we will not have to submit to the law.
('8', 126, 7, 23, 305069) It will be disgraceful to give signatures under the law, but as long as we do not submit to it, we may give fingerprints, and more, without disgrace.
('8', 126, 7, 24, 305219) The song above was about the law.
('8', 126, 7, 25, 305253) Finger impressions and suchlike were only symbols of that
('8', 127, 0, 1, 305311) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 127, 1, 2, 305353) A prisoner is recognized by the dress he wears.
('8', 127, 1, 3, 305401) In a ditty about that prisoner we may describe his shirt; but the same dress, donned by a gentleman because he chooses to or by an Englishman at a fancy dress ball, does not make either of them a prisoner.” Mr. Gandhi and other Indians deserve credit for having given 18 digit impressions while in gaol.
('8', 127, 1, 4, 305705) They did no wrong in giving them.
('8', 127, 1, 5, 305739) In fact, it would have been wrong of them to have refused to give them.
('8', 127, 1, 6, 305811) The paper on which the impressions were given, if available, would be worth framing.
('8', 127, 1, 7, 305896) For going to gaol amounted to opening the door for the eventual freedom of Indians.
('8', 127, 1, 8, 305980) Whatever happened in gaol should therefore be welcomed, if it was otherwise reasonable.
('8', 127, 1, 9, 306068) A silken cord can be used to hang a man.
('8', 127, 1, 10, 306109) When it is so used it will become an object of fear.
('8', 127, 1, 11, 306162) But the same cord can be used for stringing a necklace, and then it becomes an ornament.
('8', 127, 1, 12, 306251) It is not yet finally settled that ten finger prints will have to be given.
('8', 127, 1, 13, 306327) The matter is still under discussion.
('8', 127, 1, 14, 306365) If, however, we are required to give them in return for the repeal of the law, it would be childish to fight against the provision.
('8', 127, 1, 15, 306497) It would be like running after a fire fly in preference to the sun.
('8', 127, 1, 16, 306565) Moreover, [the system of] ten finger prints has now been intro duced for the whites also under the immigration law, and one cannot stress the point.
('8', 127, 1, 17, 306714) It should normally have been needless to go into all this.
('8', 127, 1, 18, 306773) But then the matter is being discussed by several persons.
('8', 127, 1, 19, 306832) Hence these detailed explanations.
('8', 127, 2, 20, 306867) EDUCATED PERSONS AND PERSONS OF STANDING
('8', 127, 3, 21, 306908) The discretion vested in officials to accept signatures by educated persons and persons of standing, such as businessmen, is an additional point about [this system of] voluntary registration.
('8', 127, 3, 22, 307100) This was not added at Mr. Gandhi’s instance, but was included in the draft put before him.
('8', 127, 3, 23, 307191) As it was not considered desirable to forgo this [benefit], it was allowed to remain.
('8', 127, 3, 24, 307277) It appears reasonable that educated persons should be allowed to sign their names [for purposes of identification]; because the decision as to who is educated cannot be made at the discretion of the official.
('8', 127, 3, 25, 307486) But allowing a man of standing to sign, even if he is uneducated, is quite improper.
('8', 127, 3, 26, 307571) The fact that the decision as to who is a man.
('8', 127, 3, 27, 307618) of standing will be made by the official carries with it a suggestion of slavery.
('8', 127, 3, 28, 307700) I therefore advise people not to avail themselves of this concession.
('8', 127, 3, 29, 307770) Whatever we get as a matter of right is welcome, but it is wrong to accept anything as a favour.
('8', 127, 3, 30, 307867) I do not mean to say
('8', 128, 0, 1, 307888) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 129
('8', 128, 1, 2, 307933) that there should be no distinction between good and bad, between the poor and the rich, but such distinctions should not be left to the discretion of an official.
('8', 128, 2, 3, 308097) THE END
('8', 128, 3, 4, 308105) On leaving the Colonial Office, Mr. Gandhi was allowed to go to Johannesburg.
('8', 128, 3, 5, 308183) The watchful pickets, having come to know of this, had surrounded the Colonial Office.
('8', 128, 3, 6, 308270) They were told by Superintendent Bates that Mr. Gandhi had left.
('8', 128, 3, 7, 308335) But they refused to believe that Mr. Gandhi could have left without their knowledge, for they had been guarding all the exits.
('8', 128, 3, 8, 308462) And thus it happened that Mr. Gandhi met the pickets as soon as he came out.
('8', 128, 3, 9, 308539) He informed them that every Indian would be set free on Friday and asked them to convey the information to the others.
('8', 128, 4, 10, 308658) MIDNIGHT MEETING
('8', 128, 5, 11, 308675) Mr. Abdulla sent a telegram to Mr. Essop Mia asking him and Mr. Polak to receive Mr. Gandhi who was arriving at Park Station by the last train.
('8', 128, 5, 12, 308819) Only Mr. Essop Mia and Mr. Aswat were there to receive him, most of the other Indians having gone to the Indian mosque.
('8', 128, 5, 13, 308939) A meeting was held in the precincts at midnight attended by about a thousand people.
('8', 128, 5, 14, 309024) Mr. Gandhi told them to go about their work quietly without noisy demonstrations or processions.
('8', 128, 5, 15, 309121) The reporter of the Leader, who was present, promised not to publish a report of the meeting.
('8', 128, 5, 16, 309215) Everyone agreed that they were only concerned with the result, and that there was no need for any celebrations.
('8', 128, 5, 17, 309327) People felt extremely happy.
('8', 128, 6, 18, 309356) PRISON GATES OPEN
('8', 128, 7, 19, 309374) The prison gates opened at 12 noon on Friday.
('8', 128, 7, 20, 309420) All over the Transvaal, Indians who had been arrested in connection with the law or for carrying on trade without licences have been released.
('8', 128, 7, 21, 309563) Almost all that happened was reported in the newspapers.
('8', 128, 7, 22, 309620) Everyone was sur prised and the whites, too, were happy.
('8', 128, 7, 23, 309677) Telegrams were sent to the Association congratulating the [released] prisoners.

('8', 128, 7, 25, 309807) There is no need to reproduce their names here.
('8', 128, 7, 26, 309855) In any case, there is hardly any space for them.

('8', 129, 2, 3, 310178) CONSENT OF PROGRESSIVE PARTY
('8', 129, 3, 4, 310207) Before accepting this compromise, Mr. Smuts had obtained the consent of the Progressive Party.
('8', 129, 3, 5, 310302) He wrote the following letter 1 to Sir George Farrar 2 on the 27th:
('8', 129, 4, 6, 310370) DEAR SIR GEORGE FARRAR,
('8', 129, 5, 7, 310394) Will you kindly consult your friends to see whether there would be any objection to registration being re opened for Asiatics and the chance being given them to register voluntarily, as they desire to do, and to dispense with finger prints in the case of educated or well known Indians?
('8', 129, 5, 8, 310681) It is probable that Parliamentary ratification of such registration will have to take place, and in the meantime the penalties under the Act will not be enforced against those who register voluntarily.
('8', 129, 5, 9, 310883) I understand that Asiatics may be willing to make such an offer to Government, and before closing with it we should like to have your concurrence in so doing.
('8', 129, 6, 10, 311042) Yours sincerely, J. C. SMUTS In reply, Sir George Farrar wrote on the 30th as follows: 3
('8', 129, 7, 11, 311131) DEAR MR. SMUTS, I am in receipt of your letter of January 27, and have communicated its contents to my friends.
('8', 129, 7, 12, 311243) From it we extract certain questions or suggestions, which I append together with our replies.
('8', 129, 8, 13, 311338) QUESTION NO.
('8', 129, 8, 14, 311351) 1: Is there any objection to Registration being re opened for Asiatics and the chance being given them to register voluntarily as they desire to do?
('8', 129, 9, 15, 311500) ANSWER: No, provided time is limited.
('8', 129, 10, 16, 311538) QUESTION NO.
('8', 129, 10, 17, 311551) 2: Is there any objection to dispense with finger prints in the case of educated or well known Indians?
('8', 129, 11, 18, 311655) ANSWER: No, provided that other adequate evidence of identity be forth coming.
('8', 129, 12, 19, 311734) QUESTION NO.
('8', 129, 12, 20, 311747) 3: Is there any objection to the penalties not being enforced in the meantime against those who voluntarily register?

('8', 130, 2, 3, 312293) Am I to understand from the concluding sentence of your letter that the Government do not intend to make the above concessions unless they are satisfied that the Asiatic community is prepared to accept the new position?
('8', 130, 3, 4, 312513) I desire to make our position in this matter perfectly clear.

('8', 130, 6, 9, 313074) MEANING OF THESE LETTERS
('8', 130, 7, 10, 313099) These letters show that the Progressive Party is not opposed to us.
('8', 130, 7, 11, 313167) If one argues that some of these letters do not say categorically that the new law would be repealed or that it would not apply to those who volunteer to take out registers, one would not be wholly wrong.
('8', 130, 7, 12, 313372) But then the letters have been so drafted as not to shock the whites.
('8', 130, 7, 13, 313442) However, the question has been raised as to what would happen if the Government were to play foul and retain the law in its present form.
('8', 130, 7, 14, 313580) The question is easily answered.
('8', 130, 7, 15, 313613) It is obvious that we are not taking out new registers under the law.
('8', 130, 7, 16, 313683) We shall not therefore be bound by it in any way if the Government does not repeal it.
('8', 130, 7, 17, 313770) And if it is not repealed, we shall fight afresh, and the strength that we shall have gained over these three months will stand us in good stead.
('8', 130, 7, 18, 313916) Besides, the Government will be further disgraced, and in that measure ourcase will gain in strength.
('8', 130, 7, 19, 314018) This is the marvellous beauty of voluntary registration and satyagraha; the initiative rests with us instead of with the Government.
('8', 130, 8, 20, 314151) COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING
('8', 130, 9, 21, 314174) After the foregoing account of the compromise had been written, there took place another meeting with General Smuts at which all points were satisfactorily settled.
('8', 130, 9, 22, 314339) 1. If the Indian community takes out registers voluntarily, the new law will be repealed.
('8', 130, 9, 23, 314429) 2. Voluntary registration will be legalized by a new Bill.
('8', 130, 9, 24, 314488) 3. Voluntary registration will not apply to children under sixteen years of age.
('8', 131, 0, 1, 314569) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 131, 1, 2, 314611) 4. There will be new forms of application for voluntary regi stration and for registration certificates.
('8', 131, 1, 3, 314716) The register will mention the names of husband, wife and children and their respective ages.
('8', 131, 1, 4, 314809) In the application form for voluntary registration the name of the mother need not be mentioned but those of children and minors will be necessary.
('8', 131, 1, 5, 314957) Children under sixteen years of age will accompany their parents [to the Registration Office] if they can, so that their ages and facial marks of identification can be noted down.
('8', 131, 1, 6, 315137) Those whose children are outside the Transvaal need only furnish the name and age of each.
('8', 131, 1, 7, 315228) If parents ask for separate registers also for their children under sixteen years of age, these will be granted.
('8', 131, 1, 8, 315341) It should be remem bered therefore that children who are in the Transvaal must accom pany their parents, if they possibly can, when the latter go to apply for registers.
('8', 131, 2, 9, 315511) CONCERNING FINGER PRINTS
('8', 131, 3, 10, 315536) (i) Those who know English well will not be required to give either finger prints or thumb impressions.
('8', 131, 3, 11, 315640) (ii) Men of standing and those who own property can be exempted from the giving of finger prints or thumb impressions.
('8', 131, 3, 12, 315759) (iii) Those who strongly object [on grounds of conscience] to giving ten finger prints will be allowed to give thumb impressions.
('8', 131, 3, 13, 315889) (iv) The rest will have to give the ten finger impressions.
('8', 131, 3, 14, 315949) These concessions appear satisfactory.
('8', 131, 3, 15, 315988) To ask for more will seem unworthy of the Indian community.
('8', 131, 3, 16, 316048) Always the respect that a man enjoys depends on his self restraint.
('8', 131, 3, 17, 316116) Even if a thoughtless demand is conceded, it would be better not to accept the concession.
('8', 131, 3, 18, 316207) I therefore advise every Indian not to avail himself of the exemption allowed on grounds of education or ownership of property.
('8', 131, 3, 19, 316335) Within reasonable limits, whatever we do under [this scheme of] voluntary registration will be a sign of our goodness rather than of disgrace.
('8', 131, 3, 20, 316478) For instance, we will be helping the Government to ensure identification of Indians; we will be giving all the requisite information and more.
('8', 131, 3, 21, 316621) We can be sure that by doing so, we shall rise in the esteem of others.
('8', 131, 3, 22, 316693) That being so, Mr. Essop Mia, Mr. Gandhi and other satyagrahis have decided to give digit impressions.
('8', 131, 3, 23, 316796) By doing so they will not forfeit their rights; a right can be kept in reserve.
('8', 131, 3, 24, 316876) There are rights which, if not enjoyed, add grace like jewellery, but prove harmful when exer cised.
('8', 131, 3, 25, 316977) A perfect analogy occurs to me, which I mention here to explain the object of our struggle.
('8', 131, 3, 26, 317069) The secret of the law, that is, its ess ence, can be described as its soul.
('8', 131, 3, 27, 317145) The regulations prescribing finger prints, etc., can be compared to its body.
('8', 131, 3, 28, 317223) The soul of the law being
('8', 132, 0, 1, 317249) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 133
('8', 132, 1, 2, 317294) evil, we have been struggling for months to destroy it.
('8', 132, 1, 3, 317350) We have succe eded in achieving that result.
('8', 132, 1, 4, 317395) That the body survives does not concern us.
('8', 132, 1, 5, 317439) If the same body be dwelt in by a good soul instead of an evil one, we shall not oppose it.
('8', 132, 1, 6, 317531) Now that the body is to be inhabited by a good soul in the form of voluntary registration, we shall have no quarrel with the body.
('8', 132, 1, 7, 317662) More, we shall even honour that body.
('8', 132, 1, 8, 317700) The writer (of this article) means this comparison seriously.
('8', 132, 1, 9, 317762) This analogy leads to other thoughts besides.
('8', 132, 1, 10, 317808) By further elaborating it we can prove beyond doubt that ours was in fact a holy and religious movement, and a thoughtful person will easily see that we have achieved full success with unexpected speed.
('8', 132, 2, 11, 318011) WHO CAN BE REGISTERD?

('8', 135, 2, 12, 325214) 76. A DIALOGUE ON THE COMPROMISE
('8', 135, 3, 13, 325247) We find many questions being asked about the compromise that has been arrived at.
('8', 135, 3, 14, 325329) People are saying all kinds of things and some ignorant persons even refer to what is obviously a triumph as if it were a defeat.
('8', 135, 3, 15, 325459) It is our considered opinion that the Transvaal Indians’ victory goes so deep that every Indian should understand its real significance.

('8', 150, 5, 16, 364343) 81. SECRET OF SATYAGRAHA
('8', 150, 6, 17, 364368) There appears to have been a good deal of misunderstanding following the Transvaal Indians’ failure to comprehend the secret of satyagraha.
('8', 150, 6, 18, 364508) It is therefore necessary to give a little more thought to satyagraha in the context of our victory against the obnoxious law.
('8', 150, 6, 19, 364635) Those who know the real meaning of satyagraha should not have the slightest doubt as to what the victory means.
('8', 150, 6, 20, 364747) A satyagrahi enjoys a degree of freedom not possible for others, for he becomes a truly fearless person.
('8', 150, 6, 21, 364852) Once his mind is rid of fear, he will never agree to be another’s slave.
('8', 150, 6, 22, 364925) Having achieved this state of mind, he will never submit to any arbitrary action.
('8', 150, 6, 23, 365007) Such satyagraha can be, ought to be, practised not only against a Government but against society as well [if need be].
('8', 150, 6, 24, 365126) It can oftenhappen that a society is as wrong as a government.
('8', 150, 6, 25, 365189) It becomes one’s duty then to use satyagraha against society.
('8', 150, 6, 26, 365251) The late
('8', 150, 7, 27, 365260) 1 This is taken from a precise of events in the Transvaal sent by Ritch along with his letter of October 6, 1908 to the Colonial Office.
('8', 151, 0, 1, 365397) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 151, 1, 2, 365439) Mr. Thoreau, whose book 1 we have already summarized, thought that his country men did wrong in carrying on slave trade.
('8', 151, 1, 3, 365560) He therefore ranged him self against his people.
('8', 151, 1, 4, 365609) The great Luther defied his people single handed and it is thanks to him that Germany enjoys freedom today.
('8', 151, 1, 5, 365717) And there was Galileo who opposed society.
('8', 151, 1, 6, 365760) The people were resolved to kill him.
('8', 151, 1, 7, 365798) Undaunted, he told them that they could kill him if they wanted to, but that it was nevertheless true that the earth revolved [round the sun].
('8', 151, 1, 8, 365941) Today, we all know that the earth is round and that it rotates round its axis once every 24 hours.
('8', 151, 1, 9, 366040) Columbus acted like a true satyagrahi when facing his sailors.
('8', 151, 1, 10, 366103) Exhausted [by the long voyage], they declared, “We will never get to America.
('8', 151, 1, 11, 366181) Let us turn back, else we will kill you.” Unperturbed, Columbus answered, “I am not afraid of being killed, but I think we ought to go on for a few days more.” They did discover America, and Columbus won everlasting fame.
('8', 151, 1, 12, 366403) Such a wonderful remedy is this satyagraha.
('8', 151, 1, 13, 366447) When we ask in fear what will happen if the Government does not repeal the Act, we only betray the deficiency of our satyagraha or talk as if we had been unmanned, having lost the weapon of satyagraha.
('8', 151, 1, 14, 366649) But our satyagraha prompts us to become free and feel independent.
('8', 151, 1, 15, 366716) We have therefore nothing to fear.
('8', 151, 1, 16, 366751) ‘All this is idle talk.
('8', 151, 1, 17, 366775) Whatever you do, you cannot start the campaign again.
('8', 151, 1, 18, 366829) Once has been quite enough.’ There are persons who talk thus.
('8', 151, 1, 19, 366891) If it is true that we cannot resume the struggle, it will have been in vain that we started it at all.
('8', 151, 1, 20, 366994) Let us justify this view of ours.
('8', 151, 1, 21, 367028) It is a matter of common observation that what we have won can be retained only by the same means through which it was got.
('8', 151, 1, 22, 367152) What is won by force can be retained by force alone.

('8', 159, 1, 2, 384877) 84. A BRIEF EXPLANATION 1
('8', 159, 2, 3, 384903) Everyone knows that this paper contains a good deal of my writing though a reader will normally be unable to say which articles are mine and which are by others.
('8', 159, 2, 4, 385065) I print this one under my signature so that the views put forward here may be specifically known to be mine.
('8', 159, 2, 5, 385174) The controversy over the compromise with the Government has now largely subsided.
('8', 159, 2, 6, 385256) There is a better appreciation of it among the people and, to that extent, they appear to have been pacified.
('8', 159, 2, 7, 385366) However, controversies continue.
('8', 159, 2, 8, 385399) I have received some deprecatory letters from Natal.
('8', 159, 2, 9, 385452) Some of them pour abuse on me, and this only shows the piti able state we are in.
('8', 159, 2, 10, 385534) The abuse has not had the slightest effect on my mind, but it indicates the extent to which feelings have been roused.
('8', 159, 2, 11, 385653) I also see that the objections some persons have to the com promise are only a pretext, their real intention being to set the Hindus and the Muslims at variance with each other.
('8', 159, 2, 12, 385831) I believe I have equal regard for the two communities.
('8', 159, 2, 13, 385886) In public service, Hindus and Mus lims have stood together as a united people.
('8', 159, 2, 14, 385965) It is not, I have noticed, the Hindus who have blamed me; they are presumably satisfied that the compromise is a reasonable one.
('8', 159, 2, 15, 386094) The condemnatory letters that I have received are all from Muslims.
('8', 159, 2, 16, 386162) It is necessary to go into the rea son.
('8', 159, 2, 17, 386202) I am reluctant even to write of this matter, but it would not be proper to keep back [from the readers] what is on the lips of many and has become a subject of talk.
('8', 159, 2, 18, 386368) Not only that; it may prove positively harmful to suppress the incident.
('8', 159, 2, 19, 386441) When the passive resistance movement was at its height, Mr. Ally 2 could not continue to trust me fully because I was a Hindu.

XIV); came to South Africa in 1884 and devoted himself whole heartedly to the Indian cause; took notable part in the agitation against Cape Franchise Law Amendment Act; elected Chairman, Cape Coloured People’s Organization in 1892; founder President, Hamidia Islamic Society and member, along with Gandhiji, of the Transvaal Indian Deputation to England in 1906 (vide Vol. VI).
('8', 159, 3, 22, 387186) Unable to join satyagraha campaign and unwilling, at the same time, to submit to the Asiatic Registration Act, he left the Transvaal in 1907, leaving behind large interests; vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 31 8 1907

('8', 160, 1, 2, 387443) He therefore sent a telegram to Ameer Ali 1. On this occasion, a few Muslims thought of sending a telegram to Mr. Jinnah, and the Pathans eventually sent one.
('8', 160, 1, 3, 387602) I do not blame Mr. Ally for what he did.
('8', 160, 1, 4, 387643) Again, I do not blame the Pathans for what they have done now.
('8', 160, 1, 5, 387706) I have known Mr. Ameer Ali.
('8', 160, 1, 6, 387734) I asked for his help on behalf of the community and it was given.
('8', 160, 1, 7, 387800) I have also known Mr. Jinnah.
('8', 160, 1, 8, 387830) I regard them both with respect.

('8', 160, 1, 10, 387967) The symptom is this: I occasionally observe some lack of trust [in me] though I have worked hard to bring the two communities together.
('8', 160, 1, 11, 388103) This is a sign of our weakness.
('8', 160, 1, 12, 388135) It makes me unhappy.
('8', 160, 1, 13, 388156) I have heard some Muslim brethren say in arguments about the compromise, “Gandhi has totally ruined the Muslims and has been doing so for the last fifteen years.” It is most regrettable that any Indian should utter these words.
('8', 160, 1, 14, 388384) I am sure those who say this themselves know that I have never even dreamt of harming anyone.
('8', 160, 1, 15, 388478) The entire campaign was intended to preserve the status of the well to do Indians.
('8', 160, 1, 16, 388561) Muslims are better placed in South Africa and it was chiefly a businessmen’s campaign.
('8', 160, 1, 17, 388648) Had it not been for the massive effort of the Hamidia Islamic Society, we would never have won.
('8', 160, 1, 18, 388744) Also, had not a large number of Muslims worked hard for it, there would have been no victory.
('8', 160, 1, 19, 388838) How can it be said then that I have brought utter ruin on the Muslims?
('8', 160, 1, 20, 388909) I know that there are only a few persons who say these things.
('8', 160, 1, 21, 388972) Most of the Muslims realize that in South Africa Hindus and Muslims make up a single [community] and ought to live together as one.
('8', 160, 1, 22, 389104) If I have done anyone harm, it must be to the community as a whole and not to the Muslims alone.
('8', 160, 1, 23, 389201) And I do not see that any harm has been done.
('8', 160, 1, 24, 389247) Yet people go on arguing.
('8', 160, 1, 25, 389273) I therefore wish to warn my Muslim brethren against those who are out to set people at variance with each other by saying these things; they ought to be treated as enemies of the community, and no one should take any notice of what they say.

('8', 162, 1, 2, 391217) 85. LETTER TO GENERAL SMUTS 1
('8', 162, 2, 3, 391247) JOHANNESBURG, February 22, 1908
('8', 162, 3, 4, 391279) DEAR MR. SMUTS, In accordance with the permission given by you, I now take the opportunity of sending you a draft Bill 2 to amend Immigration Restriction Act No.
('8', 162, 3, 5, 391441) 15 of 1907. The draft, in my opinion, meets the situation entirely.
('8', 162, 3, 6, 391509) The time is ripe for me to submit it, inasmuch as there is every evidence now of the Asiatics loyally accepting the compromise.
('8', 162, 3, 7, 391637) You will see that some of the rights given by the Asiatic Act have not been availed of by the draft; for instance, Asiatics who were in the Transvaal on the 31st day of May, 1902 are, under the Act to be repealed, entitled to registration, whereas, under the draft now sub mitted, they are not.
('8', 162, 3, 8, 391932) I have omitted them advisedly, because it exposes Asiatics to temptation.
('8', 162, 3, 9, 392006) I have assumed that those who were in the Colony on the 31st day of May, 1902 must have by the time volun tary registration is completed availed themselves of it.
('8', 162, 3, 10, 392169) There could not be many outside the Colony who were in it on that day and have not yet returned.
('8', 162, 3, 11, 392266) If, however, there are any exceptional cases, they can bedealt with under the last clause of the amendment of Paragraph g.
('8', 162, 3, 12, 392389) On the other hand, I have ventured to specifically protect Asiatics who paid £3 to the old Government before the war, because, although they are not mentioned in Act 2 of 1907, it always was the intention to protect them, and holders of such certificates who are without the Colony cannot now number more than one hundred.
('8', 162, 3, 13, 392712) The clause about temporary permits has been taken over from Act 2 of 1907. I have ventured to import into the draft Bill a section dealing with the Church Street property 3 held by the late Aboobaker Amod.
('8', 162, 3, 14, 392918) As you are aware, the section in Act 2 of 1907 proved abor tive.
('8', 162, 3, 15, 392983) A section of that description may not appear in its place in an Immigration Bill but, as the law repeals the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, the relief sought to be granted under that Act might well be

In my opinion, no further amendments would be necessary in order to carry out the main purpose of the Asiatic Act in the way of inspection and in the way of restriction of licences only to those who are not prohibited immigrants, because both these are already more than provided for under the Immigration Restriction Act.
('8', 163, 2, 14, 395514) Every per son applying for a licence will have to prove that he is not a prohi bited immigrant and the officers appointed under the Immigration Restriction Act will have the power to put to proof any person sus pected of being a prohibited immigrant.
('8', 163, 2, 15, 395765) If there are any Asiatics who do not avail themselves of the voluntary offer, I do not think, in view of the amendment suggested by me, that you require the use of the Asiatic Act to deal with them, because they will ipso facto become prohibited immigrants and would, therefore, be liable to an expulsion order.

('8', 165, 3, 5, 398875) 86. BLUE BOOK
('8', 165, 4, 6, 398889) The Blue book published by Lord Elgin 1 in January is now available in South Africa.
('8', 165, 4, 7, 398974) It is called a Blue book, though it should really be called a black book.
('8', 165, 4, 8, 399048) Anyone who reads this Blue book and follows it will soon realize that the Indians’ success was in spite of the Imperial Government, which had ranged itself on the other side; it was won entirely on the strength of truth.
('8', 165, 4, 9, 399269) It appears that, until January 10, the attitude of the Imperial Government was a feeble one.
('8', 165, 4, 10, 399362) We have seen how it changed after that date.
('8', 165, 4, 11, 399407) But we do not have to be grateful to the Imperial Government for that.
('8', 165, 4, 12, 399478) For them it was a good deed done under the stress [of circumstances].
('8', 165, 4, 13, 399548) We see from the Blue book that, if the Immigrants’[Restriction] Act remains in its present form, sub section 4 of section 2 of the Act 2, as interpreted by the Government, will preclude the entry of any Indian residing outside the Transvaal.
('8', 165, 4, 14, 399790) If this interpretation of the Act is correct, it is all the more clear how valuable has been our success.
('8', 165, 4, 15, 399896) At the same time we must realize that, if the Government’s interpretation of the immigration Act is correct, even Indians who pass the education test cannot enter.
('8', 165, 4, 16, 400060) If the Indian community acquits itself well during the [next] three months, this fear will very likely prove to have been without basis.
('8', 165, 4, 17, 400197) For the present, however, the first comment we have to make on the Blue book is this: though the immigration Act admitted of this insidious interpretation, Lord Elgin acquiesced in it.
('8', 165, 4, 18, 400382) Likewise, he also acquiesced in section 6, which provides for the deportation of Indians on the plea of the Asiatic [Registration] Act having received Royal
('8', 165, 5, 19, 400539) 1 Lord Elgin (1849 1917); Viceroy of India, 1894 99; nominated, on his return, chairman of a Royal Commission to investigate the conduct of the South African War; became in 1905 Secretary of State for the Colonies in Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman's Cabinet.
('8', 165, 5, 20, 400796) For report of his interview to Transvaal Indian Deputation, vide “Deputation to Lord Elgin”, 8 11 1906 2 Vide Appendices III
('8', 166, 0, 1, 400921) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 167
('8', 166, 1, 2, 400966) assent.
('8', 166, 1, 3, 400974) The Colonial Government should, therefore, be granted the powers required to enforce that Act and to deport the satyagrahis.
('8', 166, 1, 4, 401099) Mr. Morley 1, too, acquiesced in this after some hesitation, being satisfied with Mr. Smuts’ assurance given him and Lord Elgin that [Indian] Princes and other [dignitaries] would be given the necessary permits for visits.
('8', 166, 1, 5, 401322) The whole affair is as much a disgrace to the Indian community as it is to the British Empire.
('8', 166, 1, 6, 401417) The British rulers take us to be so lowly and ignorant that they assume that, like the Kaffirs 2 who can be pleased with toys and pins, we can also be fobbed off with trinkets.
('8', 166, 1, 7, 401594) It is a tribute to the marvellous power of truth—be it noted by the Indians—that our rulers who thought us despicable were forced to change their opinion when they saw 200 Indians in gaol.
('8', 166, 1, 8, 401783) We also learn from the same Blue book that the Chinese Consul, having raised the question of finger impressions, found it necessary to withdraw it in view of the petition by the Chinese Association, and to tell Sir Edward Grey later that the [Chinese] objection was really to the Act itself [and not just to the finger impressions].
('8', 166, 1, 9, 402116) We earnestly hope that the Indian community will not throw away, through a mistaken step or sheer thoughtlessness, the success that has been gained after such strenuouseffort.
('8', 166, 1, 10, 402292) When we have more time, we shall place before our readers the translations of relevant portions of this Blue book so that they may have the same picture of it as we have in our mind.
('8', 166, 1, 11, 402475) Meanwhile, the only request we make is that they should remember that the movement has a long way to go yet and that these three months have been granted to us for finalizing our preparations and sharpening our weapons.
('8', 166, 1, 12, 402695) If we make the mistake of supposing that we cannot again put up the same kind of fight, we shall to our regret lose even that which we have gained.
('8', 166, 1, 13, 402843) Those who wish India well must ponder over this.
('8', 166, 1, 14, 402892) They ought not toallow their character patience, endurance, generosity, industrious ness, etc.—to desert them.

('8', 167, 3, 16, 404646) 88. BAD HABIT
('8', 167, 4, 17, 404660) A reader from Durban writes to say that many of us are in the habit of referring to Indians from Calcutta or Madras, in public as well as in private, as “coolya” or “coolie”.
('8', 167, 4, 18, 404835) The complaint appears to be justified.
('8', 167, 4, 19, 404874) We have often heard well bred Indians use such terms.
('8', 167, 4, 20, 404928) We are annoyed when Mr. Smuts or other whites use the word “coolie”, but ourselves frequently use the same word deliberately or unwit tingly, referring to persons from Calcutta or Madras who may not be labourers.
('8', 167, 4, 21, 405141) The correspondent informs us that he once heard an Indian businessman refer to a person from Calcutta as a “coolie” in the presence of a lawyer.
('8', 167, 4, 22, 405286) We hope that every Indian who has this habit will give it up, if only because such behaviour stands in the way of bringing all the Indians together.

('8', 168, 1, 2, 405596) 89. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('8', 168, 2, 3, 405620) REGISTRATION
('8', 168, 3, 4, 405633) Registration is going on apace.
('8', 168, 3, 5, 405665) The officials are not able to attend to all the Indians who turn up.
('8', 168, 3, 6, 405734) They cannot manage more than 200 applications a day.
('8', 168, 3, 7, 405787) Since all the officials are fully occupied in Johannesburg, it has not been possible to move the office to other towns.
('8', 168, 3, 8, 405907) But it is likely that by the middle of March the office will have visited all the other towns.
('8', 168, 4, 9, 406002) THE CHINESE
('8', 168, 5, 10, 406014) There arose a further misunderstanding about registration certi ficates for the Chinese.
('8', 168, 5, 11, 406103) Mr. Chamney told Mr. Quinn that it was not right that all the Chinese should give their thumb impressions only.
('8', 168, 5, 12, 406215) Mr. Gandhi then found it necessary to intervene, and it was eventually agreed that the Chinese who reported might give their thumb impres sions only.
('8', 168, 5, 13, 406365) The more the Chinese persist in such childish obstinacy, the more they lose their good name.
('8', 168, 5, 14, 406458) The Indians readily go to the Office and furnish their finger impressions, and this wins for them an increasing appreciation of their nobility and gentleness.
('8', 168, 5, 15, 406617) About 95 per cent.
('8', 168, 5, 16, 406636) of the Indians have already given their finger impressions.
('8', 168, 5, 17, 406696) About five per cent.
('8', 168, 5, 18, 406717) probably gave only their thumb impressions.
('8', 168, 5, 19, 406761) True bravery implies humility and gentleness.
('8', 168, 5, 20, 406807) We find the most fear less per sons appear calm and gentle.
('8', 168, 5, 21, 406867) The famous General Gordon 1 was ordinarily mild as a lamb, kind hearted and gentle in his dealings,and alto gether without a trace of rudeness about him.
('8', 168, 5, 22, 407021) Even children could talk to him freely.
('8', 168, 5, 23, 407061) The same person roared like a lion when his honour was at stake.
('8', 168, 6, 24, 407126) STORY OF FINGER IMPRESSIONS
('8', 168, 7, 25, 407154) I feel ashamed for the community that I should still have to write about finger impressions.
('8', 168, 7, 26, 407247) The point is so simple that it is difficult to understand why it is still being argued.
('8', 168, 7, 27, 407335) But the late Profe ssor Max Muller said that as long as truth is not effectively impressed on the mind of the other, there is nothing wrong in repeating the same thing over and over again in different words.
('8', 168, 7, 28, 407543) It is indeed necessary to do so.
('8', 168, 7, 29, 407576) Besides, there are some mischief mongers among us who want

('8', 169, 1, 2, 407932) to see troublein the community.
('8', 169, 1, 3, 407964) In order to counter the arguments of such persons from time to time and thus prevent sincere but simp leminded Indians from wavering, it is necessary to put down every idea that occurs to one.
('8', 169, 1, 4, 408157) I can see indications that in the end digit impressions will be introduced all over South Africa—maybe ten, maybe eighteen of them—although, of course, I do not see why that should frighten us.
('8', 169, 1, 5, 408351) The immigration Act has been in force in the Transvaal since January 1. It has not yet been possible to enforce it against Indians, for their campaign has been directed against regis tration itself.
('8', 169, 1, 6, 408550) Under that law, there are four different kinds of passes to be taken out.
('8', 169, 1, 7, 408624) In the first place, under the law, even a person who, by virtue of being an old resident, is entitled to return to the Colony [after temporary absence] is required to have a pass; he may, however, find it difficult to return for want of proficiency in a European language.
('8', 169, 1, 8, 408897) Such passes will rarely be necessary for Indians as they will have their registration certificates with them.
('8', 169, 1, 9, 409007) But they will be required of whites —Jews and others—belonging to the working class, for it may happen that they do not know English and that some of them do not have £20 in cash.
('8', 169, 1, 10, 409187) On one side this pass will carry particulars about the holder, such as his name, address, and on the other his ten finger impressions.
('8', 169, 1, 11, 409322) That is, the position is for them the same as that obtaining for Indians today.
('8', 169, 1, 12, 409402) The only difference is that the Indians have to affix their finger impressions on the application only, not on their passes.
('8', 169, 1, 13, 409527) But the [other kind of] passes referred to earlier will bear the ten finger impressions [of the holder] and will have to be produced often.
('8', 169, 1, 14, 409667) The second kind of pass is meant for new immigrants under the same law.
('8', 169, 1, 15, 409739) It is intended mostly for Jews, for they will not be able to take the test at Volksrust easily.
('8', 169, 1, 16, 409835) Moreover, there are no Yiddish kno wing officials at the border.
('8', 169, 1, 17, 409900) Arrangements have been made for issuingpasses to such persons at the port or in England itself.
('8', 169, 1, 18, 409996) This pass, like the first, will bear impressions of all the ten fingers.
('8', 169, 1, 19, 410069) The third kind of pass is in the nature of a permit which may be issued to anyone for a limited period.
('8', 169, 1, 20, 410173) It will also bear ten finger imp ressions.
('8', 169, 1, 21, 410216) The fourth is meant for witnesses who may be allowed into the Transvaal but who cannot take the test.
('8', 169, 1, 22, 410318) This will also bear ten finger impressions.
('8', 169, 1, 23, 410362) There are thus four kinds of passes [to be had against] varying fees, of which two categories are such as will most likely apply only to the whites.
('8', 169, 1, 24, 410511) [The system of] finger impressions has been introduced for these passes.
('8', 169, 1, 25, 410584) How can the Indian community then protest against
('8', 170, 0, 1, 410634) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 171
('8', 170, 1, 2, 410679) finger impressions?
('8', 170, 1, 3, 410699) It is to be observed moreover that the whites do not oppose these regulations at all.
('8', 170, 1, 4, 410785) The reason is worth noting.
('8', 170, 1, 5, 410813) The whites are free and independent.
('8', 170, 1, 6, 410850) They do not get scared unneces sarily, neither do they see humiliation where in fact there is none.
('8', 170, 1, 7, 410950) And for the same reason they do not feel that finger impressions by themselves imply criminality.
('8', 170, 1, 8, 411048) The fact is that for the identification [of pass holders] and for the prevention of fraud, digit impressions offer a simple, effective and scientific means.
('8', 170, 1, 9, 411205) It is true that this method was at first applied only to criminals.
('8', 170, 1, 10, 411273) That is the reason why, when the method was sought to be applied particularly to Indians under compulsion, we opposed it and were justified in doing so.
('8', 170, 1, 11, 411426) But there is no reason to oppose it now.
('8', 170, 1, 12, 411467) Many reforms have been adopted after they were first tried out on criminals; for instance, vaccination with cow pox serum.
('8', 170, 1, 13, 411590) When Mr. Jenner discovered this method of vaccination, he first tried it on prisoners.
('8', 170, 1, 14, 411677) It was introduced among the rest of the population after the experiment had proved successful.
('8', 170, 1, 15, 411772) No one could argue that the free population was thereby humiliated.
('8', 170, 1, 16, 411840) If anyone wants to know why all these arguments were not adva nced earlier, it is easy to answer the question.
('8', 170, 1, 17, 411951) Formerly, finger prints were a part of an enslaving law and therefore a symbol of our slavery.
('8', 170, 1, 18, 412046) It was thus our duty to draw attention to the humiliating aspect of [giving] finger impressions.
('8', 170, 1, 19, 412143) It was then no part of this journal’s intention to help [the Government] to dress the Indian community in a cloak of slavery by arguing that finger impressions were bound to be introduced in the end, or that the method had advantages from a scientific point of view.
('8', 170, 1, 20, 412410) There was no need, therefore, at that time to argue that in a certain context it would become necessary to give finger impressions, or that there should be no objection to [giving] them.
('8', 170, 1, 21, 412597) That was at a time when it was necessary to present a strong case against the law.
('8', 170, 1, 22, 412680) All the arguments advanced at that time either in my news letters or elsewhere in this paper were valid.
('8', 170, 1, 23, 412785) Even today, given an identical situation, they would be absolutely valid.
('8', 170, 1, 24, 412859) If anywhere in the world they should introduce the [system of] compulsory finger imp ressions, or even a thumb impression for the Indian community alone, with the object of stigmatizing it for the colour of its skin, this journal will again take up the banner and repeat the arguments used in the past.
('8', 170, 1, 25, 413162) Besides, everyone must know that we have always said that our campaign was not directed against finger impressions as such but against the law.
('8', 170, 1, 26, 413306) The repeal of the law being assured, the Indian sword returned, on its own as it were, to the scabbard.

('8', 175, 0, 1, 423125) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 175, 1, 2, 423167) Indians at midnight.
('8', 175, 1, 3, 423188) I put the question of finger prints before the meeting, and all the Indian leaders who were present authorized me to agree to the proposal.
('8', 175, 1, 4, 423328) Shahji was the only one who opposed it.

('8', 175, 1, 7, 423542) I had kept myself fully informed of the real difficulties of the people and the state of their mind.
('8', 175, 2, 8, 423643) I DID NOT SHOW PATIENCE
('8', 175, 3, 9, 423667) Some persons believe that since I was in gaol I was not posted with the developments in England.
('8', 175, 3, 10, 423764) It would have been, they argue, a very good thing if I had waited a little longer.
('8', 175, 3, 11, 423847) This again is not true.
('8', 175, 3, 12, 423871) While in gaol I was kept posted with all the information.
('8', 175, 3, 13, 423929) Even if I had notbeen, I had already predicted what would happen in England.
('8', 175, 3, 14, 424006) I have not therefore acted in ignorance.
('8', 175, 3, 15, 424047) We stood to gain nothing by waiting longer than we did, for it is not as if we had agreed to finger impressions under pressure.
('8', 175, 3, 16, 424175) It was because of our offer of voluntary registration that we received support in England.
('8', 175, 3, 17, 424266) If I had lost any time when the offer came from the Government, it would have cost us the sympathy we got in England.
('8', 175, 3, 18, 424384) Let us remember that there were elderlyand respectable businessmen who were to go to gaol the day following that of the compromise.
('8', 175, 3, 19, 424516) The thought was gnawing at my heart.
('8', 175, 3, 20, 424553) I saw that it was my duty to prevent this from happening if I could.
('8', 175, 3, 21, 424622) It is therefore wrong to speak of undue haste on my part.
('8', 175, 3, 22, 424680) Moreover, those who followed me to gaol had rather discoura ging reports to give.
('8', 175, 3, 23, 424762) They told me that people were losing courage.
('8', 175, 3, 24, 424808) The hawkers, they told me, had stopped going their rounds.
('8', 175, 3, 25, 424867) They wanted me to bring about a compromise as early as possible.
('8', 175, 3, 26, 424932) Those who went to gaol lost their nerve in a few days, and some of them hinted that they would not go to gaol again.
('8', 175, 3, 27, 425049) General Smuts told me much the same thing when I met him: that I did not have the slightest idea of the number of people who had wanted to submit to the law.
('8', 175, 3, 28, 425207) A few people had already sent applications to him in secret.
('8', 175, 3, 29, 425268) I even know the names of some of them.
('8', 175, 3, 30, 425307) All these things could not just be ignored by a person who had been deeply involved in the struggle for 16 months.
('8', 175, 3, 31, 425422) However, if I had seen any objection to finger impressions, or if I had even known that Indians in the Transvaal would be extremely unhappy about having to give their finger impressions, there would perhaps have been some reason for further deliberation.
('8', 175, 3, 32, 425677) But, as far as I could judge, there was no objection to the voluntary provision of finger impressions just as there was none to voluntary registration;

('8', 176, 1, 2, 425874) and I knew that sensible persons in the Transvaal were not opposed to the idea, for they had no objection to finger impressions as such, but only to the manner in which they were [required] to give them under the law.
('8', 176, 1, 3, 426092) Since that situation no longer obtained, finger impressions in themselves had become innocuous.
('8', 176, 2, 4, 426188) DID I LOSE COURAGE IN GAOL?

('8', 176, 4, 8, 426471) POINT IN GIVING FINGER IMPRESSIONS

('8', 179, 3, 9, 433644) JOHANNESBURG, March 3, 1908 THE EDITOR, INDIAN OPINION
('8', 179, 4, 10, 433699) SIR, The honour of the Indian community has been vindicated and a great victory won.
('8', 179, 4, 11, 433784) It has earned the admiration of the world and gai ned more prestige.
('8', 179, 4, 12, 433853) During the early stages of the struggle the whitepopulation of the Transvaal and South Africa laughed at the commu nity, and it was only after the movement had gathered momentum that thoseamong the whites who valued truth and were men of conscience came forward to help us.
('8', 179, 4, 13, 434127) In England, the brave Ritch, neglecting his dear, bed ridden wife and his children, rushed about working like a convict under a sentence of hard labour.
('8', 179, 4, 14, 434280) He roused public opinion throughout England.
('8', 179, 4, 15, 434325) His impassioned eloquence touched every heart [and evoked] the sympathy of the nobility, the rich and the poor alike.
('8', 179, 4, 16, 434443) The spark [that he struck] broke forth into a warm burning flame in the hearts of the Transvaal Ministers.
('8', 179, 4, 17, 434550) Indian prisoners were set free as a result and their offer of [voluntary registration] was acce pted.
('8', 179, 4, 18, 434652) Indeed, God has saved the community’s honour.
('8', 179, 4, 19, 434698) The Indians’ success is the first example of its kind.
('8', 179, 4, 20, 434753) Its value cannot be exaggerated.
('8', 179, 4, 21, 434786) Every Indian ought to be proud of it.
('8', 179, 4, 22, 434824) If one adheres to truth, succour from God or His servants will follow inevitably.
('8', 179, 4, 23, 434906) If we are to keep alive the memory of that divine succour in the minds of our descendants, every Indian will agree that the Federation Hall is a necessity.
('8', 179, 4, 24, 435062) All those who have Indian blood in their veins will work sincerely to promote the cause in every possible manner.
