('8', 180, 2, 18, 437099) 92. MY GAOL EXPERIENCES[ I] 2
('8', 180, 3, 19, 437129) Many friends have asked me to reduce to writing my expe riences of the gaol life, all too brief though it was.
('8', 180, 3, 20, 437240) There were certain things that came under my observation which might be of advantage if they were put in a more or less permanent form.
('8', 180, 3, 21, 437376) Believing as I do
('8', 180, 4, 22, 437394) 1Vide also “To Those Who Submitted to the Obnoxious Law”,8 2 1908 2 This appeared in two instalments in the English section under Gandhiji's name as “Special to Indian Opinion”.
('8', 181, 0, 1, 437572) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 181, 1, 2, 437614) firmly that incarceration may often be the means of opening the gateway to freedom, liberty, and reform, the experiences I am about to relate may not be profitless to those who do not mind, for the sake of a principle, suffering some inconvenience, or, at any rate, restraint on their personal liberty.
('8', 181, 1, 3, 437917) It was on the 10th of January, 1908, in the afternoon of a Friday, that Messrs P. K. Naidoo, C. M. Pillay, Karwa, Easton and Fortoen (the latter two Chinese) and I were sentenced to be imprisoned for two months, without hard labour, for the crime of not having taken out our registration certificates under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act 1. I was the first to be tried at Johannesburg, and, after receiving my sen tence, and after having been detained for a few minutes at the pris oners’ yard attached to the Magistrate’s Court, I was asked to get into a cab, to which I was stealthily taken in order to evade the enormous crowd that was waiting outside the Court House, and was quickly driven to the Fort.
('8', 181, 1, 4, 438624) Many were the thoughts that came surging through my mind as I was being driven.
('8', 181, 1, 5, 438704) Was I to be specially treated as a purely political prisoner?
('8', 181, 1, 6, 438766) Was I to be separated from my fellow pris oners?
('8', 181, 1, 7, 438815) Was I to be taken to the Johannesburg gaol at all?
('8', 181, 1, 8, 438866) To my very great relief I was soon disillusioned.
('8', 181, 1, 9, 438916) I was not to be separated from Mr. Naidoo and others who were tried with me, nor were we to receive any special treatment.
('8', 181, 1, 10, 439039) At the same time I was a little unprepared for what followed.
('8', 181, 1, 11, 439101) We were all first taken to the reception room, as the room which is used for measuring and dressing prisoners is called.
('8', 181, 1, 12, 439222) There we were weighed and totally undressed.
('8', 181, 1, 13, 439267) We were given non labour clothes to wear, consisting of trousers, shirt, jumper, cap, socks, and a pair of closed sandals.
('8', 181, 1, 14, 439390) We were all required to give our digit impressions, and at about four o’clock marched to our cell with eight ounces of bread for our evening meal.
('8', 181, 2, 15, 439537) CLASSIFICATION OF ASIATICS WITH NATIVES
('8', 181, 3, 16, 439577) The cell was situated in the Native quarters and we were housed in one that was labelled “For Coloured Debtors”.
('8', 181, 3, 17, 439690) It was this exper ience for which we were perhaps all unprepared.
('8', 181, 3, 18, 439756) We had fondly imagined that we would have suitable quarters apart from the Natives.
('8', 181, 3, 19, 439840) As it was, perhaps, it was well that we were classed with the Natives.
('8', 181, 3, 20, 439911) We would now be able to study the life of Native prisoners, their customs and manners.
('8', 181, 3, 21, 439998) I felt, too, that passive resistance had not been under taken too soon by the Indian community.
('8', 181, 3, 22, 440094) Degradation underlay the classing of Indians with Natives.
('8', 181, 3, 23, 440153) The Asiatic Act seemed to me to be the summit of our degradation.
('8', 181, 3, 24, 440219) It did appear to me, as I think it would
('8', 181, 4, 25, 440260) 1 Asiatic Registration Act
('8', 182, 0, 1, 440287) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 183
('8', 182, 1, 2, 440332) appear to any unprejudiced reader, that it would have been simple humanity if we were given special quarters.
('8', 182, 1, 3, 440442) The fault did not lie with the gaol authorities.
('8', 182, 1, 4, 440491) It was the fault of the law that has made no provision for the special treatment of Asiatic prisoners.
('8', 182, 1, 5, 440594) Indeed, the Governor of the gaol tried to make us as comfortable as he could within the regulations.
('8', 182, 1, 6, 440695) The chief warder, as also the head warder, who was in immediate charge of us, completely fell in with the spirit that actuated the Governor.
('8', 182, 1, 7, 440836) But he was powerless to accommodate us bey ond the horrible din and the yells of the Native prisoners throughout the day and partly at night also.
('8', 182, 1, 8, 440983) Many of the Native prisoners are only one degree removed from the animal and often created rows and fought among themselves in their cells.
('8', 182, 1, 9, 441123) The Governor could not separate the very few Indian prisoners (It speaks volumes for Indians that among several hundred there were hardly half a dozen Indian prisoners.) from the cells occupied by the Native prisoners.
('8', 182, 1, 10, 441342) And yet it is quite clear that separation is a physical necessity.
('8', 182, 1, 11, 441409) So much was the classification of Indians and other Asiatics with the Natives insisted upon that our jumpers, which being new were not fully marked, had to be labelled “N”, meaning Natives.
('8', 182, 1, 12, 441599) How this thoughtless classification has resulted in the Indians being partly starved will be clearer when we come to consider the question of food.
('8', 182, 2, 13, 441747) DESCRIPTION OF THE CELL
('8', 182, 3, 14, 441771) The cell in which we were placed was legally capable of holding thirteen prisoners, so that there was, naturally, sufficient accomm odation to start with.
('8', 182, 3, 15, 441926) It was a novel sensation to be locked up at half past five.
('8', 182, 3, 16, 441986) The cell was a galvanized iron construction, fairly strong, though none too strong for prisoners bent on escaping.
('8', 182, 3, 17, 442101) There was, perhaps, fair ventilation.
('8', 182, 3, 18, 442139) But two small windows at the top, half open, and apertures in the opposite wall hardly reach modern requirements, though I was assured that these cells were the best ventilated of all the prisons in the Transvaal.
('8', 182, 3, 19, 442353) There was electric light in the cell, but the only lamp in it was not strong enough to do any reading with any degree of comfort.
('8', 182, 3, 20, 442483) The light was switched off at eight o’clock in the evening and was spasmodically switched on and off during the night.
('8', 182, 3, 21, 442602) A bucket of water and a tin tumbler was our ration of water for the night.
('8', 182, 3, 22, 442677) For natural convenience a bucket in a tray with disinfectant fluid in it was placed in a corner.
('8', 182, 3, 23, 442774) Our bedding consisted of wooden planks fixed to three inch legs, two blankets, an apology for a pillow, and matting.
('8', 182, 3, 24, 442891) At our request the Governor ordered a table and two benches to be placed in the room for writing purposes.
('8', 182, 3, 25, 442998) THE MEALS The cell was opened at six o’clock, and with the day began our
('8', 183, 0, 1, 443071) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 183, 1, 2, 443113) first meal.
('8', 183, 1, 3, 443125) For the first week we were served with twelve ounces of mealie pap.
('8', 183, 1, 4, 443193) Most of us had more of the spoon than of the porridge for the first breakfast.
('8', 183, 1, 5, 443272) Neither the Chinese nor the Indians were at all in the habit of taking mealie porridge, especially as it was without any milk or sugar.
('8', 183, 1, 6, 443408) The following is the scale for non labour Native prisoners for the first week: breakfast daily, twelve ounces of mealie porridge; dinner, Monday, Wednesday and Friday, twelve ounces of beans; Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday, one quart of mealie porridge; supper daily, four ounces of crushed mealies and one ounce of fat.
('8', 183, 1, 7, 443737) Indian prisoners, however, get instead of crushed mealies, four ounces of rice and one ounce of ghee (clarified butter).
('8', 183, 1, 8, 443858) This diet was hardly satisfactory not because it was not palatable but because it was not a diet at all suitable for the Asiatic constitution.
('8', 183, 1, 9, 444001) The Chinese fared worse because they had the entire Native scale and therefore no rice.
('8', 183, 1, 10, 444089) For the first few days, for most of us, it meant practically starvation.
('8', 183, 1, 11, 444162) Even when we got over the natural repugnance, it was a diet that constipated some of us and gave diarrhoea to the others; but we weredetermined to go through it and not to ask for any favours or concessions.
('8', 183, 1, 12, 444370) We felt that it was for the Governor to move and see that a more suitable diet was issued to us.
('8', 183, 1, 13, 444467) When, therefore, the Governor enquired whether we had anything to say regarding diet, we simply stated that we did not wish to ask for any concessions, though the diet was not suitable.
('8', 183, 1, 14, 444653) For the second week the scale was a little relieved by the addition of eight ounces of potatoes or vegetables to the dinner when it consisted of mealie porridge, and on Sunday twelve ounces of meat were also added; but, as most of us were either vegetarians or could not take the meat as it was not religiously cut, we had one pound of vegetables.
('8', 183, 1, 15, 445001) This diet, however, did not last long.

('8', 184, 2, 7, 446299) LORD SELBORNE’S LETTER
('8', 184, 3, 8, 446322) Replying to Lord Elgin on the question of the Asiatic [Registration] Act, Lord Selborne wrote on July 27: The Colonial Government are not in a position to accept Your Lordship’s suggestion about the finger impressions.
('8', 184, 3, 9, 446541) Mr. Henry’s book has revealed that finger impressions have been in extensive use in India.
('8', 184, 3, 10, 446632) I am surprised to see that Sir Lepel Griffin 1, who has had experience of conditions in India, has taken exception to them.
('8', 184, 3, 11, 446756) For my part, I am convinced that the Asiatics who are lawfully settled in the Transvaal will not object to finger impressions.
('8', 184, 3, 12, 446883) It is certain, however, that those who have been carrying on a traffic in faked permits or have made huge profits by helping illegal immigration will go out of business.
('8', 184, 3, 13, 447053) Similarly, in view of the requirement regarding finger impressions, Indians who have entered unlawfully will find it impossible to stay on [in the Transvaal].
('8', 184, 3, 14, 447212) The magnitude of the traffic, the size of the profits made and the extent of the corruption can be judged from the encloseddocuments.
('8', 184, 3, 15, 447346) Your Lordship may please note that only those cases have been included in the accompanying notes of which the Transvaal Government has had definite information.
('8', 184, 3, 16, 447507) But there must have been many more instances which never came to the notice of the Transvaal Government.
('8', 184, 3, 17, 447612) I wish the officials to keep clear of the kind of temptations which were held out to Superintendent Vernon and Constable Harris by an Indian named Lala.
('8', 184, 3, 18, 447765) The only reason why some Indians have protested against the new Act is that it puts an end to their lucrative business and to the ease with which they have carried it on.

('8', 185, 1, 2, 448304) CHAMNEY’S NOTE
('8', 185, 2, 3, 448319) Mr. Chamney’s report covers more than seven pages of the Blue book.
('8', 185, 2, 4, 448387) All of this long report is taken up with factual accounts of cases of faked permits, illicit immigration, corruption, substitution of thu mb impressions on permits, furnishing wrong information about age and other fraudulent practices relating to permits.
('8', 185, 2, 5, 448643) About 100 persons are stated to have been arrested for one or the other of these offences between February 1906 and June 24, 1907. About ten of these were Chinamen and the rest Indians.
('8', 185, 2, 6, 448829) The facts in some of these cases are reported by Mr. Chamney as under.
('8', 185, 2, 7, 448900) In May 1907, an Indian named Fateh Mahomed obtained the address of Mr. Cody of the Asiatic Office through a Sikh servant.
('8', 185, 2, 8, 449022) He went to Mr. Cody’s place and offered a bribe of $50 for permits for two boys from Delagoa Bay.
('8', 185, 2, 9, 449120) In May 1906, a man named Shivabux approached the Asiatic Office with the request that his son, Chandman, be expe lled from the Transvaal.
('8', 185, 2, 10, 449258) It transpired later that Chandman was not his son, but had been brought in fraudulently.
('8', 185, 2, 11, 449347) Chandman wanted later to murder Shivabux; hence the latter’s request.
('8', 185, 2, 12, 449417) In April 1906, two Indians at Delagoa Bay applied for permits.
('8', 185, 2, 13, 449480) Before the permits were issued, they entered [the Trans vaal] with faked permits.
('8', 185, 2, 14, 449562) It transpired during the trial that they had obtained these permits in Delagoa Bay.
('8', 185, 2, 15, 449646) A notebook found on one of these individuals contained information on questions usually put to the applicants for permits when they are exami ned [by the permit authority]: for example, English, Kaffir and Dutch words in commercial use, a brief description of Johannes burg with particulars of the Indian Location, the Post Office, the Magistrate’s Court, the railway station, etc.
('8', 185, 2, 16, 450028) The men also stated that 13 others had entered Johannesburg in the samemanner.
('8', 185, 2, 17, 450107) A Chinaman had applied for a permit.
('8', 185, 2, 18, 450144) When he was exam ined, it was found that he had entered the Transvaal under three different names at different times and had been thrice convicted for felony and deported.
('8', 185, 2, 19, 450316) In August, 1906, one Arabi Isa was sentenced to six months’ hard labour for attempting to bribe [the authorities] in Komatipoort to secure the release of a prisoner.
('8', 185, 2, 20, 450482) In the same month, Dahyabhai Shankarbhai, an Indian, offered to help Sergeant MacDougal earn between £100 and 150 every month if the latter would abet unauthorized immi gration.
('8', 186, 0, 1, 450660) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 187
('8', 186, 1, 2, 450705) A Portuguese detective in the employ of the British Consul at Delagoa Bay wrote in December 1906 that a person named Lala had offered him a bribe of £17 for smuggling two boys into the Transvaal.
('8', 186, 1, 3, 450901) In January 1907, a Chinaman named He yi yang was arrested for erasing the thumb impression on a permit and affi xing another in its place.
('8', 186, 1, 4, 451040) He declared on oath in the Court that he had bought that permit in Delagoa Bay for £40 and that there were 18 other Chinese who had done the same thing.

('8', 186, 1, 6, 451266) At a searching cross examination, he broke into tears and admitted that his name was Zina Lala, and that Morar Lala was his brother who had died after returning to India.
('8', 186, 1, 7, 451437) In March 1907, four Indians entered the Transvaal.
('8', 186, 1, 8, 451488) Their thumb impressions closely resembled those on [their] permits.
('8', 186, 1, 9, 451556) On investigation it was found that the duplicates of four permits had been missing from the [Permit] Office, and that these four persons had erased the thumb impressions and affixed their own instead.
('8', 186, 1, 10, 451757) They are absconding, and the police are still trying to trace them.
('8', 186, 1, 11, 451825) Other cases are on record of persons who were subse quently found to have entered on faked permits but whose whereabouts are still unknown to the police.

('8', 186, 1, 14, 452224) In Johannesburg, in June 1907, one Kaka Hira said that he had purchased a permit from a person named Kanji Morar for £30. A letter addressed by one Indian to another fell into the hands of the police.

('8', 187, 4, 8, 453544) DE VILLIERS’S NOTE ON IMMIGRATION ACT
('8', 187, 5, 9, 453582) Mr. De Villiers, Attorney General of the Transvaal, comments as follows : 3
('8', 187, 6, 10, 453658) Till now, the restrictions on the entry of persons [into the Transvaal] were enforced by means of the permit system [under the Peace Preservation Ordinance] which was administered thro ugh the office of the High Commissioner.
('8', 187, 6, 11, 453884) After the granting of self rule to the Transvaal, the High Commissioner refused to carry on with the administration of the Ordinance.
('8', 187, 6, 12, 454018) The need was felt therefore of passing an immigration Act on the lines of the Acts of Natal and the Cape Colony.
('8', 187, 6, 13, 454131) The term ‘prohibited immi grants’ includes those Indians to whom the Asiatic Registration Act is also applicable, that is, even those who possess knowledge of a European language.
('8', 187, 6, 14, 454311) In the same manner, those Asiatics who have temporarily left the Colony in order to evade compliance with that Act are also covered by the term ‘prohibited immi grants’.
('8', 187, 6, 15, 454481) That means that only those Asiatics who are in the Colony and who have complied with the provisions of the new Asiatic Act can remain in the Transvaal.
('8', 187, 6, 16, 454633) Besides, section 6 con fers authority [on the Government] to deport those Indians who refuse to obey the law.
('8', 187, 6, 17, 454743) Itis considered necessary to confer such

('8', 189, 2, 5, 458022) WHAT THIS MEANS
('8', 189, 3, 6, 458038) Lord Elgin’s letter is a very disappointing one.
('8', 189, 3, 7, 458087) His interpre tation of the Act makes it much harsher than the Acts of the Cape Colony or Natal.
('8', 189, 3, 8, 458183) Under the Acts of the Cape Colony and Natal, Ind ians with some knowledge of English are considered eligible, but under the Transvaal Act there is an implied restriction on [the immi gration of] such Indians.
('8', 189, 3, 9, 458392) In spite of this, Lord Elgin asserts that there is nothing new in the Act.
('8', 189, 3, 10, 458467) Besides, section 6(c) relates to deportation of Indians in particular, and this also Lord Elgin appears to approve.
('8', 189, 3, 11, 458583) It follows from this that, if Indians refused to obey a particular law, Lord Elgin would assent to any measure, including the death penalty, to enforce submission to that law.
('8', 189, 3, 12, 458759) Where there is a question of compli cations with foreign governments, Lord Elgin wants amendment of the section concerned, and he has already obtained an assurance from General Smuts about this amendment.
('8', 189, 3, 13, 458964) How can anyone assert, after reading Lord Elgin’s letter, that the Indian community would not have been utterly ruined if it had not put up a fight, relying on God and its own strength.
('8', 189, 3, 14, 459150) Look at the concern he feels for subjects of foreign governments.
('8', 189, 3, 15, 459216) There is a saying among us, “Where there is no fear, there is no love”.
('8', 189, 3, 16, 459288) We do not believe that this is true on all occasions, but it is certainly true in Lord Elgin’s case.
('8', 189, 4, 17, 459389) LORD ELGIN’S LETTER TO FOREIGN OFFICE

('8', 189, 5, 20, 459692) It appears to confer a danger ously wide power over British subjects as well as over foreign subjects.

('8', 191, 1, 12, 464204) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 7 3 1908
('8', 191, 2, 13, 464245) 94. WHEREIN LIES VICTORY We have been assured that the law will be annulled, and [the principle of] voluntary registration has been accepted.
('8', 191, 2, 14, 464387) That this is a victory, everyone will grant.
('8', 191, 2, 15, 464432) But in this article we want to approach the question from a rather different point of view.
('8', 191, 2, 16, 464524) On reflection we find that in this world what people take to be success is in most cases not real success.
('8', 191, 2, 17, 464631) Sometimes that may signify failure rather than success.
('8', 191, 2, 18, 464687) We do not exaggerate when we say this.
('8', 191, 2, 19, 464726) If someone sets out from home with the intention of committing a robbery, and after much effort gains his end, it may be a success from his point of view.
('8', 191, 2, 20, 464881) On second thoughts we realize that his success was in fact a defeat for him.
('8', 191, 2, 21, 464958) If he had failed, that would have been true success.
('8', 191, 2, 22, 465011) This is an obvious example, for it is easy to understand in this context.
('8', 191, 2, 23, 465085) There are hundreds of occasions in a man’s life when he is unable to distinguish easily between right and wrong.
('8', 191, 2, 24, 465198) It is therefore difficult to determine whether the achievement of one’s aim is truly failure or triumph.
('8', 191, 2, 25, 465303) It follows from this that success and failure do not essentially depend on the result.
('8', 191, 2, 26, 465390) Besides, the result is not in one’s hands.
('8', 191, 2, 27, 465433) Whenever success
('8', 192, 0, 1, 465450) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 193
('8', 192, 1, 2, 465495) makes a manvain, he behaves like the fly on the wheel which imagines that it is making the wheel go round.
('8', 192, 1, 3, 465602) Man’s duty is to do the best he can in a given situation.
('8', 192, 1, 4, 465660) What he achieves then will, in fact, be true success.
('8', 192, 1, 5, 465714) The physician’s duty is not to save the patient, for that does not lie in his hands, but to use all his skill in a sincere effort to save him.
('8', 192, 1, 6, 465857) If he does that, he will have succeeded well enough.
('8', 192, 1, 7, 465910) What happens to the patient—whether he lives or dies—will not detract from, or add to, the physician’s success.
('8', 192, 1, 8, 466022) We are certain that, if we could have had the law repealed without much effort, that would have satisfied us.
('8', 192, 1, 9, 466132) But then there would have been no question of victory or defeat.
('8', 192, 1, 10, 466197) There would have been no occasion for us to take out a procession [in celebration], neither would the Indians’ victory be hailed as it is today the world over.
('8', 192, 1, 11, 466357) This would suggest that the Indians’ victory does not lie so much in the expectations that the law will be annulled as in their exertions to bring about that result.
('8', 192, 1, 12, 466523) Even if the repeal of the law had not come about, the Indians courage would have been admired in every home.
('8', 192, 1, 13, 466632) We can call many similar instances to mind.
('8', 192, 1, 14, 466676) A well known example occurs to me just now.
('8', 192, 1, 15, 466720) A handful of Spartans once stood guarding the pass at Thermopylae and defended it against the enemy to the last man.
('8', 192, 1, 16, 466837) 1 In the end the pass was taken by the enemy.
('8', 192, 1, 17, 466883) But the world knows today that it was the brave Spartans who won.
('8', 192, 1, 18, 466949) Even today, if anyone in Europe shows great courage, it is referred to as Spartan courage.
('8', 192, 1, 19, 467040) As for the Indians, though we cannot claim that they did all they ought to have done, they nevertheless did much.
('8', 192, 1, 20, 467154) They did exert themselves and to that extent we look upon the result, such as it has been, as a triumph.
('8', 192, 1, 21, 467259) The Indian community, it must be noted, will have to go on fighting indefinitely in this spirit.
('8', 192, 1, 22, 467356) For we here want a great many things.
('8', 192, 1, 23, 467394) We want [to own] land; we want to be free to ride in carriages.
('8', 192, 1, 24, 467458) To achieve all this, we shall have to exert ourselves as strenuously as we did on this occasion.
('8', 192, 1, 25, 467555) If we do, it is easy to see that every step forward is in itself a victory.
('8', 192, 1, 26, 467631) For we will be doing our duty at every turn.
('8', 192, 1, 27, 467676) No one will be inflated with success if he looks at it in this light.
('8', 192, 1, 28, 467746) He will never make a mistake and will not even be concerned about the outcome of his labours, for he will not assume the responsibility [for the result].
('8', 192, 1, 29, 467900) The Creator alone must bear that responsibility.
('8', 192, 1, 30, 467949) It is there fore sheer ignorance for one to be impatient to do things like the dog [under a moving cart] who fancied he was drawing the cart.

('8', 193, 1, 2, 468405) 95. GUJARATI EQUIVALENTS FOR PASSIVE RESISTANCE, ETC.
('8', 193, 1, 3, 468459) In response to our offer 1 of a prize for the best Gujarati equivalents for certain English words, we have received some entries, almost all of which, we are sorry to say, are useless.
('8', 193, 1, 4, 468644) Only four persons took the trouble of sending in suggestions, and it would thus appear that our readers take little interest in the language used in Indian Opinion or in Gujarati.
('8', 193, 1, 5, 468824) One of them says that “passive resistance” can be rendered as pratyupaya.
('8', 193, 1, 6, 468898) He explains the word as connoting [the state of] being passive to whatever happens and taking all possible remedial measures.
('8', 193, 1, 7, 469024) The word and the explanation are both worthless.
('8', 193, 1, 8, 469073) Pratyupaya means counter measure.
('8', 193, 1, 9, 469107) Opposing good to evil will then be pratyupaya, but so will be the use of force to solve a problem.
('8', 193, 1, 10, 469206) Passive resistance means resistance of evil with inner force instead of physical force.
('8', 193, 1, 11, 469294) The explanation offered betrays ignorance.
('8', 193, 1, 12, 469337) A passive resister cannot remain passive to everything that happens.
('8', 193, 1, 13, 469406) In other words, he will always pit his inner strength against everything evil.
('8', 193, 1, 14, 469485) Another equivalent that has been received is kashtadhin prativartan 2. Here the word prati is superfluous and suggestive of antipathy.
('8', 193, 1, 15, 469620) It betrays an ignorance of language.
('8', 193, 1, 16, 469657) Kashtadhin vartan has in it a suggestion of the significance of passive resistance.
('8', 193, 1, 17, 469741) But it is a big word and does not convey the full meaning.
('8', 193, 1, 18, 469800) The third term is dridha pratipaksha 3. Like pratyupaya, this too cannot he used to convey the meaning we attach to passive resistance.
('8', 193, 1, 19, 469936) The person who sent in that word has also sent us an equivalent for “civil disobedience”.
('8', 193, 1, 20, 470026) It appe ars to have been sent in without much thought.
('8', 193, 1, 21, 470081) The word suggested is satyanadar.
('8', 193, 1, 22, 470115) The meaning here is the contrary.
('8', 193, 1, 23, 470149) It means “disobe dience to truth”, that is, resistance to truth.
('8', 193, 1, 24, 470214) 4 Civil disobedience is disobe dience to untruth, and it becomes “civil” if it is “truthful” in its manner.
('8', 193, 1, 25, 470322) The word [civil] also includes the meaning of passive.
('8', 193, 1, 26, 470377) We have therefore only one word available to us for the present, and that is satyagraha.
('8', 193, 1, 27, 470466) The person 5 who suggested this word would not like his
('8', 193, 2, 28, 470522) 1Vide “Some English Terms”, 28 12 1907 2 Prativartan resistance; kashtadhin prativartan resistance through submis sion to hardship 3 Dridha pratipaksha firmness in resistance 4 The correspondent may have intended it to mean “truthful disregard” of laws, using as an adjective.
('8', 193, 2, 29, 470799) Literally, however, it could mean, as Gandhiji assumed, “disobedience to truth”.
('8', 193, 2, 30, 470880) 5 This was Maganlal Gandhi; he had suggested Satyagraha as an equivalent for passive resistance, which Gandhiji changed into satyagraha.
('8', 193, 2, 31, 471017) Vide Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XII.

('8', 194, 1, 3, 471152) Not that he means any slight to theprize, but being in a way connected with this paper, he does not want it awarded to himself.
('8', 194, 1, 4, 471280) We have made these comments with a purpose.

('8', 196, 2, 3, 475579) I have heard that there are some Indians who are trying, as though they were India’s enemies, to enter the Transvaal by unfair means.

('8', 196, 6, 13, 476571) 97. MY EXPERIENCE IN GAOL[ I] 1
('8', 196, 7, 14, 476603) Though the imprisonment that the Indian [satyagrahis] and I suffered for a righteous cause was all too brief, I propose to describe my gaol experiences in these columns, having been asked to do so by a number of persons.
('8', 196, 7, 15, 476824) Also, I think it may be useful to others.
('8', 196, 7, 16, 476866) It is also my belief that there are many [other] rights that the Indian community is yet to win by courting imprisonment.
('8', 196, 7, 17, 476988) It is therefore necessary for everyone to have an idea of the hardships of gaol life.
('8', 196, 7, 18, 477074) Often we imagine hardships where in fact there are none.
('8', 196, 7, 19, 477131) Clearly, nothing but good can result from a knowledge of the true state of affairs.
('8', 196, 7, 20, 477215) After two [earlier] attempts by the Government to arrest and imprison me it happened at last at 2 p.m.
('8', 196, 7, 21, 477318) on January 10. Before my colleagues and I received our sentences a telegram was received from Pretoria, which reported that the Indians arrested there for not complying with the Act had received [sentences of] three months’ hard labour and fines in addition, with a further term of three months’
('8', 196, 8, 22, 477614) 1 This and the subsequent articles in this series were published as “From Mr. Gandhi”.
('8', 197, 0, 1, 477701) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 197, 1, 2, 477743) hard labour in default of payment.
('8', 197, 1, 3, 477778) I was upset by the news, and asked the Magistrate to give me the maximum penalty, but this was not done.
('8', 197, 2, 4, 477883) And so we were all awarded two months’ simple imprisonment each.
('8', 197, 2, 5, 477948) Messrs P. K. Naidoo, C. M. Pillay, Karwa, Easton and Fortoen were my fellow prisoners.
('8', 197, 2, 6, 478035) The two last named are from China.
('8', 197, 2, 7, 478070) After the sentence I was detained for a few minutes in the Prisoners’ Yard behind the Court.
('8', 197, 2, 8, 478163) Then I was secretly led to a cab.
('8', 197, 2, 9, 478197) Many were the thoughts that surged in my mind.
('8', 197, 2, 10, 478244) Was I to be given a separate cell and treated as a political prisoner?
('8', 197, 2, 11, 478315) Was I to be isolated from my fellow prisoners?
('8', 197, 2, 12, 478362) Was I to be taken out of Johannesburg?
('8', 197, 2, 13, 478401) These were the thoughts runningthrough my mind.
('8', 197, 2, 14, 478449) I was accompanied by a detective, who was apologetic.
('8', 197, 2, 15, 478503) I told him that he had no reason to be, as he was only doing his duty in taking me to gaol.
('8', 197, 2, 16, 478595) All that I had imagined was soon falsified.
('8', 197, 2, 17, 478639) I was taken to where all prisoners are kept, and was soon joined by my fellow prisoners.
('8', 197, 2, 18, 478728) First, all of us were weighed.
('8', 197, 2, 19, 478759) Then we were asked to give our finger impressions.
('8', 197, 2, 20, 478810) After being stripped we were given prison uniforms to wear, consisting of black trousers, a shirt, a jumper, a cap and socks.
('8', 197, 2, 21, 478936) We were given a bag each to pack away our own clothes in.
('8', 197, 2, 22, 478994) Before being led off to our ward, we were each given eight ounces of bread.
('8', 197, 2, 23, 479070) We were then marched off to a prison intended for Kaffirs.
('8', 197, 3, 24, 479129) INDIANS ON PAR WITH KAFFIRS
('8', 197, 4, 25, 479157) There, our garments were stamped with the letter “N”, which meant that we were being classed with the Natives.
('8', 197, 4, 26, 479268) We were all prepared for hardships, but not quite for this experience.
('8', 197, 4, 27, 479339) We could understand not being classed with the whites, but to be placed on the same level with the Natives seemed too much to put up with.
('8', 197, 4, 28, 479478) I then felt that Indians had not launched on passive resistance too soon.
('8', 197, 4, 29, 479552) Here was further proof that the obnoxious law was intended to emasculate the Indians.
('8', 197, 4, 30, 479638) It was, however, as well that we were classed with the Natives.
('8', 197, 4, 31, 479702) It was a welcome opportunity to study the treatment meted out to Natives, their conditions [of life in gaol] and their habits.
('8', 197, 4, 32, 479829) Looked at from another point of view, it did not seem right to feel bad about being bracketed with them.
('8', 197, 4, 33, 479934) At the same time, it is indubitably right that Indians should have separate cells.
('8', 197, 4, 34, 480017) The cells for Kaffirs were adjacent to ours.
('8', 197, 4, 35, 480062) They used to make a frightful din in their cells as also in the adjoining yard.
('8', 197, 4, 36, 480142) We were given a separate ward because we were sentenced to simple imprisonment; otherwise we would have
('8', 197, 5, 37, 480246) 1Vide “Trial at Johannesburg”, 10 1 1908
('8', 198, 0, 1, 480287) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 199
('8', 198, 1, 2, 480332) been in the same ward [with the Kaffirs].
('8', 198, 1, 3, 480374) Indians sentenced to hard labour are in fact kept with the Kaffirs.
('8', 198, 1, 4, 480442) Apart from whether or not this implies degradation, I must say it is rather dangerous.
('8', 198, 1, 5, 480529) Kaffirs are as a rule uncivilised—the convicts even more so.
('8', 198, 1, 6, 480590) They are troublesome, very dirty and live almost like animals.
('8', 198, 1, 7, 480653) Each ward contains nearly 50 to 60 of them.
('8', 198, 1, 8, 480697) They often started rows and fought among themselves.
('8', 198, 1, 9, 480750) The reader can easily imagine the plight of the poor Indian thrown into such company!
('8', 198, 2, 10, 480836) OTHER INDIAN PRISONERS
('8', 198, 3, 11, 480859) Apart from us, there were hardly three or four Indian prisoners in the whole gaol.
('8', 198, 3, 12, 480942) They were locked up with the Kaffirs and, to that extent, they were worse off than we.
('8', 198, 3, 13, 481029) However, I noticed that they were quite cheerful and enjoyed better health than when they were outside.
('8', 198, 3, 14, 481133) They had earned the favour of the Chief Warder.
('8', 198, 3, 15, 481181) Being quick at their work and well informed, as compared with the Kaffirs, they were given respectable work to do inside the gaol.
('8', 198, 3, 16, 481312) That is, they supervised the work on the machines in the store or did similar jobs which were not strenuous or did not seem unclean.
('8', 198, 3, 17, 481445) They were particularly helpful to us.
('8', 198, 5, 18, 481483) We were kept in a ward 1 which had room for 13 persons.
('8', 198, 5, 19, 481539) It was labelled “For Coloured Debtors”; that is, for the most part it was used for Coloured persons who were imprisoned for civil offences.
('8', 198, 5, 20, 481679) For ventilation, the ward had two small windows with a strong iron grilling which, I thought, did not let in enough air.
('8', 198, 5, 21, 481800) Galvanized iron sheets served for walls with glazed apertures at three places, half an inch in diameter, through which the gaolers could watch the prisoners whileremaining unobserved themselves.
('8', 198, 5, 22, 481995) The ward next to ours had Kaffir prisoners in it.
('8', 198, 5, 23, 482045) In the wards beyond, there were Kaffirs, Chinese and Cape Boys—all witnesses—who had been locked up in gaol lest they should abscond.

('8', 199, 2, 3, 482500) The late Dr. G. U. Pope 1, whose biography in The Times we reproduce elsewhere, was one of the few Anglo Indians carrying forward today the traditions of fifty years ago.
('8', 199, 2, 4, 482671) His erudition and scholarship need no other outward token than the monument of works with which his name will always be associated.
('8', 199, 2, 5, 482803) There have been few Englishmen for whom the people of Madras should bear greater reverence and deeper respect than Dr. Pope.
('8', 199, 2, 6, 482928) His example is a shining light to the educated classes of Madras leading them along the path of investigation and explanation so that the world may know something of that great past which only recently was sunk in oblivion, that the treasures of literature, philology, philosophy, and theology may be brought to light, and that the people may receive some indication of their line of growth for the future.
('8', 199, 2, 7, 483335) The demise of Dr. Pope is a loss to Indian and European scholarship alike.
('8', 199, 2, 8, 483410) His memory will be ever dear to all who love Indiaand those who have worked for India’s enlightenment in a spirit of sympathy for the people among whom they have spent a lifetime of toil.

('8', 200, 3, 5, 484885) The Estcourt appeal deserves to be noted and pondered over.

('8', 200, 4, 12, 485508) Colonel Greene’s powerful address had no effect on the Court, which shows
('8', 200, 5, 13, 485582) 1 On March 2 and 3, 1908, the Estcourt Local Board met to consider appeals from five Indians against the decision of the Licensing Officer refusing the renewal of their licences for 1908. The Licensing Officer's objections to the renewal of A. M. Patel's licence were that (a) his books had been kept in an unsatisfactory manner and that individual entries were incorrect and (b) the books were not of first entry but were written up from verbal information given by the applicant to the book keeper.
('8', 200, 5, 14, 486083) On cross examination of the Licensing Officer by Colonel Greene, it transpired that (a) he had renewed the appellant's licence the previous year although the books had been kept in an identical manner and (b) he had not given any notice to the applicant that they were to be kept any differently in the future.
('8', 200, 5, 15, 486394) The alleged errors in accounting, it was also discovered, were those of G.R. Beattie, a European accountant employed by the appellant.
('8', 200, 5, 16, 486529) Appearing as a witness, Beattie, the Accountant, testified that Hellet, a European shopkeeper, also employed him as book keeper and that he kept books for him in much the same manner.
('8', 200, 5, 17, 486713) By a majority of five to one the Board, however, decided that after a notice period of six months Patel was to liquidate his business.
('8', 200, 5, 18, 486848) Colonel Greene, counsel for appellants then addressed the Board.
('8', 200, 5, 19, 486913) “...the [other] shopkeepers kept note of their transactions in Gujarati and their book keeper .ascertained from them their cash sales and counted up their totals for each day.
('8', 200, 5, 20, 487089) The books were perfectly well kept, indeed remarkably well kept.” He added that they were satisfied that the rough books which were kept in Gujarati were not part of the usual books of account kept by a merchant, and they came to this decision after hearing the expert evidence of two well known accountants.
('8', 200, 5, 21, 487398) They were further satisfied that the Gujarati books had been kept at the special instigation of the previous Licensing Officer and that he had been satisfied with their method of keeping these books.
('8', 200, 5, 22, 487598) Under those circumstances he thought the appeals should very properly be allowed.
('8', 200, 5, 23, 487680) Colonel Greene had concluded an earlier address to the Board saying, “It had never been intended by the law that any dirty work of this sort should be done by a Local Board of this sort and upon my soul if you refuse this application, I think it will make us all feel like worms.” The Local Board ordered the conditional renewal of two of the five licences.

('8', 201, 2, 11, 488935) 101. MY EXPERIENCE IN GAOL[ II]
('8', 201, 3, 12, 488967) In front of the cell [s] there was a small yard in which we could move about during the day.
('8', 201, 3, 13, 489060) It was [however] too small for the purpose.
('8', 201, 3, 14, 489104) There is a rule that prisoners in this ward may not go out of the enclosed space without permission, since the bath, urinals and latrines are all located within the yard.
('8', 201, 3, 15, 489275) For bathing there were two large stone basins and two spouts which served for a shower.
('8', 201, 3, 16, 489363) There were buckets for defecation and two more for urine.
('8', 201, 3, 17, 489421) There was no provision for privacy in the bath or latrine.
('8', 201, 3, 18, 489480) Also, the Gaol Regulations forbade the provision of separate latrines which would allow the prisoners privacy.
('8', 201, 3, 19, 489591) It often happened, therefore, that two or three prisoners sat down in a row.
('8', 201, 3, 20, 489668) The arrangements for bathing were similar.
('8', 201, 3, 21, 489711) The buckets for urine, too, stood in the open.
('8', 201, 3, 22, 489758) This may well cause a feeling of revulsion; some would be offended by it.
('8', 201, 3, 23, 489832) But on reflection one realizes that a gaol cannot provide for privacy and that no feeling of shame should attach to the performing of these functions in public.
('8', 201, 3, 24, 489993) It is, therefore, necessary patiently to form the required habits without being squeamish or annoyed at the public nature of these arrangements.
('8', 201, 3, 25, 490138) For sleeping, there were hard wooden planks [mounted on] legs only three inches high.
('8', 201, 3, 26, 490224) Each prisoner had two rugs, a small pillow and a coir mat large enough to roll them up in.
('8', 201, 3, 27, 490315) Sometimes three rugs were
('8', 201, 4, 28, 490341) 1 George Nathaniel Curzon of Kedleston, 1st Marquess (1859 1925); Under Secretary of State for India, 1891 2; Viceroy and Governor General of India, 18991905; Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, 1919 24; author of British Government in India, Problems of the Far East and other books

('8', 202, 1, 2, 490674) allowed to a prisoner but only as a favour.
('8', 202, 1, 3, 490718) Some were put out at the thought of [sleeping on] a hard bench.
('8', 202, 1, 4, 490782) Those used to soft mattresses cannot easily take to hard bedding.
('8', 202, 1, 5, 490848) According to medical science, hard bedding is to be preferred.
('8', 202, 1, 6, 490911) If we, therefore, adopt the practice of using hard bedding at home, we will not find it difficult to get used to the kind of bedding available in gaol.
('8', 202, 1, 7, 491063) A bucket of water was provided in the cell, and another bucket placed on a large tray served for a chamber pot, for no prisoner was allowed to leave the cell at night.
('8', 202, 1, 8, 491231) Everyone was provided, according to his needs, with a little soap, a homespun towel and a wooden spoon.
('8', 202, 2, 9, 491335) SANITATION
('8', 202, 3, 10, 491346) I must say that sanitation in the gaol was excellent.
('8', 202, 3, 11, 491400) Every day, the floor of the cell was washed with a disinfectant and the edges of the floor [skirting the wall] lime washed.
('8', 202, 3, 12, 491524) The cell therefore always looked fresh.
('8', 202, 3, 13, 491564) The bathroom and the commodes were also washed with soap and disinfectant.
('8', 202, 3, 14, 491639) I believe, I am myself very particular about sanitation.
('8', 202, 3, 15, 491696) Therefore, when, towards the end, a large number of our people joined us, I myself used to wash the commodes with disinfe ctant fluid.
('8', 202, 3, 16, 491831) To remove the stool, a few Chinese prisoners turned up every morning at nine o’clock.
('8', 202, 3, 17, 491917) Afterwards, whenever it was necessary to clean up or wash, we had to do it ourselves.
('8', 202, 3, 18, 492003) The planks of the beds were washed every day with sand and water.
('8', 202, 3, 19, 492069) The only inconvenience was that, as it happened, the pillows and rugs changed hands among the hundreds of prisoners.
('8', 202, 3, 20, 492186) Though there was a rule that required the rugs to be aired in the sun every day, it was hardly ever observed.
('8', 202, 4, 21, 492296) SOME RULES
('8', 202, 5, 22, 492307) There are some gaol rules which everyone should know.
('8', 202, 5, 23, 492361) The prisoners are locked up at half past five in the afternoon.
('8', 202, 5, 24, 492425) They read or converse in the cell up to eight in the evening.
('8', 202, 5, 25, 492487) At eight, everyone must go to bed, meaning that even if one cannot sleep, one must get into bed.
('8', 202, 5, 26, 492584) Talking among prisoners after eight constitutes a breach of Gaol Regulations.
('8', 202, 5, 27, 492662) The Kaffir prisoners do not observe this rule too strictly.
('8', 202, 5, 28, 492722) The warders on night duty, therefore, try to silence them by knocking against the walls with their truncheons and shouting, “Thula!
('8', 202, 5, 29, 492854) thula!” Prisoners are strictly forbidden to smoke—a rule which is enforced scrupulously.
('8', 202, 5, 30, 492943) But I saw that the confirmed smokers among the prisoners broke the rule on the sly.
('8', 202, 5, 31, 493027) A bell is rung at half past five in the morning to wake up the prisoners.
('8', 202, 5, 32, 493101) Everyone must then get up, roll up his bedding and wash.
('8', 202, 5, 33, 493158) The door of the cell is opened at six when each prisoner must stand up with his arms crossed and his bedding rolled up beside him.
('8', 202, 5, 34, 493289) A sentry then calls the roll.

('8', 203, 1, 2, 493361) a similar rule, every prisoner is required to stand beside his bed, while he is being locked up [at night].
('8', 203, 1, 3, 493469) The prisoners may not have anything else in their possession except what is given them by the gaol autho rities.
('8', 203, 1, 4, 493582) Except clothes, they are forbidden to keep anything without the Governor’s permission.
('8', 203, 1, 5, 493669) One of the buttons on every prisoner’s shirt has sewn on to it a small pocket which contains a card bearing his number, his name, the particulars of his sentence, etc.
('8', 203, 1, 6, 493837) Normally the prisoners may not stay in the cell during the day.
('8', 203, 1, 7, 493901) Those sentenced to hard labour cannot do so in any case, since they are engaged in their work, but even the others are not allowed to stay in.
('8', 203, 1, 8, 494044) They must remain in the yard outside the cell.
('8', 203, 1, 9, 494091) The Governor had allowed us a table and two benches in the ward, and these were very useful.
('8', 203, 1, 10, 494184) There is a rule that every prisoner sentenced to two months [or more] must have his hair cropped close and the moustache shaved off.
('8', 203, 1, 11, 494317) In the case of Indians the rule is not enforced rigorously.
('8', 203, 1, 12, 494377) Should a prisoner object, his moustache is spared.
('8', 203, 1, 13, 494428) In this connection I had an amusing experience.
('8', 203, 1, 14, 494476) I knew very well that prisoners had to have their hair cropped.
('8', 203, 1, 15, 494540) I also knew that the rule about having the prisoner’s hair and moustache removed was really for his own convenience and not to humiliate him.
('8', 203, 1, 16, 494682) Personally, I believe that it is a very useful rule.
('8', 203, 1, 17, 494735) In gaol thereare no combs or other means for keeping the hair tidy.
('8', 203, 1, 18, 494803) If the hair is not groomed, there is the risk of scabies.
('8', 203, 1, 19, 494861) On hot days, hair makes one feel extremely uncomfortable.
('8', 203, 1, 20, 494919) Moreover, the prisoners are not given a looking glass.
('8', 203, 1, 21, 494974) There is the danger, therefore, of the moustache remaining unclean.
('8', 203, 1, 22, 495042) As there is no serviette for use at meals and the wooden spoon is rather awkward to handle, food is apt to stick in the moustache.
('8', 203, 1, 23, 495173) It was my intention to go through all the experi ences of a prisoner.
('8', 203, 1, 24, 495243) I therefore asked the Chief Warder to have my hair cropped and my moustache shaved off.
('8', 203, 1, 25, 495331) He told me the Governor had strictly forbidden that.
('8', 203, 1, 26, 495384) I said, I knew that he did not wish to force me [to observe this rule], but that I myself wanted it.
('8', 203, 1, 27, 495485) He suggested that I might apply to the Governor.
('8', 203, 1, 28, 495534) The next day, permission was received from him.
('8', 203, 1, 29, 495582) But he said that, since two days out of my two month period had elapsed, he had now no right to order the cropping of my hair and moustache.
('8', 203, 1, 30, 495723) I said, I knew the rule but wanted this of my own free will and for my own convenience.
('8', 203, 1, 31, 495811) He smilingly demurred.
('8', 203, 1, 32, 495834) I learnt later that the Governor had felt a little apprehensive.
('8', 203, 1, 33, 495899) So I offered to state in writing that I had myself requested the cropping [of my hair].
('8', 203, 1, 34, 495987) This allayed the Governor’s suspicion, and he ordered the Chief Warder to give me clippers and a pair of scissors.
('8', 203, 1, 35, 496102) My fellow prisoner, Mr. P. K. Naidoo, was a master of the tonsorial art.
('8', 203, 1, 36, 496175) I, too, know something of it.
('8', 203, 1, 37, 496205) When the others saw me cropping my hair and moustache, they saw the point of it, and followed suit.

('8', 204, 2, 8, 496664) INSPECTION
('8', 204, 3, 9, 496675) When the officials come to inspect the prisoners, the latter have all to line up.
('8', 204, 3, 10, 496757) As the official approaches, they must take off their caps and salute him.
('8', 204, 3, 11, 496831) All the prisoners wore caps, and it was not difficult to take them off, for there was a rule that they must be taken off, and this was only proper.
('8', 204, 3, 12, 496979) The order to line up was given by shouting the command “fall in” whenever an official came.
('8', 204, 3, 13, 497071) The words “fall in” therefore became our daily diet.
('8', 204, 3, 14, 497124) They meant that the prisoners should fall in line and stand to attention.
('8', 204, 3, 15, 497198) This happened four or five times a day.
('8', 204, 3, 16, 497238) One of these officials, who bore the designation of Assistant Chief Warder, was somewhat strict.
('8', 204, 3, 17, 497335) The Indian prisoners therefore nicknamed him “General Smuts”.
('8', 204, 3, 18, 497397) He often came early in the morning, and sometimes in the afternoon as well.
('8', 204, 3, 19, 497473) The doctor came at half past nine.
('8', 204, 3, 20, 497508) He appeared to be a kind and well meaning person.
('8', 204, 3, 21, 497558) He made solicitous inquiries about our health.
('8', 204, 3, 22, 497605) Under the Gaol Regula tions, every prisoner must undress himself in public for examination by the doctor.
('8', 204, 3, 23, 497711) But the doctor did not insist on the observance of this rule.
('8', 204, 3, 24, 497773) Moreover, when the number of Indian prisoners increased, he asked them if anyone had eczema or similar infection, so that he might examine the person in private.
('8', 204, 3, 25, 497935) The Governor and the Chief Warder used to come at half past ten or eleven.
('8', 204, 3, 26, 498010) The Governor appe ared to be firm, fair minded and quiet tempered.
('8', 204, 3, 27, 498077) He always had the same questions to ask: “Are you all well?
('8', 204, 3, 28, 498137) Is there anything you want?
('8', 204, 3, 29, 498165) Have you any complaints?” He listened to a request or a complaint patiently and granted every request which was reasonable; if there was a [genuine] grievance, he set matters right.
('8', 204, 3, 30, 498347) I shall discuss some of the complaints and demands later.
('8', 204, 3, 31, 498405) The Deputy Governor also came sometimes.
('8', 204, 3, 32, 498446) He, too, was a kindly person.
('8', 204, 3, 33, 498476) But the kindest among them all, the most gentle and sympathetic, was the official known as the Chief Warder, who was especially charged with looking after us.
('8', 204, 3, 34, 498635) He is a very devout man; we were not the only ones to whom he was nice and courteous in every way; [for] the other prisoners were also very warm in their praises of him.
('8', 204, 3, 35, 498805) He was anxious to respect prisoners’ rights.
('8', 204, 3, 36, 498850) He would condone any minor offence on their part.
('8', 204, 3, 37, 498900) He was particularly kind to us because he thought that we had not really committed any offence.
('8', 204, 3, 38, 498996) Often he talked with us and even expressed sympathy.
('8', 205, 0, 1, 499049) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 205, 1, 2, 499091) PRISONERS INCREASE
('8', 205, 2, 3, 499110) I mentioned earlier that we were five satyagrahi prisoners to begin with.
('8', 205, 2, 4, 499184) On Tuesday, January 14, we were joined by Mr. Thambi Naidoo, the Chief Picket, and Mr. Quinn, Chairman of the Chinese Association.
('8', 205, 2, 5, 499315) All of us were happy to see them.
('8', 205, 2, 6, 499349) On January 16, 14 others came, Samunder Khan being one of them.
('8', 205, 2, 7, 499413) He had been sentenced to a two month term.
('8', 205, 2, 8, 499456) The remaining 13 included Madrasis, Kanamias and Gujarati Hindus.
('8', 205, 2, 9, 499522) All of them had been arrested for hawking without licences and fined £2 each with 14 days’ imprison ment in default of payment.
('8', 205, 2, 10, 499650) They had had courage enough to refuse payment of the fine and to prefer imprisonment.
('8', 205, 2, 11, 499736) On Tuesday, January 21, another 76 persons joined us.
('8', 205, 2, 12, 499790) Among them, only Nawab Khan had been sentenced to two months, the rest having been fined £2 each with 14 days’ imprisonment in default of payment.
('8', 205, 2, 13, 499937) Most of them were Gujarati Hindus, the rest Kanamias and Madrasis.
('8', 205, 2, 14, 500004) On Wednesday, January 22, there was a further addition of 35 persons.
('8', 205, 2, 15, 500074) On the 23rd, three more arrived, one on the 24th, two on the 25th, six on the 28th, and, on the evening of the same day, four more.
('8', 205, 2, 16, 500206) On the 29th, there were again four arrivals, all of them Kanamias.
('8', 205, 2, 17, 500273) That made a total of 155 up to January 29. On Thursday, that is, on the 30th, I was taken to Pretoria.
('8', 205, 2, 18, 500376) But I remember, on that day also, five or six more prisoners arrived.

('8', 205, 3, 20, 500488) 102. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('8', 205, 4, 21, 500513) Registration is in progress.
('8', 205, 4, 22, 500542) There are, however, some persons who appear to be bent on working against the community’s interests; they recognize only self interest.
('8', 205, 4, 23, 500678) They furnish false information in their applications.
('8', 205, 4, 24, 500732) All this will do us harm.
('8', 205, 4, 25, 500758) There are others who imagine that, as a result of the movement, it should be possible to save even those who have no right to be here.
('8', 205, 4, 26, 500893) It is difficult to understand how a movement conducted in defence of right can also serve wrong.
('8', 205, 4, 27, 500990) If the sun shines by virtue of the truth of the truthful, it warms the untruthful as well; so it may also be possible legitimately to safeguard the interests of a few persons living here unlawfully, provided a majority of the Indians are truthful.
('8', 205, 4, 28, 501238) We may then be able to request the Government not to harass those who are here without permits.
('8', 205, 4, 29, 501334) They have, however, undeniably committed an offence in law.
('8', 205, 4, 30, 501394) But theirs is not an offence calling for rigorous punishment.

('8', 206, 1, 5, 501930) One should bear in mind that greed always begets sin.

('8', 208, 1, 2, 504038) 105. MY GAOL EXPERIENCES [ II]
('8', 208, 2, 3, 504069) CHANGE IN THE DIET
('8', 208, 3, 4, 504088) On the 14th of January came Messrs Thambi Naidoo and Quinn.
('8', 208, 3, 5, 504148) That, however, did not affect the situation much, as they were quite willing to rough it, but on the 18th, fourteen more came.
('8', 208, 3, 6, 504275) With the exception of one, these were hawkers who were sentenced to pay two pounds fine or to suffer fourteen days’ imprisonment.
('8', 208, 3, 7, 504405) It was not possible to expect these men to accommodate themselves all of a sudden to a diet to which they were never used.
('8', 208, 3, 8, 504528) Consequently it was a matter of grave anxiety.
('8', 208, 3, 9, 504575) It was duly brought to the notice of the Governor who professed helplessness by regulation.
('8', 208, 3, 10, 504667) He was quite willing to respect any religious objections but where it was a matter merely of likes and dislikes, he could not help.
('8', 208, 3, 11, 504799) Prison life was prison life and people’s tastes could not be respected.
('8', 208, 3, 12, 504871) All this would be true, if it were merely a matter of tastes.
('8', 208, 3, 13, 504933) Unfortunately it was a matter of habit.
('8', 208, 3, 14, 504973) And the scale having been fixed without due regard for national habits of Asiatics, the system broke down under the stress.
('8', 208, 3, 15, 505097) just as it would be foolish for Indians to expect national food adjuncts, such as curries, etc., it was foolish for the authorities to have prescribed a diet however nutritious it might be medically that was unsuitable for Indians.
('8', 208, 3, 16, 505329) Boiled beef or mutton would be just as useless for Indians as mealie pap.
('8', 208, 3, 17, 505403) They could live on wheaten and rice preparations, no matter how simple they might be.
('8', 208, 3, 18, 505489) But they could not live on what might be African delicacies.
('8', 208, 3, 19, 505550) So that the new batch of prisoners faced starvation.
('8', 208, 3, 20, 505603) They went without breakfast.
('8', 208, 3, 21, 505632) And rice they received for dinner, i.e., four ounces with one ounce of ghee insufficient as it was even with the breakfast was much more so for people who broke their fast on the above quantity of rice.
('8', 208, 4, 22, 505835) A PETITION IN PRISON
('8', 208, 5, 23, 505856) The following petition 1 was, therefore, forwarded through the Governor to the Director of Prisons.
('8', 208, 5, 24, 505956) Owing to the arrival, as stated at the foot of the petition, of about seventy more passive resisters, I requested the Governor either to tele graph or to telephone its contents and to apply for prompt instruc tions.
('8', 208, 5, 25, 506172) This he kindly did and orders were given immediately, pendingfurther consideration, to replace mealie pap for breakfast by four ounces of bread and to do the same thing for supper by issuing
('8', 208, 6, 26, 506363) 1 For the text, vide “Petition to Director of Prisons”,21 1 1908
('8', 209, 0, 1, 506428) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 209, 1, 2, 506470) eight ounces ofbread.
('8', 209, 1, 3, 506492) Whilst the matter was being further considered, the compromise supervened and we were all discharged.
('8', 209, 2, 4, 506594) A CONTRAST
('8', 209, 3, 5, 506605) Yet it must be clear to the reader that this question of food for Asiatic Prisoners is too important to be given up.
('8', 209, 3, 6, 506722) It is only because there are ordinarily very few Indian presoners in the Transvaal gaols that the matter has not attracted attention before now.
('8', 209, 3, 7, 506867) The change ordered by the Director removed the most four ounces of bread even for non labour Prisoners is a mere morsel.
('8', 209, 3, 8, 506988) And although the medical officer stated that the addition of cocoa or butter or dholl would be considered a relish and therefore not allowed as a prison diet, I venture to think that some such addition is absolutely necessary to make bread eatable.
('8', 209, 3, 9, 507237) Now let us for a moment glance at the scale for non labour European Prisoners.
('8', 209, 3, 10, 507316) They get for breakfast one pint of porridge and four ounces of bread; for dinner eight ounces of bread daily, together with meat or soup or beans, potatoes or vegetables; for supper they get eight ounces of bread and one pint of porridge.
('8', 209, 3, 11, 507555) I understand that they also get cocoa or some such drink.
('8', 209, 3, 12, 507613) Now it does not seem clear why the Europeans should get porridge and four ounces of bread whereas Indians should get four ounces of bread in place of porridge.
('8', 209, 3, 13, 507773) Have the former a greater appetite than Indians?
('8', 209, 3, 14, 507822) Then again, why should Indians get only twelve ounces of beans when Europeans get the same quantity of beans and eight ounces of bread?
('8', 209, 3, 15, 507958) This is an anomaly which is most difficult to understand.
('8', 209, 3, 16, 508016) It may be possible to reconcile oneself to the Europeans getting a greater variety of superior or more expensive food; but it is not possible to do so with regard to the quantity of foods.
('8', 209, 3, 17, 508205) It is obvious, therefore that the Indian dietary needs a great deal of modification.
('8', 209, 3, 18, 508290) Then again, the fact that the Colonial Secretary never troubled himself about the food provided for men who could not be classed as ordinary Prisoners betray in my opinion callous contempt for the Indian community.
('8', 209, 3, 19, 508505) In vie of the compromise effected, one does not wish to say much on this Painful phase of the question.
('8', 209, 3, 20, 508609) Indian Opinion, 21 3 1908

('8', 215, 2, 4, 521256) 108. MY EXPERIENCE IN GAOL [ III]
('8', 215, 3, 5, 521290) Diet is a subject which most of us have to think about some time or other in our lives.
('8', 215, 3, 6, 521378) In particular, prisoners’ food requires the most careful consideration.
('8', 215, 3, 7, 521450) Their well being depends a great deal on a good diet.
('8', 215, 3, 8, 521504) The rule about food in gaol is that one must accept what is offered and take nothing from any other source.
('8', 215, 3, 9, 521612) Soldiers, too, must eat what is given them.
('8', 215, 3, 10, 521656) But there is a great difference between soldiers and prisoners.
('8', 215, 3, 11, 521720) Friends may send gifts of food to soldiers, which they may accept.
('8', 215, 3, 12, 521787) Prisoners, on the other hand, are forbidden to accept [gifts of] food.
('8', 215, 3, 13, 521858) Difficulty in regard to food is one important feature of prison life.
('8', 215, 3, 14, 521928) Even in casual conversation we hear gaol authorities saying that there can be no question of preferences in gaol.
('8', 215, 3, 15, 522042) When I met the gaol doctor, I asked that bread should be served with tea or ghee.
('8', 215, 3, 16, 522124) He replied: “You want to indulge your taste.
('8', 215, 3, 17, 522169) That is not possible in gaol.” Let us now consider the regulation food in gaol.
('8', 215, 3, 18, 522249) Indians get the following items of food during the first week: in the morning, twelve ounces of mealie pap without sugar or ghee; for the midday meal, fo ur ounces of rice with an ounce of ghee; in the evening, twelve ounces of mealie pap on four days and boiled beans with salt on three days.
('8', 215, 3, 19, 522543) This scale is drawn up on the basis of what the Kaffir prisoners get, with this difference that the Kaffirs are given pounded maize and fat in the evening, instead of which Indians get rice [for their midday meal].
('8', 215, 3, 20, 522758) From the second week onward, along with mealie meal, they get boiled potatoes on two days and vegetables, such as cabbage, pumpkin, on the other two.
('8', 215, 3, 21, 522908) To those who eat it, meat is also served with vegetables every Sunday from the second week onward.
('8', 215, 3, 22, 523007) The prisoners who were the first to arrive had decided not to ask for any favours from the Government but to make do with whatever food was allowed them, provided it was acceptable [from the religious standpoint].
('8', 215, 3, 23, 523221) In point of fact, the scale described above was neither adequate for Indians nor suited to them.
('8', 215, 3, 24, 523318) It may be that dietetically the food was sufficiently nutritious.
('8', 215, 3, 25, 523384) Mealie meal is the staple of Kaffir diet, so that this scale suits them very well and they thrive on it.
('8', 215, 3, 26, 523489) But nothing except rice is acceptable to Indians; hardly any of them eat
('8', 216, 0, 1, 523562) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 217
('8', 216, 1, 2, 523607) mealie pap.
('8', 216, 1, 3, 523619) Indians are not used to eating beans as a course in itself and do not find the vegetarian dishes [cooked in gaol] agreeable.
('8', 216, 1, 4, 523744) The vegetables are not washed, neither are they dressed with spices.
('8', 216, 1, 5, 523813) Moreover, the vegetables served to the Kaffir prisoners consist mostly of the leftovers and peelings from the vegetables cooked for the whites.
('8', 216, 1, 6, 523957) Nothing except salt is allowed by way of condiment.
('8', 216, 1, 7, 524009) Of sugar one may not even dream.
('8', 216, 1, 8, 524042) Everyone was therefore bothered by the problem of food.
('8', 216, 1, 9, 524098) Even so, we resolved that 3S satyagrahis we should not ask for anything from the gaol authorities nor seek a favour So we carried on with the food described above.
('8', 216, 1, 10, 524262) When the Governor enquired [about the amenities], we told him that our food was unsatisfactory, but that we did not wish to ask for a favour from the Government.
('8', 216, 1, 11, 524424) It was for the Government to consider whether they should make changes.
('8', 216, 1, 12, 524496) Otherwise, we would make do with whatever the regulations allowed.
('8', 216, 1, 13, 524563) This attitude could not be kept up for long.
('8', 216, 1, 14, 524608) When others joined us, we agreed that it would not be proper for us to compel them to accept this inconvenience as we did.
('8', 216, 1, 15, 524731) That they had come to gaol was [sacrifice] enough.
('8', 216, 1, 16, 524782) It would be proper, we thought, to demand from the Government special treatment for these people.
('8', 216, 1, 17, 524880) To that end webroached the subject with the Governor.
('8', 216, 1, 18, 524934) We told him that, though we accepted whatever was given to us, those who came after us would not be able to do so.
('8', 216, 1, 19, 525049) The Governor thought the matter over and answered that he could [permit] cooking to meet any religious scruples, but that the food itself should remain the same.
('8', 216, 1, 20, 525211) It was not within his power to effect any changes in it.
('8', 216, 1, 21, 525268) Meanwhile, as mentioned earlier, 1 14 other Indians joined us.
('8', 216, 1, 22, 525331) Some of them plainly refused to eat mealie pap.
('8', 216, 1, 23, 525379) They starved.
('8', 216, 1, 24, 525393) I went through the gaol regulations, and discovered that a petition on this subject could be addressed to the Director of Prisons.
('8', 216, 1, 25, 525524) We therefore asked for the Governor’s permission to address a petition, and the following petition 2 was forwarded.
('8', 216, 1, 26, 525640) This petition was signed by 21 of us.
('8', 216, 1, 27, 525678) After it had been signed and was about to be submitted, we were joined by another 76 Indians, who also disliked mealie pap.
('8', 216, 1, 28, 525802) We therefore added at the end of the petition that the 76 persons do had come in also felt the same difficulty, and that immediate orders should therefore be issued.
('8', 216, 1, 29, 525968) I requested the Governor to telegraph the contents of this petition.
