('8', 219, 2, 5, 531894) 109. INTERVIEW TO D. A. REES 1
('8', 219, 3, 6, 531925) [Before March 26, 1908] 2
('8', 219, 4, 7, 531951) Q. What number of Indians are there in the Transvaal and from what parts of India do they chiefly come?
('8', 219, 5, 8, 532055) A. There are about 13,000. At present the number resident here is only about 8,000; the remaining 5,000 have left in consequence of the Registration Act.
('8', 219, 5, 9, 532209) Some are in Natal and some in Cape Town but the majority have returned to India.
('8', 219, 5, 10, 532290) Probably most of them will now return.
('8', 219, 5, 11, 532329) Those who are resident here have come chiefly from Bombay and Madras, and are mostly general traders or hawkers.
('8', 219, 6, 12, 532442) Q. What is the history of the settlement of Indians in the Transvaal?
('8', 219, 7, 13, 532512) A. In 1843, indentured labour was first introduced into Natal.
('8', 219, 7, 14, 532575) Afterwards it was suspended.
('8', 219, 7, 15, 532604) Then the prosperity of the Colony declined and in 1853 indentured labour was again resorted to.
('8', 219, 7, 16, 532700) There was a large Indian settlement in Mauritius, and one of the Bombay Indians there, hearing that Indians did well in Natal, came there, bringing with him a large number of his relatives and fellow caste men.
('8', 219, 7, 17, 532911) He prospered, and other Indians hearing of this, came on the scene and so Indian traders multiplied.
('8', 219, 7, 18, 533012) When the Transvaal mines were opened up, these traders came over from Natal and soon became prosperous.
('8', 219, 7, 19, 533116) They found that they could trade not only with their own countrymen, but also with the Kafirs and the Dutch.
('8', 219, 7, 20, 533225) They found the Dutch trade specially remunerative, and so the number of Indian traders increased.
('8', 219, 8, 21, 533323) Q. I have heard it said that you have made special efforts to increase the Indian trading community and to bring in Indian artisans.
('8', 219, 8, 22, 533456) Is this true?
('8', 219, 9, 23, 533470) A. There is not a vestige of truth in it.
('8', 219, 9, 24, 533512) I first came into the country in 1893, when things were much as they are now.
('8', 219, 9, 25, 533590) There were then fully eight or nine thousand Indians in the country.
('8', 219, 9, 26, 533659) The increase which has since taken place is small, and I have done absolutely
('8', 219, 10, 27, 533737) 1 A Methodist missionary 2 The report of the interview, corrected by Gandhiji, was returned with a covering letter dated March 26, 1908.
('8', 220, 0, 1, 533874) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 221
('8', 220, 1, 2, 533919) nothing to increase the community.
('8', 220, 2, 3, 533954) Q. Before the recent Registration Law was brought into force, what was the system of registration adopted?
('8', 220, 3, 4, 534061) A. There was no registration of the present kind in existence.
('8', 220, 3, 5, 534124) In 1885, the Dutch Government passed a law 1 dealing with immigration, but that law was not intended to restrict the immigration of Indians but it was meant to place a bar upon their trading.
('8', 220, 3, 6, 534316) At one time President Kruger passed a law imposing a prohibitive fee of £ 25 on every Indian who wished to trade in the country.
('8', 220, 3, 7, 534445) The technical wording of the Law was that any Indian desiring to trade should be registered and take out a receipt for £ 25. In consequence of representations made by the British Government the amount of the fee was subsequently reduced to £3. It will be seen that this Law simply imposed a trade tax on Indian traders, and was not a registration act applicable to Indians as a class.
('8', 220, 4, 8, 534830) A. But is not the present Act stated to be an amendment of the old Dutch Law to which you refer?
('8', 220, 5, 9, 534927) A. Yes, but my conviction is that this was done with a view to hoodwink the British public.
('8', 220, 5, 10, 535019) As a matter of fact the present Act differs in toto from the old Dutch Law.
('8', 220, 5, 11, 535095) That applied only to traders and did not touch the community as a class, this Act embraces all, without distinction, and aims not simply at registration but also at identifi cation.
('8', 220, 5, 12, 535277) The old Dutch Law did not aim at preventing Indian immig ration, neither did it concern itself with identification.
('8', 220, 5, 13, 535393) It merely required that all traders should register and contribute to the revenue by paying a specified fee.
('8', 220, 6, 14, 535502) Q. What is the system of permits and how long has it been in force?
('8', 220, 7, 15, 535570) A. After the conclusion of peace, an ordinance was passed to take the place of the procedure adopted under martial law, when every resident was more or less under supervision.
('8', 220, 7, 16, 535746) To replace martial law an ordinance called “the Peace Preservation Ordinance” was passed.
('8', 220, 7, 17, 535836) The preamble states that it was passed to check the entry of people of a dangerous character, who would be a menace to peace and good government, that is to say, it was aimed at disloyalists.
('8', 220, 7, 18, 536028) But later when a cry was raised against the immigration of Indians this Ordinance was effectively applied to that end.
('8', 220, 7, 19, 536147) When the Ordinance was passed it was designed to guard against the influx of undesirable people, but permits were granted freely to any British subject of whose good character they were satisfied, and to foreigners who could produce certificates from their Consuls.
('8', 220, 8, 20, 536413) 1 Law 3 of 1885
('8', 221, 0, 1, 536429) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 221, 1, 2, 536471) since this agitation against Indians has arisen, they have been singled out for exceptional treatment and required to give elaborate proof that they were in the country before the War, before a permit is granted.
('8', 221, 2, 3, 536684) Q. It has been stated that there had arisen a widespread traffic in the permits issued to Indians, and that there was an illicit influx of Asiatics on an organized scale which alarmed the authorities and necessitated the introduction of this severe measure.
('8', 221, 2, 4, 536942) Is this true?
('8', 221, 3, 5, 536956) A. This charge was made against our community and we approached the authorities and asked them for proofs.
('8', 221, 3, 6, 537063) 1 This they could not or would not give.
('8', 221, 3, 7, 537104) I admit that there was some traffic in permits going on, but behind the traffic, and regulating and profiting by it, were the officials of the Government.
('8', 221, 3, 8, 537259) The real facts are these —after the conclusion of peace a considerable number of Euro peans from the Volunteers were taken on by the Government and placed in positions of trust and responsibility.
('8', 221, 3, 9, 537456) It is not surprising that many proved themselves utterly unfitted for positions for which they had no previous training, and that some proved utterly untrustworthy, Several men of this class were appointed as supervisors of Asiatics.
('8', 221, 3, 10, 537690) They were given tremendous powers and they held the physical destiny of Indians in their hands.
('8', 221, 3, 11, 537786) They did not scruple to take full advantage of their positions for their own enrichment.
('8', 221, 3, 12, 537875) They inau gurated a regular system of traffic in permits, and either granted or transferred them at rates varying from £ 10 to £ 30. Where the carcass is, there the crows will gather, and when it became known that permits could be obtained for a consideration, Indians came to the Transvaal from Durban, Port Elizabeth, Cape Town and elsewhere.
('8', 221, 3, 13, 538220) Many of these had a perfect right to re enter but had to buy their permits.
('8', 221, 4, 14, 538296) Q. But why did not the respectable leaders of your community endeavour to stop the traffic?
('8', 221, 5, 15, 538388) A. They did.
('8', 221, 5, 16, 538401) When I returned from India in 1902 I found the traffic in full swing.
('8', 221, 5, 17, 538471) I then warned my fellow countrymen of what could be the results if the traffic was not stopped.
('8', 221, 5, 18, 538567) I came from India at that time specially to meet Mr. Joseph Chamberlain.
('8', 221, 5, 19, 538640) I brought the matter to the notice of Sir Arthur Lawley 2 but he would not listen, for he trusted his officers.
('8', 221, 5, 20, 538752) Three times I approached him with a view to stopping this abuse and on the third occasion I produced such proof that an enquiry was made and two officials were discharged on a technicality, but the evidence before Government was so clear that both officers were dismissed from service.
('8', 221, 5, 21, 539038) This illicit traffic had to be stopped, but it could have been done effectively without the legislation
('8', 221, 6, 22, 539142) 1Vide “ Triumph of Truth”, 8 2 1908 2 Lieutenant Governor at the time
('8', 222, 0, 1, 539212) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 223
('8', 222, 1, 2, 539257) recently introduced.
('8', 222, 1, 3, 539278) The authors of the malpractice, the active agents in carrying it out, and those who profited by it were these corrupt officials, but instead of using the power which existing laws placed at their disposal for dealing with the evil, the Government introduced an act directed against the whole Indian community.
('8', 222, 2, 4, 539588) Q. I gather then that you regard this Registration Act as unnecessary and based on assumptions which are untrue.
('8', 222, 3, 5, 539701) A. Certainly.
('8', 222, 3, 6, 539715) It proceeds on the assumption that every Indian has entered the country fraudulently, and treats his permits as invalid untilhe rehabilitates himself by producing before the Registrar evidence of his bonafides, which he can accept.
('8', 222, 3, 7, 539947) It invalidatestotally the Dutch registration certificates, for which a fee of £3 was paid, although it professes to be in harmony with the Law under which those certificates were granted.
('8', 222, 3, 8, 540135) It assumes that Turkish Mahomedans are less trustworthy than Turkish Christians and Jews, for it exempts the two latter classes from the provisions of the Act.
('8', 222, 3, 9, 540295) Thus, for these and other reasons, it has deeply offended both Hindus and Mahomedans.
('8', 222, 4, 10, 540381) Q. What other objections have you to urge against the Act?
('8', 222, 5, 11, 540440) A. First, it curtails our liberty in such a manner that no self respecting man, who has faith in God, could submit to it.
('8', 222, 5, 12, 540562) A man may, voluntarily and for the benefit of his community, submit to many restrictions, but in this case, the community gains nothing.
('8', 222, 5, 13, 540699) If any man submitted, it would be solely for the sake of gaining money.
('8', 222, 5, 14, 540771) Secondly, the distinction made between Turkish Mahomedans and Turkish Christians and Jews is most invidious.
('8', 222, 5, 15, 540880) They all come from the same social class and in many cases the Christians and Jews from Turkey are far lower in the social scale, yet they are exempted from the provisions of the Act.
('8', 222, 5, 16, 541064) Is it to be wondered at that the Mahomedans feel aggrieved?
('8', 222, 5, 17, 541124) Throughout the history of Colonial Government legislation, the Government have set their face firmly against class legislation except under very extraordinary circumstances.
('8', 222, 5, 18, 541298) The Australian Immigration Act was vetoed by Mr. Chamberlain because it was class legislation.
('8', 222, 5, 19, 541393) He would not allow the late Mr. Escombe, the Premier of Natal, to pass an act against Asiatics and he advised the Natal Ministry to introduce a general act, dealing with the evil they sought to remove not on the basis of colour, or religion, but on general grounds.
('8', 222, 5, 20, 541659) Yet the Imperial Government agreed to this Act which I regard as class legislation of a most virulent type.
('8', 222, 5, 21, 541767) Other objectionable features of the Act are the following.
('8', 222, 5, 22, 541826) Child ren under eight years have to be registered by their parents under a heavy penalty.
('8', 222, 5, 23, 541916) Those over eight years have to be taken before the
('8', 223, 0, 1, 541967) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 223, 1, 2, 542009) Registrar and made to give all identification particulars required of them.
('8', 223, 1, 3, 542085) On attaining the age of 16, they have to appear again before the Registrar and take out certificates.
('8', 223, 1, 4, 542187) I can only describe this as scientific torture.
('8', 223, 1, 5, 542235) Again, the method of identification adopted is the one pursued for the identification of criminals in this country.
('8', 223, 1, 6, 542351) No absolutely free men have ever been required to submit to such a process hitherto.
('8', 223, 1, 7, 542436) I may mention that probably in order to remove the objection which we Indians feel digit impressions have been made of general application under the Immigration Act.
('8', 223, 1, 8, 542602) This it is said will apply to Europeans as well as others, but this is manifestly an aftert hought and I doubt if it will be largely enforced.
('8', 223, 1, 9, 542745) You will not therefore be surprised that when the Act was passed, the Indians met and took a solemn oath that they would not submit to such a Law.
('8', 223, 2, 10, 542892) Q. What steps were taken to make the authorities acquainted with your objections to the Act?
('8', 223, 3, 11, 542985) A. The measure was published only a few days before it was to come up for discussion.
('8', 223, 3, 12, 543071) Immediately representatives of the Indian community sought an interview with Mr. Patrick Duncan, the Colonial Secretary 2, and I personally saw Sir Richard Solomon.
('8', 223, 3, 13, 543236) Mr. Duncan informed the deputation that they could discuss with him the details of the measure but not the principles, as the Government were committed to them.
('8', 223, 3, 14, 543397) The Indians then presented a petition to the Legislative Assembly.
('8', 223, 3, 15, 543464) That was pigeon holed and the Law was passed as it stood, with one important alteration.
('8', 223, 3, 16, 543553) The draft measure applied to Indian women as well as men.
('8', 223, 3, 17, 543611) This will show you how far they were prepared to go and how little those who drafted the Act understood Indian sentiment.
('8', 223, 3, 18, 543733) The measure was passed; then came the meeting in the Empire Theatre, when the community took an oath of passive resistance.
('8', 223, 3, 19, 543857) 3 A deputation was appointed to go to London to interview Lord Elgin 4. When they reached London they met with much sympathy from Anglo Indians, and the Press, including The Times, supported their cause.
('8', 223, 3, 20, 544061) Lord Elgin was alarmed, and said that after hearing all the facts he could not agree to the Act as it then stood, and accordingly it was then vetoed.
('8', 223, 3, 21, 544211) Then responsible government was granted, and their first
('8', 223, 4, 22, 544268) 1Vide “Mass Meeting at Pretoria”,6 7 1907 & Interview to “Rand Daily Mail”, 6 7 1907 2 On September 1, 1906; vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 8 9 1906 3 Ibid 4 Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1905 8.
('8', 224, 0, 1, 544468) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 225
('8', 224, 1, 2, 544513) act was to reintroduce this measure word for word.
('8', 224, 1, 3, 544564) The passing of the measure through both the Houses of the Legislature occupied about 48 hours.
('8', 224, 1, 4, 544659) 1 We Indians again petitioned, appealed by telegraph to the Home authorities, 2 interviewed General Smuts 3 but all was of no avail.
('8', 224, 1, 5, 544792) The measure received the Royal Assent.
('8', 224, 1, 6, 544831) 4 The Indian community again met and reaffirmed their vow of non compliance, and since then passive resistance has been going on.
('8', 224, 1, 7, 544961) 5 The registration offices were opened but only 500 Indians 6 submitted.
('8', 224, 2, 8, 545034) Q. What was the next step taken by Government?
('8', 224, 3, 9, 545081) A. The Government then passed the Immigrants Restriction Act.
('8', 224, 3, 10, 545143) 7 This act was of general application, but two clauses were incorporated in order to meet passive resisters.
('8', 224, 3, 11, 545252) Under the Registration Act Indians who did not submit to its requirements could be sent to jail for two years with hard labour, but under the Immigration Act, all Indians who did not submit to registration could be physically deported at their own cost, their chattels, if any, being sold to defray expenses.
('8', 224, 3, 12, 545561) The second clause provided that those Indians who were resident here, but did not submit to the Law, no matter of what standing they were, became “prohibited immigrants” and therefore subject to deporta tion.
('8', 224, 3, 13, 545770) This measure, instead of unmanning the Indians, nerved them for further struggle and they informed the Government that they would suffer deportation and confiscation of property but would not violate their conscience and break their oath.
('8', 224, 3, 14, 546009) Those Indians who could not stand the stress of the struggle went out of the country.
('8', 224, 3, 15, 546095) Many sold cut their businesses, others who remained here counter manded their orders for further supplies of goods, while yet others sold out and remained, living on their capital, in order to carry on the struggle.
('8', 224, 3, 16, 546311) The Government resorted to all kinds of methods to influence the Indians into compliance.
('8', 224, 3, 17, 546401) They dismissed their Indian employees in the post offices, railways, and other departments, and these in nearly every case accepted their dismissal rather than comply
('8', 224, 4, 18, 546568) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 30 3 1907 2 Ibid 3 On April 4, 1907 4 On May 7, 1907 5 On July 31, 1907 a meeting was held at Pretoria; vide “Speech at Pretoria”, 31 7 1907 & “Resolutions at Preetoria mass meeting”, 31 7 1907. 6 Out of 13,000 Indians only 511 had registered.
('8', 224, 4, 19, 546842) 7 Vide “Speech at Hamida Islamic Society”, 22 12 1907 & Speech at Hamidia Islamic Society”, 27 12 1907.

('8', 225, 1, 2, 546988) with the Act.
('8', 225, 1, 3, 547002) Then followed imprisonment 1 and nearly 200 Indians including myself and most of the leaders were put in jail, 2 and the licences of traders were stopped.
('8', 225, 1, 4, 547157) The utmost firmness was manifested by all classes of the community and even women came forward andheld meetings and informed Government that they were fully prepared to follow their husbands.
('8', 225, 2, 5, 547349) Q. What kind of treatment did you receive in prison?
('8', 225, 3, 6, 547402) A. The jail authorities did their best for us, but the treatment can only be described as inhuman.
('8', 225, 3, 7, 547501) We were treated as common felons and were put on a diet to which Indians are altogether unaccustomed, with the result that we were practically starved.
('8', 225, 3, 8, 547653) For breakfast we were given mealie meal, which is a porridge, all right for the natives of this country who have always been used to it, but to us it was most distasteful.
('8', 225, 3, 9, 547825) Many refused it altogether, others who took it rather than starve suffered from dysentery, etc.
('8', 225, 3, 10, 547921) In response to a petition, we were allowed four ounces of bread in lieu of the meal.
('8', 225, 3, 11, 548006) 3 This we had to eat without tea or coffee, only water was allowed.
('8', 225, 3, 12, 548074) For dinner we had four ounces of rice and one ounce of ghee.
('8', 225, 3, 13, 548135) For supper we were given eight ounces of bread three times a week, and three times we had haricot beans, without any accompaniment.
('8', 225, 3, 14, 548267) On Sundays we could have had meat if we desired, but as Hindus do not eat meat and Mahomedans cannot eat it unless the animals have been slain according to their own formula, the meat was not accepted.
('8', 225, 3, 15, 548469) In place of this we were allowed a double quantity of vegetables.
('8', 225, 3, 16, 548535) Asiatic prisoners are classed with Natives.
('8', 225, 3, 17, 548579) I do not object to this, but I claim that they should be supplied with food according to their customs.
('8', 225, 3, 18, 548683) The accommodation also was very bad.
('8', 225, 3, 19, 548720) The jail where we were housed has provision for only 51 prisoners, but when I was there, 151 4
('8', 225, 4, 20, 548815) had to be dealt with.
('8', 225, 4, 21, 548837) Tents were erected in an open space which provided sleeping accommodation for one hundred, but during the day time the whole 151 were crowded into a small yard, with the result that almost every day som e fainted away at the time of inspection.
('8', 225, 5, 22, 549082) Q. What is the nature of the compromise ultimately effected?

('8', 226, 1, 4, 549777) By mutual agreement, the form of registration has been altered.
('8', 226, 1, 5, 549841) If any man has scruples against giving his ten digits, he may give only his thumb mark.
('8', 226, 1, 6, 549929) The Pathans have done this and most of the Chinese.

('8', 226, 1, 9, 550193) The whole objection was against the spirit of the Act.

('8', 226, 1, 12, 550510) Registration on these terms is now going on rapidly and I anticipate that nearly all our community will comply.
('8', 226, 2, 13, 550622) Q. How was the settlement brought about?
('8', 226, 3, 14, 550663) A. The settlement was bought about largely through the intervention of Mr. Cartwright 3, the editor of The Transvaal Leader.

('8', 226, 3, 16, 550857) Having reason to believe that Government would be open to accept the original offer of voluntary registration, he came to me in the jail, and asked if we were still prepared to abide by our original proposal.
('8', 226, 3, 17, 551066) We said we were.
('8', 226, 3, 18, 551083) He then produced a draft letter which he had written to General Smuts embodying the proposal, and this letter with a few corrections I signed.
('8', 226, 3, 19, 551226) 4 After consultation with the leaders of the Progressive Party, and obtaining their consent, General Smuts sent for me 5. I left the jail, under police escort for Pretoria and there discussed the whole matter with General Smuts.

('8', 227, 2, 6, 552210) Q. What led to the murderous assault upon you?
('8', 227, 3, 7, 552257) A. I have already stated that at the meeting held after my return from Pretoria the Pathans refused to agree to the finger prints.
('8', 227, 3, 8, 552388) At a meeting held subsequently 2 they still protested and used threats.
('8', 227, 3, 9, 552460) I endeavoured to show them that the compromise was an honourable one.
('8', 227, 3, 10, 552530) We did not object to registration but to coercion and I expressed my determination to be the first to present myself at the registration office.
('8', 227, 3, 11, 552675) The Pathans threatened that the first Indian who attended for registration and to give finger prints would be killed.
('8', 227, 3, 12, 552793) Disregarding this threat many others and I set out 3 for the registration office and on the way, I was set upon by some Pathans, who aimed a blow at me, which was intended to be fatal.
('8', 227, 3, 13, 552978) It missed its mark but I received a severe gash on my face, and was rendered unconscious.
('8', 227, 3, 14, 553068) When I recovered I refused to bring a charge against my assailants, but the Government took the case up and two Pathans received three months’ imprisonment with hard labour.
('8', 227, 3, 15, 553242) Since then the Pathans themselves have registered, giving their single thumb prints, and I believe that everything will now work harmoniously.
('8', 227, 3, 16, 553385) I do not blame the Pathans.
('8', 227, 3, 17, 553413) To them finger prints was the Law.
('8', 227, 3, 18, 553448) They could, as they did, register without finger prints.
('8', 227, 3, 19, 553505) Suspicious by nature they could not understand why I should give ten digit prints.

('8', 229, 1, 2, 556061) 112. FIVE CRORES STARVING
('8', 229, 2, 3, 556087) Cables from India report Lord Minto as having said in a speech that, owing to the famine in Central India, five crores of people were faced with the prospect of starvation, and that if no relief was provided, they would simply die off [for want of food grains].
('8', 229, 2, 4, 556349) Is there any Indian who did not shudder at this news or whose heart did not cry out?
('8', 229, 2, 5, 556434) However, some of us may have felt that there is nothing that we can do from this distance.
('8', 229, 2, 6, 556525) Others may have thought that, in a situa tion such as this, they could not have helped matters much even if they had been in India.
('8', 229, 2, 7, 556657) Since the calamity is the result of a goddess’s wrath, they feel helpless.
('8', 229, 2, 8, 556732) There must also be some who blame this on the British Government.
('8', 229, 2, 9, 556798) We think that all these persons are wrong.
('8', 229, 2, 10, 556841) It is a common habit to point to the faults of others and not to see one’s own.
('8', 229, 2, 11, 556921) Others’ mistakes attract ready attention.
('8', 229, 2, 12, 556963) Let us, however, go dee per into the question.
('8', 229, 2, 13, 557010) We are convinced that, though this condition is undoubtedly the result of divine will, the blame lies with us, our chief fault being that we have very little truth in us.
('8', 229, 2, 14, 557181) It is generally from experience that the whites accuse us of untruthfulness Not all of them accuse us out of malice.
('8', 229, 2, 15, 557298) We are annoyed by the charge.
('8', 229, 2, 16, 557328) It instead of feeling annoyed, we look at the matter in the right perspective and ponder over it, we may derive much profit.
('8', 229, 2, 17, 557453) The Indians here are not very different from those at home.
('8', 229, 2, 18, 557513) If we take examples from the Transvaal or Natal, we shall find that untruthfulness is spreading among us.
('8', 229, 2, 19, 557619) This untruthfulness does us dramage.
('8', 229, 2, 20, 557656) Instead of getting rid of the habit we fight the Government and inveigh against it When the Government adopts extreme measures, we are Admittedly left with no choice but to fight.
('8', 229, 2, 21, 557836) But fighting the Government will not by itself bring us happiness It is necessary that we fight ourselves.
('8', 229, 2, 22, 557943) We must overcome this habit of deceitfulness.
('8', 229, 2, 23, 557989) In our private lives we behave as we do with the Government.
('8', 229, 2, 24, 558050) The result is that we become cowardly and, in order to cover up our cowardice, we resort to deception and hypocrisy at every turn.
('8', 229, 2, 25, 558181) In Natal, we spend any amount of money to obtain trading licences by underhand means, but we will not observe cleanniness, which is the thing necessary.
('8', 229, 2, 26, 558334) There are very few Indians who deserve trading licences on merits.
('8', 229, 2, 27, 558401) In the Transvaal everyone thinks only of self interest They must have a permit by Sir means or but As many children as possible must
('8', 230, 0, 1, 558534) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 231
('8', 230, 1, 2, 558579) be brought into the Colony.
('8', 230, 1, 3, 558607) This avidity [to have all one wants] X, to be sure, a source of evil.
('8', 230, 1, 4, 558677) These are examples which are easy to follow.
('8', 230, 1, 5, 558722) Many other instances of falsehood can be cited.
('8', 230, 1, 6, 558770) Some readers may wonder what the connection is between fraudulent practice in relation to permits in the Transvaal and trading licences in Natal on the one hand and famine on the other.
('8', 230, 1, 7, 558956) That we do not perceive this connection is in itself an error.
('8', 230, 1, 8, 559019) Our examples are only symptoms of a chronic disease within us.
('8', 230, 1, 9, 559082) We are sure that, as long as they remain addicted to cheating and deception, Indians will never be rid of their troubles.
('8', 230, 1, 10, 559204) It would be a great and true help indeed it instead of sending money from here or being useful.
('8', 230, 1, 11, 559300) in some other way, a reformed ourselves and learnt to be truthful.
('8', 230, 1, 12, 559367) If the Indians here observe truth in word and deed and behave with courage, that cannot but have some effect in India.
('8', 230, 1, 13, 559486) Pain in any part of the body is felt by the mind.
('8', 230, 1, 14, 559536) The healthy condition of a part Was a benign effect [on the whole].
('8', 230, 1, 15, 559604) Similarly, good or bad actions of individuals have a corresponding effect on a whole people.
('8', 230, 1, 16, 559697) We believe this to be a divine law, and if our readers agree that it is so, we think the only real help the kind hearted among the Indians can render to their country is to take the path of truthfulness immediately after reading the heart rending account of starvation among five crores of Indians.
('8', 230, 1, 17, 559996) This is admittedly a difficult step to take.
('8', 230, 1, 18, 560041) But it is also a very effective one.
('8', 230, 1, 19, 560078) After a little reflection, anyone will realize that this is the only solution.
('8', 230, 1, 20, 560157) [From Gujrati] Indian Opinion, 28 3 1908
('8', 230, 2, 21, 560198) 113. MY EXPERIENCE IN GOAL [ IV]
('8', 230, 3, 22, 560231) PATIENTS
('8', 230, 4, 23, 560240) It would have been surprising if not one among 150 of us had been taken ill.
('8', 230, 4, 24, 560317) The first casualty was Samunder Khan.
('8', 230, 4, 25, 560355) He was ill even when he came to gaol and so was removed to hospital the day after his arrival.
('8', 230, 4, 26, 560450) Mr. Karwa had an attack of rheumatism.
('8', 230, 4, 27, 560489) for some the doctor treated him with ointment, etc., in the gaol.
('8', 230, 4, 28, 560555) But later, he, too, was admitted to hospital.
('8', 230, 4, 29, 560601) Two other prisoners fell sick and were removed to hospital.
('8', 230, 4, 30, 560661) Since it was hot and the prisoners were exposed to the sun outside some of them fell sick occasionally.
('8', 230, 4, 31, 560765) They were treated as well as they could be [in goal].
('8', 230, 4, 32, 560819) Towards the end, Mr. Nawab Khan was also taken ill and, the day of his release, he had to be helped to walk.

('8', 231, 3, 5, 561098) I mentioned earlier that our ward could accommodate 51 prisoners.
('8', 231, 3, 6, 561164) The yard in front had the same capacity.

('8', 239, 1, 2, 579912) 115. EGYPT’S FAMOUS LEADER [ I ]
('8', 239, 2, 3, 579945) THE LATE MUSTAFA KAMAL PASHA
('8', 239, 3, 4, 579974) Mustafa Kamal Pasha, the famous leader, died in February last in Cairo at the early age of 33. We publish below his life sketch culled from Egyptian newspapers.
('8', 239, 3, 5, 580135) He was born in 1874. His education started at the age of six.
('8', 239, 3, 6, 580197) After a few years’ study [at home], he joined a school in Cairo, established in the memory of the well known Abbas Pasha.
('8', 239, 3, 7, 580319) His father, Ali Effendi Mahomed, who was Chief Engineer to the Government, died about this time.
('8', 239, 3, 8, 580416) Mustafa Kamal Pasha passed the primary school examination at the age of ten, standing first.
('8', 239, 3, 9, 580509) Four years later, he passed the secondary school examination, distinguishing himself as a gifted and intelligent student.
('8', 239, 3, 10, 580631) At the age of 15, he started studying law and French.

('8', 242, 1, 2, 586340) 118. LORD SELBORNE’S VIEW
('8', 242, 2, 3, 586366) Lord Selborne’s speech at Klerksdorp on the Indian question deserves to be pondered by every Indian.
('8', 242, 2, 4, 586467) We print a translation of it elsewhere.
('8', 242, 2, 5, 586507) The burden of Lord Selborne’s speech is that Indians and other Asiatic races should be kept out from areas reserved for whites.
('8', 242, 2, 6, 586635) They may settle in districts to be specially set apart for them.
('8', 242, 2, 7, 586700) As to how they can be prevented from settling in areas reserved for whites, he suggests that, since Indians are British subjects and a cowardly [people], they can be treated as one pleases.
('8', 242, 2, 8, 586890) But there remain the Japanese and the Chinese.
('8', 242, 2, 9, 586937) The British Navy ought to be strengthened to keep these out.
('8', 242, 2, 10, 586998) Among countries to be reserved for the whites, Lord Selborne mentions South Africa, Australia, America, New Zealand, etc.
('8', 242, 2, 11, 587120) He concedes that the Indians should be allowed facilities for colonization, and suggestion gests that Colonies in East Africa may be set apart for them.
('8', 242, 2, 12, 587273) 1 them.
('8', 242, 2, 13, 587281) On reflection we see that this would mean perpetual slavery for Indians, for, if Indians settle in regions such as East Africa, even there the whites will have the upper hand.
('8', 242, 2, 14, 587457) The whites will have found a new training ground or stepping stone.
('8', 242, 2, 15, 587525) Moreover, Indians are in capable of settling by themselves in a country and developing it along modern lines.
('8', 242, 2, 16, 587635) The suggestion therefore that certain areas be earmarked for Indians is without point altogether.
('8', 242, 2, 17, 587733) Lord Selborne’s speech also implies that no regions where the climate is congenial to white settlers should be reserved for Indians.
('8', 242, 2, 18, 587866) In other words, Indians should only be allotted swampy and malarial regions.
('8', 242, 2, 19, 587943) Lord Selborne will not mind Indians languishing in these areas.
('8', 242, 2, 20, 588007) We regard Lord Selborne’s speech as utterly selfish and dangerous.
('8', 242, 2, 21, 588074) If he had his way, not a single Indian would be left in South Africa.
('8', 242, 2, 22, 588144) He believes that East and West can never meet.
('8', 242, 2, 23, 588191) If this view is correct, India can have a place in the British Empire only as a subject country.
('8', 242, 2, 24, 588288) No other way is open to her.
('8', 242, 2, 25, 588317) We do not subscribe to this view.
('8', 242, 2, 26, 588351) If it is proved that the British people share this view and that there can be no alternative to it, we shall be compelled to raise our banner against British rule.
('8', 242, 2, 27, 588515) It will then be necessary to adopt, and to help others adopt, the means to free India totally from British rule.
('8', 242, 2, 28, 588628) But we believe that we can still enjoy freedom by continuing to live under the British flag.
('8', 242, 2, 29, 588721) The Boers live under the British flag, and are none the less free for that.
('8', 242, 3, 30, 588797) 1 Lionel Curtis made a similar suggestion in 1906; vide “Interview to The Natal Mercury”, 7 5 1907

('8', 243, 1, 2, 588938) We should therefore consider what measures to be adopted to counter [the influence of] Lord Selborne’s ideas.
('8', 243, 1, 3, 589048) The remedy, we believe, lies in our own hands.
('8', 243, 1, 4, 589095) We find that in this world we generally get what we demand and deserve.

('8', 248, 1, 13, 602626) He missed no opportunity of emphasizing the need for more intimate contacts between the peoples of the West and the East.

('8', 249, 3, 8, 604761) HAMIDIA SOCIETY’S LETTER
('8', 249, 4, 9, 604786) The Hamidia [Islamic] Society has sent an address of thanks to several persons abroad who helped in the struggle against the law.
('8', 249, 4, 10, 604916) The address is printed in gold, red and yellow on thick card of superior quality with the edges trimmed decoratively.
('8', 249, 4, 11, 605034) About 200 copies will be posted.
('8', 249, 4, 12, 605067) It is signed by Imam Abdool Kadir.
('8', 249, 4, 13, 605102) Fancy and Mr. Coovadia.
('8', 249, 4, 14, 605126) Here is a translation of the address 1:
('8', 249, 5, 15, 605166) DEAR SIR,
('8', 249, 6, 16, 605176) On behalf of the Hamidia Islamic Society, we beg to tender you our best thanks for the very warm interest you have taken in the British Indian cause in the Transvaal, and for the prompt response you have always made to our Society’s appeal for help.
('8', 249, 6, 17, 605426) We have no doubt that your advocacy contributed materially to the happy issue of the struggle which taxed the utmost resources of the community.
('8', 249, 6, 18, 605571) The Asiatic Act specially affected the Mahomedan commu nity in that it deliberately insulted Islam by distinguishing against Turkish Mahomedans and in favour of other Turkish subjects.
('8', 249, 6, 19, 605756) It was, therefore, natural that this Society should have made a special effort to secure the repeal of the Act, and it has been to our Society a matter of very great satisfaction that our appeal made to Mahomedans and others has been so favourably received.
('8', 249, 7, 20, 606014) 1 The English text is from Indian Opinion 18 4 1908.

('8', 250, 2, 7, 606385) “THE GOLD LAW” The Government has published a draft Bill for a law about mines in the Transvaal.
('8', 250, 2, 8, 606482) The law is commonly known as “The Gold Law”.
('8', 250, 2, 9, 606527) The Government intends to get it passed during the next ses sion of Parliament.
('8', 250, 2, 10, 606607) The draft Bill has reference to the existing Gold Law but some of thesections bearing on Coloured persons, which were ambiguous, will now bear a construction unfavourable to them.
('8', 250, 2, 11, 606787) The Government had, under the present law, refused to issue licences in Johannesburg and other cities.
('8', 250, 2, 12, 606890) The readers of Indian Opinion may recall the case at Roodepoort.
('8', 250, 2, 13, 606955) Owing to the ambiguity the law] the Government did not persist in its stand.
('8', 250, 2, 14, 607032) If the draft Bill referred to above is passed, it will prevent Indians not only from obtaining licences in mining areas but also from residing in them.
('8', 250, 2, 15, 607184) That is to say, in the mining areas, Indians and other Coloured races can live only in the Location.
('8', 250, 2, 16, 607285) The noteworthy sections in the Bill.
('8', 250, 2, 17, 607322) I am sending a sum mary There are other noteworthy for the English section.
('8', 250, 2, 18, 607398) But the point most worthy of note is the one I have mentioned.
('8', 250, 2, 19, 607461) It will be necessary for the Indian community to put up a stiff fight against this law.
('8', 250, 2, 20, 607549) A journal in England has already come out in our favour.
('8', 250, 2, 21, 607606) But the opposition [to the law] will inspire respect only when we do all that is required of us.
('8', 250, 2, 22, 607703) The Indian community will continue to be the target of such attacks.

('8', 250, 2, 24, 607855) PERFECT JUSTICE Some Kaffirs have bought land in their own names in Sophia town and settled there.
('8', 250, 2, 25, 607954) The sites are situated within municipal limits.
('8', 250, 2, 26, 608002) According to the municipal regulations, no Kaffir can live outside the Location without permission.
('8', 250, 2, 27, 608102) These Kaffirs were prosecuted by the municipality under the regulations.
('8', 250, 2, 28, 608175) The Magistrate fined them.
('8', 250, 2, 29, 608202) The Kaffirs went in appeal, and won.
('8', 250, 2, 30, 608239) The Supreme Court has held that it is ultra vires of the municipality to frame a regulation for Kaffirs.
('8', 250, 3, 31, 608344) 1 In fact, one of the judges remarked that, while the law might be on the side of the municipality, the equities were all on the side of the appellants.
('8', 250, 3, 32, 608497) The Court, however, gave no ruling on this point and set aside the conviction on the ground that “the resolution fixing the date was never promulgated by publication in the Gazette or in any other way”.

('8', 253, 1, 10, 613594) According to pre 1900 census figures, there were at least 100,000 lepers in India.

('8', 256, 4, 15, 621457) FREEDOM FOR BLACKS TO DRINK
('8', 256, 5, 16, 621485) There is a movement in Pretoria against prohibition among Coloured persons.
('8', 256, 5, 17, 621561) According to newspaper reports, there is a person named Cassi who plays a leading part in this movement.
('8', 256, 5, 18, 621666) Meetings have been held at Pretoria on this question.
('8', 256, 5, 19, 621720) A petition to the Transvaal Government has been drafted.
('8', 256, 5, 20, 621777) The petition argues that Coloured persons can get liquor despite the prohibidon.
('8', 256, 5, 21, 621858) A large number of whites exploit the situation to fleece the people.
('8', 256, 5, 22, 621927) Since Coloured persons do in any case drink on the sly, it would be better to let them do so openly.
('8', 256, 5, 23, 622028) Being obliged to drink surreptitiously, they gulp down whatever they can lay hands on and get drunk.

('8', 264, 1, 2, 639767) 134. NATAL GOVERNOR AND INDIANS
('8', 264, 2, 3, 639799) For the first time after assuming office the Natal Governor has spoken on the Indian question.
('8', 264, 2, 4, 639894) Speaking at the annual conference of the Natal Agricultural Union, he suggested that they should depend more on Kaffir than on Indian labour; otherwise, he added, it would not be possible to treat the Asiatics already in the country with that fairness which it was in the white man’s nature to extend to other, weaker races.
('8', 264, 2, 5, 640219) This speech gives rise to two thoughts.
('8', 264, 2, 6, 640259) Examining its impli cations we see that [ultimately] it is in the interests of the Indians that the Governor has spoken.
('8', 264, 2, 7, 640380) He has warned the whites that, if the Indian immigration continues, Natal will eventually come to be dominated by them.
('8', 264, 2, 8, 640500) Let us thank Sir Mathew Nathan for wanting to do justice by the Indians.
('8', 264, 2, 9, 640573) But duty demands that we look at both sides of a question, the good and the bad, and weigh the two.
('8', 264, 2, 10, 640673) We must not be elated and swept off our feet by the good that we may expect to find.
('8', 264, 2, 11, 640758) Equally, we must not give way to despair and anger.
('8', 264, 2, 12, 640810) Looking at the Indian question from this point of view, we find that the concluding words of the Governor’s speech are not justified by facts.
('8', 264, 2, 13, 640953) He says that it is in the nature of the whites to deal fairly with other, weaker races.
('8', 264, 2, 14, 641041) This implies that Indians are weak and will remain so, at least for some time to come.
('8', 264, 2, 15, 641128) The whites have always done justice and will go on doing it, for the present at any rate.
('8', 264, 2, 16, 641218) We shall not blame him for assuming the Indians to be weak, for we have become weak and are content to remain so.
('8', 264, 2, 17, 641332) People are bound to point their [accusing] finger at us.
('8', 264, 2, 18, 641389) But the Governor had no right to place such views before the whites.
('8', 264, 2, 19, 641458) It was unbecoming of him to have done so.
('8', 264, 2, 20, 641500) We have been further degraded in their eyes.
('8', 264, 2, 21, 641545) The remedy, however, is in our own hands.
('8', 264, 2, 22, 641587) We were weak but are not so any longer, and even if we are, we must resolve not to remain weak.
('8', 264, 2, 23, 641683) Being strong, we shall fight for our rights and our honour.

('8', 267, 2, 5, 647414) 137. IMPORTANT CASE AT THE CAPE
('8', 267, 3, 6, 647446) Impelled by the reports in newspapers of the case against four Indian boys in the Cape, we called for a special report through Reuter.
('8', 267, 3, 7, 647581) The following is the substance of the telegram we have received.
('8', 267, 3, 8, 647646) We believe our readers will be happy to read this correct version.
('8', 267, 3, 9, 647713) Often English papers do not report the full news in such cases.
('8', 267, 3, 10, 647777) Calling for a special message puts us to some extra expense but we thereby discover important facts.
('8', 267, 3, 11, 647878) We therefore intend in future to follow this practice whenever necessary.
('8', 267, 3, 12, 647952) The Reuter message says that the authorities refused the four boys permission to land.
('8', 267, 3, 13, 648039) Their case was that, since their parents were domiciled in the Cape and since they themselves were under sixteen, they were entitled to be admitted.
('8', 267, 3, 14, 648188) Four doctors testified that the boys were above sixteen.
('8', 267, 3, 15, 648245) Seven doctors Dr. Curry among them—deposed that they were under sixteen.
('8', 267, 3, 16, 648318) Dr. Curry said in his evidence that he had had a good deal of experience [of conditions] in India.
('8', 267, 3, 17, 648417) The Mahomedans in the area to which the boys belonged were known to possess a good physique.
('8', 267, 3, 18, 648510) The doctor therefore concluded that, the boys being Mahomedans, they had the sort of physique one would expect of boys under sixteen.
('8', 267, 3, 19, 648644) The Supreme Court accepted this evidence and ordered that the boys be permitted to land.

('8', 273, 1, 2, 660410) 141. EGYPT’S FAMOUS LEADER [ IV]
('8', 273, 2, 3, 660443) Here are some of the facts about the Nationalist Party founded by Mustafa Kamal Pasha.
('8', 273, 2, 4, 660530) A huge meeting was held in December last, attended by about a thousand sympathizers, to found the Nationalist Party.
('8', 273, 2, 5, 660647) Of the reso lutions passed at the meeting, the first appointed Mustafa Kamal Pasha the leader of the party during his lifetime.
('8', 273, 2, 6, 660775) Provision was made for a meeting to be held within ten days of his death for the purpose of electing a new leader.
('8', 273, 2, 7, 660890) Also a congress of the members of the Nation alist Party was to be held annually, at which an executive committee was to be elected.
('8', 273, 2, 8, 661023) A sub committee of eight members elected from it was to meet weekly.
('8', 273, 2, 9, 661092) The Party’s views have spread throughout the Nile valley thanks to newspapers and speeches.
('8', 273, 2, 10, 661184) The more well to do members of the Party have started schools at their own expense, which widely dissemi nate the party’s principles.
('8', 273, 2, 11, 661318) The object of the Party is to secure the establishment of an Egyptian Parliament.
('8', 273, 2, 12, 661400) It will continue to hold a general congress every year till this object is achieved and will more over do all it can to enable the people to defend their rights and to advance themselves.
('8', 273, 2, 13, 661588) The British Government cannot stop the Nationalist Party because the party is wise enough not to encourage acts of violence.
('8', 273, 2, 14, 661713) Addressing a 6,000 strong meeting Mustafa Kamal Pasha decla red that his party would work to open the eyes of the Egyptian people to their present conditions, foster political consciousness in them and promote peace and unity between the two sections of Egyptian.
('8', 273, 2, 15, 661977) society.
('8', 273, 2, 16, 661986) The main object of the Nationalist Party was to see that the administration was entrusted to the people’s representatives, who would be responsible to a sovereign parliament constituted on the European model; also, Egypt should enjoy complete freedom (from British control) in its internal administration.

('8', 274, 1, 2, 662379) 142. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY 1
('8', 274, 2, 3, 662415) [JOHANNESBURG, Before April 25, 1908] THE HON’BLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('8', 274, 3, 4, 662497) SIR, I have been desired by the Committee of my Association to approach the Government regarding the Draft Gold Law which the Government intend to introduce during the forthcoming session of Parliament In the humble opinion of my Committee, the Draft [law] imposes on British Indians disabilities graver than those found in the existing law.
('8', 274, 3, 5, 662839) My Committee had hoped, as it still hopes, that the legal disabilities of the community represented by it would be lightened by the Government instead of their being increased.
('8', 274, 3, 6, 663016) My Committee desired me specifically to draw the attention of the Government to the following: 1. The Draft retains in the definition of the term “Coloured per son” the word “coolie” which, as applied to the present Indian population of the Colony, is an offensive term, there being in the Transvaal very few, if any, coolies in the proper sense of the term.
('8', 274, 3, 7, 663375) Moreover, the bracketing together African natives and Asiatics, British subjects and non British subject 2, is to ignore the peculiar position occupied by British Indian.
('8', 274, 3, 8, 663546) 2. The retention of the original law as to dealing in unwrou ght gold, in so far as it specially affects Coloured people besides their coming tinder the general prohibitions of the law, assumes that Colou red people are the greater offenders in respect of dealing in unwrou ght gold, whereas in the opinion of my Association the contrary is the fact in so far as British Indians are concerned.
('8', 274, 3, 9, 663940) 3. Moreover, the definition of unwrought gold probably pre vents Indian goldsmiths from carrying on their business of manufact uring jewellery even out of gold bars prepared in and imported from England.
('8', 274, 3, 10, 664144) This, it will be readily admitted, is a grievous hardship for the goldsmiths in question.
('8', 274, 4, 11, 664234) 1 This letter was republished in Indian Opinion, 25 4 1908, under the title “The Draft Gold Law of the Transvaal: An Important Letter of Protest”.
('8', 274, 4, 12, 664381) 2 Residents of the Transvaal who were not subjects of the British Empire
('8', 275, 0, 1, 664454) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 275, 1, 2, 664496) 4. Section 127 of the draft law is, it is submitted, rather vague and seems to contemplate entire prohibition of acquisition by Coloured people of any rights under it.
('8', 275, 1, 3, 664664) The prohibition, under the same section, to holders of rights acquired previous to the draft law, to transfer or sub let such right[s] to a Coloured person makes the law retrospective in its effect.
('8', 275, 1, 4, 664863) 5. Finally, section 128 which contemplates the compulsory segrega tion of Coloured people residing within proclaimed areas, would, if carried, make it impossible for a large majority of British Indians even to remain in the country.
('8', 275, 1, 5, 665096) In this connection, my Committee begs respectfully to remind the Government that my Association represents a people who claim to belong to a cultured stock in the human family, and trading and other interests which are sufficiently large to warrant the statement that the segregation of the Indian community means utter ruination to it from sheer inability to protect those interests in Bazaars, Locations or Com pounds.
('8', 275, 1, 6, 665517) My Com mittee further reminds the Government that the majority of British Indians domiciled in the Transvaal live within the mining areas.
('8', 275, 1, 7, 665656) My Committee therefore respectfully trusts that the clauses complained of will be with drawn by the Government or will be so amended as to give the desired relief to the British Indian com munity residing in the Transvaal.
('8', 275, 2, 8, 665879) I [am] e t c .
('8', 275, 2, 9, 665894) , ESSOP ISMAIL MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION

('8', 275, 4, 11, 666007) 143. FINE ON INDIANS
('8', 275, 5, 12, 666028) On an earlier occasion we wrote about the Report 1 of the Natal Immigration Department.
('8', 275, 5, 13, 666116) We now have with us a copy of the full report.
('8', 275, 5, 14, 666163) As we read it, other thoughts occur to us.
('8', 275, 5, 15, 666206) Last year, Indians paid a sum of £2,666.1.0 to the Natal Treasury [as fees] for domicile certificates, etc.
('8', 275, 5, 16, 666314) Of this amount, £979.10.0 was for domicile passes, £631 for visiting passes and £l,036 for embarkation passes.
('8', 275, 5, 17, 666425) In addition, £120 was forfeited for breach of the conditions under which visiting passes are issued.
('8', 275, 5, 18, 666526) Last year a large amount was collected in this manner from a small number of Indians.
('8', 275, 6, 19, 666612) 1 For a summary of the Report.
('8', 276, 0, 1, 666643) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 277
('8', 276, 1, 2, 666688) Most of thepasses cost £1 each.
('8', 276, 1, 3, 666720) We may therefore take it that this sum was realized from about 2,500 Indians.
('8', 276, 1, 4, 666798) What can we do to avoid such loss of money?
('8', 276, 1, 5, 666842) It is important that we ask ourselves this question and try to find a solution.
('8', 276, 1, 6, 666922) One way out is for Indians to be bold enough to disregard the laws and do without passes altogether.
('8', 276, 1, 7, 667023) This course is open only to those domiciled [in Natal].
('8', 276, 1, 8, 667079) What about those who want to come in for a temporary stay?
('8', 276, 1, 9, 667138) This question is rather more difficult to answer.
('8', 276, 1, 10, 667188) But human ingenuity can find a way out of any difficulty.
('8', 276, 1, 11, 667246) It is necessary to keep on at the Government about this subject.
('8', 276, 1, 12, 667311) The Government should be told that a large enough revenue accrues to it from the railways on account of the immigrants.
('8', 276, 1, 13, 667431) Next, businessmen may begin educating themselves as well as they can.
('8', 276, 1, 14, 667501) If they become conversant with the English language, they will gradually be able to spare themselves the expense discussed above.
('8', 276, 1, 15, 667631) And lastly, the practice of cheating the Government should be given up.
('8', 276, 1, 16, 667703) This last remedy is the most honest and efficacious.
('8', 276, 1, 17, 667756) The Report also reveals that 3,236 Asiatics were refused permission to land and compelled to return.
('8', 276, 1, 18, 667857) Not all of them had arrived by the sea route [from India].
('8', 276, 1, 19, 667916) Some of them came through the Transvaal.
('8', 276, 1, 20, 667957) Much money, therefore, must have been wasted in trying to enter the Transvaal.
('8', 276, 1, 21, 668036) The remedy for this state of affairs at any rate lies in our hands alone.
('8', 276, 1, 22, 668110) If we spend on education even a tenth of what we spend on questionable transactions, the prejudice that we find in South Africa against the black skin will disappear.

('8', 277, 2, 7, 669577) 145. NATAL FARMERS
('8', 277, 3, 8, 669596) A heated controversy is raging among the Natal farmers over the question of ending immigration of indentured Indian labour.
('8', 277, 3, 9, 669720) The white farmers are agitated over the attitude of the Durban whites who are opposed to such immigration.
('8', 277, 3, 10, 669827) The farmers have passed a resolu tion at a conference which they held recently, saying that the supply of indentured Indian labour should not be stopped until Native labour becomes available.
('8', 277, 3, 11, 670019) Let us see what attitude the Natal Government will take up in this tug of war.
('8', 277, 3, 12, 670098) We must be on our guard and make sure that this contest between two buffaloes, that is, the Durban whites and the white farmers, does not uproot the Indian tree.
('8', 277, 4, 13, 670260) One of the farmers also argued at the conference that it was not the indentured labourers with whom the Durban whites were aggri eved.
('8', 277, 4, 14, 670395) They only wanted to stop the Indian trader, but they could not differentiate between the traders and indentured Indians.
('8', 277, 4, 15, 670516) These pro nouncements show that it is not because the white farmers are ena moured of Indian labourers that they prefer them.
('8', 277, 4, 16, 670642) Theirs is an attach ment arising only from self interest.
('8', 277, 4, 17, 670700) We should note that, in the pur suit of their common interests, the white traders and the white farmers will not hesitate to ruin the Indian trader.
('8', 277, 4, 18, 670849) By fighting the system of indenture, the Indian community will serve the Indian trader and ensure, at the same time, freedom from slavery for indentured labour ers.
('8', 277, 4, 19, 671014) We must not acquiesce in the coming of Indians to work as slaves.

('8', 278, 1, 2, 671261) 146. CAPE IMMIGRATION ACT 1
('8', 278, 2, 3, 671289) Last week we wrote on the case in the Cape.
('8', 278, 2, 4, 671333) We have now received a full report of it, which we publish in the English section.
('8', 278, 2, 5, 671416) Another case, a more important one, under the Immigration Act, was also heard in the same Court.
('8', 278, 2, 6, 671513) In the first case the Court did not give its ruling on the point of law [that was raised].
('8', 278, 2, 7, 671604) In the second it did, and its judgment applies to all Indians in the Cape.
('8', 278, 2, 8, 671679) The following is a summary [of the case].
('8', 278, 2, 9, 671721) An Indian 2 was prohibited from disembarking and he moved the Supreme Court.
('8', 278, 2, 10, 671798) Under the Immigration Act of 1902, Indians domi ciled in South Africa were free to enter the Cape; this Indian came un der that category.
('8', 278, 2, 11, 671936) Under the Act of 1906, however, only those Indians who are domiciled in the Cape can settle there.
('8', 278, 2, 12, 672035) On the other hand, whites anywhere from South Africa are free [to enter].
('8', 278, 2, 13, 672109) But there is a loop hole in the Act of 1906, namely, that an Indian who leaves the Cape must if he is entitled to return, carry with him a pass for exit and re entry.
('8', 278, 2, 14, 672276) 3 It was the contention of the prosecution that the Indian in question had not taken out such a pass and had accordingly forfeited his right.
('8', 278, 2, 15, 672418) The contention was accepted by the Supreme Court.
('8', 278, 2, 16, 672468) While delivering the judgment, the Court expressed sympathy with the Indian and recommended that the Government deal with the case leniently for the reason that he had failed to take out the pass for re entry out of ignorance and that the lapse might therefore be condo ned.
('8', 278, 2, 17, 672743) 4 The consideration shown by the Court is to be welcomed.
('8', 278, 2, 18, 672801) How ever, what the Indian community wants is not leniency under an unjust law; the leniency should be incorporated in the law itself.
('8', 278, 2, 19, 672935) [No,] it is not even lenient laws that the community asks for; it will suffice if the laws are just.
('8', 278, 2, 20, 673036) It is imperative that the law should be amended.
('8', 278, 2, 21, 673085) It will be well if the Cape leaders take this stand and work accordingly.
('8', 278, 2, 22, 673159) We are sure that, if the leaders wrote to the South Africa British Indian Committee in England, they would receive excellent help.
('8', 278, 2, 23, 673290) The Committee cannot

('8', 279, 3, 6, 673938) 147. SUGGESTIONS TO CAPE INDIANS
('8', 279, 4, 7, 673971) The South African News has published a report of a meeting of the Cape Town British Indian League.
('8', 279, 4, 8, 674070) 1 We find someone has sent us a cutting for publication in the English [section].
('8', 279, 4, 9, 674152) We have decided not to publish it, for we do not see that its publication will be of any advantage to the community.
('8', 279, 4, 10, 674269) We know that the English section is read by a large number of decent whites.
('8', 279, 4, 11, 674346) That report is not likely to make a very good impression on their minds.
('8', 279, 4, 12, 674419) The headline under which the League report is published in The South African News says that it is not the journal’s own report, but was sent to it by someone and was being pub lished at his request.
('8', 279, 4, 13, 674618) The report deals with an attack [by the League] on the South Africa British Indian Association.
('8', 279, 4, 14, 674714) We have no knowledge of how the affairs of the Association are conducted, whether or not there is anything wrong with it.
('8', 279, 4, 15, 674836) The discussion at the League meeting may or may not have any basis in fact.
('8', 279, 4, 16, 674912) The point we wish to make is that by publicizing these matters in English journals we shall not promote the interests of the community but shall only create bad blood.
('8', 279, 4, 17, 675080) They also create a misleading impression in the minds of those who are prejudi ced against the Indians, and serve to strengthen their prejudice.
('8', 279, 4, 18, 675225) Indians have no time for bickering among themselves.
('8', 279, 4, 19, 675278) The task before the community is to fight its permanent enemy, and to bend all its energies to that end.
('8', 279, 4, 20, 675383) It is to be welcomed that the League has taken steps against the immigration law.
('8', 279, 4, 21, 675465) It is the League’s duty to do all that needs to be do ne in this matter.
('8', 279, 4, 22, 675538) But in doing so it will not be proper for the League to make public attacks on the Association there or on other bodies.
('8', 279, 5, 23, 675659) 1 The meeting, held on April 12, was called to consider the complaints of some Kanamia Muslims who were dissatisfied with the affairs of the South Africa British Indian Association in the Cape.

('8', 280, 3, 5, 676270) The condition of Indians in Canada deserves notice.

('8', 280, 3, 7, 676398) Most of the Indians there are Punjabis, who are all referred to as Sikhs 2. But from our experience here we can infer that it is unlikely that they should all be Sikhs.
('8', 280, 3, 8, 676567) Most of the Indians domiciled there are workers.
('8', 280, 3, 9, 676616) For the time being the authorities have resorted to some lacuna in the law to refuse admission to some [Indians] who came via Hong Kong, on the ground that they did not come directly from India.
('8', 280, 3, 10, 676811) 3 Canada has allowed Japanese to settle there, but is doing its utmost to keep Indians out.
('8', 280, 3, 11, 676903) What is the reason?
('8', 280, 3, 12, 676923) First, the Japanese settled in that cou ntry are brave people.
('8', 280, 3, 13, 676986) The whites who tried to intimidate them were beaten back.
('8', 280, 3, 14, 677044) 4 The Japanese moreover have an independent govern ment [at home] which protects its citizens’ interests.
('8', 280, 3, 15, 677150) Their Govern ment is free because the people have an independent disposition.
('8', 280, 3, 16, 677228) As against this, the Indians in Canada shut themselves up in their rooms when there was a riot in that country.
('8', 280, 3, 17, 677340) Also, India can do nothing effe ctive.
('8', 280, 3, 18, 677379) It has no government which can fight for the interests of the country [and its nationals abroad].
('8', 280, 3, 19, 677477) Indians are a subject people.

('8', 282, 2, 12, 681954) 150. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('8', 282, 3, 13, 681979) GOLD LAW
('8', 282, 4, 14, 681988) The following letter 2 about the Gold Law has been sent to the Colonial Secretary on behalf of the Association The draft Gold Law which is to be introduced during the forthcoming session of Parliament imposes on British Indians disabilities graver than those found in the existing law.
('8', 282, 4, 15, 682274) The Committee had hoped, as it still does, that the disabilities of the Indian community would be lightened [by the Government] instead of being increased.
('8', 282, 4, 16, 682430) My Committee draws the attention of the Government to the following.
('8', 282, 4, 17, 682499) In the draft [Law] the definition of the term ‘Coloured person’ contains the word ‘coolie’ which is offensive to the Indian community as there are in the Transvaal very few, if any, coolies in the proper sense of the word.
('8', 282, 4, 18, 682722) Moreover, to bracket together African Natives and Asiatics, British subjects and others who are not British subjects is to ignore the fact of Indians being British subjects.

('8', 302, 1, 2, 728999) 166. STORY OF A SOLDIER OF TRUTH [ V1]
('8', 302, 2, 3, 729038) It was by mistake, we [the editor] announced last week that this series was concluded.
('8', 302, 2, 4, 729125) Socrates ended his defence.
('8', 302, 2, 5, 729153) He was then found guilty by a majority vote.
('8', 302, 2, 6, 729198) Socrates spoke as follows on the question of the punishment to be awarded to him.
('8', 302, 3, 7, 729280) I am not vexed at your finding me guilty.
('8', 302, 3, 8, 729322) Your decision is not an unexpected one.
('8', 302, 3, 9, 729362) I am surprised rather at the large num ber of votes in my favour.
('8', 302, 3, 10, 729428) I had thought the majority against me would be an overwhelming one.
('8', 302, 3, 11, 729496) Instead, I find the margin is narrow.
('8', 302, 3, 12, 729534) If three 2 more had voted in my favour, I would have escaped [punishment].
('8', 302, 3, 13, 729609) I find, moreover, that I have been abso lved of the charge of not believing in the gods.
('8', 302, 3, 14, 729698) You can now sentence me to death.
('8', 302, 3, 15, 729732) What can I say about it?
('8', 302, 3, 16, 729757) What do I deserve to pay or suffer for having given up offi ces and political appointments and gone from house to house to teach virtue?
('8', 302, 3, 17, 729894) If in the gymnasium someone keeps you amused and gives you the illusion of happiness, you will maintain him at public expense.
('8', 302, 3, 18, 730021) I taught you the way to real happiness, not merely to the semblance of it.
('8', 302, 3, 19, 730096) If, therefore, I am entitled to ask for anything, it is that in my old age you should maintain me at public expense.
('8', 302, 3, 20, 730213) Perhaps you will think me arrogant for talking in this way after having been pronounced guilty, for demanding a re ward instead of punishment.
('8', 302, 3, 21, 730356) But it would not be true.
('8', 302, 3, 22, 730382) Though you have found me guilty, I believe myself innocent.
('8', 302, 3, 23, 730442) I have wronged no one.
('8', 302, 3, 24, 730465) You have not been able to understand this, for my examination lasted only a day.
('8', 302, 3, 25, 730546) How much can I explain to you in so short a time?
('8', 302, 3, 26, 730596) If I had had more time with you, per haps, I could have persuaded you to better effect.
('8', 302, 3, 27, 730684) Since I am innocent, I do not propose any penalty for myself.
('8', 302, 3, 28, 730746) Shall I pro pose imprisonment?
('8', 302, 3, 29, 730777) That will not be right.
('8', 302, 3, 30, 730801) Shall I pay a fine?
('8', 302, 4, 31, 730821) 1 “If the offence was one for which the law laid down no precise penalty, then .
('8', 302, 4, 32, 730902) .the prosecutor, if he won his case, proposed one penalty, the accused proposed an alternative, and the jury [a section of the Assembly, since there were no judges] had to choose one of the two.
('8', 302, 4, 33, 731097) When Socrates had been condemned, the prosecution demanded the death penalty, but Socrates, first suggesting the Freedom of the City as the alternative, formally proposed, not exile, which the jury would gladly have accepted, but an almost derisory fine.” H. D. F. Kitto: The Greeks.
('8', 302, 4, 34, 731381) It was Plato who persuaded Socrates to raise the fine he was to propose from one to thirty minae.
('8', 302, 4, 35, 731479) 2 This should be “thirty”.
('8', 303, 0, 1, 731506) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 303, 1, 2, 731548) do not have the money for it.
('8', 303, 1, 3, 731578) Shall I propose exile?
('8', 303, 1, 4, 731601) How can I do that?
('8', 303, 1, 5, 731620) I do not hold my life so dear as to want to pass the rest of my days wandering from place to place, continually haunted by fear.
('8', 303, 1, 6, 731749) Someone may well suggest that I should retire into solitude and hold my peace.
('8', 303, 1, 7, 731828) I cannot do that either.
('8', 303, 1, 8, 731853) I believe I am commanded by the gods to discourse to people on what I hold to be virtue.
('8', 303, 1, 9, 731942) I am also commanded by the gods to look unceasingly for principles of moral conduct.
('8', 303, 1, 10, 732027) I do not think these are matters which you understand.
('8', 303, 1, 11, 732082) But that is no reason why I should hold my peace.
('8', 303, 1, 12, 732132) Socrates was then awarded the death penalty by the Court.
('8', 303, 1, 13, 732190) Un perturbed, the great Socrates immediately addressed the assembly as follows: In any case, I have only a few years left to live.
('8', 303, 1, 14, 732321) You could not be troubled to wait and you have earned an evil name for yourselves by condemning an innocent man to death.
('8', 303, 1, 15, 732443) If you had waited a while, I would have died in the course of nature, for I am an old man, far advanced in years.
('8', 303, 1, 16, 732557) If I had used ignoble arguments before you and adopted the course common on such occasions, I would have escaped the death penalty.
('8', 303, 1, 17, 732689) But that would have been inconsistent with my duty.
('8', 303, 1, 18, 732741) I am sure a free man will never do anything unworthy of himself to save himself from death or other danger.
('8', 303, 1, 19, 732849) One ought not to try to save oneself from death by any and every means.
('8', 303, 1, 20, 732921) In battle, a man can save himself by laying down his arms and surrendering to the ene my.
('8', 303, 1, 21, 733011) But we think such a man a coward.
('8', 303, 1, 22, 733045) In the same way, anyone who resorts to unscrupulous means to save himself from death is an unworthy person.
('8', 303, 1, 23, 733153) I think it is more difficult to save oneself from wickedness than from death, for wickedness is swifter than death.
('8', 303, 1, 24, 733269) Being impatient and rash, you have taken a step which sp ells wickedness—wickedness which is so swift in its advance.
('8', 303, 1, 25, 733387) You have sentenced me to death.
('8', 303, 1, 26, 733419) I shall now leave this world.
('8', 303, 1, 27, 733449) My opponents will be looked upon as men who betrayed truth and perpetrated an injustice.
('8', 303, 1, 28, 733538) I will suffer my punishment.
('8', 303, 1, 29, 733567) But they will [also] suffer the penalty for their [evil] deeds.
('8', 303, 1, 30, 733631) This is what always happens.
('8', 303, 1, 31, 733660) Perhaps it is just as well that it should be so.
('8', 303, 1, 32, 733709) And now, before I die, I wish to address a few words to you.
('8', 303, 1, 33, 733770) I am sure that after I die you will come to suffer greatly.
('8', 304, 0, 1, 733830) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 305
('8', 304, 1, 2, 733875) You must not believe that, by getting rid of me, you will be able to go your wicked ways undisturbed.
('8', 304, 1, 3, 733977) Do not assume that there will be no one toreproach you.
('8', 304, 1, 4, 734033) Before I am taken to the place of execution, I shall address a few remarks to those who trust my words.
('8', 304, 1, 5, 734137) So, those who wish to hear what I have to say may please stay on.
('8', 304, 1, 6, 734203) I want to explain to you the meaning of death as I see it.
('8', 304, 1, 7, 734262) Believe that what has happened to me is a good thing and that those who believe that death is an evil must be mistaken.
('8', 304, 1, 8, 734382) Death may mean one of two things.
('8', 304, 1, 9, 734416) Either the dead man wholly ceases to be and loses all sensation or the soul migrates to another abode.
('8', 304, 1, 10, 734519) If the first belief is true and there is an end to all sensation, death is but the highest form of sleep.
('8', 304, 1, 11, 734625) We look uponsleep as a blessing.
('8', 304, 1, 12, 734658) If that is so, death, being the highest kind of sleep, must be a still greater blessing.
('8', 304, 1, 13, 734747) If, on the other hand, we believe that death is a journey to another place, I shall only join those who have preceded me.
('8', 304, 1, 14, 734869) In their presence, I shall get pure justice.
('8', 304, 1, 15, 734914) There is no evil in this.
('8', 304, 1, 16, 734940) If I have to go where Homer has gone, and other great souls with him, I shall deem it a great good fortune.
('8', 304, 1, 17, 735048) I count it a high honour that I should join the souls of those who were victims of unjust punishment.
('8', 304, 1, 18, 735150) Believe it as a truth that no good man can come by evil either in life or after death.
('8', 304, 1, 19, 735237) Such a man is never forsaken by God.
('8', 304, 1, 20, 735274) And you may be sure that the man of truth is always happy.
('8', 304, 1, 21, 735333) Therefore I am not unhappy that I am to die today and be released from these mortal coils.
('8', 304, 1, 22, 735424) And so I am not angry with the judges or with my accusers.
('8', 304, 1, 23, 735483) If they have wanted to do me evil, they deserve to be censured for that, but their intention can have no evil effect on me.
('8', 304, 1, 24, 735607) Now my last request: if, when my sons grow up, they begin to care for riches or for any other thing before virtue, if they think they are something when they are nothing at all, warn them, censure them, punish them just in the same manner as I have warned you against these things and reproached you with the love of them.
('8', 304, 1, 25, 735930) If you can do this, I shall consider that you have been kind to me and my sons.
('8', 304, 1, 26, 736010) Now the time has come, and we must go hence: I to die, and you to live.
('8', 304, 1, 27, 736082) God alone can tell which is the better state, mine or yours.
('8', 304, 1, 28, 736143) This is a historical event, that is, an event that actually occurred.
('8', 304, 1, 29, 736213) We pray to God, and want our readers also to pray, that they, and we
('8', 305, 0, 1, 736282) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 305, 1, 2, 736324) too, may have the moral strength which enabled Socrates to follow virtue to the end and to embrace death as if it were his beloved.
('8', 305, 1, 3, 736456) We advise everyone to turn his mind again and again to Socrates’s words and conduct.

('8', 307, 1, 12, 741488) In order to make good my word, as also to assist the Government, it is within the Gen eral’s knowledge that I very nearly lost my life, and this arose beca use, in the opinion of some of my countrymen, I had sold them, by reason of having agreed to the principle of ten finger prints.
('8', 307, 1, 13, 741773) Were the proposed registration under the Act of new arrivals persisted in, not only will suspicion be accentuated, but it will be justified, and I cannot help saying that those who may feel irritated against me will be enti tled to my life.
('8', 307, 1, 14, 742014) I should consider myself totally unworthy of the trust reposed in me by my countrymen, and to hold the position that they have allowed me to hold for such a long time, were I ever to consent to the Act being applied to new comers.
('8', 307, 1, 15, 742245) If the Act was bad, as I res pectfully contend it was, it was so for all, except for those who, owing
('8', 308, 0, 1, 742347) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 309
('8', 308, 1, 2, 742392) to their fraud or obstinacy, would not voluntarily provide facility to the Government for their identification.
('8', 308, 1, 3, 742504) I am, therefore, sure that Gen eral Smuts will reconsider the matter, and not only not ask me to use whatever influence I may possess with my countrymen in the direction desired by him, but that he will assist me to make good my word to them, by either accepting voluntary registration of new arrivals or informing them that they need not be identified until after the passing of the new legislation, especially as the purpose of identification is equally well served under the compromise.
('8', 308, 1, 4, 742994) As the matter is exceedingly urgent, may I ask that a telegraphic reply be sent to me?
('8', 308, 2, 5, 743081) Yours truly,

('8', 309, 5, 26, 746061) [JOHANNESBURG, Before May 16, 1908]
('8', 309, 6, 27, 746097) As the leading member of the community most concerned, Mr. M. K. Gandhi, the Johannesburg lawyer, is entitled to a very considerable audience on the subject of the legislation which Natal proposes regarding its Indians.
('8', 309, 6, 28, 746317) With reference to the first Bill that is to stop indentured immi gration, so far as I am aware every Indian will welcome it.
('8', 309, 6, 29, 746442) The only regret will be that the stopping did not come sooner, and that it is still not to come for two years.
('8', 309, 6, 30, 746553) Had indentured labour from India not
('8', 310, 0, 1, 746590) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 311
('8', 310, 1, 2, 746635) been imported, there would have been no Indian question in South Africa.
('8', 310, 1, 3, 746708) Of course, the reason for Indian satisfaction may not be, and is not, the same as that for European satisfaction.
('8', 310, 1, 4, 746822) Indians consider that the system of indentures is of little, if any, benefit to India as a wholeor to the Indians concerned.
('8', 310, 1, 5, 746947) It does not tend to the elevation or pro gress of the indentured people, and in the words of the late Sir William Wilson Hunter 1, the official historian of India, it is a state of semi slavery.
('8', 310, 1, 6, 747142) As to the two other Bills, they are open to very serious objection.
('8', 310, 1, 7, 747210) I have never heard of such legislation in any British Colony.
('8', 310, 1, 8, 747272) The first of these two licensing Bills contemplates the stopping of all new licences in Natal.
('8', 310, 1, 9, 747367) This means the stopping of the removal of the same business from one place to another, because as soon as a trader remo ves to another place, it is considered to be a new business and a further licence is necessary.
('8', 310, 1, 10, 747583) This Bill, if it becomes law, must mean ruin, practically, to Indian traders.
('8', 310, 1, 11, 747661) Why should not the partner of a man who holds a licence in his own name, as soon as he severs his connection with the partnership, be able to take out a licence for himself?
('8', 310, 1, 12, 747835) And yet prohibition to trade will be the effect of this Bill.
('8', 310, 1, 13, 747897) There aremany other points in the Bill which must strike at decent Indian existence in Natal.
('8', 310, 1, 14, 747991) Some of the Indians, who are born traders, cannot take up any other employment or pursuit.
('8', 310, 1, 15, 748082) To them, Natal is their home.
('8', 310, 1, 16, 748112) What are they to do if they may not trade?
('8', 310, 1, 17, 748155) It will be simply encouragement for fraud if the Bill is persisted in.
('8', 310, 1, 18, 748226) It is perfectly true that the position of the Indian trader under the present licensing law is not much better.
('8', 310, 1, 19, 748338) He is always in a state of uncertainty, but that does not mean that the present Bill can be justified.
('8', 310, 1, 20, 748441) Moreover, even with reference to the existing licensing law, the position has become very critical and during my last visit to Natal I noticed that Indian traders had become very uncomfortable and were considering what could be done to obtain amelioration.
('8', 310, 1, 21, 748698) The recent cable from Home also shows that the Colonial Office is still reasoning with the Natal Government with a view to the amendment or repeal of the Dealers’ Licenses Act of Natal.
('8', 310, 1, 22, 748884) The second licensing Bill is, in truth, a confiscation of what rights there may be left after the full effect has been produced by the operation of the first Bill.
('8', 310, 1, 23, 749048) Thus the second Bill gives ten years’ notice
