('8', 315, 5, 12, 760248) PREFACE
('8', 315, 6, 13, 760256) People in the West generally hold that it is man’s duty to promote the happiness—prosperity, that is—of the greatest number.
('8', 315, 7, 14, 760381) Happiness is taken to mean material happiness exclusively, that is, economic prosperity.
('8', 315, 7, 15, 760470) If, in the pursuit of this happiness moral, laws are violated, it does not matter much.
('8', 315, 7, 16, 760558) Again, as the object is the happi ness of the greatest number, people in the West do not believe it to be wrong if it is secured at the cost of the minority.
('8', 315, 7, 17, 760716) The consequences of this attitude are in evidence in all western countries.
('8', 315, 7, 18, 760792) The exclusive quest for the physical and material happiness of the majority has no sanction in divine law.
('8', 315, 7, 19, 760899) In fact, some thoughtful persons in the West have pointed out that it is contrary to divine law to
('8', 315, 8, 20, 760998) 1Vide also “Lord Selborne’s View”, 4 4 1908 and “Johannesburg Letter”, 2 5 1908 2 The Advancement of All 3 The reference is to Bentham’s maxim of “the greatest good of the greatest number”.
('8', 315, 8, 21, 761188) Gandhiji opposed it on moral grounds; vide “The Pietersburg Claptrap”, 13 8 1904. Ruskin, too, criticized the construction of a “science” of economics on the Newtonain model from which “social affections” had been wholly abstracted.
('8', 315, 8, 22, 761421) Ruskin argued that the greatest art or science was that which aroused “the greatest number of the greatest ideas”.
('8', 316, 0, 1, 761536) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 317
('8', 316, 1, 2, 761581) pursue happiness in violation of moral principles.
('8', 316, 1, 3, 761632) The late John Ruskin 1 was foremost among these.
('8', 316, 1, 4, 761681) He was an Englishman of great learning.
('8', 316, 1, 5, 761721) He has written numerous books on art and crafts.
('8', 316, 1, 6, 761770) He has also written a great deal on ethical questions.
('8', 316, 1, 7, 761825) One of these books, a small one, Ruskin himself believed to be his best.
('8', 316, 1, 8, 761898) It is read widely wherever English is spoken.
('8', 316, 1, 9, 761944) In the book, he has effectively countered these arguments and shown that the well being of the people at large consists in conforming to the moral law.
('8', 316, 1, 10, 762096) We in India are much given nowadays to imitation of the West.
('8', 316, 1, 11, 762158) We do grant that it is necessary to imitate the West in certain respects.
('8', 316, 1, 12, 762232) At the same time there is no doubt that many western ideas are wrong.
('8', 316, 1, 13, 762302) It will be admitted on all hands that what is bad must be eschewed.
('8', 316, 1, 14, 762370) The condition of Indians in South Africa is pitiable.
('8', 316, 1, 15, 762424) We go out to distant lands to make money.
('8', 316, 1, 16, 762466) We are so taken up with this that we become oblivious of morality and of God.
('8', 316, 1, 17, 762544) We become engrossed in the pursuit of self interest.
('8', 316, 1, 18, 762597) In the sequel, we find that going abroad does us more harm than good, or does not profit us as much as it ought to.
('8', 316, 1, 19, 762713) All religions presuppose the moral law, but even if we disregard religion as such, its observance is necessary on grounds of common sense also.
('8', 316, 1, 20, 762857) Our happiness consists in observing it.
('8', 316, 1, 21, 762897) This is what John Ruskin has established.
('8', 316, 1, 22, 762939) He has opened the eyes of the western people to this, and today, we see a large number of Europeans modelling their conduct on his teaching.
('8', 316, 1, 23, 763080) In order that Indians may profit by his ideas, we have decided to present extracts from his book, in a manner intelligible to Indians who do not know English.

('8', 317, 1, 3, 764461) If we translated it, the common reader might be unable to follow some of the Biblical allusions, etc.

('8', 317, 2, 7, 764940) ROOTS OF TRUTH 2
('8', 317, 3, 8, 764957) Man suffers from many delusions; but none so great as his attempt to formulate laws for the conduct of other men disregarding the effects of social affection, as if they were only machines at work.
('8', 317, 3, 9, 765155) That we cherish such an illusion does us no credit.
('8', 317, 3, 10, 765207) Like other forms of error, the laws of political economy also contain an element of plausibility.
('8', 317, 3, 11, 765305) Political economists assert that social affections are to be looked upon as accidental and disturbing elements in human nature; but avarice and the desire for progress are constant elements.
('8', 317, 3, 12, 765496) Let us eliminate the inconstants and, considering man merely as a money making machine, examine by what laws of labour, purchase and sale, the greatest amount of wealth can be accumulated.
('8', 317, 3, 13, 765685) Those laws once determined, it will be for each individual afterwards to introduce as much of the disturbing affectional elements as he chooses.
('8', 317, 3, 14, 765830) This would be a convincing argument if the social affections were of the same nature as the laws of demand and supply.
('8', 317, 3, 15, 765949) Man’s affections constitute an inner force.
('8', 317, 3, 16, 765993) The laws of demand and supply are formulations concerning the external world.
('8', 317, 3, 17, 766071) The two, therefore, are not of the same nature.
('8', 317, 3, 18, 766119) If a moving body is acted upon by a constant force from one direction and a varying force from another, we would first measure the constant force and then the inconstant.
('8', 317, 3, 19, 766290) We will be able to determine the velocity of the body by comparing the two forces.
('8', 317, 3, 20, 766373) We can do this because the constant and the inconstant forces are of the same kind.
('8', 317, 3, 21, 766457) But in social dealings the constant force of the laws of demand and supply and the accidental force of social affection are forces that differ in kind.
('8', 317, 3, 22, 766609) Affection has a different kind of effect on man and acts in a different manner.
('8', 317, 3, 23, 766689) It changes
('8', 317, 4, 24, 766700) 1 Vide the parable of the Labourers in the Vineyard, St. Matthew, Ch. XX, v.

('8', 318, 2, 5, 767230) 176. SPEECH AT Y.M.C.A.
('8', 318, 3, 6, 767254) [JOHANNESBURG, May 18, 1908]
('8', 318, 4, 7, 767283) The following address was given by Mr. M. K. Gandhi, Bar at Law, before the Y.M.C.A., Johannesburg, in moving the negative in a debate on the question, “Are Asiatics and the Coloured races a menace to the Empire?” It seems to me somewhat remarkable that a question of this description should arise at all, or that there should be any debate whatsoever as to whether Coloured races are a menace to the Empire.
('8', 318, 4, 8, 767692) I think that a question of that description could arise only in the Colo nies or, better still, only in some of the Colonies.
('8', 318, 4, 9, 767818) In a well ordered society industrious and intelligent men can never be a menace.
('8', 318, 4, 10, 767899) If they have any defects, the very order of the society corrects them.
('8', 318, 4, 11, 767970) At the same time, we, as practical men and women living in this very practical age, have to face facts as they are and, seeing that questions of this description arise in the Colonies, it is undoubtedly well that we should discuss them and debate upon them; and, to my mind, it is a very happy augury for the future that your humble servant can be called upon to give his views on the question before an audience like this, and I think it is also a happy augury that this hall is so well filled, showing the keen interest taken in the subject.
('8', 318, 4, 12, 768514) By the term “Coloured people” generally, I think we under stand only offspring of mixed marriages, but in connection with the question before us this evening, the term “Coloured people” has been taken more comprehensively, and has been made to include the Coloured people proper—the Africans and the Asiatics.
('8', 318, 4, 13, 768824) My own observations and experience, as you know, are confined very largely to British Indians, my own fellow countrymen, but in studying the Indian question, I have endeavoured to study the question as it affects the Africans and the Chinese.
('8', 318, 4, 14, 769067) It seems to me that both the Africans and the Asiatics have advanced the Empire as a whole; we can hardly think of South Africa without the African races.
('8', 318, 4, 15, 769222) And who can think of the British Empire without India?

('8', 319, 1, 3, 769501) This brings me to the White Man’s Burden as Kipling has called it.
('8', 319, 1, 4, 769568) His writings, to my mind, have been very much misunderstood.
('8', 319, 1, 5, 769629) We know now also that he himself has very considerably, with extended experience, revised his views, and he no longer thinks that the Colo ured people are a menace to the Empire, or that the white man may not coexist with the Coloured man.
('8', 319, 1, 6, 769869) Be that as it may, he has certainly shown in some of his writings that it was really a responsibility thrown on the white people, more particularly on the British people, to act as trustees for the Coloured races.

('8', 327, 2, 5, 789908) ASSAULT ON ESSOP MIA
('8', 327, 3, 6, 789929) At 2 P.M. on Sunday, Mr. Essop Mia, Chairman of the British Indian Association, was proceeding to the Location to attend a dinner party when a Pathan struck him on the back with a heavy stick.
('8', 327, 3, 7, 790122) He turned round and was hit on the face, the blow breaking the bridge of the nose.
('8', 327, 3, 8, 790205) Blood gushed out.
('8', 327, 3, 9, 790223) Mr. Essop Mia became unconscious and fell down.
('8', 327, 3, 10, 790271) Mr. Moosa Ebrahim Patel and Mr. Cachalia tried to seize the Pathan, the former receiving injuries in the attempt.
('8', 327, 3, 11, 790385) Meanwhile, Mr. Essop Mia got on his feet and took hold of the assailant.
('8', 327, 3, 12, 790458) Mr. Camay happened to come [on the scene] and whistled for the police, who rushed to the spot and arrested the assailant.
('8', 327, 3, 13, 790580) The other Pathans, who had struggled free, ran away.
('8', 327, 3, 14, 790633) Mr. Essop Mia was in severe pain.
('8', 327, 3, 15, 790667) He was bleeding.
('8', 327, 3, 16, 790684) Never theless, he went straight to the Police Station and then to Dr. Gilchrist.
('8', 327, 3, 17, 790765) The doctor bandaged him.
('8', 327, 3, 18, 790790) The nasal bone has been set, and it is expected that the setting will be successful.
('8', 327, 3, 19, 790875) The injury on the back, too, is severe.
('8', 327, 3, 20, 790915) The front teeth are shaky, but there is no reason to fear loss of the teeth.
('8', 327, 3, 21, 790992) Mr. Essop Mia has borne his pain with great courage.
('8', 327, 3, 22, 791045) Because of the injured nose, the upper part of his face is in bandage.
('8', 327, 3, 23, 791116) The mouth being left uncovered, he can talk a little.
('8', 327, 3, 24, 791170) A large number of persons called on him on Sunday.
('8', 327, 3, 25, 791221) The assault appears to have had something to do with the com promise.
('8', 327, 3, 26, 791291) The Pathans are believed to have picked on Mr. Essop Mia also for attack on account of the prominent part he played in that reg ard.
('8', 327, 3, 27, 791424) It is said, moreover, that the Pathans wished to be revenged on Mr. Essop Mia and did so for having given evidence about the attack on Mr. Gandhi.

('8', 332, 1, 2, 800671) 181. TRANSVAAL MUNICIPAL CONSOLIDATION BILL
('8', 332, 2, 3, 800715) The Transvaal Government have published a Draft Bill regu lating the Municipalities of the Transvaal.
('8', 332, 2, 4, 800817) General Smuts has fulfilled the promise he made at a meeting recently held, and to which ref erence has been made in these columns, that Municipalities will be armed with powers to deal with Asiatic traders.
('8', 332, 2, 5, 801025) There are sections in the Bill dealing with traders.
('8', 332, 2, 6, 801078) One section gives authority to the Muni cipalities to refuse trading licences on the grounds of insanitation, unsuitability of premises, and for other similar reasons, the decision being subject to revision by a Resident Magistrate.
('8', 332, 2, 7, 801311) Another section empowers Municipalities to refuse, among others, licences to hawkers, the refusal in these cases being in the absolute discretion of the Muni cipalities, no appeal being allowed.
('8', 332, 2, 8, 801506) The first section is not open to much objection, and Asiatics must take the consequences of the preva iling prejudices, except in so far as they may be met by appeal to magistrates.
('8', 332, 2, 9, 801688) But the second section is absolutely unjust, and is aimed at the large number of Asiatic hawkers.
('8', 332, 2, 10, 801786) Why there should be no appeal to the magistrates with reference to the licences covered by this section, it is difficult to understand.
('8', 332, 2, 11, 801922) Lord Elgin, when he occupied the position of Colonial Secretary, said that he would not allow the present rights of Asiatics to be infringed.
('8', 332, 2, 12, 802064) If, however, the Draft Bill goes through, and receives the Royal sanction, Asiatic trade must be ruined.
('8', 332, 2, 13, 802169) It is well to bear in mind that the livelihood of 5,000 Asiatic hawkers is at stake, as also of over 500 Asiatic store keepers.
('8', 332, 2, 14, 802297) Another section gives the Municipalities power to lay out Locations for Asiatics, which may be shifted from time to time, subject to compensation being paid to the residents for improvements made by them.
('8', 332, 2, 15, 802502) A further section gives the Municipalities power to regulate movement on foot paths.
('8', 332, 2, 16, 802587) Thus, the Bill would give the Municipalities a threefold power.
('8', 332, 2, 17, 802651) Asiatics should ultimately go to Locations.
('8', 332, 2, 18, 802695) They must not be allowed to walk on footpaths, and they must not continue their trade unhampered.
('8', 332, 2, 19, 802793) We trust that the Imperial Government, having had enough experience now during the last 16 months, will not allow such arbitrary powers to rest in the hands of the Transvaal Municipalities.
('8', 332, 2, 20, 802983) Indian Opinion, 23 5 1908

('8', 333, 2, 20, 804483) 183. SARVODAYA [ II]
('8', 333, 3, 21, 804504) ROOTS OF TRUTH
('8', 333, 4, 22, 804519) I do not doubt the conclusions of the science of economics [if its premises are accepted].
('8', 333, 4, 23, 804610) If a gymnast formulated laws on the assumption that man is made only of flesh without a skeleton, those laws might well be valid, but they would not apply to man, since man has a skeleton.
('8', 333, 4, 24, 804799) In the same way, the laws of political economy may be valid but they cannot apply to man, who is subject to affections.
('8', 333, 4, 25, 804919) A physical culture expert may suggest that man’s flesh be detached [from the skeleton], rolled into pellets, and then drawn out into cables.
('8', 333, 4, 26, 805060) He may then say that the re insertion of the skeleton will cause little inconvenience.
('8', 333, 4, 27, 805147) We should describe such a man as a madcap, for the laws of physical culture cannot be based on the separation of the skeleton from the flesh.
('8', 333, 4, 28, 805289) In the same manner, the laws of political economy which exclude human affections are of no use to man.
('8', 333, 4, 29, 805392) And yet the political economists of today behave exactly like the gymnastic instructor.
('8', 333, 4, 30, 805480) According to their mode of reasoning, man is a mere body—a machine—and they base their laws on this assumption.
('8', 334, 0, 1, 805592) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 335
('8', 334, 1, 2, 805637) Though aware that man has a soul, they do not take it into account.
('8', 334, 1, 3, 805705) How can such a science apply to man, in whom the soul is the predominant element?
('8', 334, 1, 4, 805787) Every time there is a strike, we have a clean proof that economics is not a science, that it is worse than useless.
('8', 334, 1, 5, 805903) In such situations, the employers take one view of the matter, the workers another.
('8', 334, 1, 6, 805987) [Here] we cannot apply the laws of supply and demand.
('8', 334, 1, 7, 806041) Men rack their brains to prove that the interests of the employers and the employees are identical.
('8', 334, 1, 8, 806141) These men know nothing of such matters.
('8', 334, 1, 9, 806181) In fact, it does not always follow that because their worldly interests— economic interests—are at variance men must be antagonistic to each other.
('8', 334, 1, 10, 806329) Let us suppose that the members of a family are starving.
('8', 334, 1, 11, 806387) The family consists of a mother and her children.
('8', 334, 1, 12, 806437) They have only one crust of bread between them.
('8', 334, 1, 13, 806485) All of them are hungry.
('8', 334, 1, 14, 806509) Here, the interests of the two—of the mother on the one hand, and the children on the other—are mutually opposed.
('8', 334, 1, 15, 806623) If the mother eats, the children will starve; if the children are fed, the mother will go hungry.
('8', 334, 1, 16, 806721) There is no hostility between the mother and the children for that reason; they are not antagonistic to one another.
('8', 334, 1, 17, 806838) Though the mother is the stronger, she does not eat up the bread.
('8', 334, 1, 18, 806904) The same is true of men’s relations with one another.
('8', 334, 1, 19, 806958) Let us suppose that there is no difference between men and animals, and that we must fight like animals in pursuit of our respective interests 1. Even so we can lay down no general rule either way on whether or not the employer and the employee will always remain hostile to each other.
('8', 334, 1, 20, 807245) Their attitudes change with circumstances.
('8', 334, 1, 21, 807288) For instance, it is in the interest of both that work should be well and properly done and a just price obtained for it.
('8', 334, 1, 22, 807409) But in the division of profits, the gain of the one may or may not be the loss of the other.
('8', 334, 1, 23, 807502) It does not serve the employer’s interests to pay wages so low as to leave his men sickly and depressed.
('8', 334, 1, 24, 807607) Nor does it serve the worker’s interests to demand a high wage irrespective of whether the factory pays its way or not.
('8', 334, 1, 25, 807727) If the owner does not have enough money to keep the engine wheels in repair, it will obviously be wrong for the worker to demand full wages or to demand any wages at all.
('8', 334, 1, 26, 807898) We can thus see that we are not likely to succeed in constructing a science on the basis of the principle of supply and demand.
('8', 334, 2, 27, 808026) 1 The Gujarati has “common interests”.
('8', 335, 0, 1, 808065) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 335, 1, 2, 808107) never God’s intention that the affairs of men should be conducted on the principle of profit and loss.
('8', 335, 1, 3, 808210) Justice must provide the basis.
('8', 335, 1, 4, 808242) Man must give up, therefore, all thought of advancing his interests by following expediency regardless of moral considerations.
('8', 335, 1, 5, 808370) It is not always possible to predict with certainty the outcome of a given line of conduct.
('8', 335, 1, 6, 808462) But in most cases we can determine whether a certain act is just or unjust.
('8', 335, 1, 7, 808538) We can also assert that the result of moral conduct is bound to be good.
('8', 335, 1, 8, 808611) We cannot predict what that result will be, or how it will come about.
('8', 335, 1, 9, 808682) Justice includes affection.
('8', 335, 1, 10, 808710) The relation between master and operative depends on this element of affection.
('8', 335, 1, 11, 808790) Let us assume that the master wants to exact the utmost amount of work from his servant.
('8', 335, 1, 12, 808879) He allows him no time for rest, pays him a low wage, and lodges him in a garret.
('8', 335, 1, 13, 808960) In brief, he pays him a bare subsistence wage.
('8', 335, 1, 14, 809007) It may be argued that there is no injustice in all this.
('8', 335, 1, 15, 809064) The servant has placed all his time; at the master’s disposal in return for a given wage, and the latter avails himself of it.
('8', 335, 1, 16, 809191) He determines the limits of hardship in exacting work by reference to what others do.
('8', 335, 1, 17, 809277) If the servant can get a better place, he is free to take it.
('8', 335, 1, 18, 809339) This is called economics by those who formulate the laws of supply and demand.
('8', 335, 1, 19, 809418) They assert that it isprofitable to the master thus to exact the maximum amount of work for the minimum wage.
('8', 335, 1, 20, 809528) In the long run, the entire society will benefit by it and, through the society, the servant himself.
('8', 335, 1, 21, 809630) But on reflection we find that this is not quite true.
('8', 335, 1, 22, 809685) This method of calculation would have been valid if the employee were a mere machine which required some kind of force to drive it.
('8', 335, 1, 23, 809817) But in this case the motive power of the servant is his soul, and soul force contradicts and falsifies all the calculations of the economists.
('8', 335, 1, 24, 809960) The machine that is man cannot be driven by the money fuel to do the maximum amount of work.
('8', 335, 1, 25, 810053) Man will give of his best only when his affections are brought into play.
('8', 335, 1, 26, 810127) The master servant nexus must not be a pecuniary one, but one of love.
('8', 335, 1, 27, 810198) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 5 1908

('8', 337, 3, 4, 811894) SIR, Mr. Gandhi has just explained to me that it is the intention of the Government to legalize voluntary registration under the Asiatic Act and to make it applicable to Asiatics who have voluntarily regis tered, save for the penalties for non registration under it hitherto.

('8', 337, 3, 9, 812741) In this connection, I wish to draw the attention of the Govern ment to the fact that the leaders of the Asiatic community, with much personal risk to themselves, endeavoured throughout the last three months un ceasingly to help the Government to identify the British Indians resident in the Transvaal.
('8', 337, 3, 10, 813043) The least, therefore, that my Asso ciation had a right to expect was a scrupulous regard for the part of the compact to be carried out by the Government.
('8', 337, 3, 11, 813197) But, as I understand from Mr. Gandhi, you have irrevocably taken the step and stated that the new legislation that is to be passed will be merely to legalize registration under the Asiatic Act.
('8', 337, 3, 12, 813391) It will be the duty of my Association, therefore, again most relu ctantly to take up the position that it occupied three months ago.
('8', 337, 3, 13, 813524) My Association is advising British Indians in the Transvaal to withdraw their applications for voluntary registration and all documents lodged with Mr. Chamney.
('8', 337, 3, 14, 813685) This was an act done by the community as a matter of grace and in order to show the Government its complete bona fides.
('8', 337, 3, 15, 813805) It is impossible for the community to do otherwise than what I have above indicated, for the simple reason that it was never the intention to submit to an Act which the community was bound by a solemn obligation not to accept and moreover to strive to resist.
('8', 337, 3, 16, 814065) In conclusion, I venture respectfully to point out that the depar

('8', 342, 2, 3, 821876) The reader should think about the letter from Mr. Shakur Ismail of Rhodesia which we published last week.
('8', 342, 2, 4, 821982) 1 The Colonial Government wants to enact a law similar to the one in the Transvaal.
('8', 342, 2, 5, 822066) If it does, that will be a frightful thing indeed!
('8', 342, 2, 6, 822117) The Indians in Rhodesia must offer battle.
('8', 342, 2, 7, 822160) They are justified in expecting help from other quarters in case they are forced to fight, and we are convinced that, if they resort to satyagraha, they will also get help from all the Colonies [as the Trans vaal Indians did].
('8', 342, 2, 8, 822387) Let us hope that they will not have to take that step.
('8', 342, 2, 9, 822442) However, whether or not a new law is passed, their problems deserve some attention.
('8', 342, 2, 10, 822526) Even educated persons are refused entry [into that Colony] if they are unemployed.
('8', 342, 2, 11, 822609) If they can produce evidence of having found employment, the excuse is then advanced that the employment is unsatisfactory.
('8', 342, 2, 12, 822733) In the result, the Indians are deprived of the benefits under the existing law.
('8', 342, 2, 13, 822813) It is possible to fight against this [state of affairs] by legal means.
('8', 342, 2, 14, 822885) To be able to do that, they should consult a good lawyer in Rhodesia.
('8', 342, 2, 15, 822955) Apparently, difficulties also exist as regards trading licences.
('8', 342, 2, 16, 823020) It must be borne in mind, however, that not many Indians will be able to enter [any of the South African] Colonies in the immediate future.
('8', 342, 2, 17, 823160) Licences will not be issued freely.
('8', 342, 2, 18, 823196) In the long run, however, Indians may be able to migrate to all the Colonies and also carry on trade.

('8', 345, 2, 3, 829196) WHAT SHOULD WE DEMAND NOW ?

('8', 345, 3, 5, 829489) Earlier we had bound ourselvesto register voluntarily.
('8', 345, 3, 6, 829544) We made the offer of voluntary registration to prove our bona fides.
('8', 345, 3, 7, 829613) Now these have been established for the most part.
('8', 345, 3, 8, 829664) We can therefore raise our demands when a fresh settlement is negotiated.
('8', 345, 3, 9, 829738) To my mind we shall be justi fied in advancing the following demands: (1) Those who hold valid registers from the Dutch period should be entitled to register voluntarily.
('8', 345, 3, 10, 829909) (2) Those who have entered openly, but with permits, and have lived here for some time should be entitled to registration certificates.
('8', 345, 3, 11, 830045) (3) Those who can prove to the satisfaction of a court that they are refugees should be permitted to enter.
('8', 345, 3, 12, 830153) (4) No laws should be enacted to deprive a subject of his personal liberty exclusively on the basis of the colour of his skin.
('8', 345, 3, 13, 830280) (5) Educated Indians should be allowed to come in even if they are fresh entrants.
('8', 345, 3, 14, 830363) I do not think our campaign will reach a stage when we will be able to put forward these demands.
('8', 345, 3, 15, 830461) Be that as it may, the struggle that has now been resumed cannot but be advantageous to the Indian community.

('8', 347, 0, 1, 833396) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 347, 1, 2, 833438) 191. SARVODAYA [ III]
('8', 347, 2, 3, 833460) ROOTS OF TRUTH
('8', 347, 3, 4, 833475) It usually happens that, if the master is a man of sense and energy, the servant works hard enough, under pressure; it also happens that, if the master is indolent and weak, the performance of the servant is not of the best in quality or quantity.
('8', 347, 3, 5, 833723) But the true law is that, if we compare two masters of equal intelligence, the servant of the one who is sympathetically inclined will work better than that of the other who is not so inclined.
('8', 347, 3, 6, 833917) It may be argued that this principle does not quite hold, since kindness and indulgence are sometimes rewarded with their oppo sites.
('8', 347, 3, 7, 834051) The servant becomes unmanageable.
('8', 347, 3, 8, 834085) But the argument is never thelessinvalid.
('8', 347, 3, 9, 834127) A servant who rewards kindness with negligence will become vengeful when treated harshly.
('8', 347, 3, 10, 834217) A servant who is dishonest to a liberal master will be injurious to an unjust one.
('8', 347, 3, 11, 834300) Therefore, in any case and with any person, this unselfish treat ment will yield the most effective return.
('8', 347, 3, 12, 834408) We are here considering affections only as a motive power.
('8', 347, 3, 13, 834467) That we should be kind because kindness is good is quite another consideration.
('8', 347, 3, 14, 834547) We are not thinking of that for the present.
('8', 347, 3, 15, 834592) We only want to point out here that not only are the ordinary laws of economics, which we considered above, rendered nugatory by the motive power of kindness—sympathy—but also that affection, being a power of an altogether different kind, is inconsonant with the laws of economics and can survive only if those laws are ignored.
('8', 347, 3, 16, 834921) If the master is a calculating person who shows kind ness only in expectation of a return, he will probably be disappointed.
('8', 347, 3, 17, 835046) Kindness should be exercised for the sake of kindness; the reward will then come unsought.
('8', 347, 3, 18, 835137) It is said that he who loses his life shall find it, and he who finds it shall lose it.
('8', 347, 4, 19, 835225) Let us take the example of a regiment and its commander.
('8', 347, 4, 20, 835282) If a general seeks to get his troops to work in accordance with the principles of economics, he will fail.
('8', 347, 4, 21, 835389) There are many instances of generals cultivating direct, personal relations with their men, treating them with kindness, sharing their joys and hardships, ensuring their safety—in brief, treating them with sympathy.
('8', 347, 4, 22, 835605) A general of this kind will be able to exact the most arduous work from his troops.
('8', 347, 4, 23, 835689) If we look into history, we shall rarely find a battle won where the troops had no love for their general.
('8', 347, 4, 24, 835796) Thus the bond of sympathy between the
('8', 347, 5, 25, 835834) 1 St. Matthew, Ch. X, v.
('8', 348, 0, 1, 835859) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 349
('8', 348, 1, 2, 835904) general and his troops is the truest force.
('8', 348, 1, 3, 835948) Even a band of robbers has the utmost affection for its leader.
('8', 348, 1, 4, 836012) And yet we find no such intimate relation between the employer and the employees in textile mills and other factories.
('8', 348, 1, 5, 836131) One reason for this is that, in these factories, the wages of the employees are determined by the laws of supply and demand.
('8', 348, 1, 6, 836256) Between the employer and the employee there obtains, therefore, the relation of disaffection rather than of affection, and instead of sympathy between them we find antagonism.
('8', 348, 1, 7, 836432) We have then to consider two questions: one, how far the rate of wages may be so regulated as not to vary with the demand for labour; second, how far workmen can be maintained in factories, without any change in their numbers irrespective of the state of trade, with the same bond [between workmen and employer] as obtains between servants and master in an old family, or between soldiers and their commander.
('8', 348, 1, 8, 836842) Let us consider the first question.
('8', 348, 1, 9, 836878) It is surprising why econo mists do nothing to make it possible for standards of payment for factoryworkers to be fixed.
('8', 348, 1, 10, 836999) We see, on the other hand, that the office of the Prime Minister of England is not put up to auction, but that whoever the incumbent, the remuneration remains the same.
('8', 348, 1, 11, 837168) Nor do we offer the job of a priest to anyone who agrees to accept the lowest salary.
('8', 348, 1, 12, 837254) With physicians and lawyers, too, we do not generally deal in this manner.
('8', 348, 1, 13, 837329) Thus we observe that in these instances a certain standard of payment is fixed.
('8', 348, 1, 14, 837409) It may be asked, however, whether a good work man and a bad one must both be paid the same wage.
('8', 348, 1, 15, 837506) In fact, that is as it should be.
('8', 348, 1, 16, 837540) In the result, the rate of wages for all workers being the same, we shall engage only a good bricklayer or carpenter as we go only to a good physician or lawyer—the fees of all physicians or law yers being the same.
('8', 348, 1, 17, 837756) That is the proper reward of the good work man—to be chosen.
('8', 348, 1, 18, 837817) Therefore, the right system respecting all labour is that it should be paid at fixed rates.
('8', 348, 1, 19, 837909) Where a bad workman finds it possible to deceive employers by accepting a low wage, the eventual outcome cannot but be bad.
('8', 348, 1, 20, 838033) Let us now consider the second point.
('8', 348, 1, 21, 838071) It is that, whatever the state of trade, the factories must maintain the same number of workers in employment.
('8', 348, 1, 22, 838182) When there is no security of employment, the workers are obliged to ask for higher wages.
('8', 348, 1, 23, 838272) If, however, they can be assured of continued employment for life, they will be prepared to work for very low wages.
('8', 348, 1, 24, 838389) It is clear therefore that the employer who assures sec urity of employment to his workers will find it profitable in the long run.
('8', 348, 1, 25, 838521) The employees also stand to gain if they continue steadily in the
('8', 349, 0, 1, 838587) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 349, 1, 2, 838629) same job.
('8', 349, 1, 3, 838639) Large profits are not possible in factories run on these lines.
('8', 349, 1, 4, 838703) Big risks cannot be taken.
('8', 349, 1, 5, 838730) Gambling on a large scale will not be possible.
('8', 349, 1, 6, 838778) The soldier is ready to lay down his life for the sake of his commander.
('8', 349, 1, 7, 838851) That is why the work of a soldier is considered more honourable than that of an ordinary worker.
('8', 349, 1, 8, 838948) The soldier’s trade is really, not slaying, but being slain in defence of others.
('8', 349, 1, 9, 839030) Anyone who enlists as a soldier holds his life at the service of the state.
('8', 349, 1, 10, 839106) This is true also of the lawyer, the physician and the priest.
('8', 349, 1, 11, 839169) That is why we look up to them with respect.
('8', 349, 1, 12, 839214) A lawyer must do justice even at the cost of his life.
('8', 349, 1, 13, 839269) The physician must treat his patients at the cost of incon venience to himself.
('8', 349, 1, 14, 839349) And the clergyman must instruct his congreg ation and direct it along the right path, regardless of consequences.

('8', 355, 5, 7, 851874) 196. LETTER TO GENERAL SMUTS 1
('8', 355, 6, 8, 851905) [JOHANNESBURG,] June 6, 1908]
('8', 355, 7, 9, 851935) [DEAR MR. SMUTS, ] I hope you will pardon me for writing you about the interview 2 that took place today between you and me.
('8', 355, 7, 10, 852060) While I appreciate your desire to abide by the compromise, I cannot help saying that the interview was not satisfactory.
('8', 355, 7, 11, 852181) You still hesitate about repeal of the Act, and you are emphatic that, if the Act is not repealed, it is under it that Asiatics who arrived after the 9th ultimo and who had a right to enter the country should be registered.
('8', 355, 7, 12, 852405) The repeal of the Act, as I havealways said, was the goal of the Asiatics, and they have done much and surrendered much, in order to reach the goal.
('8', 355, 7, 13, 852554) I have gathered also that you admit the Asiatic Act to be wholly bad, and that amendment of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act is not an undesirable way of solving the problem.
('8', 355, 7, 14, 852728) I once more remind you of what you told me at the interviews on the subject: that, if the Asiatics carried out their part of the compromise, you would repeal the Act.
('8', 355, 7, 15, 852895) I know you added also that if there was one recalcitrant Asiatic who obstinately refused to take out a voluntary registration certificate you would enforce the Act against that Asiatic.
('8', 355, 7, 16, 853081) As a matter of fact, within my knowledge, there is no such recalcitrant Asiatic left.
('8', 355, 7, 17, 853167) But, if there were, I have taken the above expression to be purely theatrical to emphasize the fact that the vast majority of the Asiatics then resident in the Colony should abide by the compromise.
('8', 355, 7, 18, 853366) This they have done.
('8', 355, 7, 19, 853387) Time is of the essence of the contract at the present moment,

('8', 357, 6, 13, 857271) 198. CRIME WAVE IN NATAL
('8', 357, 7, 14, 857296) A correspondent draws our attention to the frequency of the recent murders in Natal.
('8', 357, 7, 15, 857381) There have been, he says, seven murders within two weeks: one in Tongaat, two in Cato Manor, one in Spring field, one in Northdene and two in Durban.
('8', 357, 7, 16, 857531) The correspondent adds that only in one of the seven cases have the police been able to appre hend the murderer.
('8', 357, 7, 17, 857644) And that because the culprit gave himself up.
('8', 357, 7, 18, 857690) The correspondent also reports an increase in the number of thefts.
('8', 357, 7, 19, 857758) This matter deserves attention.
('8', 357, 7, 20, 857790) A people that aspires to the
('8', 357, 8, 21, 857819) 1 The preceding item 2 An error for “his”?
('8', 358, 0, 1, 857862) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 359
('8', 358, 1, 2, 857907) privileges of freedom must have the strength to defend itself.
('8', 358, 1, 3, 857970) There are two ways of doing this.
('8', 358, 1, 4, 858004) The first—a simple and straightforward though difficult way—is to reform ourselves, to avoid the creation of circumstances that occasion murder, not to hoard wealth, and to reform those with criminal propensities.
('8', 358, 1, 5, 858218) Till the criminal improves, he must be allowed to commit as many murders as he likes.
('8', 358, 1, 6, 858304) He will give up when he wearies of killing.
('8', 358, 1, 7, 858348) Clearly, this is at once a divine and a natural law.
('8', 358, 1, 8, 858401) As a people, however, we are not yet free to follow this course of not punishing a murderer.
('8', 358, 1, 9, 858494) We shall not assert that a time will never come when all of us acquire enough courage to become indifferent to life and property, but only that it is improbable that this state of affairs will ever come about.
('8', 358, 1, 10, 858704) History records no instance of this ever having happened among any people.
('8', 358, 1, 11, 858779) However, instances are known of individuals who have acted in that manner.
('8', 358, 1, 12, 858854) If we cannot adopt this course, there is another which we, as a people aspiring to be free, ought to know about—that of countering force with force.
('8', 358, 1, 13, 859003) We should become strong enough to defend life and property.
('8', 358, 1, 14, 859063) Of course, protection is provided by the Natal Government.
('8', 358, 1, 15, 859122) But whites do not look on helplessly [when attacked by anyone].
('8', 358, 1, 16, 859186) They equip themselves with the means of self defence.
('8', 358, 1, 17, 859240) If anyone counters by saying that we are not allowed to keep arms or that we cannot have them when we need them, those excuses will not be valid.
('8', 358, 1, 18, 859386) We can defend ourselves without weapons.
('8', 358, 1, 19, 859427) It is a matter of training one’s body and of skill.
('8', 358, 1, 20, 859479) When we were attacked by the whites in Ame rica, we hid ourselves.
('8', 358, 1, 21, 859546) When they attacked the Japanese, the latter armed themselves with sticks and bottles.
('8', 358, 1, 22, 859632) 1 Many whites are able to defend themselves without so much as a revolver.
('8', 358, 1, 23, 859707) Indians must learn to do likewise.
('8', 358, 1, 24, 859742) This of course cannot happen in a day.
('8', 358, 1, 25, 859781) ‘While a fire is raging, what is the use of advising one ever so wisely that one should start digging a well?’ This would be a well deserved taunt.
('8', 358, 1, 26, 859929) But we wish to suggest a measure that can be adopted immediately and will fore stall this taunt.
('8', 358, 1, 27, 860026) Primarily our duty is to search out the hidden causes and suggest permanent remedies.
('8', 358, 1, 28, 860112) It is quackery to apply ointment on a boil; the infection should be traced to its source and effectively treated.
('8', 358, 1, 29, 860226) The immediate thing for the Indian community to do is to petition the Government asking for stricter police protection in loca lities where murders are frequent.
('8', 358, 1, 30, 860388) There is little possibility of the Government being able to provide such protection in outlying areas.
('8', 358, 1, 31, 860491) The residents of these localities or regions should act collectively and
('8', 358, 2, 32, 860564) 1 The incident referred to took place in Canada; vide “Indians in Canada”, 25 4 1908
('8', 359, 0, 1, 860649) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 359, 1, 2, 860691) employ their own watchmen.
('8', 359, 1, 3, 860718) Alternatively, the people in sparsely populated areas should shift to more thickly populated ones.
('8', 359, 1, 4, 860817) Acting collectively in these matters is an essential characteristic of nation hood.

('8', 359, 2, 9, 861122) 199. SARVODAYA [ IV]
('8', 359, 3, 10, 861143) ROOTS OF TRUTH
('8', 359, 4, 11, 861158) If this can happen in the professions mentioned, why not in trade and commerce?
('8', 359, 4, 12, 861238) Why is it that trade is always associated with unscrupulousness?
('8', 359, 4, 13, 861303) We shall see on reflection that it is always assumed that the merchant is moved [solely] by self interest.
('8', 359, 4, 14, 861410) Even though he has a socially useful function, we take it for granted that his object is to fill his own coffers.
('8', 359, 4, 15, 861524) Even the laws are so drafted as to enable the merchant to amass wealth with the utmost speed.
('8', 359, 4, 16, 861618) It is also accepted as a principle that the buyer must offer the lowest possible price and the seller must demand and accept the highest.
('8', 359, 4, 17, 861756) The trader has thus been encouraged in this habit, yet the public themselves look down on him for his dishonesty.
('8', 359, 4, 18, 861870) This principle must be abandoned.
('8', 359, 4, 19, 861904) It is not right that the merchant should look only to self interest and amass wealth.
('8', 359, 4, 20, 861990) This is not trade, but robbery.
('8', 359, 4, 21, 862022) The soldier lays down his life for the state and the trader ought to suffer [a comparable] loss, ought even to lose his life in the interests of society.
('8', 359, 4, 22, 862176) In all states the soldier’s profession is to defend the people; the pastor’s to teach it; the phy sician’s to keep it in health; the lawyer’s to enforce pure justice in it; and the merchant’s to provide for it.
('8', 359, 4, 23, 862387) And it is the duty of each on due occasion to die for the people.
('8', 359, 4, 24, 862453) The soldier must be prepared to die at his post of duty rather than desert it.
('8', 359, 4, 25, 862532) During a plague epidemic, the physician must not run away [from his task] but instead attend to the patients even at the risk of infection.
('8', 359, 4, 26, 862672) The priest must lead people from error to truth even if they should kill him for it.
('8', 359, 4, 27, 862757) The lawyer must ensure, even at the cost of his life, that justice prevails.
('8', 359, 5, 28, 862834) 1 Ruskin found Beauty in “the appearance of felicitous fulfilment of function in living things, more especially of the joyful and right exertion of perfect life in man”.
('8', 359, 5, 29, 863004) (Modern Painters, Vol. II, Part III, Sec.
('8', 359, 5, 30, 863046) I, Ch. 3.) Gandhiji, too, speaks of the beauty
('8', 359, 6, 31, 863093) )) of satyagraha, which is “suffering undergone to exemplify Truth”.
('8', 359, 6, 32, 863162) To see Truth is to assent to it, and thus it helps Reason as a means of ordering social relations.
('8', 360, 0, 1, 863261) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 361
('8', 360, 1, 2, 863306) We pointed out above the proper occasions for members of the professions to lay down their lives.
('8', 360, 1, 3, 863404) What, then, is the proper occasion for the merchant to lay down his life?
('8', 360, 1, 4, 863478) This is a question which all, the merchant included, must ask themselves.
('8', 360, 1, 5, 863552) The man who does not know when to die does not know how to live.
('8', 360, 1, 6, 863617) We have seen that the mer chant’s function is to provide for the people.
('8', 360, 1, 7, 863690) Just as the clergyman’s function is not to earn a stipend but to instruct, so the merchant’s function is not to make profits but to provide for the people.
('8', 360, 1, 8, 863846) The clergyman who devotes himself to preaching has his needs provided for, and in the same manner the merchant will have his profits.
('8', 360, 1, 9, 863980) But neither of them must have an eye only on the main chance.
('8', 360, 1, 10, 864042) Both have work to do—each a duty to perform—irrespective of whether or not they get the stipend or the profit.
('8', 360, 1, 11, 864153) If this proposition is true, the mer chant deserves the highest honour.
('8', 360, 1, 12, 864225) For his duty is to procure com modities of high quality and distribute them at a price which people can afford.
('8', 360, 1, 13, 864337) It also becomes his duty at the same time to ensure the safety and wellbeing of the hundreds or thousands of men working under him.
('8', 360, 1, 14, 864469) This requires a great deal of patience, kindness and intel ligence.
('8', 360, 1, 15, 864537) Also, in discharging these several functions he is bound, as others are bound, to give up his life, if need be.
('8', 360, 1, 16, 864649) Such a trader would not sell adulterated goods or cheat anyone, whatever his difficulties or even if he was going to be reduced to utter poverty.
('8', 360, 1, 17, 864795) Moreover, he will treat the men under him with the utmost kindness.
('8', 360, 1, 18, 864863) Very often a young man taking up a situation with a big factory or commercial house travels a long way from home, so that the master has to accept the role of his parents.
('8', 360, 1, 19, 865035) If the master is indifferent, the young man will be like an orphan.
('8', 360, 1, 20, 865103) At every step, therefore, the merchant or the master must ask himself this question, ‘Do I deal with my servants as I do with my sons?’ Suppose a ship’s captain places his son among the common sailors under his command.
('8', 360, 1, 21, 865323) The captain’s duty is to treat all sailors as he would treat his son.
('8', 360, 1, 22, 865393) In the same manner, a merchant may ask his son to work alongside of those under him.
('8', 360, 1, 23, 865478) He must always treat the workers as he would then treat his son.
('8', 360, 1, 24, 865543) This is the true meaning of economics.
('8', 360, 1, 25, 865582) And as the captain is bound to be the last man to leave his ship in case of shipwreck, so in the event of famine or other calamities, the trader is bound to safeguard the interests of his men before his own.
('8', 360, 1, 26, 865790) All this may sound strange.
('8', 360, 1, 27, 865818) But the really strange thing about the modern age is that it should so sound.
('8', 360, 1, 28, 865896) For anyone who applies his mind to it will be able to see that the true principle is as we have stated
('8', 361, 0, 1, 865999) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 361, 1, 2, 866041) Any other standard is impossible for a progressive nation.
('8', 361, 1, 3, 866100) If the British have survived so long, it is not because they have lived up to the maxims of economics, but because they have had many heroes who have questioned them and followed instead these principles of moral conduct.
('8', 361, 1, 4, 866322) The harm that results from the violation of these principles and the nation’s consequent decline from greatness, we shall consider on another occasion.
('8', 361, 1, 5, 866474) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 6 6 1908

('8', 361, 5, 15, 867148) WHAT WERE THE CHANGES?
('8', 361, 6, 16, 867171) This is the letter that was sent.
('8', 361, 6, 17, 867205) The original draft Act had the following features: 1. it did not refer to the Chinese; 2. even children under sixteen were to take out registers voluntarily; 3. it was provided that the voluntary registrants should not be subject to the penalties of the Act; 4. no provision was made for Indians who might return to the Colony after the date of the settlement; 5. the Registration Office was to be re opened; 6. no reference was made to religious susceptibilities.
('8', 361, 6, 18, 867670) In the letter mentioned above,
('8', 361, 7, 19, 867701) 1 They were translated and paraphrased in the process.
('8', 361, 7, 20, 867756) Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 30 1 1908 2 This has not been translated; for English text, vide :Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 28 1 1908
('8', 362, 0, 1, 867891) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 363
('8', 362, 1, 2, 867936) 1. the Chinese were included; 2. it was provided that children under sixteen should not have to take out the new registers even on a voluntary basis; 3. it was provided that the Act would not apply to voluntary registrants; (The reader should note that there is a great deal of difference between “the Act would not apply [to those who register voluntarily]” and “[they] would not be subject to the penalties of the Act”.) 4. those who came after the date of the settlement were also given the right to apply for voluntary registration; 5. the “reopening of the Registration Office” 1 was capable of two interpretations.
('8', 362, 1, 3, 868557) We therefore wrote “[in order] to accept” registration; 6. reference was made to religious susceptibilities to point out that they must be respected.
('8', 362, 1, 4, 868707) If now we remember that, since the number of those who have applied for voluntary registration is very large, the Act ceases to have any meaning, it will be noted that the repeal of the Act was implied [in our letter].

('8', 363, 2, 6, 870458) INTERVIEW WITH GENERAL SMUTS
('8', 363, 3, 7, 870487) As a result of the notices sent by Indians withdrawing their applications and the good offices of friends like Mr. Cartwright, a letter was received from General Smuts last Friday [inviting Mr. Gandhi] for a discussion on the proposed Bill.
('8', 363, 3, 8, 870728) A meeting of the Committee [of the British Indian Association] was immediately held.

('8', 363, 3, 11, 871060) Mr. Gandhi was instructed not to commit himself in any way to General Smuts.
('8', 363, 3, 12, 871137) He was only to reiterate the demand for the repeal of the outrageous Act.
('8', 363, 3, 13, 871211) The interview with General Smuts took place on Saturday.
('8', 363, 3, 14, 871268) Mr. Mathews, who had drafted the Bill, Mr. Gorges 1 and Mr. Chamney were present at the meeting.

('8', 363, 3, 16, 871497) General Smuts admitted that the Asiatic Act served no useful purpose.
('8', 363, 3, 17, 871567) Mr. Lane’s letter to Mr. Cartwright was the result of a mistake.
('8', 363, 3, 18, 871632) He added that, whatever the nature of the Bill that was ultimately passed, the voluntary registrants would certainly not be subject to the Asiatic Registration Act.
('8', 363, 3, 19, 871797) No clarification was, however, offered about the status of those who had not taken out registers [voluntarily], neither was any assurance given about the repeal of the Act; it was merely stated that the Bill was yet to be drafted.
('8', 363, 3, 20, 872028) That is to say, General Smuts means to keep at least one of his three promises, and voluntary registrants will not therefore come within the scope of the law.
('8', 363, 3, 21, 872187) [But] fulfilling this promise implies the fulfilment of the two others as well.
('8', 363, 3, 22, 872267) For it cannot happen that one half of the Indian community is governed by one law and the other half by another.
('8', 363, 3, 23, 872380) That is, the law will be repealed.
('8', 363, 3, 24, 872415) It has to be.
('8', 363, 3, 25, 872429) The new Bill must also make provision for those who may enter the Colony hereafter.

('8', 367, 1, 2, 879098) 204. SARVODAYA [ V]
('8', 367, 2, 3, 879118) VEINS OF WEALTH
('8', 367, 3, 4, 879134) Economists may reply in the following manner to what we said earlier concerning “roots of truth”: ‘It is true that certain advantages flow from social affection.
('8', 367, 3, 5, 879296) But economists do not take these advantages into their reckoning.
('8', 367, 3, 6, 879362) The science with which they are concerned is the science of getting rich.
('8', 367, 3, 7, 879436) Far from being fallacious, it has in experience been found to be effective.
('8', 367, 3, 8, 879512) Those who follow it do become rich, and those who disregard it become poor.
('8', 367, 3, 9, 879588) All the millionaires of Europe have acquired their wealth by following the laws of this science.
('8', 367, 3, 10, 879685) It is futile to seek to controvert this.
('8', 367, 3, 11, 879726) Every man of the world knows how money is made and how it is lost.’ This is not quite true.
('8', 367, 3, 12, 879818) Men of business do indeed make money but they do not know whether they make it by fair means and if their money making contributes to the national weal.
('8', 367, 3, 13, 879971) Very often they do not even know the meaning of the word “rich”.
('8', 367, 3, 14, 880036) They do not realize that, if there are rich men, there must also be poor men.
('8', 367, 3, 15, 880114) People sometimes believe, mistakenly, that by following certain precepts it is possible for everybody to become rich.
('8', 367, 3, 16, 880232) But the true position can be compared to a water wheel where one [bucket] empties out as another fills.
('8', 367, 3, 17, 880336) The power of the rupee you possess depends on another going without it.
('8', 367, 3, 18, 880408) If no one wants it, it will be useless to you.
('8', 367, 3, 19, 880455) The power it possesses depends on your neighbour’s lack of it.
('8', 367, 3, 20, 880518) There can be wealth only where there is scarcity.
('8', 367, 3, 21, 880568) This means that, in order to be rich, one must keep another poor.
('8', 367, 3, 22, 880634) Political economy consists in the production, preservation and distribution, at the fittest time and place, of useful and pleasurable things.
('8', 367, 3, 23, 880776) The farmer who reaps his harvest at the right time, the builder who lays bricks properly, the carpenter who attends to woodwork with care, the woman who runs her kitchen efficiently are all true political economists.
('8', 367, 3, 24, 880993) All of them add to the national income.
('8', 367, 3, 25, 881033) A science that teaches the opposite of this is not “political”.
('8', 367, 3, 26, 881097) Its only concern is with individuals merely accumulating a certain metal and putting it to profitable use by keeping others in want of it.
('8', 367, 3, 27, 881236) Those who do this estimate their wealth—the value of their farms and cattle—by the number of rupees they can get for them, rather than the value of their rupees by the number of cattle and farms they can buy with them.
('8', 367, 3, 28, 881455) Furthermore, men who thus accumulate metal—rupees—think [in terms] of the number of workmen whose services they can command.
('8', 367, 3, 29, 881580) Let us suppose that a certain individual possesses gold, silver, corn, etc.
('8', 368, 0, 1, 881656) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 369
('8', 368, 1, 2, 881701) This person will require a servant.
('8', 368, 1, 3, 881737) And if none of his neighbours is in need of gold, silver or corn, he will find it difficult to get one.
('8', 368, 1, 4, 881841) He will then have to bake his bread, make his clothes and plough his field all by himself.
('8', 368, 1, 5, 881932) This man will find his gold to be of no greater value than the yellow pebbles on his estate.
('8', 368, 1, 6, 882025) His hoard of corn will rot.
('8', 368, 1, 7, 882053) For he cannot consume more than his neighbour.
('8', 368, 1, 8, 882100) He must therefore maintain himself by hard labour as other men do.
('8', 368, 1, 9, 882167) Most people will not want to accumulate gold or silver on these terms.
('8', 368, 1, 10, 882238) Careful reflection will show that what we really desire through acquisition of wealth is power over other men—[power] to acquire for our advantage the labour of a servant, a tradesman or an artisan.
('8', 368, 1, 11, 882437) And the power we can thus acquire will be in direct proportion to the poverty of others.
('8', 368, 1, 12, 882526) If there is only one person [in a position] to employ a carpenter, the latter will accept whatever wage is offered.
('8', 368, 1, 13, 882642) If there are three or four persons who need his services, he will work for the person who offers him the highest wage.
('8', 368, 1, 14, 882761) So that growing rich means contriving that as large a number of men as possible shall have less than we have.
('8', 368, 1, 15, 882871) Economists generally assume that it is of advantage to the nation as a whole if the mass of people are thus kept in want.
('8', 368, 1, 16, 882993) Equality among men is certainly not possible.
('8', 368, 1, 17, 883039) But conditions of scarcity, unjustly created, injure the nation.
('8', 368, 1, 18, 883104) Scarcity and abundance arising naturally make, and keep, the nation happy.
('8', 368, 1, 19, 883179) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 13 6 1908
('8', 368, 2, 20, 883221) 205. LETTER TO GENERAL SMUTS 1
('8', 368, 3, 21, 883252) JOHANNESBURG, June 13, 1908
('8', 368, 4, 22, 883280) DEAR MR. SMUTS, With reference to the interview I had with you today, I trust you will excuse my trespassing upon your time and attention yet awhile.
('8', 368, 4, 23, 883430) Until the Asiatic question, as far as it arises out of the Asiatic Act, is settled, I am obliged to approach you.
('8', 368, 4, 24, 883544) You doubt my full representative capacity, or, better still, the full representative character of the views submitted by me.
('8', 368, 4, 25, 883669) I admit it only in so far as it affects those who, whilst the passive resistance struggle was going on, accepted the Asiatic Act.
('8', 368, 4, 26, 883799) Even they do not differ from my views, but they, like the national scouts, intend to save their faces.
('8', 368, 5, 27, 883902) 1 This was republished in Indian Opinion, 4 7 1908, and a copy was sent by Ritch as an annexure to his letter of July 27, 1908 to the Colonial Office.
('8', 369, 0, 1, 884053) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 369, 1, 2, 884095) But I hope, with your assistance, to have even them side by side with the other membersof the community.
('8', 369, 1, 3, 884200) I clearly consider that they have erred from fear, but every endeavour is being made to win them over, and, should they not—why, they represent but a microscopic minority.
('8', 369, 1, 4, 884372) Some of them have had many conversations with me, and they are, undoubtedly, as anxious as the rest of the community that the Asiatic Act should be repealed.
('8', 369, 1, 5, 884530) With reference to the amendment of the Immigration Act, I wish to make the Asiatic position perfectly clear with reference to the following: 1. No position will ever be accepted by the Asiatic communities that does not put those who have not yet entered the country but are entitled to do so on a level with Asiatics who have voluntarily registered.
('8', 369, 1, 6, 884880) They will, therefore, exchange their documents under the amended Act, and take out certificates in the same form as the voluntary form.
('8', 369, 1, 7, 885016) 2. Refugees who have not yet received permits under the Peace Preservation Ordinance should be protected.
('8', 369, 1, 8, 885122) There will be no objection to defining who may be termed a refugee—I suggest residence in the Transvaal for two years prior to the 11th day of October, 1899—and a period may be fixed within which these applications may be received, say one year, and they should be entitled to prove their claim before a court of law.
('8', 369, 1, 9, 885440) 3. Those who hold £3 Dutch Registration Certificates should also be protected, the onus being on them to prove that they are bona fide holders thereof.
('8', 369, 1, 10, 885592) 4. Those who hold Peace Preservation Ordinance permits or permits issued by Asiatic Officers should be protected.
('8', 369, 1, 11, 885706) 5. Those who possess educational qualifications, whatever the test may be, should be free like the European immigrants.
('8', 369, 1, 12, 885826) 6. There are applications being made which have not been yet decided by Mr. Chamney, or which he has refused.
('8', 369, 1, 13, 885936) These should be decided finally before a court of law.
('8', 369, 1, 14, 885991) You told me that you did not want to give any rights of domicile beyond those given by the Asiatic Act.
('8', 369, 1, 15, 886095) You will see that in the above, with the exception of holders of £3 Dutch registration certificates, all are provided for under the Asiatic Act, and I have told you that, in my opinion, and according to Mr. Duncan’s speech, even the holders of £3 Dutch registration certificates are protected under the discretionary clause.
('8', 369, 1, 16, 886420) Only I have suggested that they should be recognized as a matter of right, provided, of course, that they prove their bona fides.
('8', 369, 1, 17, 886550) I need hardly point out that refugees are protected by the
('8', 370, 0, 1, 886609) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 371
('8', 370, 1, 2, 886654) Asiatic Act, because the Peace Preservation Ordinance permits were still to be issued.
('8', 370, 1, 3, 886741) They have only lately been stopped, under your instructions and by virtue of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act, but I am sure you could never have intended that those who are still outside the Colony and who can beincontestably proved to be old residents should not have their claims considered.
('8', 370, 1, 4, 887035) The definition of a refugee and the time limit provide against possible frauds.
('8', 370, 1, 5, 887115) I ask you to recognize the very great service rendered by the Indian community in giving finger prints in the face of enormous odds, and to recognize also that the resident portion of the community did not avail themselves of the discretionary clause of the compro mise, with reference to education and property qualifications.
('8', 370, 1, 6, 887443) This was done in order to protect those few who were to come in future, and to show what grace, if I may use the term, Asiatic peoples are capable of.
('8', 370, 1, 7, 887594) But I may state that they will never accept, so far as I am aware, anything in the nature of compulsion, when they can be otherwise completely identified.
('8', 370, 1, 8, 887749) The idea is that ignorance or such other thing should be the basis of disqualification, and not race or colour.
('8', 370, 1, 9, 887861) The great principle that the Colonists have laid down, namely, that, in future, Asiatic immigration should be limited only to those who possess educational qualifications of a high order has been admitted.
('8', 370, 1, 10, 888067) But those who are entitled to reside in the country will not accept the bar sinister 1. And, if the question cannot be satisfactorily settled on the above, as I consider it, most reasonable basis, it is better that it is not settled at all.
('8', 370, 1, 11, 888308) I take it that, as you have promised, you will let me see the draft Bill before it is published.
('8', 370, 1, 12, 888405) I have informed the Committee of the Association that you have definitely promised to settle the matter next week.
('8', 370, 1, 13, 888520) The Committee has, therefore, authorized me to postpone the filing of the affidavits 2 in the meanwhile.

('8', 371, 2, 3, 889002) JOHANNESBURG, June 15, 1908
('8', 371, 3, 4, 889030) TO THE HON’BLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HON’BLE THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE TRANSVAAL PRETORIA
('8', 371, 4, 5, 889135) THE PETITION OF ESSOP ISMAIL MIA IN HIS CAPACITY AS CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION OF THE TRANSVAAL
('8', 371, 5, 6, 889247) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT 1. Your Petitioner has read with alarm Sections 3, 104, 113, 114, 127, 128 of the Bill2 to amend the Gold Law of the Colony, recently published in the Government Gazette.
('8', 371, 5, 7, 889438) 2. Your Petitioner humbly submits that the above mentioned Sections, if they are approved by this Hon’ble House, will impose upon British Indians resident in the Transvaal disabilities graver than those contemplated by the existing Gold Law, thereby inflicting grave loss to and threatening with ruin a community admitted to be peaceable and law abiding.
('8', 371, 5, 8, 889793) 3. Your Petitioner ventures to draw the attention of this Hon’ble House to the following specific objections 3 on the part of the British Indians resident in this Colony: (a) The Bill retains in the definition of the term “Coloured person” the word “coolie”, which, as this Hon’ble House is doubtless aware, when applied to the present British Indian population of the Colony, is an offensive term, there being in the Transvaal very few, if any, “coolies” in the proper sense of the term.
('8', 371, 5, 9, 890282) Moreover, the bracketing together of African aboriginal Natives and Asiatics, British subjects and non British subjects, is to ignore the peculiar position occupied by British Indian subjects of the Crown.
('8', 371, 5, 10, 890488) (b) In your Petitioner’s humble opinion, the definition of “unwrought gold” is calculated to prevent Indian goldsmiths from plying their trade of manufacturing goldware and jewellery even out of gold bars prepared in and imported from
('8', 371, 6, 11, 890723) 1 This appeared in Indian Opinion, 20 6 1908, under the title “Transvaal Gold Law: British Indian Protest”.
('8', 371, 6, 12, 890831) 2 For the relevant sections of the Draft Gold Law.
('8', 371, 6, 13, 890882) 3 Vide also “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, Before 25 4 1908.
('8', 372, 0, 1, 890944) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 373
('8', 372, 1, 2, 890989) England, and, it is submitted, this would be a grievous hardship for the goldsmiths in question.
('8', 372, 1, 3, 891086) (c) The retention of the original law as to dealing in unwrought gold, in so far as it specially affects Coloured people, besides their coming under the general prohibitions of the law, assumes that Coloured people are the greater offenders in respect of this crime, whereas, in the humble opinion of the petitioning Association, the contrary is the fact, in so far as British Indians are concerned.
('8', 372, 1, 4, 891486) (d) Your Petitioner ventures to assert that Section 127 of the Bill is vaguely drawn and seems to contemplate entire prohibition of acquisition by British Indians of any rights under it.
('8', 372, 1, 5, 891673) The prohibition, under the same Section, to holders of rights acquired previously to the Bill to transfer or sub let such rights to a Coloured person makes the proposed law retrospective in its effect.
('8', 372, 1, 6, 891875) (e) Section 128 contemplates the compulsory segregation of British Indians residing within certain proclaimed areas, to wit, the entire Witwatersrand District, and, if approved by this Hon’ble House, would make it impossible for a very large number of British Indians even to remain in the Colony.
('8', 372, 1, 7, 892173) Your Petitioner would remind this Hon’ble House that the large majority of British Indians resident in the Transvaal are to be found in the above mentioned areas, whilst the principle of compulsory segregation of British Indians under penalty is a direct extension of existing disabilities by indirect means, which disabilities the petitioning Association has consistently protested against.
('8', 372, 1, 8, 892565) 4. Your Petitioner ventures to assert that, inasmuch as these Sections are based upon race and class distinctions, they can never give satisfaction to the British Indian community.
('8', 372, 1, 9, 892746) Moreover, such distinctions cast an undeserved slur upon the community that your Petitioner has the honour to represent, as they must inevitably raise in the minds of the white Colonists of the Transvaal, feelings of contempt and scorn towards British Indians, thus increasing the difficulties unfortunately standing in the way of a better understanding between the two communities.
('8', 372, 1, 10, 893129) 5. In your Petitioner’s humble opinion, restrictions of the kind above referred to obviously confer absolutely no privileges upon British Indians, but, on the contrary, deprive them of many rights and much esteem that they at present possess.

('8', 373, 4, 7, 894108) 207. PETITION TO TRANASVAAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY 1
('8', 373, 5, 8, 894159) JOHANNESBURG, June 15, 1908
('8', 373, 6, 9, 894187) TO THE HON’BLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE TRANSVAAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY PRETORIA
('8', 373, 7, 10, 894273) THE PETITION OF ESSOP ISMAIL MIA, IN HIS CAPACITY AS CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION OF THE TRANSVAAL
('8', 373, 8, 11, 894386) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT 1. Your Petitioner has read with grave concern Sections 68, 93, 94 and 172 of the Bill to consolidate and amend the law relating to Municipal Government, recently published in the Government Gazette of this Colony.
('8', 373, 8, 12, 894621) 2. In your Petitioner’s humble opinion, the above mentioned Sections, if they are approved by this Hon’ble House, will impose very great hardship and loss upon the British Indian community resident in the Transvaal, will ruin many peaceable and law abiding citizens, and break up many an Indian home.
('8', 373, 8, 13, 894922) 3. Your Petitioner ventures to assert that, inasmuch as these Sections are based upon race and class distinctions, they can never give satisfaction to the British Indian community.
('8', 373, 8, 14, 895103) Moreover, such
('8', 373, 9, 15, 895118) 1 This was published under the title “Transvaal Municipal Consolidation Bill: British Indian Protest”.
('8', 374, 0, 1, 895221) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 375
('8', 374, 1, 2, 895266) distinctions cast an undeserved slur upon the community that your Petitioner has the honour to represent, as they must inevitably raise in the minds of the white Colonists of the Transvaal feelings of contempt and scorn towards British Indians, thus increasing the difficulties unfortunately standing in the way of a better understanding between the two communities.
('8', 374, 1, 3, 895633) 4. In your Petitioner’s humble opinion, the above provisions are open to serious objection on the ground that they are restrictive of the liberty of the subject, in that thereby it is sought to empower the municipalities: (a) to set apart new Asiatic Bazaars, thus reasserting the prin ciple of segregation of British Indians, a principle against which the petitioning Association [has] consistently pro tested; (b) to close existing Asiatic Bazaars without consulting the convenience of those who may be thereby affected and without guaranteeing to them fresh sites equally valuable and convenient (such uncertainty of tenure, as this Hon’ ble House will easily perceive, cannot but militate seriously against a settled and decent mode of life, and the erection of permanent and solid residential premises, by British Indians); (c) to arbitrarily refuse certain licences, including hawkers’ and pedlars’ licences, without the right of appeal from their decisions, thus striking a deadly blow at the long established businesses of Indian merchants, traders, haw kers, pedlars, and others, threatening them with immediate ruin; the licences which come under this last provision, may, under the Bill, be arbitrarily refused to those who, today, have the right of appeal from the adverse decisions of municipalities; (d) to indicate certain trades and businesses from which Bri tish Indians are excluded in any capacity, whether as would be licensees or as employees, thus restricting their means of earning an honest livelihood; (e) to frame regulations prohibiting British Indians respect ably dressed and well conducted from travelling upon municipal tram cars, thus imposing humiliation upon a highly civilized community and debasing it to the level of the aboriginal native of the country.
('8', 374, 1, 4, 897425) 5. In your Petitioner’s humble opinion, restrictions of the kind above referred to obviously confer absolutely no privileges upon
('8', 375, 0, 1, 897555) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 375, 1, 2, 897597) British Indians, but, on the contrary, deprive them of many rights and much esteem that they at present possess.
('8', 375, 1, 3, 897710) 6. Your Petitioner further ventures to remind this Hon’ble House that the imposition of further disabilities upon the resident British Indian population of the Transvaal will enormously intensify the irritation and bitterness of feeling already existing in the minds of many millions of His Majesty’s subjects in India.
('8', 375, 1, 4, 898030) 7. Wherefore, your Petitioner humbly prays that this Hon’ble House will be pleased to reject the provisions hereinbefore referred to, or to grant such other relief as to this Hon’ble House may seem meet; and for this act, etc., etc.

('8', 379, 6, 6, 906430) 210. CAUSE OF MURDERS IN NATAL
('8', 379, 7, 7, 906461) Following upon our article 2 on the murders committed among the Natal Indians, a correspondent states that the growing prevalence of adultery among Indians is the cause of these murders.
('8', 379, 7, 8, 906648) He observes that [the cause of] most of these murders can be traced to women.
('8', 379, 7, 9, 906726) This is regrettable, if true.
('8', 379, 7, 10, 906756) What we write now is unlikely to fall into the hands of those who are busy committing murders or others who are the cause of them.
('8', 379, 7, 11, 906887) But the readers of this journal must think [this matter over].
('8', 379, 7, 12, 906950) Every thoughtful person can help in solving these problems.
('8', 379, 7, 13, 907010) If it is true that adultery is on the increase among the Indian youth, that is a sign of our degeneracy.
('8', 379, 7, 14, 907115) We are in the habit of comparing our vices with those of the whites and if we have some in common, we take no further notice of them.
('8', 379, 7, 15, 907249) This attitude reveals how depraved we are.
('8', 379, 7, 16, 907292) Following that line of thinking, we conclude that the whites are superior to us and that they have attained the acme of virtue.
('8', 379, 7, 17, 907420) In fact, the whites are generally not superior to us.
('8', 379, 7, 18, 907474) It is equally false that we cannot become more virtuous.
('8', 379, 7, 19, 907531) There is no more fallacious argument than that we may indulge in adultery because the whites do so.
('8', 379, 7, 20, 907631) Their adultery is a different sort of thing, and even in their case, a strenuous effort is being made by their priests and reformers to eradicate the vice.
('8', 379, 8, 21, 907787) 1 This was sent at 7.40 p.m.
