('8', 381, 1, 2, 910388) 212. MEMORIAL COLUMN IN JOHANNESBURG
('8', 381, 2, 3, 910425) We publish alongside of this, as a supplement to today’s issue, a photograph 1 a memorial column erected in Johannesburg.
('8', 381, 2, 4, 910547) It was erected by public subscription at the end of the Boer War.
('8', 381, 2, 5, 910613) At the moment, it is the only symbol in South Africa [that] perpetuates the memory of Indians there.
('8', 381, 2, 6, 910714) The first one is a close view of the column and the inscription on it.
('8', 381, 2, 7, 910785) The second affords a view of the column amidst As surroun dings.
('8', 381, 2, 8, 910850) The photograph thus serves to give an idea of the elevation at which the column is built.
('8', 381, 2, 9, 910940) Visible at some distance from the column is the boundary of Sir George Farrar’s farm.
('8', 381, 2, 10, 911026) The column is of carved stone set in cement.
('8', 381, 2, 11, 911071) It is fenced in with iron palings so as to avoid risk of damage to the inscription on the marble tablet set in it.
('8', 381, 2, 12, 911186) The column is located near the Johannesburg Observatory (the department which studies atmospheric phenomena).
('8', 381, 2, 13, 911296) That is to say, it stands atop the highest eminence in Johannesburg thanks to the concerted efforts of the people.
('8', 381, 2, 14, 911411) The large marble slab is set on the eastern face of the column.
('8', 381, 2, 15, 911475) It carries the following inscription: To the sacred memory of British officers and other ranks and Indian sepoys who lid down their lives on the fields of battle in South Africa between 1899 1902. These lines are inscribed in Hindi, Urdu and English.
('8', 381, 2, 16, 911726) A marble slab has been set on each of the other three faces of the column.
('8', 381, 2, 17, 911801) Thefollowing words are inscribed on them in this order: Mussalman; Christian Zoroastrian; Hindu Sikh.
('8', 381, 2, 18, 911903) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 20 6 1908
('8', 381, 3, 19, 911945) 213. SARVODAYA[ VI]
('8', 381, 4, 20, 911965) VEINS OF WEALTH
('8', 381, 5, 21, 911981) Thus the circulation of wealth among a people resembles the circulation of blood in the body.
('8', 381, 5, 22, 912075) When circulation of blood is rapid, it may indicate any of these things: robust health, [effects of] exercise,or a feeling of shame or fever.
('8', 381, 5, 23, 912217) There is a flush of the body which is
('8', 381, 6, 24, 912255) 1 This should be "two photographs".
('8', 382, 0, 1, 912291) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 383
('8', 382, 1, 2, 912336) indicative of health, and another which is a sign of gangrene.
('8', 382, 1, 3, 912399) Further more, the concentration of blood at one spot is harmful to the body and, similarly, concentration of wealth at one place proves to be the nation’s undoing.
('8', 382, 1, 4, 912563) Let us suppose that two sailors are shipwrecked on an uninhabited coast They are then obliged to produce food and other necessaries of life through their own labour.
('8', 382, 1, 5, 912729) If they both keep good health and work in amity, they may build a good house, till the land and lay by something for the future.
('8', 382, 1, 6, 912858) All these things would constitute real wealth.
('8', 382, 1, 7, 912905) If both of them work equally well they will have equal shares.
('8', 382, 1, 8, 912968) Therefore, all that [economic] science would have to say about their case is that they had acquired a right to an equal share in the fruits of their labour.
('8', 382, 1, 9, 913125) Let us suppose now that after a while one of them feels dis contented.
('8', 382, 1, 10, 913196) So they divide the land and each one works on his land by himself and on his own account.
('8', 382, 1, 11, 913286) Let us suppose that at a critical time one of them falls ill.
('8', 382, 1, 12, 913348) He would then approach the other for help.
('8', 382, 1, 13, 913391) The latter might reply: ‘I shall do this work for you, but on condition that you do the same amount of work for me when required.
('8', 382, 1, 14, 913521) You must undertake in writing to work on my field when required for the same number of hours that I work [for you now].’ Suppose further that the disabled man’s illness continues and that every time he has to give a written promise to the other, healthy person.
('8', 382, 1, 15, 913783) What will be the position of the reduced to utter poverty.
('8', 382, 1, 16, 913842) For, during the time that the invalid was laid up, his labour was unavailable.
('8', 382, 1, 17, 913921) Even assuming that the friend was very hard working, it is obvious that the time which he devoted to the ailing man’s land was at the expense of work on his own.
('8', 382, 1, 18, 914083) This means that the combined property of the two would be less than it would have been otherwise.
('8', 382, 1, 19, 914181) Also, the relation in which the two stood to each other has altered.
('8', 382, 1, 20, 914250) The sick man becomes a debtor, and can only offer his labour [as payment towards the debt].
('8', 382, 1, 21, 914342) Suppose now that the healthy man decided to make use of the documents in his possession.
('8', 382, 1, 22, 914431) He would then find it possible wholly to abstain, from work—that is, be idle.
('8', 382, 1, 23, 914509) If he chose, he could exact further pledges 1 from the man who has recovered.
('8', 382, 1, 24, 914587) No one can attribute any illegality to such a transaction.
('8', 382, 1, 25, 914646) If now a stranger were to arrive on the scene, he would find that one of the two men had become wealthy and the other had lost his well being.
('8', 382, 1, 26, 914789) He would also see one of them passing his days in idle luxury and the other in want, though labouring hard.
('8', 382, 1, 27, 914897) The reader will note from this that claiming the fruits of another’s labour as of right
('8', 382, 2, 28, 914985) 1 Pledges of bonded labour in return for the provision of the debtor's current needs
('8', 383, 0, 1, 915070) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 383, 1, 2, 915112) leads to a diminution of real wealth.
('8', 383, 1, 3, 915150) Let us consider another illustration.
('8', 383, 1, 4, 915188) [Suppose that] three men established a kingdom 1 and then they all lived separately.
('8', 383, 1, 5, 915273) Each of them raised a different crop which the others could also avail them selves of.
('8', 383, 1, 6, 915360) Suppose, further, that one of them, in order to save the time of all the three, gave up farming and undertook to arrange the transfer of commodities from one to the other, receiving in return a quantity of food grains.
('8', 383, 1, 7, 915579) If this man provided the [required] commodity 2 at the right time, all of them would prosper.
('8', 383, 1, 8, 915673) Now suppose that he kept back some of the grain he was to transfer.
('8', 383, 1, 9, 915741) Then suppose there set in a period of scarcity, and the middleman offered the stolen corn at an exorbitant price.
('8', 383, 1, 10, 915855) In this way he could reduce both the farmers to poverty and employ them as labourers.
('8', 383, 1, 11, 915941) This would be a case of obvious injustice.
('8', 383, 1, 12, 915984) This is, however, the way the merchants of today manage their affairs.
('8', 383, 1, 13, 916055) We can also see that in consequence of this fraudulent practice the wealth of the three, taken collectively, will be less than it would have been if the [middle]man had behaved honestly.
('8', 383, 1, 14, 916242) The other two farmers have done less work [than they could have].
('8', 383, 1, 15, 916308) Because they could not obtain the supplies they wanted, their labour did not fructify to the fullest, and the stolen commodities 3 the hands of the dishonest middleman were not put to the most effective use.
('8', 383, 1, 16, 916516) We can therefore reckon with mathematical accuracy how far the estimate of a nation’s wealth depends on the manner in which that wealth has been acquired.
('8', 383, 1, 17, 916671) We cannot estimate a nation’s wealth on the basis of the quantity of cash it possesses.
('8', 383, 1, 18, 916759) Cash in the hands of an individual may be a token of perseverance, skill and prosperity, or of harmful luxuries, merciless tyranny and chicanery.
('8', 383, 1, 19, 916905) Our way of estimating wealth not only takes into account the moral attributes [of thedifferent modes of acquiring it] but is also sound mathematically.
('8', 383, 1, 20, 917057) One stock of money is such that it has created ten times as much in the gathering of it.
('8', 383, 1, 21, 917146) Another is such that it has annihilated ten times as much in the gathering of it.
('8', 383, 1, 22, 917228) To lay down directions for the making of money without regardto moral considerations is therefore a pursuit that bespeaks of man’s insolence.
('8', 383, 1, 23, 917370) There is nothing more disgraceful to man than the
('8', 383, 2, 24, 917420) 1 “Republic” in Unto This Last 2 Farming implements, seeds, etc.
('8', 383, 2, 25, 917485) 3 The food grains and farming implements withheld by the middleman
('8', 384, 0, 1, 917552) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 385
('8', 384, 1, 2, 917597) principle “buy in the cheapest market and sell in the dearest”.
('8', 384, 1, 3, 917661) Buy in the cheapest market?
('8', 384, 1, 4, 917689) Yes, but what made your market cheap?
('8', 384, 1, 5, 917727) Char coal may be cheap among roof timbers after a fire and the bricks of buildings brought down by an earthquake may be cheap.
('8', 384, 1, 6, 917854) But no one therefore will make bold to assert that fire and earthquake redound to the nation’s benefit.
('8', 384, 1, 7, 917958) Again, sell in the dearest market?
('8', 384, 1, 8, 917993) Yes, but what made your market dear?
('8', 384, 1, 9, 918030) You made good profit today from the sale of your bread.
('8', 384, 1, 10, 918086) But was it by extorting the last cowrie from a dying man?
('8', 384, 1, 11, 918144) Or, did you sell it to a rich man who will tomorrow appropriate all that you have?
('8', 384, 1, 12, 918227) Or did you give it to a bandit on his way to pillaging your bank?
('8', 384, 1, 13, 918293) Probably you will not be able to answer any of these questions, for you do not know.
('8', 384, 1, 14, 918378) But there is one question you can answer, namely, whether you sold it justly and at a reasonable price.
('8', 384, 1, 15, 918482) And justice is all that matters.
('8', 384, 1, 16, 918515) It is your duty to act so that no one suffers through your actions.

('8', 385, 1, 2, 918994) 215. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('8', 385, 2, 3, 919021) JOHANNESBURG, June 22, 1908 Various statements have appeared in the Press regarding the charge of breach by the Colonial Secretary of the compromise between the Government and the Asiatic communities.
('8', 385, 2, 4, 919222) Hitherto, owing to the delicate nature of the negotiations that were going on between the Government and the Asiatic communities, it has not been possible to state the case before the public.
('8', 385, 2, 5, 919414) I am sorry to say that the negotiations came to an abrupt and unsatisfactory end today.
('8', 385, 2, 6, 919502) I use the term unsatisfactory as applicable not merely to the Asiatics, but to the whole Empire.
('8', 385, 2, 7, 919599) General Smuts was willing to repeal the offending Asiatic Act, which has cost the Asiatics treasures of money and much trouble, including incarceration of over two hundred innocent Asiatics, mostly British.
('8', 385, 2, 8, 919806) This shows that General Smuts was, and still is, under promise to repeal the Act.
('8', 385, 2, 9, 919888) But if he was willing to carry out the letter of the compromise, he wanted to break the spirit of it.
('8', 385, 2, 10, 919990) For it will not be argued that the material position of the Asiatics was, under and after the compromise, to be lower than under the Asiatic Act.
('8', 385, 2, 11, 920136) Yet such was General Smuts’ draft which I was today pained to study and, so far as I was concerned, to reject.
('8', 385, 2, 12, 920247) The draft measure proposed to treat the following as prohibited immigrants: (a) Asiatics possessing educational qualifications prescribed by the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('8', 385, 2, 13, 920421) (b) Asiatics, whether in or out of the Colony, holding Dutch registration certificates under Law 3 of 1885, for which they paid £3. (c) Other Asiatics who were residents of the Transvaal before the war, and who could prove before a court of law their previous domicile.
('8', 385, 2, 14, 920691) (d) Those Asiatics whose claims have been rejected by Mr. Chamney.
('8', 385, 2, 15, 920758) (For these it is contended only that they
('8', 385, 3, 16, 920800) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 27 6 1908, under the title “Mr. Gandhi Speaks”.
('8', 385, 3, 17, 920888) It was also published in The Star among other papers.
('8', 385, 3, 18, 920942) The Star version is, however, unavailable.
('8', 385, 3, 19, 920985) Ritch forwarded a copy of the letter to the India Office.
('8', 385, 3, 20, 921043) He described it as a “circular letter” which set out the “issues between the Transvaal Government and the British Indians”.

('8', 386, 1, 2, 921212) should have the right to have their claims investigated by a judicial tribunal, not finally disposed of by an adminis trative official.) In rejecting these claims for consideration and adjudication, not for admission ipso facto, General Smuts has misread the passive resistance struggle.
('8', 386, 1, 3, 921500) It was undertaken, not for selfish purposes, but for the benefit of the Asiatics as a whole, and, shall I add, even the Empire.
('8', 386, 1, 4, 921628) Moreover, he has wrecked a whole compromise to avoid the possible accession to the Asiatic population of the Colony of two thousand Asiatics as an outside figure.
('8', 386, 1, 5, 921791) I call these people an “accession”, but, in fact, they are already domiciled residents of the Colony, though General Smuts’ draft ignored their rights.
('8', 386, 1, 6, 921943) The position of the Asiatics is simple.
('8', 386, 1, 7, 921983) They must revert to the condition that prevailed in January last in this matter, and they have been advised to withdraw their voluntary application forms.
('8', 386, 1, 8, 922138) 1 General Smuts has declined to return them.
('8', 386, 1, 9, 922183) If he had the courage to face the passive resisters, he would return them without much ado.
('8', 386, 1, 10, 922275) Asiatics were labouring under a cloud of suspicion up to January last.
('8', 386, 1, 11, 922346) Mr. Duncan had levelled the charge and it was repeated, even in the highest places, that there was an organized illicit entry of Asiatics.
('8', 386, 1, 12, 922485) 2 The fact that over 7,600 out of 9,000 have already proved their bona fides disposes of the charge.
('8', 386, 1, 13, 922586) It was in order to refute that foul charge that voluntary registration was tendered, and for no other reason.
('8', 386, 1, 14, 922696) The Asiatics, therefore, approach the public with clean hands.
('8', 386, 1, 15, 922759) Moreover, they have shown by their sufferings that they have a right to command sympathy from a humanitarian public.
('8', 386, 1, 16, 922876) Lastly, they have shown, by some of their leaders being severely assaulted by their own countrymen, that they are just as eager to serve the Government as they are to serve their countrymen.
('8', 386, 1, 17, 923067) General Smuts’ Act will be that of the Government and the Government’s will be the white men’s—mostly British.
('8', 386, 1, 18, 923178) When I explai ned the compromise to my countrymen, the less thinking among them said: “Do not trust the white man.
('8', 386, 1, 19, 923293) Repeal of the Act should precede voluntary registration and not succeed it.” I told them that that was not a dignified position to take up.
('8', 386, 1, 20, 923433) In tampering with the compromise, I venture to say that General Smuts does not know what he is doing.
('8', 386, 1, 21, 923535) Will the Englishmen in the
('8', 386, 2, 22, 923562) 1Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 30 5 1908 2Vide “Deputation to Morley”, 22 11 1906

('8', 387, 6, 15, 924593) 217. INTERVIEW TO “THE STAR” 2
('8', 387, 7, 16, 924624) [PRETORIA, June 22, 1908]
('8', 387, 8, 17, 924650) We regret to announce that all efforts to avoid a breach of the settlement, arrived at last January between the Government and the Transvaal Asiatics, have proved unsuccessful.
('8', 387, 9, 18, 924827) At the request of the Colonial Secretary, Mr. Gandhi waited on him this morning and was permitted to peruse the draft amendment to the Immigration Restriction Act proposed by the Government.
('8', 387, 9, 19, 925018) General Smuts intimated that it was the intention of the Government to repeal the Asiatic Registration Act.
('8', 387, 10, 20, 925126) 1 This is taken from a precis of events in the Transvaal sent by Ritch along with his letter of October 6, 1908 to the Colonial Office.
('8', 387, 10, 21, 925262) 2 This was republished in Indian Opinion under the title “The Transvaal Trouble: General Smuts Plays False”.
('8', 388, 0, 1, 925371) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 389
('8', 388, 1, 2, 925416) After perusing the Act, Mr. Gandhi had an interview with the Colonial Secre tary, and raised the following points: (a) The position of the Asiatics who had made voluntary application for registration, having given their finger prints, and who for some reason or other have not received their permits.
('8', 388, 1, 3, 925717) Mr. Gandhi asked that, in case[s] where permits were refused, an application or appeal should lie from the Registrar of Asiatics to some judicial officer; (b) he also asked that those Indians outside South Africa, whoare in possession of residential passports issued by the Republican Government in return for the registration fee of £3, should be permitted on returning from India to register voluntarily; (c) that the educational exemption should be maintained in the new Act as it was in the old; (d) that genuine refugees domiciled in the Transvaal before the war, now in India or elsewhere, who were in possession of the Republican passport or not, be permitted, on producing evidence, to return and register voluntarily.
('8', 388, 2, 4, 926444) With regard to the education exemption, General Smuts argued that they had no exemption under the original law.
('8', 388, 2, 5, 926556) He declined to make provisions for appeal from the Registrar of Asiatics in cases where voluntary registration had been refused.
('8', 388, 2, 6, 926685) He also declined to offer facilities for the return of Asiatics at present out of the country, who were genuine refugees, or possessed the Republican residential passport.
('8', 388, 3, 7, 926857) The interview was a brief one, and the Colonial Secretary, we understand, intimated to Mr. Gandhi that if he, as leader of the Indian community, was prepared to accept the proposed amendments to the Immigration Restriction Act, the Asiatic Law Amendment Act would be withdrawn.
('8', 388, 3, 8, 927135) The Colonial Secretary would proceed to introduce a Bill legalizing the registration in the existing Registration Act.
('8', 388, 4, 9, 927254) Mr. Gandhi then withdrew, and during the course of an interview gave a representative of this paper authority to make the above statement.
('8', 388, 4, 10, 927393) He stated that he would immediately apply to the Supreme Court for an order calling on Mr. Chamney
('8', 388, 5, 11, 927492) 1 Indian Opinion published the following report of a statement by General Smuts: “In connection with Mr. Gandhi's statement, we have received a statement from the Colonial Secretary to the effect that the repeal of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act was not part of the arrangement with the Asiatics, as was apparent from letters constituting the arrangements.
('8', 388, 5, 12, 927848) The Colonial Secretary was willing to meet the Indian community and repeal Act 2 of 1907 and to treat Indians in future coming into the Transvaal as prohibited Indians under the Immigrants’Restriction Act if the leaders of the Asiatic community would agree to the amendment of the Act which the Colonial Secretary proposed.
('8', 388, 5, 13, 928172) These proposed amendments were submitted to Mr. Gandhi, and they did not at all satisfy him for various reasons, which he advanced, and therefore he was informed that nothing remained to be done but to abide by the agreed terms of the compromise, as the Colonial Secretary was unwilling to repeal Act 2 of 1907 and then to find an agitation started afresh against the Immigrants’Act.
('8', 388, 5, 14, 928556) Voluntary registration would not be legalized under Act 2 of 1907 but under a separate measure, according to the compromise.”

('8', 389, 3, 4, 928852) 218. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('8', 389, 4, 5, 928893) [JOHANNESBURG, June 22, 1908]
('8', 389, 5, 6, 928923) Mr. Gandhi was seen last night by a representative of The Transvaal Leader, and, asked to state what course it is now intended to adopt, Mr. Gandhi said: Throughout the negotiations the leaders of the Indian community have been kept informed, as also, indeed, the general body of the community, of what was going on.
('8', 389, 5, 7, 929240) Though, therefore, the decision of General Smuts has come to them as a painful surprise, they have not been taken altogether unawares.
('8', 389, 5, 8, 929375) When it first became known that there was no likelihood of the Act being repealed, many Indians wrote to Mr. Chamney asking him to return their application forms and other documents filed with him voluntarily.
('8', 389, 5, 9, 929585) These documents have not been returned.
('8', 389, 5, 10, 929625) The Supreme Court will be approached immediately, and if the documents are returned, that at once places the Indian community in the position in which it was before the compromise —that is to say, every Indian is liable to be prosecuted, under the Asiatic Act, for non registration; but if the action were unsuccessful, even then so far as I am aware, it is not the intention of the Asiatics to allow voluntary registration to be legalized anyhow.
('8', 389, 5, 11, 930073) Immediately on my return from Pretoria, a meeting of the committee was held, and the members were very enthusiastic.
('8', 389, 5, 12, 930190) They realized that the whole of the passive resistance will have to be gone through all over again, and they seem to me to be ready for it.
('8', 389, 5, 13, 930330) We are holding on Wednesday next at three o’clock, in front of the Hamidia Mosque, a mass meeting of British Indians throughout the Colony, 2 Delegates have been invited by telegram from all parts of the Colony.
('8', 389, 5, 14, 930542) A series of resolutions will be passed at the meeting.

K. Gandhi, Honorary Secretary, British Indian Association, as follows: (a) residents of the Transvaal would apply voluntarily, within a period of three months, for registration certificates in a form to be agreed upon between the leaders of the Indian community and the Government; (b) those who were outside the Transvaal but had domiciliary rights in the Colony and possessed the right of re entry, would also be eligible for voluntary registration; (c) on the fulfilment by Asiatics of their obligations in accordance with the terms of the compromise, the Government would repeal the Act; and those Asiatics who had registered voluntarily would not in any way be subject to the operation of the Asiatic Registration Act.
('8', 391, 3, 5, 933759) (6) As far as he is aware, most Indians had applied for voluntary reg istration.

('8', 393, 1, 2, 936368) 221. ESSOP MIA’S AFFIDAVIT 1
('8', 393, 2, 3, 936397) JOHANNESBURG, June 23, 1908 I, Essop Ismail Mia of Johannesburg, Merchant, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows: 1. I am Managing Partner of the firm of Suliman Ismail Mia & Co.
('8', 393, 2, 4, 936590) of Johannesburg, and Chairman of the British Indian Association.
('8', 393, 2, 5, 936655) 2. I have read the Petition 2 Ebrahim Ismail Aswat of Vere eniging, dated the 23rd day of June, 1908. 3. At the several meetings of the British Indian Association referred to in the said petition I presided, and some of these meetings were attended by several thousand Indians.
('8', 393, 2, 6, 936933) 4. As the British Indian Association has been informed by M. K. Gandhi of Johannesburg, As Honorary Secretary, to the effect that the Government may not repeal the Asiatic Act No.
('8', 393, 2, 7, 937113) 2 of 1907, the British Indian Association has decided to advise all British Indians to withdraw their voluntary applications for registration and other documents handed to Montford Chamney of Pretoria.
('8', 393, 2, 8, 937315) 5. I have also applied for the return of my application and documents, but they have not yet been returned.
('8', 393, 2, 9, 937423) 6. It was at very great personal risk that I and my fellow countrymen have assisted the Government to carry out the terms of the compromise referred to in the said petition so far as the Indian part of it was concerned.
('8', 393, 2, 10, 937643) 7. By reason of so doing I was very severely assaulted on the 17th day of May last.
('8', 393, 2, 11, 937727) The assault was so severe that I was laid up in bed for nearly a fortnight, and I very nearly lost a portion of my nose.

('8', 394, 1, 2, 938015) 222. AFFIDAVIT
('8', 394, 2, 3, 938030) JOHANNESBURG, June 23, 1908 I, M. K. Gandhi of Johannesburg, Attorney, [and] Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows: 1. I have read the Petition 1 Ebrahim Ismail Aswat of Vere eniging, dated the 23rd day of June, 1908, and the Affidavit 2 Essop Ismail Mia, the Chairman of the British Indian Association, dated the 23rd day of June, 1908. 2. The statement made by the said Ebrahim Ismail Aswat, in his Petition, with reference to the compromise, is correct.
('8', 394, 2, 4, 938555) 3. I was sentenced, together with many other Indians, to be imprisoned for not having complied with the Asiatic Law Amendment Act No.
('8', 394, 2, 5, 938689) 2 of 1907, which I believed, and do still believe, to be contrary to my independence as a free man, and my conscience.
('8', 394, 2, 6, 938808) 4. While I was undergoing sentence of Imprisonment in the month of January, 1908, negotiations were put forward, I believe by the Government, for a compromise with the Indian community.
('8', 394, 2, 7, 938994) 5. A letter 3 placed before me for my signature, copy of which is hereto attached.
('8', 394, 2, 8, 939077) 6. As that letter was not considered by me to be satisfactory, and as it left the question of the inapplicability of the Asiatic Act to those who voluntarily registered open, I made certain alterations 4. Copy of the letter as altered by me is also hereto attached.
('8', 394, 2, 9, 939343) The saidletter was then signed by Leung Quinn, Chairman of the Chinese Association, and Thambi Naidoo, a British Indian, both of whom were my fellow prisoners, and myself.
('8', 394, 2, 10, 939515) 7. On Thursday, the 30th January, I was taken to Pretoria, under escort, to call on the Colonial Secretary.
('8', 394, 2, 11, 939623) 8. At the interview I had with the Colonial Secretary, the repeal of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act was discussed, and the promise given definitely there and then that, if the Asiatics applied for voluntary registration, the Act would be repealed.
('8', 394, 2, 12, 939870) At the same time, a formal reply to the said letter was handed to me, copy where of is

('8', 395, 1, 2, 940218) hereto attached.
('8', 395, 1, 3, 940235) 9. After the said interview, my fellow prisoners and myself were discharged 10. On the 3rd day of February, I had another interview with the Colonial Secretary, and the repeal of the Act, as well as other matters, was discussed, and the promise made to me and referred to above was repeated; though, at the said interview, the Colonial Secretary, at the time I took leave, added, “Remember, if there is a single recalcitrant Asiatic who does not take out voluntary registration, I shall enforce the Act against that man”, or some words to that effect, which I took to mean that the vast majority of the Asiatics then resident in the Colony would have to take out voluntary registration certificates to bring about the repeal of Ass Act 11. After that, correspondence passed between the Colonial Secretary and myself confirming the question of repeal.
('8', 395, 1, 4, 941086) 12. To my surprise, however, I saw a letter 1 signed by the Private Secretary to the Colonial Secretary, stating that even voluntary registrants would be brought under the said Act.
('8', 395, 1, 5, 941268) 13. I have since ascertained that it is the intention of the Government not to Apply the said Act to those who have voluntary registered, but they decline to give any assurance with reference to the repeal of the Act.
('8', 395, 1, 6, 941486) 14. This news has created a great commotion amongst the Asiatics, and they have demanded the return of their voluntary applications for registration and documents handed to Montford Chamney of Pretoria.
('8', 395, 1, 7, 941689) 15. When the compromise was completed, it gavedissa tisfaction to a certain section of the Indian community, by reason of my having accepted, under authority of public meetings held at the time, the principle of identification by digit impressions; and, in my desire to carry out the compact with the Government, I proceeded to the said Montford Chamney, on Monday the 10th February last to make myapplication, and I was very severely assaulted by those who were dissatisfied with the compromise.
('8', 395, 1, 8, 942186) 16. It is within my knowledge that many Indians, in order to carry out the compromise and to help the Government, had to suffer much inconvenience and undertook great personal risk.

('8', 396, 3, 5, 942625) SETTLEMENT?
('8', 396, 4, 6, 942637) “Man proposes, God disposes” should be inscribed in everyone’s memory.
('8', 396, 4, 7, 942708) It was hoped that Monday would see the end of the law.
('8', 396, 4, 8, 942763) On that very day it was made known that the law would stay— for the present at any rate.
('8', 396, 4, 9, 942852) Mr. Smuts told Mr. Gandhi on Saturday: ‘Please see me on Monday.
('8', 396, 4, 10, 942917) One or two minor points remain to be considered.
('8', 396, 4, 11, 942966) All else is settled.’[The Transvaal] Leader wrote editorially on Monday that it had been decided to repeal the Act.
('8', 396, 4, 12, 943082) Mr. Gandhi met Mr. Smuts on Monday.
('8', 396, 4, 13, 943118) He was shown a printed draft of the proposed Bill repealing the Act.
('8', 396, 4, 14, 943187) If the Indian community approved the draft, the Bill would be passed and the Act repealed.
('8', 396, 4, 15, 943278) The temptation was great.
('8', 396, 4, 16, 943304) It was an excellent Bill from the point of view of those who had registered voluntarily or might do so in future.
('8', 396, 4, 17, 943418) It did not contain any of the objectionable provisions of the obnoxious Act.
('8', 396, 4, 18, 943495) There was, however, a “but” about the Bill.
('8', 396, 4, 19, 943539) Accepting it meant forgoing rights as under: (1) Even educated persons would not be allowed to enter [except on a temporary visit].
('8', 396, 4, 20, 943671) (2) Even those who hold £3 Dutch registers may not enter.
('8', 396, 4, 21, 943729) (3) Other [Asiatic] refugees [from the Boer War] may not enter.
('8', 396, 4, 22, 943793) (4) If the applications now being examined by Mr. Chamney rejected, there is no appeal against his [administrative] decision.
('8', 396, 5, 23, 943919) If we agreed to forgo these rights, the Immigrants’[Restriction] Act would be amended and the obnoxious Act repealed.
('8', 396, 6, 24, 944037) 1 In effect, the points made by Gandhiji in his letter to Smuts of June 13 were not acceded to.
('8', 396, 6, 25, 944133) Addressing the mass meeting of June 24, Essop Mia, Chairman, made the following points: (a) the evidence about the claims to domicile in the Transvaal should be taken from voluntary registrants in a public and judicial manner, so that the reasons for any official decision could not be kept secret; and (b) they would not sell the rights of would be educated Indian immigrants in return for some questionable advantages given to Indians already in the Colony.

('8', 399, 1, 2, 949245) 224. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING 1
('8', 399, 2, 3, 949275) JOHANNESBURG June 24, 1908] The receipt of so many telegrams shows the unanimity with which the object of this meeting has been received, but though I have read these telegrams to you, it is due to this meeting, due to the executive of the British Indian Association, and due to the Transvaal public to state also that there is, at this meeting, electric; in the air, and these telegrams by no means demonstrate the whole truth.
('8', 399, 2, 4, 949704) The whole truth is that there is, even in this meeting, a number of Indians who are seething with discontent over what the leaders have done, and over what especially I myself have done, in connection with the compromise.
('8', 399, 2, 5, 949926) There is a number of Indians in this meeting who believe, as the Chairman has stated in his speech, that the whole Indian community has been sold for selfish purposes.
('8', 399, 2, 6, 950094) The Chairman has repudiated the charge, and so do I, but I do not blame my countrymen who bring that charge against me especially.
('8', 399, 3, 7, 950225) Some of my countrymen tell me and, perhaps, with some justi fication that I did not take them into confidence, when I approached General Smuts on the strength of the letter that was placed before me in the gaol yard, and it is better that I myself should voice their complaint I believe that, in seeing General Smuts As I saw him, I acted correctly and in accordance with my conscience, but time has shown that they were right, time has shown also that I need not have gone to General Smuts as I did.
('8', 399, 3, 8, 950726) What I did was simply and solely to accept voluntary registration that was placed before him for over a year by the whole Indian community.
('8', 399, 3, 9, 950866) I felt that I was yielding nothing, not a single new principle, not a single concession, in accepting this volun tary compromise.
('8', 399, 3, 10, 950996) I believed that I had full instructions from my cou ntrymen to do so, but I believed too much.
('8', 399, 3, 11, 951091) I did not know what was to

('8', 399, 4, 14, 951407) For resolutions passed at the meeting, vide Appendix V. 2 The Chairman had said: “They who assaulted the Chairman and the Secretary distrusted the Government.
('8', 399, 4, 15, 951566) In their opinion, we had misled them, and, when the proper time came, we had sold the community to the Government.
('8', 399, 4, 16, 951681) Whilst I emphatically repudiate any such suggestion, it is impossible for me to deny that the Government have, by their recent conduct, lent colour to the suspicion and distrust.”

('8', 400, 2, 15, 954312) 1 The Chairman again: “We went to prison to buy liberty of conscience and freedom from molestation and restraint, and we did not come out of the prison gates in order to submit to a law, or a revised edition of it, which was calculated to take away those priceless possessions.

('8', 401, 1, 2, 954815) perfect right, and if they proved that the documents that they held were correct documents and were properlyobtained by them, and were not fraudulent documents, then they undoubtedly believed that the Act would be repealed, that their position was to be much better than it would have been under the Asiatic Act.
('8', 401, 1, 3, 955128) They believed also that they had fought for 16 months, not merely to secure a nominal repeal of the Act, but to secure recognition for themselves as human beings, to secure a voice in the management of their own affairs, to secure a voice in the legislation that may be passed so far as they are con cerned; not a voting paper by any means a voting paper for the Ind ians or the Asiatics may not be worth the paper on which the signature might be put but they wanted a real voting paper, they wanted to be consulted before any legislation was passed.

('8', 401, 1, 17, 956953) I may understand, I may distinguish, but, just as my fellow country men could not distinguish and they only had the remedy of assaulting me, another had the remedy of telling me that I had sold my country men; similarly it is not possible for them to distinguish between one white man’s word and another white man’s word, especially when that word happens to be the word of almost the highest man in the State.
('8', 401, 1, 18, 957364) I state most emphatically and definitely that General Smuts did promise that he was going, to repeal the Act, in the presence of the Registrar of Asiatics, if the Asiatic communities abided fully, frankly,

('8', 402, 1, 2, 957615) and freely by the terms of the compromise, if the Asiatic communities enabled General Smuts to identify every Asiatic in the country, and if the Asiatic communities enabled General Smuts to see to it that there wasno Asiatic who could surreptitiously enter into the country and not be found out by his Police.
('8', 402, 1, 3, 957925) These terms the Asiatic communities have fulfilled, and yet we find today, we meet this afternoon to find out, that this Act is not to be repealed as it should be repealed, and that the promise of repeal is hedged in on all sides by such restrictions as could never be accepted by any self respecting man.
('8', 402, 1, 4, 958231) The passive resistance movement has been undertaken only to gain rights for the whole of the Asiatics who have a right to remain in this country and not for a chosen few, and if—there is one man, whom I can recall, who is in Ladysmith, who came to the country in 1885 and paid £25 to the Boer Government for remaining in this country, carried on a trade, and possesses European credentials—if he cannot enter this country, I, for one, do not wish to remain in this country, if my countrymen before that time do not remove this head which seems to have done grievous wrong to them.
('8', 402, 2, 5, 958812) Indian Opinion, 4 7 1908
('8', 402, 3, 6, 958837) 225. REVIVAL OF PASSIVE RESISTANCE
('8', 402, 4, 7, 958872) It is a thousand pities that General Smuts has, while yielding on the question of the repeal of the Asiatic Act, taken up an obstinate no position on mere matters of detail and of no significance from a Colonial standpoint.
('8', 402, 4, 8, 959096) General Smuts’ attitude savours very much of straining at a gnat and swallowing a camel.
('8', 402, 4, 9, 959185) He has taken all the grace away from his offer to repeal the Act by robbing it of all advantage to the Asiatics of the Transvaal, and it is hardly to be wondered at that British Indians have summarily rejected an offer which, in effect, places them, as a body, in a worse position than they occupied before the struggle.
('8', 402, 4, 10, 959506) It is true that the bait was held out by the General in the shape of easing the position of those who were included by him in the repealing Bill.
('8', 402, 4, 11, 959652) To the credit of the communities, let it be said that they have not taken the bait.
('8', 402, 4, 12, 959736) As passive resisters, they could not, in order to gain a position for themselves, barter away the rights of others who were just as much entitled to remain in or enter the Transvaal as they themselves.
('8', 402, 4, 13, 959938) The proceedings of the Mass Meeting show unmistakbly that Indians are just as much determined as ever to see the fight to the
('8', 403, 0, 1, 960064) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 403, 1, 2, 960106) finish, and this time they will command far greater sympathy and help, and, if General Smuts has the slightest regard for the Empire to which he belongs, he will still, while there is yet time, refrain from unnecessarily wounding Indian feeling.
('8', 403, 1, 3, 960352) Indian Opinion, 27 6 1908
('8', 403, 2, 4, 960378) 226. SATYAGRAHA AGAIN
('8', 403, 3, 5, 960400) General Smuts has offered to repeal the [Asiatic Registration] Act, but on certain conditions [which are unacceptable].
('8', 403, 3, 6, 960520) That a further battle remained to be fought in the Indian war in the Transvaal has now become clear.
('8', 403, 3, 7, 960621) In every great war, more than one battle has to be fought.
('8', 403, 3, 8, 960680) The Russo Japanese war lasted for over a year.
('8', 403, 3, 9, 960727) In the course of that war, four or five well known battles were fought, at Port Arthur, Mukden, etc.
('8', 403, 3, 10, 960828) The Boer War also lasted for two or three years and came to an end only after several battles had been fought.
('8', 403, 3, 11, 960939) The war of the Transvaal Indians is not an armed conflict as these were.
('8', 403, 3, 12, 961012) Save for that, this, too, is a war.
('8', 403, 3, 13, 961048) For, if we think of the consequences, this war [waged] through satyagraha is no whit less of a war than those fought with [gun and] powder.
('8', 403, 3, 14, 961188) Victory or defeat in this war will have Far reaching consequences for Indians in other Colonies.
('8', 403, 3, 15, 961285) No otherconsequence can be more important than this.
('8', 403, 3, 16, 961338) 1 Looking at it thus, we can unhesitatingly compare this fight by a handful of Indians in the Transvaal to the great campaigns mentioned above.
('8', 403, 3, 17, 961482) A number of battles may be won in the course of a war, but all the gains are wiped out if the final battle is lost.
('8', 403, 3, 18, 961598) The same is true of the Transvaal Indians’ satyagraha.
('8', 403, 3, 19, 961653) The first battle was fought in 1906. 2 It was waged in the arena of British politics, and the Deputation returned victorious.
('8', 403, 3, 20, 961779) This was followed by a series of encounters in which the Indian community showed fine mettle it earned for itself a name as a brave community which, though a mere handful, compelled the Boers to yield by sheer dint of courage and truth.
('8', 403, 3, 21, 962016) As it happened, however, a large number of Indians were dissatisfied with the settle ment, which means that in their dew, the fight had not been carried far
('8', 403, 4, 22, 962173) 1 No other consequence of satyagraha, such as loss of property or personal inconvenience suffered by satyagrahis, can be more important than that which bears on the conditions of Indians everywhere.
('8', 403, 4, 23, 962372) 2 The reference is to the Transvaal Indian Deputation that visited England.
('8', 403, 4, 24, 962448) Vide Vol. VI.
('8', 404, 0, 1, 962462) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 405
('8', 404, 1, 2, 962507) enough.
('8', 404, 1, 3, 962515) General Smuts has now provided the opportunity to complete what was prematurely abandoned.
('8', 404, 1, 4, 962606) We believe therefore that satyagra his Indians, instead of feeling unhappy at the resumption of the camp aign, will shout back an eager response to the [war] cry.
('8', 404, 1, 5, 962769) Those who were angry with the leaders for having prematurely called off the campaign have now an opportunity to prove their sincerity.
('8', 404, 1, 6, 962904) They must make common cause with the others and boldly declare that they are ready to lay down their lives for the sake of the honour and rights of Indians.
('8', 404, 1, 7, 963061) If the Indian community evinces this spirit forthe last time—for the present at any rate—we have no doubt that we will win a resounding victory.
('8', 404, 1, 8, 963206) This is the last battle in this war we have been talking of, and it must be won.
('8', 404, 1, 9, 963287) The condition of South African Indians will depend a great deal on the issue of this battle.
('8', 404, 1, 10, 963380) On the one hand, the clouds are louring upon Natal.
('8', 404, 1, 11, 963432) 1 the other, a law regarding registration has already been passed in Rhodesia.
('8', 404, 1, 12, 963511) 2 A Member of Parliament in that Colony pointed out in passing that the Transvaal law had not yet been repealed.
('8', 404, 1, 13, 963624) The Transvaal Indians should take a cue from this and carry the dead law to the crematorium and dispose of it properly.
('8', 404, 1, 14, 963744) They must gird up their loins—for their own sake and for the sake of all South African Indians.
('8', 404, 1, 15, 963840) Indeed, it appears from a report of the mass meeting that they are thus prepared.
('8', 404, 1, 16, 963922) We congratulate them on this, and urge them to mount a vigorous attack and, for once, let the enemy have a taste of their strength.
('8', 404, 1, 17, 964054) The sword of satyagraha is far superior to the steel sword.
('8', 404, 1, 18, 964114) Truth and justice provide its point; divine help is the hilt that adorns it.
('8', 404, 1, 19, 964191) One who has the use of this sword has no cause to fear defeat.
('8', 404, 1, 20, 964254) Therefore, brave Indians, arise, and without ado, draw the sword of satyagraha and fight unto victory!
('8', 404, 1, 21, 964357) When Japan’s brave heroes forced the Russians to bite the dust of the battle field, the sun rose in the east.
('8', 404, 1, 22, 964467) And it now shines on all the nations of Asia.
('8', 404, 1, 23, 964513) The people of the East will never, never again submit to insult from the insolent whites.

('8', 405, 1, 2, 964761) 227. SARVODAYA [ VII]
('8', 405, 2, 3, 964783) VEINS OF WEALTH
('8', 405, 3, 4, 964799) We saw that the value of money consists in its power to command the labour of men.
('8', 405, 3, 5, 964882) If that labour could be had without payment, there should be no further need of money.
('8', 405, 3, 6, 964969) Instances are known where human labour can be had without payment.
('8', 405, 3, 7, 965036) We have considered examples which show that moral power is more effective than the power of money.
('8', 405, 3, 8, 965135) We also saw that man’s goodness can do what money cannot do.
('8', 405, 3, 9, 965196) There exist men in many parts of England who cannot be beguiled with money.
('8', 405, 3, 10, 965272) Moreover, if we admit that wealth carries with it the power to direct labour, we shall also see that the more intelligent and moral men are, the greater is the wealth amassed.
('8', 405, 3, 11, 965448) It may even appear on a fullerconsideration that the persons themselves constitute the wealth, not gold and silver.
('8', 405, 3, 12, 965564) We must search for wealth not in the bowels of the earth, but in the hearts of men.
('8', 405, 3, 13, 965648) If this is correct, the true law of economics is that men must be maintained in the best possible health, both of body and mind, and in the highest state of honour.
('8', 405, 3, 14, 965813) A time may also come when England, instead of adorning the turbans of its slaves with diamonds from Golkonda and thus sporting her wealth, may be able to point to her great men of virtue, saying, in the words of a truly eminent Greek, “This is my wealth.”
('8', 405, 4, 15, 966069) EVEN HANDED JUSTICE 1
('8', 405, 5, 16, 966091) Some centuries before Christ there lived a Jewish merchant, Solomon 2 name.
('8', 405, 5, 17, 966167) He had made a large fortune and earned great fame.
('8', 405, 5, 18, 966218) His maxims are remembered in Europe even today.
('8', 405, 5, 19, 966266) He was so beloved of the Venetians that they erected a statue in the city to his memory.
('8', 405, 5, 20, 966355) Though his maxims are known by rote, very few persons actually practise them.
('8', 405, 5, 21, 966433) He says: “Those who make money through lies are afflicted with pride, and that is a sign of their death.” At another place, he adds: “Treasures of wickedness profit nothing.
('8', 405, 5, 22, 966607) It is truth which delivers from death.” 3 In both these maxims Solomon asserts that death is the outcome of wealth unjustly acquired.
('8', 405, 5, 23, 966741) Nowadays,
('8', 405, 6, 24, 966751) 1 This corresponds to Ruskin’s chapter “Qui Judicatis Terram”.
('8', 405, 6, 25, 966814) “Ye that be judges of the earth, [love righteousness].” 2 (993 953 B.C.); believed in Ruskin’s day to have been the author of Proverbs in the Old Testament 3 Cf.
('8', 405, 6, 26, 966976) Proverbs, Ch. XXI, v.
('8', 405, 6, 27, 966998) 6 and Ch. X, v.
('8', 406, 0, 1, 967014) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 407
('8', 406, 1, 2, 967059) people tell lies or perpetrate injustice so cleverly that we cannot find them out.
('8', 406, 1, 3, 967142) For there are misleading advertisements.
('8', 406, 1, 4, 967183) Things bear attractive labels, and so on.
('8', 406, 1, 5, 967225) Again the wise man says: “He that oppresseth the poor to multiply his riches shall surely come to want.” And he adds: “Rob not the poor because he is poor.
('8', 406, 1, 6, 967381) Oppress not the afflicted in the place of business.
('8', 406, 1, 7, 967433) For God 1 will corrupt the soul of those that torment them.” At present, however, it is the practice in business to administer kicks to those who are already dead.
('8', 406, 1, 8, 967597) We are eager to take advantage of a needy man.
('8', 406, 1, 9, 967644) The highwayman robs the rich, but the trader robs the poor.
('8', 406, 1, 10, 967704) Solomon says further: “The rich and the poor are equal.
('8', 406, 1, 11, 967760) God is their maker.
('8', 406, 1, 12, 967780) God gives them knowledge.” 2 The rich and the poor cannot live, the one without the other.
('8', 406, 1, 13, 967871) They always need each other.Neither of them can be regarded as superior or inferior to the other.
('8', 406, 1, 14, 967969) But evil consequences follow when the two forget that they are equal, and that God is their light.
('8', 406, 1, 15, 968068) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 27 6 1908
('8', 406, 2, 16, 968110) 228. MUSTAFA KAMAL PASHA’S SPEECH 3

('8', 406, 3, 18, 968244) It is a remarkable speech from which all of us can learn something.
('8', 406, 3, 19, 968312) We therefore print a translation of it here.
('8', 406, 4, 20, 968357) The speech was delivered in the Jijinia Theatre on October 22, 1907. It is said that more than 6,000 people heard this address.

('8', 410, 1, 2, 973775) 233. JOHANNESBURG LETTER [Before July 2, 1908] 1
('8', 410, 2, 3, 973824) SATYAGRAHA IN FULL BLOOM
('8', 410, 3, 4, 973849) The satyagraha campaign has been revived.
('8', 410, 3, 5, 973891) Indians have evinced a spirit of sterling worth and everyone appears to be full of courage.
('8', 410, 4, 6, 973983) WHAT CAMPAIGN IS ABOUT
('8', 410, 5, 7, 974006) It necessary to understand this well.
('8', 410, 5, 8, 974044) The fight, then, is not for the repeal of the Act, for General Smuts was quite prepared to do that.
('8', 410, 5, 9, 974144) The Act is bound to be repealed.
('8', 410, 5, 10, 974177) It is in any case as good as repealed for those who do not intend to submit to it.
('8', 410, 5, 11, 974260) Neither is it a fight against [the giving of]finger impressions.
('8', 410, 5, 12, 974325) They are not of the least importance.
('8', 410, 5, 13, 974363) They will not be insisted upon in Rhodesia, 2 but it will be none the less disgraceful for that.
('8', 410, 5, 14, 974460) When it is a matter of preserving self respect and resisting the imposition of slavery, why should there be so much fuss about finger impressions?
('8', 410, 5, 15, 974607) The fight is for [the rights of] those who hold the £3 Dutch registration certificates, for those who are outside the Transvaal at present, but are in a position to prove that they are old residents of the Transvaal.
('8', 410, 5, 16, 974824) It is also for the sake of the educated Indians.
('8', 410, 5, 17, 974873) Every Indian must be clear about this.
('8', 410, 5, 18, 974912) At the time of compromise, this issue could not have been settled.
('8', 410, 5, 19, 974979) The important thing then was to prove the bona fides of the Indian community.
('8', 410, 5, 20, 975057) Till that was done, it was impossible for us to protest.
('8', 410, 5, 21, 975114) No decision could then be taken about those holding the £3 [registration certificates], about the other refugees and about the educated [Asiatic immigrants].
('8', 410, 5, 22, 975272) It was not possible therefore to have the matter settled.
('8', 410, 5, 23, 975330) Now that, while repealing the [Asiatic Registration] Act, General Smuts wants to define the position to their disadvantage and to exclude them, the Indians can insist upon their own view of the matter.
('8', 410, 5, 24, 975532) One should not blame all this on the compromise.
('8', 410, 5, 25, 975581) It is because of the compromise, because of the demonstration of its strength
('8', 410, 6, 26, 975659) 1 This news letter was drafted before the Supreme Court had pronounced on Aswat’a affidavit asking for the return of his application form for voluntary registration.
('8', 410, 6, 27, 975825) The case was heard on July 2. 2 Vide “Rhodesia Indians”,30 5 1908
('8', 411, 0, 1, 975891) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 411, 1, 2, 975933) by the Indian community that we have got thus far.
('8', 411, 3, 3, 975984) There is only one remedy.
('8', 411, 3, 4, 976010) And that lies in our hands.
('8', 411, 3, 5, 976038) We should ignore the Government’s law and act as follows: (1) When necessary, we should burn the certificates of volun tary registration.
('8', 411, 3, 6, 976176) (2) We must refuse to affix our finger impressions or signa tures [on any documents] or to give our names when asked for these by the police.
('8', 411, 3, 7, 976318) (3) We should tender the licence fee, but if the licence is refu sed, should carry on trade without one.
('8', 411, 3, 8, 976423) If, as a consequence of any of these actions, we have to suffer imprisonment, we must accept it.
('8', 411, 3, 9, 976520) If we do that the day of our freedom will be hastened.
('8', 411, 3, 10, 976575) Even otherwise, people have so far fought, if only for their own rights.
('8', 411, 3, 11, 976648) Henceforth, those who have received certificates of voluntary registration will fight especially for the sake of the others referred to above.
('8', 411, 3, 12, 976791) And if we refuse to fight, we cannot claim that ours is true satyagraha.
('8', 411, 3, 13, 976864) It is not as if the sword of satyagraha can be used only once and becomes useless afterwards.
('8', 411, 3, 14, 976958) If we have discovered its real worth, we can use it each time we have to fight.
('8', 411, 3, 15, 977038) It is more effective than a sword of steel.
('8', 411, 3, 16, 977082) All that is required is the capacity to endure suffering.
('8', 411, 3, 17, 977140) We should not fight shy of imprisonment.
('8', 411, 3, 18, 977181) We must not imagine that eating mealie pap will do us any harm.
('8', 411, 4, 19, 977245) HOW THEN CAN WE LEAVE COLONY?
('8', 411, 5, 20, 977275) This question has been raked by a number of persons.
('8', 411, 5, 21, 977328) If people burn their certificates, what authority will they have for returning to the Transvaal after leaving the Colony once?
('8', 411, 5, 22, 977455) That the question has at all been asked suggest an inadequacy in our concept of satyagraha.
('8', 411, 5, 23, 977547) My reply is : a resident of the Transvaal would only need authority if it was necessary for him to have any authority for going to India.
('8', 411, 5, 24, 977685) Indian residents of the Transvaal should undoubtedly enter [the Colony] even if they are without registers.
('8', 411, 5, 25, 977793) The only risk in doing so is that one may be put in gaol.
('8', 411, 5, 26, 977851) Let them imprison [us].
('8', 411, 5, 27, 977875) But bail [money] must not be paid.
('8', 411, 5, 28, 977910) We do not want to be let out on bail.
('8', 411, 5, 29, 977948) The fine must not be paid either.
('8', 411, 5, 30, 977982) Even defence which would make a lawyer neces sary must not be offered.
('8', 411, 5, 31, 978053) Whatever defence is needed will be provided by Mr. Gandhi, free of charge as usual, the only condition being that the person concerned should be a true satyagrahi, that he should have
('8', 412, 0, 1, 978237) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 413
('8', 412, 1, 2, 978282) a valid case, and that the case should promote the community’s interests.
('8', 412, 2, 3, 978356) SUPREME COURT
('8', 412, 3, 4, 978370) Those who wish to adopt this course are not in any wise with the case in the Supreme Court It will be well and good it as a result of it, application forms [for voluntary registration] are returned.
('8', 412, 3, 5, 978569) The end will come sooner in that case.
('8', 412, 3, 6, 978608) But if the forms are not returned, that should not matter.
('8', 412, 3, 7, 978667) What is necessary is that we ourselves should remain strong.
('8', 412, 3, 8, 978728) If the forms are returned, that would have the effect of instantaneously invalidating the registers.
('8', 412, 3, 9, 978829) Burning them also comes to the same thing.
('8', 412, 3, 10, 978872) One should not assume that the registers will remain valid even after the forms have been returned.
('8', 412, 3, 11, 978972) Registers without applications are like revolvers without cartridges.
('8', 412, 3, 12, 979042) The only object of asking for the return of application forms is to ensure that the registers are invalidated immediately.
('8', 412, 3, 13, 979165) Burning them will not quite render them invalid for there are copies with the Government and the applications contain all the particulars.
('8', 412, 3, 14, 979304) What we are afraid of is that, even if we do burn the registers, the Government may not prosecute us.
('8', 412, 3, 15, 979406) We want to go to gaol.
('8', 412, 3, 16, 979429) The Government does not want to send us to gaol.
('8', 412, 3, 17, 979478) The best way, therefore, to arrive in gaol is to get our applications back.
('8', 412, 3, 18, 979554) Mr. Smuts has said that the Government itself wants to act like a passive resister.
('8', 412, 3, 19, 979638) I shall not admit this to be satyagraha, for that will be mere unreasonable obstinacy on its part.
('8', 412, 3, 20, 979737) By refusing to return our applications, the Government wants to avoid being obliged to send us to gaol.
('8', 412, 3, 21, 979841) Its motives in doing so are unworthy.
('8', 412, 3, 22, 979879) It is afraid of the 7,000 voluntary registrants, who are full of courage.
('8', 412, 3, 23, 979953) They are capable of fighting it out.
('8', 412, 3, 24, 979990) The Government does not wish to do anything which may provoke them.
('8', 412, 3, 25, 980058) All this is easy to understand.
('8', 412, 3, 26, 980090) Let everyone think it over and then ask himself whether it would have been possible to put up such a fight three months ago.
('8', 412, 3, 27, 980215) Was the Government afraid of us then?
('8', 412, 3, 28, 980253) Is there any doubt that if we fight we shall win?
('8', 412, 4, 29, 980303) FAKE REGISTERS
('8', 412, 5, 30, 980318) The community’s enemies persist in their mischievous activities.
('8', 412, 5, 31, 980383) There is a barber named Jaymal who has been arrested for selling faked permits.

('8', 415, 1, 8, 986118) General Smuts denies having promised to repeal the Act, and interprets the compromise to mean that those who entered the country after the lapse of three months after the date of the compromise should register under the Act.

('8', 416, 3, 17, 989576) 235. SELF SACRIFICE
('8', 416, 4, 18, 989596) It is necessary that every Indian should understand the nature of the campaign in the Transvaal.
('8', 416, 4, 19, 989693) We have earlier explained the meaning of satyagraha through many examples.
('8', 416, 4, 20, 989768) 1 Time has now come to realize that meaning through action.
('8', 416, 4, 21, 989828) Satyagraha and self interest do not go together.
('8', 416, 4, 22, 989877) Satyagraha always calls for sacrifice of self.
('8', 416, 4, 23, 989924) The rights of Indians holding permits have been secured; the Government is prepared to exempt them from the obnoxious Act However, the situation demands that it the permit holders should sacrifice their interests for the sake of those holding the £3 Dutch registration certificates and the educated.

('8', 416, 5, 25, 990260) 1Vide “Secret of Satyagraha”, 22 2 1908, and “Licences in Natal”, 2 5 1908

('8', 417, 1, 2, 990377) sacrifice] as though it were a nuptial occasion, and want every Indian to do the same.
('8', 417, 1, 3, 990464) Satyagraha will reveal its real meaning now.
('8', 417, 1, 4, 990509) The Government is agreeable to repeal of the Act.
('8', 417, 1, 5, 990559) But no action is being taken because the Indian community will not accept the conditions for the repeal.

('8', 418, 2, 13, 993728) 237. SARVODAYA [ VIII].
('8', 418, 3, 14, 993752) Wealth is like a river.
('8', 418, 3, 15, 993776) A river always flows towards the sea, that is, down an incline.
('8', 418, 3, 16, 993840) So, as a general rule must wealth go where it is needed.
('8', 418, 3, 17, 993897) But the flow of wealth, like the course of a river, can be regulated.
('8', 418, 3, 18, 993967) Most of the rivers run out their courses unregulated, their marshy banks poisoning the wind.
('8', 418, 3, 19, 994060) If dams are built across these rivers to direct the water flow as required, they will irrigate the soil and keep the atmosphere pure.
('8', 418, 3, 20, 994194) Similarly the uncontrolled use of wealth will multiply vices among men and cause starvation; in brief, such wealth will act like a poison.
('8', 418, 3, 21, 994333) But the selfsame wealth, if its circulation is regulated and its use controlled, can, like a river whose stream has been properly harnessed, promote prosperity.
('8', 418, 3, 22, 994494) The principle of regulating the circulation of wealth is ignored altogether by economists.
('8', 418, 3, 23, 994585) Theirs is merely the science of getting rich.
('8', 418, 3, 24, 994631) But there are many different ways of getting rich.
('8', 418, 3, 25, 994682) There was a time in Europe when people sought to acquire wealth by poisoning owners of large estates and appropriating their possessions.
('8', 418, 3, 26, 994820) Nowadays, merchants adulterate the food sold to the poor, for example, milk with borax, [wheat] flour with potato flour, coffee with chicory, butter with fat and so on.
('8', 418, 3, 27, 994989) This is on the same level as getting rich by poisoning others.
('8', 418, 3, 28, 995052) Can we call this either an art or a science of getting rich?
('8', 418, 3, 29, 995113) Let us not, however, assume that by “getting rich” economists merely mean “getting rich by robbing others”.
('8', 418, 3, 30, 995221) They should point
('8', 419, 0, 1, 995239) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 419, 1, 2, 995281) out that theirs is a science of getting rich by legal or just means.
('8', 419, 1, 3, 995350) It happens these days that many things which are legal are not just.
('8', 419, 1, 4, 995419) The only right way, therefore, to acquire wealth is to do so justly.
('8', 419, 1, 5, 995488) And if this is true, we must know what is just.
('8', 419, 1, 6, 995536) It is not enough to live by the laws of demand and supply.
('8', 419, 1, 7, 995595) Fish, wolves and rats subsist in that manner.
('8', 419, 1, 8, 995641) Bigger fish prey on smaller ones, rats swallow insects and wolves devour even human beings.
('8', 419, 1, 9, 995733) That for them is the law [of Nature]; they know no better.
('8', 419, 1, 10, 995792) But God has endowed man with understanding, with a sense of justice.
('8', 419, 1, 11, 995861) He must follow these and not think of growing rich by devouring others—by cheating others and reducing them to beggary.
('8', 419, 1, 12, 995981) Let us examine what then the laws of justice regarding payment of labour are.
('8', 419, 1, 13, 996059) As we stated earlier, a just wage for a worker will be that which will secure him the same labour, when he needs it, as he has put in forustoday.
('8', 419, 1, 14, 996205) If we give him a lower wage, he will be underpaid, and if more, overpaid.
('8', 419, 1, 15, 996279) [Suppose] a man wants to engage a worker.
('8', 419, 1, 16, 996321) Two persons offer their services.
('8', 419, 1, 17, 996355) If the man who offers to accept a lower wage is engaged, he will be underpaid.
('8', 419, 1, 18, 996434) If there is a large number of employers and only one worker, he will get his own terms and will very likely be overpaid.
('8', 419, 1, 19, 996555) The just wage lies between these two points.
('8', 419, 1, 20, 996600) If someone lends me money which I have to repay after a time, I shall pay him interest.
('8', 419, 1, 21, 996688) Similarly, if someone gives me his labour today, I must return him an identical quantity of labour and something more by way of interest.
('8', 419, 1, 22, 996826) If someone gives me an hour [of labour] today, I should promise to give him an hour and five minutes or more.
('8', 419, 1, 23, 996936) This is true of every kind of worker.
('8', 419, 1, 24, 996974) If, now, of two men who offer me their services, I engage the one who accepts the lower wage, the result will be that he will be half starved while the other man will remain unemployed.
('8', 419, 1, 25, 997160) Even otherwise, if I pay full wages to the workman whom I employ, the other man will be unemployed.
('8', 419, 1, 26, 997260) But the former will not starve, and I shall have made just use of my money.
('8', 419, 1, 27, 997336) Starvation really occurs only when the due wages are not paid.
('8', 419, 1, 28, 997399) If I pay due wages, surplus wealth will not accumulate in my hands.
('8', 419, 1, 29, 997467) I shall not waste money on luxuries and add to the poverty.
('8', 419, 1, 30, 997527) The workman whom I pay justly will in turn learn to pay others justly.
('8', 419, 1, 31, 997598) Thus the stream of justice will not dry up; instead it will gather speed as it flows.
('8', 419, 1, 32, 997684) And the nation which has such a sense of justice will grow happy and prosper in the right direction.
('8', 419, 1, 33, 997785) According to this line of reasoning, economists are found to be wrong.
('8', 419, 1, 34, 997856) They argue that increased competition means growing
('8', 420, 0, 1, 997908) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 421
('8', 420, 1, 2, 997953) prosperity for a nation.
('8', 420, 1, 3, 997978) This is not true in fact.
('8', 420, 1, 4, 998004) Competition is desired because it reduces the rate of wages.
('8', 420, 1, 5, 998065) The rich become richer thereby and the poor poorer.
('8', 420, 1, 6, 998117) Such competition is likely to ruin a nation in the long run.
('8', 420, 1, 7, 998178) The right law of demand and supply should ensure the payment of a just wage to a workman according to his worth.
('8', 420, 1, 8, 998291) This, too, will mean competition, but the result will be that people will be happy and skilful, for, instead of being obliged to underbid one another, they will have to acquire [new] skills to secure employment.
('8', 420, 1, 9, 998503) It is for this reason that men are drawn to government service.
('8', 420, 1, 10, 998567) There, salaries are fixed according to the gradation of posts.
('8', 420, 1, 11, 998630) The competition is only with regard to ability.
('8', 420, 1, 12, 998678) A candidate does not offer to accept a lower salary but claims that he is abler than others.
('8', 420, 1, 13, 998771) The same is the case with the Army and the Navy, and that is why there is much lesscorruption in these services.
('8', 420, 1, 14, 998884) But only in trade and commerce is there unhealthy competition, as a result of which corrupt practices, such as fraud, chicanery, theft, have increased.
('8', 420, 1, 15, 999036) Furthermore, goods of poor quality are manufactured.
('8', 420, 1, 16, 999089) The manufacturer wants a lion’s share [of the price] for himself, the workman to throw dust in the eyes of others and the consumer to exploit the situation to his own advantage.
('8', 420, 1, 17, 999267) This poisons all human intercourse, there is starvation all round, strikes multiply, manufacturers become rogues and consumers disregard ethical considerations.
('8', 420, 1, 18, 999428) One injustice leads to numerous others, and in the end the employer, the operative and the customer are all unhappy and meet with ruin.
('8', 420, 1, 19, 999564) A people among whom these [corrupt] practices prevail comes to grief in the end.
('8', 420, 1, 20, 999645) Its very wealth acts like a poison.
('8', 420, 1, 21, 999681) This is why men of wisdom have held that where Mammon is God, no one worships the true God.
('8', 420, 1, 22, 999773) Wealth cannot be reconciled with God.
('8', 420, 1, 23, 999811) God lives only in the homes of the poor.
('8', 420, 1, 24, 999852) This is what the British profess, but in practice they place wealth above everything else, estimate the prosperity of the nation by the number of its rich, and their economists formulate precepts for everyone to get rich quickly.
('8', 420, 1, 25, 1000082) True economics is the economics of justice.
('8', 420, 1, 26, 1000126) That people alone will be happy which learns how to do justice and be righteous under all conditions of life.
('8', 420, 1, 27, 1000236) All else is vain, a kind of moral perversity that presages doom.
('8', 420, 1, 28, 1000301) To teach the people to get rich at any cost is to teach them an evil lesson.
('8', 420, 1, 29, 1000378) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 4 7 1908
