('8', 421, 1, 2, 1000461) 238. LETTER TO “THE STAR” 1
('8', 421, 2, 3, 1000489) [JOHANNESBURG] [THE EDITOR THE STAR
('8', 421, 3, 4, 1000525) SIR,] Mr. Duncan’s letter with reference to the charge, which, with all deference to him, I must still continue to describe as “foul”, as to an organized illicit entry of Asiatics enables me to explain the position more fully to the public.
('8', 421, 3, 5, 1000766) It is the charge of organized illicit entry that Asiatics have always denied, and which only it was in their power to deny.
('8', 421, 3, 6, 1000890) One swallow does not make a summer, nor can isolated cases of unlawful entry be used to condemn a whole community.
('8', 421, 3, 7, 1001005) The charge was threefold: (1) that Asiatics entered on permits which were not their bona fide property; (2) that they entered on permits fraudulently obtained; (3) that they entered on forged permits.
('8', 421, 3, 8, 1001206) And it A was in order to test whether the documents held by Asiatic communities at the time were so tainted or not that the Bill was brought in.
('8', 421, 3, 9, 1001351) With reference to the 9,000 applications, it is admitted in the Governor’s Speech that almost all the Asiatics in the Colony have tendered voluntary registration.
('8', 421, 3, 10, 1001514) 2 I, therefore, assume that, in January last there were 9,000 Asiatics in the Colony.
('8', 421, 3, 11, 1001600) They have all tendered their documents, and, on the strength thereof, 7,600 have already been proved to have been legitimate residents of the Transvaal.
('8', 421, 3, 12, 1001753) As a matter or fact, the balance of the applications have not yet been rejected.
('8', 421, 3, 13, 1001834) On the contrary, most of them will probably be able to establish their bona fides.
('8', 421, 3, 14, 1001917) Their claims are still under consideration only because of the deadlock that has ensued, that is to say, they are holders of Dutch registration certificates, which General Smuts has declined to recognize as sufficient tide to residence in the Colony.
('8', 421, 4, 15, 1002168) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion under the title “Rejoinder to Mr. Duncan”.
('8', 421, 4, 16, 1002250) 2 In the course of his address to Parliament on June 15, on the occasion of its reopening, the Governor had said, “Practically the whole of the Asiatic population of this Colony to the number of 9, 072 have tendered voluntary registration and provisional registration certificates have already been issued to 7,617 Asiatics.
('8', 422, 0, 1, 1002575) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 423
('8', 422, 1, 2, 1002620) I may add that, according to the figures supplied by the Registrar of Asiatics, over 13,000 permits have been issued and are now in circulation.
('8', 422, 1, 3, 1002765) of these, under voluntary registration, 8,500 (assuming 500 are represented by Dutch registration certificates) have been called in and, it out of 8,500, 7,000 have established their tide, will Mr. Duncan allow me to claim that there was no organized illicit entry?
('8', 422, 1, 4, 1003031) With reference to the 4,500 outstanding permits (and they outstanding because those Asiatics are outside the Colony).
('8', 422, 1, 5, 1003149) I make bold to say that it will be found that very few of these permits are tainted.
('8', 422, 1, 6, 1003234) The Indian community has never endeavoured to challenge the statement that there was some illicit immigration of Asiatics.
('8', 422, 1, 7, 1003357) All that was stated in 1906, and I make bold to repeat, is that the evidence adduced was not, and is not now, sufficient to establish the charge of wholesale fraudulent entry.
('8', 422, 1, 8, 1003533) The Peace Preservation Ordinance was enough to deal with isolated cases.
('8', 422, 1, 9, 1003606) The compulsory measure was brought in because of, and was based upon, the assumption that Asiatics would not voluntarily allow their claims to be examined because they were largely tainted with fraud.
('8', 422, 1, 10, 1003807) Hence the offer of voluntary registration and hence also my statement that the result of voluntary registration has disposed of the foul charge of an organized illicit entry of Asiatics.
('8', 422, 2, 11, 1003994) [I am, etc., M.K. GANDHI] Indian Opinion, 4 7 1908
('8', 422, 3, 12, 1004045) 239. LETTER TO “INDIAN OPINION”
('8', 422, 4, 13, 1004077) JOHANNESBURG, July 4, 1908 EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('8', 422, 5, 14, 1004126) SIR, The test case brought against Mr. Sorabji, a Parsi gentleman of culture and English education, who has entered the Colony under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act, marks another stage in the Asiatic struggle.
('8', 422, 5, 15, 1004337) Mr. Sorabji, who holds splendid testimonials from the Chair man of the Charlestown Local Board and other prominent Europeans, is now to be tried not under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act but under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, for being an Asiatic without regis tration under the Act.
('8', 422, 5, 16, 1004623) I say nothing with reference to the trial under
('8', 423, 0, 1, 1004671) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 423, 1, 2, 1004713) the Asiatic Act because it is sub judice: but the Act of the case being brought under the Asiatic Act proves the point I have ventured to raise before General Smuts that educated Asiatics were free to enter under the Immigrants Restriction Act.
('8', 423, 1, 3, 1004958) That they become liable to a removal order if they do not accept Asiatic Act has been known all along, and that was why the petition 1 against the Immigrants’ Restriction Act stated that what the Government gave with the one hand, they took away with the other.
('8', 423, 1, 4, 1005220) Could Mr. Sorabji bring himself to accept degra dation under the Asiatic Act, he would not be a prohibited immigrant.
('8', 423, 1, 5, 1005338) What General Smuts asks Asiatics to give against repeal of the Asiatic Act is that they should surrender the rights of, say, Sir Mancherji Bhownaggree.
('8', 423, 1, 6, 1005490) It will now be seen clearly that Asiatics are not asking for any thing they are not entitled to by law.
('8', 423, 1, 7, 1005594) The anomalous position before the Colony in view of the arrest of an alleged permit forger at Pretoria today is that those who are rightful residents and who helped the Government can be kept on tenter hooks, whereas those Indians who are dishonest and steal into the country, by forgery or otherwise, may remain in it without molestation, because they would never approach the Government officials for identification, licence, or otherwise.
('8', 423, 2, 8, 1006036) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 11 7 1908
('8', 423, 3, 9, 1006087) 240. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY 2
('8', 423, 4, 10, 1006123) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 6, 1908 THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('8', 423, 5, 11, 1006184) SIR, A mass meeting 3 over eight hundred British Indians was held yesterday at the Hamidia Mosque to consider the Indian position as it is affected by the Supreme Court decision on the application for the return of the voluntary registration applications.
('8', 423, 5, 12, 1006440) My Association still
('8', 423, 6, 13, 1006461) 1 Vide”Petition to Secretary of State for Colonies”, 23 8 1907 2 This appeared in Indian Opinion the title “The Ultimatum” and was part of the precis forwarded by the Colonial Office along with his letter of July 22, 1908. 3 At this meeting, Sorabji Shapurji declared his determination not to submit to the registration law.
('8', 423, 6, 14, 1006786) He also claimed as an educated man free right of entry into the Transvaal.
('8', 424, 0, 1, 1006861) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 425
('8', 424, 1, 2, 1006906) respectfully trusts that these forms may be returned.
('8', 424, 1, 3, 1006960) The mass meet ing decided to hold another next Sunday for the purpose of burning voluntary registration certificates, in order that, in the event of the claims of domiciled British Indians and others not being considered by the Government, they may range themselves alongside of suchIndians and suffer with them.
('8', 424, 1, 4, 1007273) My Association is most anxious to avoid such a drastic step and, therefore, once more humbly approaches the Government for assistance.
('8', 424, 1, 5, 1007408) My Association reminds you of the speech delivered by you at Richmond 1 just the compromise, and reported in The Star of the 6th February last.
('8', 424, 1, 6, 1007552) In that speech, you are reported to have stated as follows: “He had told them, that is the Asiatics, that the law would not be repealed so long as there was an Asiatic in the country who had not registered.” And again, “until every Indian in the country had regis tered, the law would not be repealed.
('8', 424, 1, 7, 1007854) This shows that the only condi tion of repeal was complete registration.
('8', 424, 1, 8, 1007927) My Association need hardly say that practically every Asiatic in the Colony has made voluntary application in terms of the compromise.
('8', 424, 1, 9, 1008062) But now my Association understands that the Government, in exchange for repeal, ask British Indians to consent to the following: (a) That British Indians holding Dutch registration certificates, for which they have paid either £3 or £25, should become prohibited immigrants, whether they are within the Colony or outside the Colony.
('8', 424, 1, 10, 1008395) (b) That pre war Indian refugees, who have not yet returned to the Transvaal, should become prohibited immigrants.
('8', 424, 1, 11, 1008510) (c) That the voluntary applications which are now under consideration by the Registrar of Asiatics should be finally decided by the Registrar without the right of appeal to the Supreme Court.
('8', 424, 1, 12, 1008702) (d) That British Indians who can pass the severe test under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act should also be treated as prohibited immigrants.
('8', 424, 1, 13, 1008843) My Association ventures respectfully to submit that it is highly unfair to ask the British Indian community of the Transvaal to consent to a deprivation of the rights of some, in whose name the community cannot even speak With any effect.
('8', 424, 1, 14, 1009082) It would be one thing for the Government to pass legislation independently of the community affected thereby, and another thing to ask the community to consent to such legislation restrictive of the liberty of a portion of that class.
('8', 424, 1, 15, 1009317) With reference to (a) and (b), my Association ventures to state that their claims have never been summarily rejected, as it is now
('8', 424, 2, 16, 1009448) 1 On February 6, 1908
('8', 425, 0, 1, 1009470) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 425, 1, 2, 1009512) proposed, but that pre war refugees have received more or less consideration and have been granted permits to return.
('8', 425, 1, 3, 1009630) The repeated declarations of responsible officials after British occupation have made it perfectly clear that the domiciliary rights of pre war Asiatic residents would be respected.
('8', 425, 1, 4, 1009812) In wishing to treat such people now as prohibited immigrants, a most novel and, for British Indians, painful, position is sought to be created.
('8', 425, 1, 5, 1009956) My Association is quite willing that the burden of proving bona fide ownership of registration certificates should be thrown on the holders, and that the claims of those pre war residents who do not hold registration certificates should be limited to residence for a fixed period of, say, two years, such residence to be proved to the satisfaction of a court of law, always with the right of appeal to the Supreme Court so as to bring decisions of different lower courts into harmony.
('8', 425, 1, 6, 1010441) My Association further, in order to prevent any possible frauds, is prepared to accept a reasonable period within which all these outstanding claims should be submitted.
('8', 425, 1, 7, 1010611) It is within the knowledge of my Association that at least one Indian is outside the Colony who paid, in 1885, the sum of £25 to purchase his domicile in terms of Law 3 of 1885 before it was amended, and who holds European credentials, and has not yet been allowed to return.
('8', 425, 1, 8, 1010887) There are several such cases, though not of payment of £25 but of £3. My Association invites your attention to the following clause in Law 3 of 1885, which shows clearly that the fee of £3 was imposed to entitle the payer to settlement in the country:
('8', 425, 2, 9, 1011139) Those who settle in the Republic for the purposed carrying on any wade or otherwise shall be bound to have their names entered in a register to be separately kept for the purpose by the Landdrosts of the various districts, in accordance with a form to be prescribed by the Government.
('8', 425, 2, 10, 1011424) On suchregistra tion, which shall be effected within eight days after arrival, a sum of £25 sterling (subsequently £3) shall be paid.
('8', 425, 2, 11, 1011558) With reference to (c), it would be manifestly unfair to deprive those Indians who have already applied for voluntary registration of the right of having their claims examined judicially, when the claims of those who are entitled to return may be judicially examined, My Association fails to see any reason for such a differential treatment between Indians having similar claims.
('8', 425, 2, 12, 1011937) With reference to (d), my Association cannot help feeling that the proposal that Indians domiciled in the Transvaal should be consenting parties to the deprivation of the rights of Indians with high educational attainments, professional men, to whom British Indians in general are always prone to look up for assistance, is extraordinary.
('8', 425, 2, 13, 1012276) My Association respectfully contends that the interpretation of the
('8', 426, 0, 1, 1012344) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 427
('8', 426, 1, 2, 1012389) Immigrants’ Restriction Act leaves it open for Indians with European education to enter the country, and the fact that Mr. Sorabji, who has entered the country to test such interpretation, is now to be tried under the Asiatic Act for failing to produce a registration certificate, seems to uphold the contention of my Association and to show that the Government have abandoned their interpretation of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('8', 426, 1, 3, 1012823) My Association thinks that, so far as the European Colonists are concerned, in this question there is no substantial point involved, whereas it is one of deeply cherished sentiment to British Indians.
('8', 426, 1, 4, 1013024) In effect, the vast majority of even educated Indians will be shut out of the Colony because of the stringency of the test, and my Association does not object to any reasonable stringency, so long as education of a real type is respected and recognized as much in an Indian as in a European.
('8', 426, 1, 5, 1013316) In Natal, where the test is by no means so severe as in the Transvaal, according to the last Immigration Report, only a few Indians 1 entered under the test 2 Australia, which has also a similar education test, has successfully solved the problem of Asiatic immigration.
('8', 426, 1, 6, 1013587) My Association, therefore, ventures to trust that the Transvaal will not be an exception, and that the Government will be pleased to spare the natural feelings of British Indians in the matter.
('8', 426, 1, 7, 1013781) My Association, in conclusion, respectfully trusts that the Gov ernment will take into serious consideration the above representation, and finally close the Asiatic question so far as it is affected by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act; and thus, not only fulfil its part of the compromise, but give the lawful Asiatic residents of the Colony the rest and peace to which their conduct during the recent trouble has, by universal acknowledgement, entitled them; and, last but not least, to save the British Indians from the step to which they are committed, as above mentioned, in the event of the Government’s unfavourable decision.

('8', 436, 9, 15, 1034725) 1 Vide “ Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 6 7 1908. 2 Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 9 8 1908 3 This was in reply to the Leader’s editorial of July 10, 1908, which was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 18 7 1908, under the title “The Transvaal Trouble: How Government Promises Are Fulfilled”.
('8', 436, 9, 16, 1035018) The Leader had expressed the hope that the Asiatics would not “take steps of a sensational nature in pursuance of their contention with the Government” for that might put Parliament, then in session, in its “sternest mood”.
('8', 436, 9, 17, 1035242) Adverting to a comment on the situation by The Friend of Bloemfontein, the Leader further said that the advice that the compromise should be redeemed could be given “to both sides”, but urged Asiatics to recognize that in no circumstances would the Colony’s Europeans open the door to fresh immigration.

('8', 437, 1, 2, 1035588) runs as follows:
('8', 437, 2, 3, 1035605) I have the honour to inform you that it has been decided that Act No.
('8', 437, 2, 4, 1035675) 2 of 1907 is to remain on the Statute book; consequently all Asiatics applying for licences to trade must be required to produce a registration certificate issued under the Act, or in the form of the voluntary certificate, a specimen of which is attached, and to furnish a clear impression of their right hand thumb for examination in this Office.

('8', 437, 4, 13, 1037139) 246. TRIAL OF SORABJI SHAPURJI II
('8', 437, 5, 14, 1037173) [JOHANNESBURG, July 10, 1908]
('8', 437, 6, 15, 1037203) On Friday, the 10th instant, before Mr. Jordan, in B Court, Mr. Sorabji Shapurji, the Parsi gentleman, who had already been acquitted of a similar charge, 1 was charged, in terms of Section 8, Sub Section 3 of Act 2 of 1907, with having failed to produce a registration certificate issued under the Act, when the same was demanded of him by Superintendent Vernon, on the 9th instant.
('8', 437, 6, 16, 1037587) Mr. Cramer prosecuted for the Crown, and Mr. Gandhi appeared for the defence.
('8', 437, 7, 17, 1037665) Before replying generally to the indictment, Mr. Gandhi raised the plea
('8', 437, 8, 18, 1037737) 1 For earlier judgment, vide 3rd n footnote of “Johannesburg Letter”, 7 7 1908.
('8', 438, 0, 1, 1037817) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 439
('8', 438, 1, 2, 1037862) of autre fois acquit claiming that the accused had already been discharged in regard to the same offence.
('8', 438, 2, 3, 1037968) THE MAGISSTRATE: It is a continuous offence.
('8', 438, 3, 4, 1038013) Mr. Gandhi replied that he was aware of that, but claimed that, although the date in the indictment was given as July 9th, the accused should have been given eight clear days before being again brought before the Court and charged with the same offence.
('8', 438, 3, 5, 1038267) If the acquittal was worth anything to the accused, he should not be called upon to appear before the Court for another week.
('8', 438, 3, 6, 1038393) He did not for one moment, say that, for the purpose of his case, he required eight days.
('8', 438, 3, 7, 1038483) At the same time, there was that legal defence, and he was not justified in abandoning it.
('8', 438, 3, 8, 1038574) He claimed that the accused should have had a new lease of life from the preceding day, in accordance with the law.
('8', 438, 3, 9, 1038690) As it was, the accused was ruthlessly carried away from the Court Rude hands had been laid upon him, and he had not even been given the opportunity of leaving the Colony, if he had so desired, on the previous day.
('8', 438, 4, 10, 1038904) The Magistrate overruled the plea, and said that he would make a note of it.
('8', 438, 5, 11, 1038981) Superintendent Vernon gave formal evidence of arrest.
('8', 438, 5, 12, 1039035) He produced notices published in the Government Gazette containing official notifications by the Colonial Secretary that the time for registration under the Act expired on October 31, 1907, and the extension thereof on November 30, 1907.
('8', 438, 6, 13, 1039273) CROSS EXAMINED
('8', 438, 7, 14, 1039288) Witness was in Court the previous day, when accused was discharged.
('8', 438, 7, 15, 1039356) He had beckoned to him to come outside, and had arrested him outside the Court.
('8', 438, 7, 16, 1039436) It was a fact that between the time of accused’s discharge and his getting to the door of the Court he had not much time.
('8', 438, 8, 17, 1039558) Montford Chamney sated that he was Registrar of Asiatics.
('8', 438, 8, 18, 1039616) The accused had not applied for a certificate of registration under the Act 2 of 1907, nor had he been granted such a certificate.
('8', 438, 8, 19, 1039747) An application had been made for registration outside the provisions of the Act, but, upon consideration, witness found that accused was not entitled to registration.
('8', 438, 8, 20, 1039914) Witness proceeded that, under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act, the accused was not eligible to obtain such a certificate of registration.
('8', 438, 9, 21, 1040052) Mr. Gandhi objected to this statement on the ground that witness’s opinion as to the interpretation of the clause did not go for Anything, as he was not a judicial officer but merely an administrative officer.
('8', 438, 9, 22, 1040262) The Magistrate upheld the objection.
('8', 438, 10, 23, 1040299) Cross examined, witness stated that he had not examined the accused with reference to his educational qualifications.
('8', 438, 11, 24, 1040417) This closed the case for the prosecution.
('8', 439, 0, 1, 1040459) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 439, 1, 2, 1040501) Mr. Gandhi immediately applied for the discharge of the accused, because, although notices had been proved, the proper notice had not been proved.
('8', 439, 1, 3, 1040648) The Notice that should have been proved before the Court was one notifying that persons found within the Colony after a certain date would be called upon to produce registration certificates.
('8', 439, 1, 4, 1040840) The notices produced only referred to application for registration, and had absolutely no bearing whatever on the case.
('8', 439, 1, 5, 1040960) After all, November 30 had already passed, and his client had never applied for registration.
('8', 439, 1, 6, 1041054) The Notice contemplated in the section of the Act on which the charge was based was a notice authorizing the police to demand registration certificates, and it was only under such a notice that registration certificates could be demanded.
('8', 439, 1, 7, 1041293) This had not been proved.
('8', 439, 1, 8, 1041319) A lengthy argument resulted in Mr. Gandhi producing the required Notice.
('8', 439, 1, 9, 1041392) He would help the prosecution to that extent in regard to the third prosecution of the accused, but not in the present, holding that it was impossible for the Crown to obtain a conviction in the present case.
('8', 439, 1, 10, 1041601) He read the Notice.
('8', 439, 1, 11, 1041621) It set forth that the Government had appointed November 30, 1907 as the date after which any Asiatic over the age of sixteen who was found within the Colony and failed upon demand by any duly authorized person to produce a certificate of registration of which he was the lawful holder might be arrested and dealt with as provided.
('8', 439, 1, 12, 1041952) That Notice had never been put in.
('8', 439, 2, 13, 1041987) THE MAGISSTRATE: The question is whether the putting in of the Gazette is not sufficient notice in itself.
('8', 439, 3, 14, 1042094) Mr. Gandhi said that he felt it very keenly that such an argument should be adduced, after he had shown that his contention was correct.
('8', 439, 3, 15, 1042231) He still argued that the two notices produced by the Crown did not apply to the case at all.
('8', 439, 3, 16, 1042324) It was not his fault that he had over argued the case.
('8', 439, 3, 17, 1042379) The notice required had not been put in by the Crown and had not even been cited in the indictment.
('8', 439, 4, 18, 1042479) Mr. Jordan then adjourned the Court for luncheon, and intimated that he would give his decision upon resuming.
('8', 439, 5, 19, 1042590) When the Court resumed, the Public Prosecutor said that it appeared to be absolutely essential that the Gazette containing the notice should be produced in Court.
('8', 439, 5, 20, 1042753) Mr. Gandhi had taken advantage, and rightly so from his point of view, of a purely technical point, and he asked His Worship to allow him also to take advantage of a technicality.
('8', 439, 5, 21, 1042933) He asked His Worship to take it that the production of the Gazette and the reading of the notices by Mr. Gandhi was sufficient publication for the purposes of the case.
('8', 439, 6, 22, 1043102) In reply, Mr. Gandhi contended that he had not put in the Gazette.
('8', 439, 6, 23, 1043169) The Notice had never been put in at all.
('8', 439, 6, 24, 1043210) He had simply produced it as he would produce a law book to carry conviction to the Court as he was in the unfortunate position of not being able to make himself otherwise understood, but it would be unfair to penalize him for having helped the Court.
('8', 439, 6, 25, 1043462) In point of fact, so far as the evidence was concerned, the notice required by the law was
('8', 440, 0, 1, 1043553) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 441
('8', 440, 1, 2, 1043598) not within the judicial cognizance of the Court.
('8', 440, 2, 3, 1043647) The Magistrate said that he would take judicial notice of Mr. Gandhi’s argument, but overruled him.
('8', 440, 3, 4, 1043747) The accused was then called, and stated, in examination, that he had been in South Africa for six years, in Durban for a year and a half, and in Charlestown for four and a half years.
('8', 440, 3, 5, 1043931) He was book keeper and manager of the store of Mr. Hajee Hassam, of Charlestown, Natal.
('8', 440, 3, 6, 1044019) He received his English education at the Surat High School in the Bombay Presidency.
('8', 440, 3, 7, 1044104) He had received seven years’ education through the medium of the English language, and before that, seven years in the vernacular.
('8', 440, 3, 8, 1044235) He had entered the Transvaal under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('8', 440, 4, 9, 1044303) THE MAGISSTRATE: How can he ?
('8', 440, 5, 10, 1044333) Mr. Gandhi said that that was for him to show.
('8', 440, 5, 11, 1044380) It was for him to argue that accused was entitled to enter, after he had put the facts before the Court, but it was not possible for the Court to decide that question before the facts had been placed before it and properly argued when the right time came.
('8', 440, 6, 12, 1044636) The Magistrate stated that Mr. Gandhi had to show that his client was one of those exempted.
('8', 440, 7, 13, 1044729) Mr. Gandhi argued that as his client was educated and had means, he was entitled to enter the Transvaal under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('8', 440, 8, 14, 1044872) THE MAGISSTRATE: Do you mean to say that every Asiatic who can read and write in a European language can come into this Colony?
('8', 440, 8, 15, 1045000) MR. GANDHI: I do, Sir, and I am going to try and argue that before the Court, if I get the opportunity.
('8', 440, 9, 16, 1045104) Proceeding, witness stated that, when he entered the country, he had sufficient means.
('8', 440, 9, 17, 1045191) He was asked by Sergeant Mansfield of the South African Constabulary, the officer in charge of the Immigration Department at Volk srust, how much money he had.
('8', 440, 9, 18, 1045351) He had made an application for voluntary registration on the 22nd April last, having received written permission from Sergeant Mansfield to enter the Colony and make application.
('8', 440, 9, 19, 1045530) He held several testimonials from prominent townsmen, and some of these had been sent to Mr. Chamney in connection with his application.
('8', 440, 9, 20, 1045667) He had been discharged on the previous day on a similar charge to that whereon he was now brought before the Court.
('8', 440, 9, 21, 1045783) 1 He had no wish to apply under the Registration Act No.
('8', 440, 9, 22, 1045840) 2 of 1907.
('8', 440, 10, 23, 1045851) CROSS EXAMINED
('8', 440, 11, 24, 1045866) He was fully conversant with the provisions of that Act.
('8', 440, 11, 25, 1045923) He knew what steps should be taken for obtaining a registration certificate.
('8', 440, 11, 26, 1046000) He had never applied for registration under the Act, and had no desire to apply.
('8', 440, 11, 27, 1046081) He would
('8', 440, 12, 28, 1046090) 1 Vide Trial of Sorabji Shapurji I”, 8 7 1908
('8', 441, 0, 1, 1046136) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 441, 1, 2, 1046178) never apply or have anything to do with such an un British and disgraceful Act, and associated himself with his brethren in opposition to the Act.
('8', 441, 1, 3, 1046325) He had not come only for the purpose of making this a test case, but in order to make the Transvaal his home.
('8', 441, 1, 4, 1046435) He had come to reside in the Transvaal.
('8', 441, 1, 5, 1046475) Charlestown was his last place of residence, and he had never resided in the Transvaal before.
('8', 441, 1, 6, 1046570) It was his own intention to come to the Transvaal; he had never come by anyone’s advice, but of his own accord.
('8', 441, 1, 7, 1046682) He had, however, asked Mr. Gandhi’s opinion in a legal capacity first.
('8', 441, 1, 8, 1046753) The application that he made through the Magistrate’s Office at Volksrust had been refused.
('8', 441, 1, 9, 1046845) Since he came to Johannesburg, he lived in the Malay Location with Mr. Cama.
('8', 441, 1, 10, 1046922) It was not a fact that, prior to his entering the Transvaal, he had been in constant communication with the British Indian Association.
('8', 441, 2, 11, 1047058) Re examined, he stated that he was a British subject, and a Parsi.
('8', 441, 3, 12, 1047125) This closed the case for the defence.
('8', 441, 4, 13, 1047163) Mr. Gandhi argued his case at length.
('8', 441, 4, 14, 1047201) He first submitted that his client was not a prohibited immigrant under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act, in as much as he had shown that he had sufficient means and educational attain ments, and if he chose to apply under the Asiatic Act he would not be a prohi bited immigrant.
('8', 441, 4, 15, 1047480) He proceeded to argue that the Asiatic Act referred only to Asiatics who were in the Colony, and who resided in the Colony before the Act was passed, and, whatever the intention of the framers of the Immigrants’ Res triction Act, it left the door open for Asiatic immigration—undoubtedly of a very modified type.
('8', 441, 5, 16, 1047793) The Magistrate referred to Mr. Gandhi’s argument as very subtle and very able.
('8', 441, 5, 17, 1047872) He dealt with the points raised, and said that the accused had not made application for registration, but he gloried in the fact, and had set the Government at defiance.
('8', 441, 5, 18, 1048042) He ordered him to leave the Colony within seven days.

('8', 441, 7, 21, 1048150) It is known the world over that the Hindus cremate their dead.
('8', 441, 7, 22, 1048213) A request was made to the Government that cremation facilities similarto those available in Durban be provided for the Colony as a whole, and to this Mr. Diwan has received a very discouraging reply.
('8', 441, 7, 23, 1048413) The Government has said, without assigning any reasons, that the arrangements asked for cannot be made.

('8', 447, 3, 17, 1060893) 254. REPLY TO “THE STAR” 2
('8', 447, 4, 18, 1060920) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 16, 1908 THE EDITOR THE STAR
('8', 447, 5, 19, 1060970) SIR, You published in your notes yesterday the statement that a settlement of the Asiatic question is probable, and you state very properly that the point (that is, of education) would not appear to be essential to the general principles involved, as educated Indians could not, outside of their own community, make an adequate pittance.
('8', 447, 5, 20, 1061308) I hope that the news published by you is correct.
('8', 447, 6, 21, 1061358) 1 Some words missing 2 This appeared in Indian Opinion, 25 7 1908, under the title “Mr. Essop Mia’s Explanation”.
('8', 448, 0, 1, 1061472) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 449
('8', 448, 1, 2, 1061517) What, however, I understand to be the situation is that, whilst the Government are willing now to repeal the Act and recognize the rights of Asiatics domiciled in the Colony before the war, they insist upon British Indians accepting total prohibition of the entry of Indians, no matter what educational attainments they may possess.
('8', 448, 1, 3, 1061850) This is not in the law today, as Mr. Sorabji’s case has made clear.
('8', 448, 1, 4, 1061918) In asking us, therefore, to accept the above disqualification, the Government ask us to commit communal suicide.
('8', 448, 1, 5, 1062031) If the resident Asiatic population is to be fully protected, and is to be allowed to remain in the country in a becoming manner, it must be apparent to every Colonist that they will need the assistance and guidance of their educated brethren.
('8', 448, 1, 6, 1062274) By education I do not mean a mere knowledge of the elements of the English or any other European language, but I mean a very high degree of culture.
('8', 448, 1, 7, 1062423) Does anyone suppose that Indians in the Colony, the majority of whom are traders, can live with any degree of comfort, if they have not amongst them such men as I have described above ?
('8', 448, 1, 8, 1062609) There is not a British Colony in the world, with a resident Asiatic population, which has legislation of the kind to which our consent is now required as a condition precedent to the granting of simple jus tice to pre war Indians.
('8', 448, 1, 9, 1062840) If the Government think that they can carry their drastic policy of exclusion, let them do so and let them at the same time recognize the other rights.
('8', 448, 1, 10, 1062992) If justice is on our side on the question of education, and if we have sufficient strength in us, we will win.
('8', 448, 1, 11, 1063103) But, as the position stands at present, it seems to me that I and other Indians have armed ourselves with voluntary registration certificates and also yearly licences, and have placed ourselves in a better position than our other countrymen who have an equal right with us to live and trade in this Colony; and, as their position is in jeopardy, in view of the entire disregard by General Smuts of the solemn obligations undertaken by him, I feel I have erred in having been the first to take out my voluntary registration certificate and my annual licence.
('8', 448, 1, 12, 1063661) I, as well as other British Indians, who have taken a prominent part hitherto in the passive resistance campaign and since the compromise, have helped the Government to the best of our ability, have therefore decided, by way of protest and penance, ourselves to become hawkers and give ourselves the privilege of hawking without a licence.
('8', 448, 1, 13, 1064001) If, therefore, the people of Johannesburg see strange Indian faces with baskets of fruit and vegetables, they should understand that they have become unlicensed hawkers by way of protest against injustice.
('8', 448, 1, 14, 1064207) In taking this step with deliberation, my compatriots have no desire willingly to defy the laws of the land.
('8', 448, 1, 15, 1064316) It is because we have so great a respect for the laws of the country in which
('8', 449, 0, 1, 1064394) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 449, 1, 2, 1064436) we live that we have undertaken to break certain statutes, which are miscalled laws, but which can be more properly described as engines of tyranny.
('8', 449, 1, 3, 1064585) It is nobody’s duty to submit to tyranny.
('8', 449, 1, 4, 1064627) The step that has now been taken is, therefore, I hold, a perfectly lawful and just one.
('8', 449, 2, 5, 1064716) I a m , e t c .
('8', 449, 2, 6, 1064732) , ESSOP ISMAIL MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION The Star, 18 7 1908
('8', 449, 3, 7, 1064808) 255. WHAT WAS, AND IS, THE CAMPAIGN ABOUT?
('8', 449, 4, 8, 1064851) The Transvaal campaign is likely to teach the Indians a great many lessons.
('8', 449, 4, 9, 1064927) It did not, and does not, aim merely at securing the repeal of the Act.
('8', 449, 4, 10, 1064999) It is possible to get the Act repealed.
('8', 449, 4, 11, 1065039) But there exist loopholes which present difficulties, so that though General Smuts is prepared to repeal the Act we are unable to give our consent.
('8', 449, 4, 12, 1065187) The movement was never directed against finger impressions as such.
('8', 449, 4, 13, 1065255) 1 Now, when they demand the thumb impression on [traders’]licences, under the law, the community refuses to give them.
('8', 449, 4, 14, 1065374) It says to the Government: “We will not agree to anything under compulsion.” It would not agree even to names being signed on the applications for licences under the obnoxious Act.
('8', 449, 4, 15, 1065555) What, then, does disobedience of the obnoxious law mean?
('8', 449, 4, 16, 1065612) That is exactly what needs to be understood.
('8', 449, 4, 17, 1065657) If the law is repealed and replaced by another another even worse, we shall have gained nothing.
('8', 449, 4, 18, 1065754) The point is that the obnoxious law puts us in fetters, and they must be broken.
('8', 449, 4, 19, 1065835) It fetters us because if we submit to it, we must endure all manner of harassment by the Government.
('8', 449, 4, 20, 1065936) How can we put up with that?
('8', 449, 4, 21, 1065965) Once the fetters are broken, the Government will cease enacting unwanted laws affecting us, and will consult us beforehand.
('8', 449, 4, 22, 1066089) Does it bind itself so to consult us?
('8', 449, 4, 23, 1066127) Both yes and no.
('8', 449, 4, 24, 1066144) It will undertake to consult us— it has done so before—so long as we are prepared to fight against it with the sword of satyagraha.
('8', 449, 4, 25, 1066276) It will cease to remain so bound the moment we abandon satyagraha.
('8', 449, 4, 26, 1066343) The Government is prepared to safeguard the rights of those who hold the £3 registers.
('8', 449, 4, 27, 1066430) It also offers the right of appeal to the Supreme Court.
('8', 449, 4, 28, 1066487) But it will not allow educated Indians to enter.
('8', 449, 4, 29, 1066536) What does this
('8', 449, 5, 30, 1066551) 1Vide “A Dialogue on the Compromise”, 15 2 1908
('8', 450, 0, 1, 1066599) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 451
('8', 450, 1, 2, 1066644) Many people imagine that the term “educated Indians” denotes clerks.
('8', 450, 1, 3, 1066713) This is a mistake.
('8', 450, 1, 4, 1066732) Whether or not clerks are able to come in is another question.
('8', 450, 1, 5, 1066795) But forbidding the entry of lawyers, physicians, etc., is an intolerable situation.
('8', 450, 1, 6, 1066879) The true significance of all this is that the authorities first want to please the Indians by repealing the Act and then to finish them off.
('8', 450, 1, 7, 1067020) A lawyer or a physician is not worth more than a businessman or a farmer.
('8', 450, 1, 8, 1067094) But a trader is concerned with trade.
('8', 450, 1, 9, 1067132) A lawyer’s duty is to fight and help others fight.

('8', 454, 9, 24, 1078585) WHAT IS JUST?
('8', 454, 10, 25, 1078599) We saw in the three preceding chapters that the generally accept ed principles of economics are invalid.
('8', 454, 10, 26, 1078704) If acted upon, they will make individuals and nations unhappy.
('8', 454, 10, 27, 1078767) The poor will become poorer and the rich richer; neither will be any the happier for it.
('8', 454, 10, 28, 1078856) Economists do not take men’s conduct into account but
('8', 455, 0, 1, 1078910) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 455, 1, 2, 1078952) estimate prosperity from the amount of wealth accumulated and so conclude that the happiness of nations depends upon their wealth alone.
('8', 455, 1, 3, 1079089) Hence they advocate greater accumulation of wealth through more and more work in factories.
('8', 455, 1, 4, 1079181) In England and elsewhere factories have multiplied because of the spread of these ideas.
('8', 455, 1, 5, 1079270) Large numbers of men leave their farms and concentrate in cities.
('8', 455, 1, 6, 1079336) They give up the pure and fresh air of the countryside and feel happy breathing the foul air of factories.
('8', 455, 1, 7, 1079443) As a result, the nation grows weaker, and avarice and immorality increase, and if someone suggests measures for eradicating vice, the so called wise men argue that vice cannot be eliminated, that the ignorant cannot be educated all at once and that it is best to let things alone.
('8', 455, 1, 8, 1079724) While advancing this argument, they forget that it is the rich who are responsible for the immorality of the poor.
('8', 455, 1, 9, 1079839) The wretched workers slave for them day and night so that they may be kept supplied with their luxuries.
('8', 455, 1, 10, 1079944) They have not a moment to themselves for self improvement.
('8', 455, 1, 11, 1080003) Thinking about the rich, they also want to be rich.
('8', 455, 1, 12, 1080055) When they fail in this, they become angry and resentful.
('8', 455, 1, 13, 1080112) They then forget themselves [in their anger], and having failed to gather wealth by honest means, turn in desperation to fraud.
('8', 455, 1, 14, 1080240) Both wealth and labour are thus wasted, else they are utilized for promoting fraud.
('8', 455, 1, 15, 1080324) Labour, in the real sense of the term, is that which produces use ful articles.
('8', 455, 1, 16, 1080404) Useful articles are those which support human life.
('8', 455, 1, 17, 1080456) Suppo rting human life means provision of food, clothing, etc., so as to enable men to live a moral life and to do good while they live.
('8', 455, 1, 18, 1080593) For this purpose, large scale industrial undertakings would appear to be use less.
('8', 455, 1, 19, 1080676) To seek to acquire wealth by establishing big factories is likely to lead to sin.
('8', 455, 1, 20, 1080758) Many people amass wealth but few make good use of it.
('8', 455, 1, 21, 1080812) If the making of money is likely to lead a nation to its destruction, that money is useless.
('8', 455, 1, 22, 1080905) On the contrary, present day capitalists are respon sible for widespread and unjust wars.
('8', 455, 1, 23, 1080995) Most of the wars of our times spring from greed for money.
('8', 455, 1, 24, 1081054) We hear people say that it is impossible to educate others so as to improve them, and the best course would be to live as well as one could and accumulate wealth.
('8', 455, 1, 25, 1081217) Those he hold these views show little concern for ethical principles.
('8', 455, 1, 26, 1081287) For the person who values ethical prin ciples and does not yield to avarice has a disciplined mind; he does not tray from the right path, and influences others merely by his exa mple.
('8', 455, 1, 27, 1081471) If the individuals who constitute a nation do not observe moral principles of conduct how can the nation become moral?
('8', 455, 1, 28, 1081590) If we behave as we choose and then point the accusing finger at an errant neigh bour, how can the result [of our actions] be good?
('8', 455, 1, 29, 1081721) We thus see that money no more than a means which may make
('8', 456, 0, 1, 1081780) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 457
('8', 456, 1, 2, 1081825) for happiness or misery.
('8', 456, 1, 3, 1081850) In the hands of a good man, it can be used for cultivating land and raising crops.

('8', 459, 3, 8, 1090269) They hold the honour of India and their educated countrymen just as dearly as any Indian.
('8', 459, 3, 9, 1090359) In point of fact, my co religionists have stronger objections to the Asiatic Act than the other Indians, for the simple reason that it constitutes a direct attack on Mahomedanism, and offers a deliberate insult to the Caliph of the Faithful, His Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, who is the spiritual head of Islam, as His Majesty the King Emperor is the temporal head of the citizens of the British Empire.

('8', 462, 3, 7, 1096841) 261. SPEECH IN JOHANNESBURG [July 20, 1908]
('8', 462, 4, 8, 1096885) At the conclusion of the Court proceeding 1, Mr. Gandhi addressed the crowd outside his office.
('8', 462, 5, 9, 1096981) Mr. Sorabji, he pointed out, had gone to gaol because of a principle and not to open the gates of the Transvaal to the unrestricted immigration of Asiatics.
('8', 462, 5, 10, 1097138) He had come in under the Immigration Act in order to pass the educational test of that Act which made no distinction as to race, class or colour.
('8', 462, 5, 11, 1097284) He had studied English for seven years, but he now found that all his English was of no avail, notwithstanding that the Immigration Act was general in its application and that he was a British subject in a British Colony.
('8', 462, 6, 12, 1097506) The next step, continued Mr. Gandhi, was for those Indians who possessed licences to return them and stand the consequence of being arrested for trading without licences and going to gaol; also for them to return their certificates.
('8', 462, 6, 13, 1097739) It was only by showing that they were willing to undergo communal suffering and not to avail themselves of any present privileges that they could bring conviction to the minds of the European community that they were fighting for principle.
('8', 462, 6, 14, 1097980) He repeated that the Colonial Secretary had promised unconditionally to repeal the Asiatic Act provided the Asiatics registered voluntarily, but this promise had not been kept.
('8', 462, 7, 15, 1098157) Before the Indians broke up, some handed over their trading licences and several their registration certificates, and it is expected that this example will be largely followed.
('8', 462, 7, 16, 1098334) The Indians, we Understand, are indignant at the manner in which the police cleared them away from the entrance to the Police Court during the after noon, and also at the sentence passed on Mr. Sorabji, contending that hard labour should not have been given for what they consider a political offence.

('8', 464, 5, 12, 1100912) Witness saw accused sell bananas and oranges.
('8', 464, 5, 13, 1100958) He watched accused for 25 minutes.
('8', 464, 5, 14, 1100993) He asked accused for his licence, and the latter produced one that had expired on June 30, but he did not have one for the current quarter.

('8', 464, 6, 16, 1101175) Cross examined, [he said] he had received instructions to arrest all such men.
('8', 464, 6, 17, 1101254) He did not know whether accused had already applied for a licence.

('8', 464, 9, 21, 1101670) It would not be political, but would be entirely relevant to the matter before the Court.
('8', 464, 9, 22, 1101760) His client had not received a licence because instructions had been issued to the Municipality that all Asiatics applying for licences should undergo the formalities prescribed under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('8', 464, 9, 23, 1101974) In the month of January there was a settlement arrived at between the Government and the Asiatic communities whereby those who voluntarily registered were not to come under the Asiatic Act.
('8', 464, 9, 24, 1102164) His client had voluntarily regis tered, and because he had now been called upon to accept the Asiatic Act, under a reso lution passed by the British Indian Association, accused, in common with other Ind ians, had tendered the licence fee but had declined to accept the formalities of the Act.

('8', 465, 3, 7, 1102874) 265. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING
('8', 465, 4, 8, 1102902) [JOHANNESBURG, July 20, 1908] We have been informed through Mr. Cartwright that the Government Will agree to a settlement if we do not insist on the rights of educated [Asiatics].
('8', 465, 4, 9, 1103082) But all of you resolved at a previous meetingthat you would agitate for the cause of the educated.
('8', 465, 4, 10, 1103181) Your decision is commendable.
('8', 465, 4, 11, 1103211) We certainly cannot agree to the abolition of the rights of educated Asiatics.
('8', 465, 4, 12, 1103290) Notices were published by the Government in newspapers to the effect that the [Asiatic Registration] Act would stay, and also that those who refused to take out licences would be puni shed in accordance with that law.
('8', 465, 4, 13, 1103508) We cannot take out licences at this juncture, for the Government demands thumb impressions from us under the law.
('8', 465, 4, 14, 1103622) If they had been asked for outside the law, that is, an a voluntary basis, I myself would have advised [that they should be given].
('8', 465, 4, 15, 1103754) But under the law I cannot advise anyone to give even his signature.
('8', 465, 4, 16, 1103823) There are many persons who allege that I have charged a fee of two guineas each from Hindus as well as Muslims.
('8', 465, 4, 17, 1103935) Can anyone at this meeting [come forward and] tell me if I have accepted fees from any of them?
('8', 465, 4, 18, 1104031) The Government blames me for needlessly inciting the people.
('8', 465, 4, 19, 1104092) Whatever the Government may say, my duty is to place the facts as they are before my brethren.
('8', 465, 4, 20, 1104187) So I go on doing my duty, regardless of the Government’s accusations.
('8', 465, 4, 21, 1104257) To those who were frightened by the Government notices into taking out licences, I must say that they should not make use of them but court arrest and thereby fill the gaols as they did in January.
('8', 465, 4, 22, 1104455) By doing so they will humble the Government.
('8', 465, 4, 23, 1104500) Many have sought to dissuade the Chairman 1 from going the rounds as a hawker.
('8', 465, 4, 24, 1104579) That was not a nice thing to have done.
('8', 465, 4, 25, 1104619) Those who assume the garb of hawkers not indeed in the service of self interest but for the sake of others’ interests ought to be proud rather than ashamed of themselves.

('8', 466, 1, 2, 1104847) proud to have such a Chairman.

('8', 466, 2, 16, 1105757) 266. TRIAL OF ISMAIL AKOOJEE AND OTHERS
('8', 466, 3, 17, 1105797) [JOHANNESBURG, July 21, 1908]
('8', 466, 4, 18, 1105827) On Tuesday, the 21st instant, in the same Court [before Mr. P. C. Dalmahoy in D Court], Ismail Akoojee was charged with trading without a licence.
('8', 466, 4, 19, 1105974) He pleaded not guilty.
('8', 466, 4, 20, 1105997) Mr. Gandhi appeared for the defence.
('8', 466, 5, 21, 1106034) J. B. Barret stated that he was a Licensing Inspector under the Johannesburg Municipality.
('8', 466, 5, 22, 1106125) On the previous day, on the Market Square, within the Municipal area, he had seen accused exposing fruit for sale.
('8', 466, 5, 23, 1106240) He had asked accused for his licence, but the latter had replied that he did not have one.
('8', 466, 6, 24, 1106331) Cross examined, [he said] he did not know anything about Government instructions.
('8', 466, 7, 25, 1106413) T. H. Jefferson stated that he was Chief Licensing Inspector of the Municipality of Johannesburg.
('8', 466, 7, 26, 1106511) He produced Government Gazettes containing the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, the regulations thereunder, and the notices thereunder authorizing him to prosecute.
('8', 466, 7, 27, 1106670) He had seen a letter addressed to the Town Clerk by the Registrar of Asiatics, dated the 7th instant, stating that the Asiatic Law Amendment Act was to remain on the Statute book, and that no licences were to be renewed or issued except to Asiatics who produced registration certificates and gave thumb prints under the Act.
('8', 466, 8, 28, 1106995) Cross examined, he recollected that, in January last, several prosecutions took place, and that Asiatics were then sentenced.
('8', 466, 9, 29, 1107121) In the month of February the Government had issued instructions to him to
('8', 467, 0, 1, 1107195) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 467, 1, 2, 1107237) issue licences to all Asiatics who produced a letter from the Registrar of Asiatics acknowledging having received an application for voluntary registration.
('8', 467, 1, 3, 1107394) Such Asiatics were not called upon to give any thumb impressions at all.
('8', 467, 1, 4, 1107467) It was competent then for him to give licences for the quarter ended March 31, and afterwards he was authorized to issue licences to the quarter ended June 30. He did not think that any licences had been issued from his Department for the whole year.
('8', 467, 1, 5, 1107718) The instructions contained in the letter of the 7th instant were the revised and most recent ones.
('8', 467, 1, 6, 1107817) He admitted that many Asiatics had produced voluntary registration certificates but had declined to give thumb impressions.
('8', 467, 2, 7, 1107941) [MAGISSTRATE:] If thumb impressions are refused?
('8', 467, 3, 8, 1107990) JEFFERSON: I refuse to give licences.
('8', 467, 3, 9, 1108028) The registration certificate must be produced.
('8', 467, 4, 10, 1108075) Witness did not think that there had been any refusal to produce registration certificates.
('8', 467, 4, 11, 1108167) Registration certificates had not been produced only by those who had not received them.
('8', 467, 5, 12, 1108256) In reply to the Magistrate, witness stated that it was unnecessary up to the end of June to give thumb impressions.
('8', 467, 5, 13, 1108372) There had been no intimation thereafter of that requirement until Asiatics came to apply for licences.
('8', 467, 5, 14, 1108475) There was nothing in the Gazette as to not giving thumb marks up to the end of June.
('8', 467, 5, 15, 1108560) That appeared to be an act of grace on the part of the Government.
('8', 467, 6, 16, 1108627) This closed the case for the Crown.
('8', 467, 7, 17, 1108663) Accused giving evidence on his own behalf stated that he had applied for a licence during the current month.
('8', 467, 7, 18, 1108772) He had offered the licence fee.
('8', 467, 7, 19, 1108804) The licence was refused to him because they wanted his thumb impression under the Act which he had refused to give.
('8', 467, 7, 20, 1108920) He had the licence up to the end of June and also a voluntary registration certificate.
('8', 467, 8, 21, 1109008) Cross examined, [he said] he was not hawking without a licence at the time stated, but was walking along with his fruit in a basket on his way to the fruit store.
('8', 467, 8, 22, 1109171) He was not looking for customers.
('8', 467, 8, 23, 1109205) He admitted, however, that he had been hawking in the morning without a licence.
('8', 467, 8, 24, 1109286) This closed the case for the defence.
('8', 467, 9, 25, 1109324) Mr. Gandhi, addressing the Court said that he really had very little more to say than what he had said in evidence the previous afternoon.
('8', 467, 9, 26, 1109463) It appeared that the Government had first issued one set of instructions and afterwards another and the position was that the Indians did not know where they were.
('8', 467, 9, 27, 1109627) If the Government wished to proceed, they should proceed against those who Were the leaders and not against men like the accused.
('8', 467, 10, 28, 1109757) Accused was sentenced to pay a fine of 10s or to go to gaol [for] four days with hard labour.
('8', 467, 11, 29, 1109851) Similar sentences were imposed on Moosa Essop, Hari Bhikha, Dyah Parag, Saleji Bemath, Ismail Ebrahim, Keshav Goolab, and Nagar Morar, who were also defended by Mr. Gandhi.
('8', 468, 0, 1, 1110024) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 469
('8', 468, 1, 2, 1110069) Ahmed Essop Dowd was also similarly charged, but did not answer to his name when called, and his bail was estreated.
('8', 468, 1, 3, 1110186) A few minutes afterwards he entered the Court and stated that he had not heard his name called.
('8', 468, 1, 4, 1110282) Mr. Gandhi asked that his bail might be refunded, but the Magistrate stated that he did not have the power to do this.

('8', 468, 13, 20, 1110900) 268. SUMMARY OF LETTER TO GENERAL SMUTS 2
('8', 468, 14, 21, 1110942) July 21, 1908
('8', 468, 15, 22, 1110956) Mr. Gandhi, in a letter to General Smuts, points out that, while so many of the rank and file of the community are suffering imprisonment under the Registration Act, he himself, who has also not taken out a certificate, and is the chief instrument in his countrymen having done what they have, is still at large.
('8', 468, 15, 23, 1111269) He asks, “Is it coura geous to leave me alone and to harass poor Indians?” He reasserts his eagerness to serve the people of the Transvaal generally as to serve his own countrymen.

('8', 469, 3, 6, 1112131) Mr. Imam Abdul Cader, Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, Mr. T. Naidoo, co signatory with me to the letter sent from the gaol, and four others have also been arrested for hawking without licences.
('8', 469, 3, 7, 1112334) These last are all gentlemen who, in the ordinary walk of life, are not hawkers, but they have taken.
('8', 469, 3, 8, 1112436) to it by way of protest.
('8', 469, 3, 9, 1112461) The arrest of Imam Abdul Cader will create a sensation, not only in South Africa, but throughout India.
('8', 469, 3, 10, 1112565) The word “Imam” means “priest”.
('8', 469, 3, 11, 1112597) His vocation was, and still is very often, that of priest at the Mosque, and the position of Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society is also a very responsible one.
('8', 469, 3, 12, 1112762) I am, Yours sincerely, ALBERT CARTWRIGHT, ESQ.

('8', 470, 1, 2, 1113828) reply to his question, that he was chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society and the Assistant Priest of the Indian Mosque.

('8', 470, 2, 4, 1113982) [GANDHIJI:] Will you explain to the Court why?
('8', 470, 3, 5, 1114029) [BAWAZEER:] Because there was a compromise between General Smuts and some of the Indian leaders .
('8', 470, 4, 6, 1114127) The Crown Prosecutor intervened, and asked if the witness knew this of his own knowledge.
('8', 470, 5, 7, 1114217) THE MAGISSTRATE: Has he got permission from the Colonial Secretary to hawk without a licence?
('8', 470, 6, 8, 1114311) MR. GANDHI: No.
('8', 470, 7, 9, 1114327) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said the reason why he wanted to lead evidence was just the same as that he gave yesterday.
('8', 470, 7, 10, 1114442) The Court had a right to know, he thought, why a gentleman occupying the position of the accused had taken to hawking.
('8', 470, 8, 11, 1114561) The Magistrate said it was not a matter which concerned the Court.
('8', 470, 9, 12, 1114628) Mr. Gandhi replied that, if that was not a question of interest, it was a question of justice.
('8', 470, 10, 13, 1114723) Witness, continuing, said that when the compromise was effected he assisted in fulfilling it, but he now found that the compromise, so far as the Government was concerned, was not being properly fulfilled, and as a protest he took to hawking without a licence.
('8', 470, 11, 14, 1114984) The Magistrate asked : Was he one of the 14 people exempted?
('8', 470, 12, 15, 1115045) Mr. Gandhi said he did not know of any exemptions.
('8', 470, 12, 16, 1115096) If there were people exempted, they were in a most fortunate position.
('8', 470, 13, 17, 1115167) The Crown Prosecutor said there were a certain number of exemptions, and witness would probably know if he was exempt.
('8', 470, 14, 18, 1115286) Mr. Gandhi said he had not the slightest information of any exemption.
('8', 470, 14, 19, 1115357) His position was that his client felt aggrieved and decided to suffer with his poorer countrymen because they were suddenly called upon to submit to the Asiatic Act, having complied with voluntary registration.
('8', 470, 14, 20, 1115568) They thought they would not be called upon to do so.
('8', 470, 15, 21, 1115621) THE MAGISSTRATE: You took to hawking lately to put yourself in the same position as the hawkers?
('8', 470, 16, 22, 1115718) ACCUSED : I took to hawking to defend my people.
('8', 470, 17, 23, 1115767) MR. GANDHI: You are one of the people who assisted the Government in carrying out the compromise?
('8', 470, 18, 24, 1115865) [ACCUSED:] Yes; I endeavoured to explain to my own people what the compromise was, and I told them if they complied with voluntary registration, they would not be called upon to submit.
('8', 470, 19, 25, 1116051) [GANDHIJI:] And the members of the Society you represent followed your advice and took out voluntary registration certificates?
('8', 471, 0, 1, 1116179) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 471, 1, 2, 1116221) [ACCUSED :] Yes.
('8', 471, 2, 3, 1116238) In further examination, the witness said he had seen a circular in connection with hawkers who did not comply with the Act.
('8', 471, 2, 4, 1116362) He was married and had a wife and children residing in Johannesburg, and he had resided there himself for 13 years.
('8', 471, 3, 5, 1116478) THE EXEMPTIONS
('8', 471, 4, 6, 1116493) Mr. T. H. Jefferson, Chief Inspector of Licences, called by Mr. Gandhi, stated he had got a list of names of people who were exempted from having to comply with the terms of the Act.
('8', 471, 4, 7, 1116676) They were not compelled to give thumb impressions.
('8', 471, 4, 8, 1116727) He could not recall the names and he only got the list yesterday.
('8', 471, 4, 9, 1116793) He did not know if any of the accused were exempt.
('8', 471, 5, 10, 1116844) Mr. Gandhi, in his address to the Court, said the only point he would deal with was the question of exemptions.
('8', 471, 5, 11, 1116956) He asked the Court to take note of the arbitrary proceedings on the part of the Government.
('8', 471, 5, 12, 1117048) He had absolutely no knowledge that there were any exemptions, but he wished to point out that in the Asiatic Act there was absolutely no authority given to the Government to grant exemptions, and was the Court going to countenance an arbitrary administration of the Act?
('8', 471, 6, 13, 1117320) The Magistrate said the charge was admitted and that was all he had got to do with it.
('8', 471, 6, 14, 1117407) He sentenced the accused to pay a fine of 10 s or [undergo] imprisonment for four days with hard labour.
('8', 471, 7, 15, 1117512) Mahomed Ebrahim Kunkey, Moosa Bagas, Mahomed Ebrahim, Ahmed Mahomed Motara and S. Bagas were similarly sentenced after formal evidence.
('8', 471, 8, 16, 1117648) Thambi Naidoo was also charged with hawking without a licence, and after formal evidence of arrest the accused gave evidence.
('8', 471, 8, 17, 1117774) He stated he was a cartage contractor and had taken to hawking since last Friday.
('8', 471, 8, 18, 1117856) He went to gaol in January last for non compliance with the Registration Act.
('8', 471, 8, 19, 1117934) He was one of the signatories to the letter addressed to General Smuts in connection with the compromise, and in trying to carry out the Indian part of the compromise, he suffered assault.
('8', 471, 9, 20, 1118123) A similar sentence to [sic] the others was passed.

('8', 471, 11, 23, 1118241) THE COMBAT DEEPENS
('8', 471, 12, 24, 1118260) Mr. Sorabji is in gaol.
('8', 471, 12, 25, 1118284) He got one month’s hard labour.
('8', 471, 12, 26, 1118316) It has now become the duty of every Indian to volunteer for imprisonment.
('8', 471, 12, 27, 1118390) Mr. Sorabji was arrested and taken to prison at seven on Monday in the extreme cold of morning.
('8', 471, 12, 28, 1118486) There was no need to have done this.
('8', 471, 12, 29, 1118523) Mr. Gandhi had sent a notice [to the authorities] saying that Mr. Sora bji would present himself whenever required, and this was ignored.

('8', 472, 1, 2, 1118706) Hundreds of Indians had turned up to hear the case.

('8', 472, 1, 5, 1118849) The Indians who remained outside were treated in a mosthigh handed fashion.

('8', 476, 3, 4, 1127839) I have received a report today (an authoritative one) to the effect that out of the 800 Indian hawkers in Johannesburg, 700 have taken out licences.

('8', 476, 3, 6, 1128035) The rest have taken them under the law, that is, by giving thumb impressions.

('8', 476, 3, 8, 1128257) The remaining 100, 1 hope, will not take out licences under any circumstances.
