('8', 482, 4, 6, 1143264) APPENDIX III
('8', 482, 5, 7, 1143277) THE ETHICS OF PASSIVE RESISTANCE
('8', 482, 6, 8, 1143310) PRIZE ESSAY
('8', 482, 7, 9, 1143322) M. S. Maurice
('8', 482, 9, 10, 1143336) Nineteen centuries ago one of the greatest moralists of the world laid down his life in passive resistance to constituted authority in what was then a great centre of spiritual activity.
('8', 482, 9, 11, 1143523) The ground for the resistance was unquestionably valid, as it has continued down to this day a memorable and living example of loyal submission to human law, where such submission was not in direct conflict with the higher law of conscience.
('8', 482, 9, 12, 1143765) The resistance had reference to an injunction that a living faith in a superhuman or divine power was to be abjured, and a claim to spiritual kingship over a certain race of people was to be renounced in favour of the temporal power then existing.
('8', 482, 9, 13, 1144013) “We found this fellow perverting the nation, and forbidding to give tribute to Caesar, saying that he himself is Christ, a King.” To Pilate’s question, after asking him whether he put the question of himself, Jesus said: “My Kingdom is not of this world: if My Kingdom were of this world then would My servants fight.” His death on the cross has ever been a unique episode in the world’s history—a magnificent example of what disobedience to the law really meant.
('8', 482, 9, 14, 1144477) There was no question as to the doubtful character of the authority which sought to enforce the decree of death by crucifixion.
('8', 482, 9, 15, 1144605) The illegal nature of the punishment was not in itself a matter of dispute.
('8', 482, 9, 16, 1144681) It was harsh; it was unjust; it was rigorous in the extreme; it was wholly unmerited.
('8', 482, 9, 17, 1144767) But he who found himself placed in subjection to the law as it then operated, and to the authority which asserted itself in carrying out that law, deemed it within his right, in obedience to his conscience, to resist both, but in a passive manner: there was no idea of resisting it by force.
('8', 482, 9, 18, 1145059) A combination of his servants and followers against the law would have been a direct condemnation of his faith.
('8', 482, 9, 19, 1145171) A concerted action to enforce his claim by physical means would have been derogatory to his moral character and to his high mission.
('8', 482, 9, 20, 1145304) And so the man who had the most powerful force behind him, by virtue of his transcendent moral sway—a force irresistible in its inherent strength, and overwhelming in its ultimate result, if put into effect—preferred to resist the law
('8', 483, 0, 1, 1145539) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 483, 1, 2, 1145581) by submitting to the dread decree pronounced against him for breaking the laws’ (to him) unlawful demand.
('8', 483, 2, 3, 1145687) During the same epoch of Christian history, and but a few months after the consummation of Christ, a holy man met martyrdom at the hands of his adversaries.
('8', 483, 2, 4, 1145844) His offence was “speaking blasphemous words against Moses and against God”.
('8', 483, 2, 5, 1145920) He, however, proved a passive resister.
('8', 483, 2, 6, 1145960) His detractors proceeded to open violence.
('8', 483, 2, 7, 1146003) He was dragged out of the city and stoned to death.
('8', 483, 2, 8, 1146055) Upon the removal of Stephen a general persecution was raised against the Church people at Jerusalem.
('8', 483, 2, 9, 1146156) Men and women were haled and committed to prison.
('8', 483, 2, 10, 1146206) Thus passive resistance obtained Divine sanction, and men had recourse to it as the only effective weapon against tyranny and injustice and oppression.
('8', 483, 2, 11, 1146358) As martyrdom was a penalty of self consciousness, born of the deepest convictions in religious life, so in civil life those whose minds and whose consciences revolt against oppressive laws, against laws which seek to take away the best of manhood and to degrade humanity, adopt passive resistance as the most effectual salve to their outraged consciences.
('8', 483, 3, 12, 1146714) What kind of Society is it which, at this period, has for its base, in equality and injustice?
('8', 483, 3, 13, 1146809) The hell of the poor makes the paradise of the rich.
('8', 483, 3, 14, 1146862) Not only has happiness not come, but honour has fled.
('8', 483, 4, 15, 1146916) We should be sorry to think with Victor Hugo that this is so.
('8', 483, 4, 16, 1146978) And yet Tolstoy and Hugo shine as two of the greatest minds which have probed into the deeps of humanity in our time.
('8', 483, 4, 17, 1147096) Thoreau, one of the greatest of American moralists, the author of The Duty of Civil Disobedience, was a martyr to his principles—principles dictated by the highest sense of duty to the State, as well as obedience to conscience.
('8', 483, 4, 18, 1147324) Human convictions may be right or wrong, but there is always a limit to human endurance in the fulfilment of human law.
('8', 483, 4, 19, 1147444) No man today will pretend to deny to a modern Japanese the highest form of personal courage and the severest form of moral rectitude.
('8', 483, 4, 20, 1147578) They have been apparent to us of late years in many ways.
('8', 483, 4, 21, 1147636) To us his “Bushido” may seem a blind fetish, but its true meaning, its deep significance, is understood and appreciated by the deepest thinkers of our day.
('8', 483, 4, 22, 1147792) They know it touches the deep chords of humanity.
('8', 483, 4, 23, 1147842) When we have grasped the true moral side of Japanese ethics, and realize to ourselves what a changed being a cultured Japanese has become under the law of evolution, it will be easy for us to understand why at moments of great trial when the spirit of patriotism and family relationship is in the ascendant— he passively resists the admonitions of the inner monitor, refuses to save his life, and creates for himself a moral injunction as it were for physical extinction so as to reach up to a spiritual life of national redemption and regeneration.
('8', 483, 5, 24, 1148392) Passive resistance as a political weapon and a moral action has, therefore, the fullest possible justification behind it.
('8', 483, 5, 25, 1148514) To offer physical force against recognized authority which seeks to enforce any law, good or bad, would be morally wrong.
('8', 483, 5, 26, 1148636) When you however resist the law, not actively but passively, you thereby imply that what is good and just law to some may be bad to others.
('8', 483, 5, 27, 1148776) While human institutions
('8', 484, 0, 1, 1148801) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 485
('8', 484, 1, 2, 1148846) continue, imperfect men of strong conscience and rational ideas will adopt this mode of expressing their protest against iniquitous ordinances.
('8', 484, 2, 3, 1148990) Under any form of government power is relegated to a group of men to judge in righteousness and to rule with equity and justice.
('8', 484, 2, 4, 1149119) It does not follow that, because men are called to power and are invested with authority to enact laws, they must be considered immaculate or infallible.
('8', 484, 2, 5, 1149273) Too often the best men—the most humane, the most just, the most practical, the most considerate—remain subjects, and do not become rulers or framers of laws for their fellow men.
('8', 484, 2, 6, 1149452) Similarly, too often those who attain to power are inconsiderate, tyrannical, unjust.
('8', 484, 2, 7, 1149538) If proof were needed, it will be found ready to hand from almost every country and from every age.
('8', 484, 2, 8, 1149637) To take a recent case in point from a nation in the front rank, I would cite the passive resistance offered by a large section of highly educated people in England against the last Education Act.
('8', 484, 2, 9, 1149833) Here we have a form of government which has undergone a purifying process during centuries of civilization—a government which, by common admission, has reached almost the highest limit of advanced democracy, in which power is attained by a just and equitable process—by sheer force of intellect and reason—a government which bears on the face of it every element of moral right and expediency.
('8', 484, 2, 10, 1150227) Yet we see a law promulgated apparently in the best interests of the whole community, but which proves in its operation, directly antagonistic to, and unacceptable by a large, intelligent and otherwise obedient section of that community.
('8', 484, 2, 11, 1150465) Numerous laws are in operation to which it gives willing and unquestioned obedience, but, owing to reasons which have swayed humanity in all ages, it finds that its conscience revolts against the new measure.
('8', 484, 2, 12, 1150674) The new enactment caused a serious conflict in their minds: it warred against their sense of right.
('8', 484, 2, 13, 1150774) It therefore simply declined to do the law’s bidding and accepted the consequent penalties.
('8', 484, 3, 14, 1150866) Laws are said to be made for the safety, the security and the protection of the interests of the people: they are not made to chastise and oppress.
('8', 484, 3, 15, 1151014) They must be guided by reason, necessity, expediency in the interests of all.
('8', 484, 3, 16, 1151092) They must injure none: they must not remorselessly override the domain of reason and conscience.
('8', 484, 3, 17, 1151189) They must act with justice and circumspection.
('8', 484, 3, 18, 1151236) “Render unto Caesar that which is Caesar’s” does not mean that men should resign themselves body and soul to the law, at the law’s bidding.
('8', 484, 3, 19, 1151376) Three times within my knowledge has a high minded, law abiding and intelligent citizen met the laws’ injunctions by paying the required fine instead of complying with the law which demanded that he should have his child vaccinated.
('8', 484, 3, 20, 1151608) On moral grounds he was right not to set aside his conscientious scruples.
('8', 484, 3, 21, 1151683) To salve his conscience he became a passive resister.
('8', 484, 3, 22, 1151737) In the words of Thoreau, this man was a man first and a subject afterwards.
('8', 484, 3, 23, 1151813) He obeyed the law of conscience before blindly complying with the alternative of man made law.
('8', 484, 3, 24, 1151908) “It is not desirable to cultivate a respect for the law so much as for the right.
('8', 484, 3, 25, 1151990) The only obligation which I
('8', 485, 0, 1, 1152018) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 485, 1, 2, 1152060) have a right to assume is to do at any time what I think right.” III
('8', 485, 2, 3, 1152129) Passive resistance is indeed an extreme course with an honest man; he is generally driven to that course by the stress of physical power, and hence his action is not unjustifiable on moral grounds.
('8', 485, 2, 4, 1152327) If passive resistance on the part of a minority in a state becomes an imperative necessity, then the majority cannot continue strong for long; it is bound to weaken and become effete as to its action in the matter of en forcing its power or its authority against that minority.
('8', 485, 2, 5, 1152605) And passive resistance of subjects, who are not even legal units of a lawful or legally constituted Government, has all the more reason for its action, in a given case, since such a Government cannot justly impose burdens or restrictions on units which had no voice in its creation.
('8', 485, 2, 6, 1152888) Such imposition of burdens on one particular section of a community would be tyrannical, and must ultimately tend to endanger the political fabric of that community.
('8', 485, 2, 7, 1153054) The very raison d’etre of the Government would, in these circumstances, become open to question.
('8', 485, 3, 8, 1153151) There is so much force in what Thoreau has written on the ethics of passive resistance that I make no apology for introducing here some of the relevant passages bearing on the subject of civil disobedience.
('8', 485, 4, 9, 1153358) Unjust laws exist: shall we be content to obey them, or shall we endeavour to amend them, and obey them until we have succeeded, or shall we transgress them at once?
('8', 485, 4, 10, 1153524) Men generally, under such a government as this, (United States) think that they ought to wait until they have persuaded the majority to alter them.
('8', 485, 4, 11, 1153672) They think that, if they should resist, the remedy would be worse than the evil.
('8', 485, 4, 12, 1153753) But it is the fault of the government itself that the remedy is worse than the evil.
('8', 485, 4, 13, 1153838) It makes it worse.
('8', 485, 4, 14, 1153857) Why is it not more apt to anticipate and provide for reform?
('8', 485, 4, 15, 1153918) Why does it not cherish its wise minority?
('8', 485, 4, 16, 1153961) Why does it cry and resist before it is hurt ?
('8', 485, 4, 17, 1154008) Why does it not encourage its citizens to be on the alert to point out its faults, and do better than it would have [by] them?
('8', 485, 5, 18, 1154135) Action from principle, the perception and performance of right, changes things and relations; it is essentially revolutionary, and does not consist wholly with anything which was.
('8', 485, 5, 19, 1154315) It not only divides states and churches, it divides families: ay, it divides the individual, separating the diabolical in him from the divine.
('8', 485, 6, 20, 1154458) Speaking of the inconsistent side of the aggregate intelligence placed in authority and power, he says:
('8', 485, 7, 21, 1154562) After all, the practical reason why, when the power is once in the hands of the people, a majority are permitted, and for a long period continue, to rule, is not because they are most likely to be in the right, not because this seems fairest to the minority, but because they are physically the strongest.
('8', 485, 7, 22, 1154868) But a Government in which the majority rule in all cases cannot be based on justice, even as far as men understand it.
('8', 486, 0, 1, 1154987) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 487
('8', 486, 1, 2, 1155032) I think that it is enough if they have God on their side without waiting for that other one.
('8', 486, 1, 3, 1155125) Moreover, any man more right than his neighbours constitutes a majority of one already.
('8', 486, 1, 4, 1155213) Under a government which imprisons any unjustly the true place for a just man is also prison.
('8', 486, 2, 5, 1155307) Modern conditions have altered the whole face of State administration.
('8', 486, 2, 6, 1155378) The voting system under a party government often, however, places an illiberal group of men in place and power.
('8', 486, 2, 7, 1155490) To meet conditions of this kind, Thoreau exhorts all honest men in this wise:
('8', 486, 3, 8, 1155568) Cast your whole vote, not a strip of paper merely, but your whole influence.
('8', 486, 3, 9, 1155645) A minority is powerless while it conforms to the majority; it is not even a minority then; but it is irresistible when it clogs by its whole weight.
('8', 486, 4, 10, 1155794) Upwards of four centuries before the advent of Christ, Socrates, of’ Greece, was reputed to be the wisest moralist of his age.
('8', 486, 4, 11, 1155921) His unflinching integrity made him many enemies.
('8', 486, 4, 12, 1155970) The State, or rather those in power in the State, accused him of corrupting the Athenian youth and of despising the national gods.
('8', 486, 4, 13, 1156101) He was indicted in a regular manner.
('8', 486, 4, 14, 1156138) His chief offence consisted in his heeding the divine voice or inward monitor, which people in those times did not comprehend as clearly as he did.
('8', 486, 4, 15, 1156286) He declared that his demon rebuked him for misconduct, and commended him for every good word and work.
('8', 486, 4, 16, 1156389) He was in advance of his times.
('8', 486, 4, 17, 1156421) And for his originality, integrity and wisdom be was condemned to death.
('8', 486, 4, 18, 1156494) When one of his disciples exclaimed “How shameful to condemn a man so innocent!” Socrates asked if his friends would think it less shameful if he were guilty.
('8', 486, 4, 19, 1156653) Here was a man who, abandoning all speculations as regards the material world, fearlessly taught “that the proper study of mankind was man”, was derided, reviled and then condemned to undergo the extreme penalty of the law.
('8', 486, 4, 20, 1156877) The law of conscience was accounted nothing in those days as it is still considered of little account in reference to human laws and administrative enactments, under our present forms of civilized government.
('8', 486, 4, 21, 1157086) The Delphic Oracle pronounced Socrates the wisest of men.
('8', 486, 4, 22, 1157144) To this he made a characteristic declaration: “Whereas other men thought they knew something, he alone had attained to this element of true knowledge, he knew that he knew nothing.”
('8', 486, 5, 23, 1157326) Passive resistance is emphatically submission to physical force under protest.
('8', 486, 5, 24, 1157405) “Resist not evil,” said Jesus of Nazareth, and Socrates, by drinking the poison, refrained from resisting what he had adjudged in his own mind as evil.
('8', 486, 5, 25, 1157557) How far this consorts with the philosophy of Plato, another brilliant heathen sage, will be apparent from the following prophetic picture of the Man of Sorrows whom the western world has defined:
('8', 486, 6, 26, 1157753) A man perfectly good, virtuous and just; not one who wishes to appear so before his fellows, but one who is really and sincerely so.
('8', 486, 6, 27, 1157886) We strip him of his good name .
('8', 486, 6, 28, 1157918) deprive him of everything except his intrinsic goodness.
('8', 486, 6, 29, 1157975) Without doing wrong, we will suppose him to be accounted an evil doer, that his virtue may be tried so as by fire.
('8', 486, 6, 30, 1158090) Neither infamy nor ill usage, neither
('8', 487, 0, 1, 1158128) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 487, 1, 2, 1158170) poverty nor distress, neither the malignity of persecution nor the pain of cruel torture can make him swerve from the path of duty.
('8', 487, 1, 3, 1158302) Death stares him in the face, but he remains unshaken; branded as a sinner, he is still a saint .
('8', 487, 1, 4, 1158400) To complete the picture, we will suppose this godly man to be beaten with bats, scourged with whips, put to the torture, laden with chains, nailed to a cross, numbered with transgressors, and yet without sin.
('8', 487, 2, 5, 1158609) Plato wrote thus, three centuries before the advent of Christ.
('8', 487, 2, 6, 1158672) His further definition of a modern passive resister is almost inspired:
('8', 487, 3, 7, 1158744) A bad man is wretched amidst every earthly advantage; a good man—troubled on every side, yet not distressed; perplexed, but not in despair; persecuted, but not forsaken; cast down, but not destroyed.
('8', 487, 4, 8, 1158944) Most men of our day account Count Tolstoy a paradox.
('8', 487, 4, 9, 1158997) By common admission, however, he is a great thinker, if not quite a seer.
('8', 487, 4, 10, 1159071) He has certainly probed into the deeps of humanity.
('8', 487, 4, 11, 1159123) He has laid bare many of the human follies and foibles.
('8', 487, 4, 12, 1159179) Upon war as upon capital punishment, he looks with the deepest horror.
('8', 487, 4, 13, 1159250) An extremist he may be, yet he is a realist—a rationalist.
('8', 487, 4, 14, 1159309) Passive resistance is almost a fetish with him.
('8', 487, 5, 15, 1159357) We can suffer, we might not break the law.
('8', 487, 5, 16, 1159400) Men do far more harm and inflict far more injury on one another by attempting to prevent evil by violence than if they endured evil patiently.
('8', 487, 5, 17, 1159543) Besides, have you ever considered that it is only by suffering pain, torture, misery and death that you are able to convert men?
('8', 487, 5, 18, 1159672) Do you think Christianity made its way in the world by preaching?
('8', 487, 5, 19, 1159738) No such thing.
('8', 487, 5, 20, 1159753) No one was ever converted by preaching.
('8', 487, 5, 21, 1159793) What converts men is not preaching but martyrdom.
('8', 487, 5, 22, 1159843) It is only when men see other men—weak, sensitive, comfort loving men like themselves—taking joyfully the spoiling of their goods, rejoicing in persecution, and going gladly to death for their faith, that they begin to believe there is something in it.
('8', 487, 5, 23, 1160096) No one ever believes in the truth of anything till he sees that someone is willing to die for it.
('8', 487, 5, 24, 1160194) The prison, the stake, the gallows—these are the great arguments which convince men.
('8', 487, 5, 25, 1160279) And if you refuse to submit to these punishments, you destroy your only chance of converting men to your faith.
('8', 487, 6, 26, 1160391) Count Tolstoy explicitly lays it down that all punishments are in their nature persecution.
('8', 487, 7, 27, 1160483) If you say a man is a trouble and a nuisance to his neighbours, remember that the best of men have been so regarded.
('8', 487, 7, 28, 1160600) Do you think that Christ was not considered as a great nuisance and a trouble by his brothers?
('8', 487, 7, 29, 1160695) The household went on quietly until he began to make a stir.
('8', 487, 8, 30, 1160756) Tolstoy and Thoreau appear to agree in the matter of civil disobedience: they seem to be at one in regard to the claim of conscience on the individual soul.
('8', 487, 8, 31, 1160913) Yet far be it from me to claim human perfection for either of them: they are merely men of advanced thought in the domain of reason; their intellectual pre eminence claims respect from us for their ideas.
('8', 487, 8, 32, 1161118) Tolstoy holds peculiar views with regard to
('8', 488, 0, 1, 1161162) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 489
('8', 488, 1, 2, 1161207) Christianity.
('8', 488, 1, 3, 1161221) There is much in them which we may discard as inconsistent with his own writings.
('8', 488, 1, 4, 1161303) Still we must admit that there is wisdom in most things he has said.
('8', 488, 1, 5, 1161372) Christianity to him is a broad humanitarianism: Christ a supreme Rationalist; he subordinated everything to the inner light “the light that is in you” that is, the light of reason.
('8', 488, 1, 6, 1161553) This is the deduction upon which all philosophers and moralists base their passive resistance to constituted authority—the conflict of reason with the surrender of conscience.
('8', 488, 2, 7, 1161729) I think I have now made it clear that passive resistance, as an honourable weapon in extremis to those who are subject to physical force, has high, if not divine, sanction for its exercise.
('8', 488, 2, 8, 1161919) Its ethics in governments and communities of men are plain and unmistakable.
('8', 488, 2, 9, 1161996) I have referred to Socrates and Plato, to Christ and to modern morality.
('8', 488, 2, 10, 1162069) Going further back to antiquity we find Confucius indicating in his moral code the dividing line between active disobedience and passive resistance in simple and homely words:
('8', 488, 3, 11, 1162245) At first my way with men was to hear their words and give them credit for their conduct.
('8', 488, 3, 12, 1162334) Now my way is to hear their words and look at their conduct.
('8', 488, 3, 13, 1162395) To see what is right and not to do it is want of courage.
('8', 488, 4, 14, 1162453) I will conclude in the words of Macaulay, so eloquent and so pregnant with meaning:
('8', 488, 5, 15, 1162537) The sceptre may pass away from us.
('8', 488, 5, 16, 1162572) Unforeseen accidents may derange our most profound schemes of policy.
('8', 488, 5, 17, 1162642) Victory may be inconstant to our arms.
('8', 488, 5, 18, 1162681) But there are triumphs which are followed by no reverse.
('8', 488, 5, 19, 1162738) There is an empire exempt from all natural causes of decay.
('8', 488, 5, 20, 1162798) Those triumphs are the pacific triumphs of reason over barbarism; that empire is the imperishable empire of our arts and our morals, our literature and our laws.
('8', 488, 5, 21, 1162960) But let not us, mistaking her character and her interests, fight the battle of truth with the weapons of error and endeavour to support by oppression that religion which first taught the human race the great lesson of universal charity.
('8', 488, 5, 22, 1163197) Indian Opinion, 18 4 1908

('8', 488, 7, 24, 1163235) REPORT OF NATAL IMMIGRATION DEPARTMENT
('8', 488, 8, 25, 1163274) The report of the Natal Immigration Department for the year 1907 has been published by its head, Mr. Harry Smith.
('8', 488, 8, 26, 1163388) Below are some interesting facts from it.
('8', 488, 9, 27, 1163430) The revenues of the department for the year 1907 exceeded those for 1906 by £178.4.8. Revenues from embarkation pass fees increased by £58 [during the same period].
('8', 488, 9, 28, 1163595) While other departments have to be financed by the Government, the Immigration Department pays its way.
('8', 488, 10, 29, 1163699) During the year under review, 27,522 passengers arrived, of whom 15,958 were British, 2,262 Chinese and 8,171 Indians.
('8', 488, 10, 30, 1163818) The number of indentured Indians was
('8', 489, 0, 1, 1163855) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 489, 1, 2, 1163897) 6,489, of whom 3,942 were men, 1,641 women and 906 children.
('8', 489, 1, 3, 1163958) In all 5,206 were detained [for verification of claims].
('8', 489, 1, 4, 1164015) Of these 323 were Arabs, 256 Chinese, 2,459 Indians, 317 Sinhalese and 1,407 from Zanzibar, other miscellaneous groups accounting for the rest.
('8', 489, 1, 5, 1164159) While in 1906 nine certificates were issued to persons who passed the education test, 59 such certificates were issued in 1907.
('8', 489, 2, 6, 1164287) A total of 11,425 domicile certificates was issued in 1906 and 12,483 in 1907. Seventy nine certificates were confiscated as they were found to be in possession of persons other than those to whom they were issued.
('8', 489, 2, 7, 1164502) Of those who were detained [for the verification of their claims] four persons—one white and three Asiatic escaped.
('8', 489, 2, 8, 1164618) The white was later apprehended and sent back.
('8', 489, 2, 9, 1164665) From among thosewere detained, although they had passes, 12 escaped.
('8', 489, 2, 10, 1164734) In all 16 persons, some of whom were notorious white criminals or women of ill repute, were deported.
('8', 489, 2, 11, 1164836) When the applicants for domicile certificates were examined, it was found that 90 percent.
('8', 489, 2, 12, 1164927) of them were married; 50 per cent.
('8', 489, 2, 13, 1164962) had not seen their wives [in Natal] for periods varying from 10 to 15 and even 20 years.
('8', 489, 2, 14, 1165051) Of the Asiatics who entered the Colony in 1903, 51 were women and 209 children; in 1904, 42 women and 134 children; in 1905, 48 women and 195 children; in 1906, 69 women and 237 children and in 1907, 71 women and 139 children.

('8', 489, 4, 17, 1165331) RESOLUTIONS AT MASS MEETING
('8', 489, 5, 18, 1165359) [JOHANNESBURG, June 24, 1908]
('8', 489, 6, 19, 1165389) The following resolutions were passed at the mass meeting:
('8', 489, 7, 20, 1165448) RESOLUTION I
('8', 489, 8, 21, 1165461) This Mass Meeting of British Indians domiciled in the Transvaal deplores the fact that the Government intend to depart from the spirit of the compromise entered into by them with the Asiatic communities of the Transvaal last January, in that they make it a condition of repeal of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act that rights of certain Asiatics domiciled in the Transvaal before the War are surrendered, and that the Asiatic communities should consent to an insult being offered to Asiatics of educational attainments.
('8', 489, 9, 22, 1165977) This resolution was proposed by Moulvi Ahmed Mukhtar.
('8', 489, 10, 23, 1166031) RESOLUTION 2
('8', 489, 11, 24, 1166044) By reason of the decision of the Government not to carry out their part of the compromise, and regard being had to the fact that the Asiatics in the Transvaal have, almost without exception, made application for voluntary registration, this Mass Meeting hereby resolves to withdraw all the applications so made, and reaffirms the
('8', 490, 0, 1, 1166374) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 491
('8', 490, 1, 2, 1166419) solemn declaration made on the 11th day of September, 1906, not to submit to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, but to suffer, as loyal citizens and conscientious men, all the penalties consequent upon non submission thereto.
('8', 490, 2, 3, 1166641) This was proposed by Imam Abdool Cadir Bawazeer.
('8', 490, 3, 4, 1166690) RESOLUTION 3
('8', 490, 4, 5, 1166703) This Mass Meeting tenders its respectful thanks to all those, whether in South Africa, England, or India, who have helped and sympathized with the British Indian Community of the Transvaal during its struggle for legitimate freedom and to retain its self respect, and earnestly trusts that they will continue to assist with their sympathy and support until justice is fully vindicated.
('8', 490, 5, 6, 1167089) RESOLUTION 4
('8', 490, 6, 7, 1167102) This Mass Meeting hereby authorizes and instructs the Chairman of the British Indian Association to forward copies of the preceding resolutions to the Hon’ble the Colonial Secretary, and to His Excellency the Governor of the Transvaal, for transmission to the Imperial Secretaries of State for the Colonies and India.
('8', 490, 7, 8, 1167420) This resolution was proposed by Mr. Mulji G. Patel.

('8', 492, 6, 10, 1171552) APPENDIX VII
('8', 492, 7, 11, 1171565) J. J. DOKE’S LETTER TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER” [July 4, 1908] [THE EDITOR THE TRANSVAAL LEADER
('8', 492, 9, 12, 1171659) We all deplore the reappearance of the Asiatic difficulty.
('8', 492, 9, 13, 1171718) When passive resistance came to an end five months ago, we earnestly hoped that the trouble would never recur in such a form.
('8', 492, 9, 14, 1171844) It dislocated trade; it filled our prisons with men who, as General Smuts said, were “not criminals”, it embarrassed the Government, and made us all feel extremely wretched.
('8', 492, 9, 15, 1172018) The resuscitation of this would be indeed a calamity.
('8', 492, 9, 16, 1172072) We still hope it may be averted.
('8', 492, 9, 17, 1172105) It behoves us to work for this end, “with both hands earnestly”.
('8', 492, 9, 18, 1172170) But at present the outlook is very serious, and those who should know best say passive resistance is once more inevitable.
('8', 492, 10, 19, 1172293) My apology for writing is that I have some knowledge of the subject as it appears from the Asiatic point of view, and that a re statement of it may be of some value at this crisis.
('8', 492, 11, 20, 1172474) The Colonial Secretary has at last agreed to repeal the objectionable Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('8', 492, 11, 21, 1172571) This, I believe, is inevitable to any just and hopeful settlement.
('8', 492, 11, 22, 1172638) When the compromise was being effected, circumstances placed me at the very focus of the trouble, and I am convinced from personal knowledge that the Asiatics did not doubt that the repeal of the Act was an essential part of the agreement.
('8', 492, 11, 23, 1172878) The Colonial
('8', 493, 0, 1, 1172891) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('8', 493, 1, 2, 1172933) Secretary himself fostered this conviction in his speech 1 at Richmond, published in the Press of February 6, when he said: “He had told them (i.e., the Asiatics) that the law would not be repealed so long as there was an Asiatic in the country who had not registered’.
('8', 493, 1, 3, 1173203) And again: “Until every Indian in the country had registered the law would not be repealed”.
('8', 493, 1, 4, 1173296) This prospective repeal was thus evidently made an incentive to obtain the registration of all the Asiatics.
('8', 493, 1, 5, 1173405) This is simply to show that these men had good ground for believing what is now so emphatically denied.
('8', 493, 1, 6, 1173509) But the Colonial Secretary has now agreed to repeal the Act[;] only unfortunately in offering this concession, he has attached conditions to it which the Asiatics deem themselves unable to accept.
('8', 493, 1, 7, 1173706) These conditions are new to the subject.
('8', 493, 1, 8, 1173747) The idea has apparently been promulgated that the Asiatics have brought forward new claims.
('8', 493, 1, 9, 1173839) This is untrue.
('8', 493, 1, 10, 1173855) The conditions insisted on by General Smuts are new claims, not one of them having been contemplated in the compromise.
('8', 493, 2, 11, 1173975) Briefly, they amounted to this:
('8', 493, 3, 12, 1174007) (1) That the Immigration Restriction Act shall not be regarded as applying to Asiatics in respect of admitting educated men to residence here.
('8', 493, 3, 13, 1174150) This has always been the interpretation which General Smuts has given to this Act.
('8', 493, 3, 14, 1174233) He has said repeatedly: “It is a law that completely and finally shuts the door from India.” The Asiatic leaders have never accepted his interpretation, but they have always professed themselves willing to accept this very drastic Act according to its interpretation by the Supreme Court.
('8', 493, 3, 15, 1174522) And their position is unchanged.
('8', 493, 3, 16, 1174555) But now apparently, not being quite sure that his reading is the right one, General Smuts requires the Asiatic leaders to accept an amendment of this Immigration Restriction Act, incorporating his interpretation of it.
('8', 493, 3, 17, 1174774) The effect would be that they would consent to the exclusion of the most cultured of their brethren from entering the Colony, though they might be able to pass the most vigorous educational test enforced by the Act.
('8', 493, 3, 18, 1174990) The Asiatics reply: ‘You cannot expect us to accept this new amendment.
('8', 493, 3, 19, 1175062) We have not understood the Act in the sense you have given to it, but we may be wrong.
('8', 493, 3, 20, 1175149) We are willing to stand or fall by the decision of the Supreme Court; only do not force us to decide the matter ourselves.’ But General Smuts answers, in effect: ‘You must take my interpretation or have no repeal!’
('8', 493, 4, 21, 1175364) The singular part of the whole affair is that a few weeks ago the Colonial Secretary himself granted an educated Indian full registration, at the instance of Mr. Gandhi, on this ground, among others, that he fulfilled the requirements of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act!
('8', 493, 5, 22, 1175635) 2. The second and third points at issue are also entirely new conditions.
('8', 493, 5, 23, 1175709) The leaders are asked to consider all Asiatics, whether in the Colony or out of it, who hold Dutch registration certificates under Law 3 of 1885, for which they paid from £3 to £25, as prohibited persons.
('8', 493, 5, 24, 1175914) Also, that all Asiatics who were residents in the Transvaal before the war, and who can prove their previous domicile in any court of law, but who had not returned to the Colony during the three months allowed by the
('8', 493, 6, 25, 1176131) 1Vide , “General Smuts’ Speech in Richmond”, 5 2 1908.
('8', 494, 0, 1, 1176186) VOL. 8 : 14 DECEMBER, 1907 22 JULY, 1908 495
('8', 494, 1, 2, 1176231) compromise, and do not hold the “peace preservation permits”, shall be counted as prohibited persons.
('8', 494, 1, 3, 1176333) This is a distinct contravention of the compromise.
('8', 494, 1, 4, 1176385) It means that those Asiatics who have established their right to be here, through long residence, and by costly registration under the old Dutch law, shall be refused their rights, and be turned out of the Colony while the Asiatics, who were so far from home that they could not return within the three months of grace, and who probably did not know of the compromise within that time, shall be prohibited from entering the Colony, unless they have “peace preservation permits”.
('8', 494, 1, 5, 1176864) These measures would probably affect 600 men!
('8', 494, 2, 6, 1176910) 3. But the last new claim is perhaps the worst of all, because of the principle involved.
('8', 494, 2, 7, 1177000) General Smuts demands that all those Asiatics who have applied voluntarily for registration, but who have been, or shall be, rejected by Mr. Chamney, shall be regarded as prohibited persons, without any right of appeal from Mr. Chamney’s judgment!
('8', 494, 2, 8, 1177248) Surely this is monstrous.
('8', 494, 2, 9, 1177274) A rejected Asiatic is to be allowed no right to have his case properly tried!
('8', 494, 2, 10, 1177352) He may not even know why he is rejected!
('8', 494, 2, 11, 1177393) Even Mr. Chamney is not infallible, and may blunder like the rest of us; but if the Registrar says he is not satisfied, the poor Asiatic must leave his home and go, without any right of appeal!
('8', 494, 2, 12, 1177587) This is not common humanity, and I do not wonder that the Asiatics refuse to buy the promised “repeal” at such a price.
('8', 494, 3, 13, 1177707) It is well to have a clear perception of the principle at stake.
('8', 494, 3, 14, 1177772) In these “terms” the spirit of autocracy is dominant.
('8', 494, 3, 15, 1177826) The Asiatics claim simply the interpretation and protection of the Supreme Court.
('8', 494, 3, 16, 1177908) They do not resent the “Immigration Restriction Act”.
('8', 494, 3, 17, 1177962) They only claim that it be not interpreted by any official, however exalted he may be, but by the recognized Court, and by that judgment they will stand.
('8', 494, 3, 18, 1178116) They do not resent the rejection of Asiatics by Mr. Chamney, and their deportation, but they claim that no official shall be made supreme.
('8', 494, 3, 19, 1178255) They ask for the right of appeal in such cases to the well balanced judgment of a properly constituted tribunal.
('8', 494, 3, 20, 1178368) It is a protest against new claims not contemplated in the compromise, and against the spirit of autocracy which dominates them.
('8', 494, 3, 21, 1178497) But surely, while these points are of supreme moment to the sufferers, they are not, after all, vital matters, so far as our Government is concerned.
('8', 494, 3, 22, 1178647) There can be no inrush of Asiatics under the stringent tests possible by enforcing the Immigration Restriction Act, and there can be no loss of prestige in acting justly.
('8', 494, 3, 23, 1178818) To these men the new conditions involve so much that I understand they are prepared to return to the position in which the compromise found them, and that passive resistance will be commenced again in a few days!
('8', 494, 3, 24, 1179031) Cannot something be done even now to effect a settlement without suffering such a calamity?
('8', 494, 3, 25, 1179123) We recognize that whatever is done must be a real settlement this time.
('8', 494, 3, 26, 1179195) I trust a patchwork will be tolerated by no one.
('8', 494, 3, 27, 1179244) But we may rest assured of this, that there will be no such thing as final settlement unless justice and good faith are alike satisfied.
('8', 494, 4, 28, 1179381) [Yours etc., J. J. DOKE] Indian Opinion, 11 7 1908
